HEADLINE: IRAQ OFFERS STEPS TO AVOID ATTACK; U.S. REJECTS PLAN

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Faced with an imminent American military attack, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq made a show of backing down today, saying in a letter to the United Nations that his Government would resume full cooperation with arms inspectors.
But a two-page annex to the letter outlining Mr. Hussein's interpretation of what he would get in return raised immediate doubts about his sincerity. Excerpts, page 16. Within hours, the Clinton Administration rejected the Iraqi offer as inadequate, and said American forces remained poised to strike. 
 "In order for us to accept the proposition that there will be compliance, there has to be a clear, unequivocal statement to that effect by the Iraqis," Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said at a news conference in Washington. "What we have instead is a letter, and particularly an annex, that's got more holes than Swiss cheese."
But according to American officials, the Iraqi move did avert military action at least for today. Administration officials said they had canceled a plan to stage a military strike just hours before it was set to begin.
As a further indication that the White House considered the crisis unresolved, President Clinton delayed his trip to Asia today, sending Vice President Al Gore to Malaysia for an economic conference of leaders from Pacific rim countries.
When the United Nations Security Council met here tonight, most members took a different view of the Iraqi letter, saying they were prepared to take Mr. Hussein at his word and urging a quick resumption of weapons inspections.
But the British remained strong in support of Washington's insistence on military preparedness. In London Prime Minister Tony Blair said that until Iraq's compliance was "unconditional," British forces were "on alert to the possibility of military action at any time without further warning."
Still, the British delegates here suggested that London might be willing to give Iraq a chance to re-admit the arms inspectors. Thus, with the United States insistent but somewhat isolated, the Council debate dragged on until near midnight without an agreement about how to respond to Iraq. The session was adjourned until Sunday afternoon.
The annex, which Mr. Annan's special envoy in Baghdad, Prakash Shah, described in an accompanying note as something the Iraqis did not want made public, restates demands by Iraq that have already been rejected by the United States, Britain and other Council members.
Intentionally or not, it could reopen divisions and foment distrust between Russia and the United States in the crucial next few days. Arriving for a Security Council meeting today, Sergey Lavrov, the Russian representative, said the Iraqi conditions in the annex "are beliefs that are going to have to be dealt with."
Publicly, Iraq wrapped its announcement today in a cloak of statesmanship. Diplomats here and officials in Washington said Mr. Hussein, isolated diplomatically even by his friends, had apparently decided to buy time.
"We offer this chance not out of fear of the aggressive American campaign and the threat to commit a new aggression against Iraq," Iraq said in the letter to Secretary General Kofi Annan, "but as an expression of our feeling of responsibility and in response to your appeal and those of our friends."
The letter was signed by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz.
United Nations officials argued that the Iraqis were not hedging their decision to resume cooperation, and that the annex was no more than a wish list. "Our understanding is that the annex to the letter does not constitute conditions," said Fred Eckhard, Mr. Annan's spokesman.
But later in the day, Mr. Annan appeared to be less optimistic, saying only that the letter "made at least a step in the right direction."
Iraq's representative to the United Nations, Nizar Hamdoon, said, "The annex that was delivered with the letter today contains the views and the preferences of the Government of Iraq on the comprehensive review that has been agreed in principle by the Security Council before this recent crisis."
Mr. Hamdoon said the nine points in the annex were not conditions for compliance, and late this evening he submitted a second letter to the Council stating flatly, "This annex was not connected to the decision of Iraq to resume its relations with Unscom and with the I.A.E.A." -- the United Nations Special Commission of arms inspectors and the Interntional Atomic Energy Agency.
The White House rejected the second letter as insufficient. David Leavy, a spokesman for the National Security Council, using words similar to Mr. Berger's earlier, said, "With all due respect to the Iraqi Ambassador to the United Nations, what we are looking for is a clear, public and authoritative statement of compliance -- no conditions."
The annex is a copy of Iraqi policy points as they were presented to Russia, China and France on Friday. The summary was mentioned in the letter as a description of what Iraq would consider a "serious, fair and fruitful" review.
It asks that Baghdad be given direct assurances by the Secretary General or "a delegation from the Council" that its demands, many of which have already been rejected, be taken into account now.
It also asks that the comprehensive review of relations with the United Nations "be carried out within a very short time (seven days for example)" after arms inspectors resume their work. The United States has already suggested that four to six weeks would be more realistic, to allow time to see if inspections were really unfettered.
The annex makes clear that Iraq wants to shift the burden of evidence to the inspection team, forcing it to prove what Iraq is supposed to be hiding rather than allowing the commission to continue compelling Baghdad to produce answers.
The Iraqis want a timetable -- "a short period," they say -- for them to take whatever steps are necessary to close files on weapons programs. Inspectors fear that this will result in pro-forma inspections, after which the Iraqis could declare they had met all their obligations so the economic embargo could be lifted.
The annex again raises questions about the future of Richard Butler, the executive chairman of Unscom, whom Iraq wants dismissed, and of the commission itself, which Iraq wants to make part of the United Nations system. It is now a free-standing creation of the Council.
The Iraqis also reiterated their preference for a comprehensive review to be conducted under Mr. Annan's direction. The Security Council has said it will run that review.
In their public letter to the Secretary General, the Iraqis said the decision to resume cooperation was made today at meetings of the President's Cabinet and party, with Mr. Hussein presiding.
The meetings followed the receipt of a letter on Friday night from Mr. Annan reiterating his warning, in effect, that Iraq could never hope to have sanctions lifted unless it played by the rules, and by appeals from Russia, China and France, among others, the Iraqis said.
Arguing against recent evidence, the letter states that "the goal sought by Iraq was not to sever the relationship with Unscom and the I.A.E.A."
"The leadership of Iraq decided to resume working with the Special Commission and the I.A.E.A. and to allow them to perform their normal duties," the letter said.
The first hint that Iraqi would back down came early today from an unidentified Iraqi official in Baghdad. A few hours later, Mr. Shah, Mr. Annan's envoy, said publicly that the Iraqis had agreed "without conditions" to resume cooperation, which was broken off on Oct. 31.
As Mr. Shah spoke, the Secretary General was meeting with Mr. Hamdoon at Mr. Annan's official residence in New York. There, Mr. Annan took a call from Mr. Aziz, and they discussed the letter.
Mr. Annan made a last-minute appeal to Mr. Hussein in his letter on Friday, after a meeting with the Security Council that lasted nearly five hours. The Secretary General, who had abruptly cut off a trip in North Africa on Wednesday to confront the crisis, said after the marathon session, "Events on the ground seem to be running away from us."
By that time, the Iraqi President had been warned by virtually all his erstwhile friends -- Russia, France, China and the Arab nations -- that he would take the blame for bringing down American missiles on his country and people. Even governments that oppose the use of force to settle this crisis had made it clear that the Iraqis were isolated in their defiance.
The present crisis with Iraq, which came on the heels of a year of confrontations, has its roots in a decision by Mr. Hussein on Aug. 5 to curtail cooperation with inspectors who biological, chemical and prohibited missile systems.
They and their counterparts from the International Atomic Energy Agency, which watched nuclear developments, were forbidden to make new on-site searches and were restricted to using existing monitoring systems -- cameras, and air, soil and water samplers -- and to making routine visits to previously agreed sites. That move set off alarms here, because the Security Council had intended the inspectors to continue unannounced searches even after sanctions end.
In early September, the Council responded with a resolution that ended all further sanctions reviews, and therefore hopes of having the embargo lifted, until weapons inspections resumed.
In the meantime, the Security Council and the Secretary General were working on plans for a comprehensive review of Iraq's relations with the United Nations, going back to the 1990 invasion of Kuwait, when sanctions were imposed.
Iraq has also made demands about how the review should be conducted.
On Oct. 30, the Council laid out its plans for conducting a review. It did not promise more than a new look at sanctions after Iraq had met all its disarmament requirements. The next day, Mr. Hussein surprised everyone involved by shutting down the inspection system entirely. In the face of possible American bombing, all the inspectors have now been withdrawn from Iraq.

HEADLINE: City's Perverse Welfare Policy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You say Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani boasts of getting people off the welfare rolls (editorial, Nov. 12). It is not clear, however, whether these people are finding jobs. In fact, the Giuliani administration is reluctant to release figures, so determining the truth is difficult. 
 Even if this rosy view were true, does a job promise a living wage? Of American families classified as poor in 1997, 66 percent had at least one member working full time. Also, what will happen to welfare recipients in New York City when the inevitable economic downturn arrives?
Mayor Giuliani should concentrate less on creating a positive spin and more on creating jobs with livable wages.
 
CRAIG BUTLER
New York, Nov. 12, 1998
 
The writer is executive director of the Business, Labor and Community Coalition of New York.

HEADLINE: City's Perverse Welfare Policy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Why hold off giving a welfare applicant an application for food stamps or Medicaid (editorial, Nov. 12)? Do we not have unintentional delay enough in our response to the needs of people to discourage the applicant who is not truly in need? Or do we presume that most welfare applicants are looking for a free lunch? 
 Welfare is a necessary accommodation for the weaknesses in our economic, social and personal lives. It does not have to be a trap. It does not need delays to erode its existence. It will recede when we remedy our economic, social and personal weaknesses: a challenge that will require more creative strategies than postponement.
 
FRANCES A. SULLIVAN
Brooklyn, Nov. 13, 1998
 
The writer is a former Human Resources Administration official.

HEADLINE: GRAND OLD TERMINAL;
SOME 'AMAZING GRACE'

 BODY:
WENDY LAMB, a Manhattan book editor, wrote the Oct. 4 Soapbox essay, chronicling milestones of her life that occurred in Grand Central Terminal. She suggested that others record their memories of the place. The City section solicited "most memorable moments" and here are a few:
Back in New York City after a five-year hiatus. After work, I cut through Grand Central. My thoughts, anxiety-filled: The job . . . the condo in Cleveland . . . the husband back in Cleveland trying to sell the condo . . . recession.
Suddenly, I'm transfixed by a singer's sonorous tones: "Amazing grace, how sweet the sound . . . I once was lost. . . ." Yes, I was lost without this fair city. "But now am found." This will always be my town! "Was blind but now I see." Fears, entirely relieved.
 
CYNTHIA SODERHOLM
Sutton

HEADLINE: Honoring Past Beauty In Theaters of Present

BYLINE: By E. KYLE MINOR 

 BODY:
IF the success of Theater Projects Consultants can be distilled into one philosophy, it's "Back to the Future." That concept, in fact, served as the company's mantra long before the 1985 film that made Michael J. Fox a movie star.
"People do say that expression around here, yes," said Richard Pilbrow, founder and chairman of the Ridgefield-based company. "That's because there's a lot to learn from the classical architecture of the past, I guess." Or, as the company's president of the past 19 months, Victor Gotesman, put it: "We recognize the beauty of the past while celebrating the advantages of the future." 
 This helps explain the sense of deja vu that strikes an audience the moment it lands in a T.P.C.-related performing arts venue: the immediacy of high-tech performance within the intimate style of the old European opera houses.
With 600 projects worldwide, T.P.C. is arguably the busiest performing arts venue consultant operating today. The company has worked with the Tanglewood Music Center in Lenox, Mass., and the New Amsterdam Theater on Broadway as well as the 300-seat Centennial Theater at the Westminster School in Simsbury and the 350-seat Greenwich Academy theater, among others.
"I think one reason we're successful certainly is that we've been doing it longer than everybody else," said Mr. Pilbrow.
"Another is that all our staff consists of practicing theater artists. We work in the theater, so we understand the needs of the artists creating the work as well as those of the audience."
The 40-person staff consists of production managers, stage managers, set designers, architects, sound designers and arts administrators. Mr. Pilbrow is a former London producer and a current Broadway lighting designer. His last Broadway project, Cy Coleman's musical "The Life," earned him his second Tony nomination.
Mr. Gotesman, formerly executive director of the Cerritos Center for the Performing Arts in Cerritos, Calif., first met Mr. Pilbrow when T.P.C. worked on the Cerritos building. Brian Hall, T.P.C.'s director of design in North America, owned an architectureal firm in Toronto, specializing in performing arts centers. He too met Mr. Pilbrow when they were teamed up on several projects.
"It was sort of like the Victor Kiam thing," Mr. Hall said, referring to the Remington owner, who said "I liked the blade so much I bought the company."
With all the talent Mr. Pilbrow has assembled, T.P.C. is equipped to advise on nearly every detail of a performing arts center, from the architecture of the building to the placement of its drinking fountains.
David Taylor, a lighting and scenic designer with 15 years at the company, says teamwork keeps the staff's egos from clashing. "Everyone helps and complements each other," said Mr. Taylor. "We can cover each other on big projects."
Mr. Taylor added that the staff is free to pursue individual projects, helping keep everybody fresh.
"I still get time to continue my scenic and lighting design work," he said. "Richard, in fact, encourages us to keep up our own work."
When Mr. Pilbrow started his theatrical profession four decades ago technology was relatively primitive. In fact, many of the jobs listed on today's play programs didn't exist when Mr. Pilbrow graduated from drama school in London.
"There were no sound designers, lighting designers or even any theater architects," Mr. Pilbrow said. "No new theaters were being built in England. Everything was technically very old-fashioned."
Trained as a stage manager, Mr. Pilbrow considered himself lucky to walk into a long-running production of "Teahouse of the August Moon" in London. "The trouble," he said, "is that long runs are terribly boring to work. I started lighting shows, which was more interesting. I also got the idea of renting out lighting equipment. I went out and bought up a bunch of old equipment, fixed it up and went into business for myself."
Mr. Pilbrow, who was looking for more business in America, arrived in New York in 1961. "I stayed with my friend Tony Walton, who was married to Julie Andrews," he said.
The producer Hal Prince was one of the people he met, and Mr. Prince's project at the time was Stephen Sondheim's "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum." While Mr. Prince already had a lighting designer in hand, he hired Mr. Pilbrow to design scenic projections to compliment Mr. Walton's scene design.
"When Hal was looking to bring the show to England," Mr. Pilbrow said, "he asked Tony and me if we were interested in producing for him. We actually were. Though Tony abandoned producing thereafter, I continued to produce Hal's shows in London."
Mr. Pilbrow continued producing Mr. Prince's musicals in England into the 80's, including "Fiddler on the Roof," "Cabaret," "Company" and "A Little Night Music." When Mr. Pilbrow, his wife, Molly, and daughter Daisy, now 18, moved to Ridgefield in 1988 (they also have homes in Manhattan and in Scotland), he retired from producing, although his plate remains overflowing.
"Our work takes years of commitment, even the smaller projects," Mr. Pilbrow said, as much as 20 years in some cases. "It's not just that we get involved from the start," Mr. Taylor said. "Theater people are known for changing their minds."
Usually T.P.C. starts each project with a feasibility study. This entails going into the community where the project will exist to see if there is an audience to support the venue.
"We also evaluate the space, costs, time investment," Mr. Pilbrow said. "Sometimes we'll do a study and not hear back from the people for years."
Or, as Mr. Hall put it, "Theater people tend to have unlimited vision and limited resources."
Much of T.P.C.'s consultation comes with compromise. "Three-quarters of it, actually," Mr. Pilbrow said. "We're lucky to have some very large projects, enabling us to play a little Robin Hood."
Mr. Pilbrow remembers one particularly satisfying project involving a theater with empty pockets.
He was working in the National Theater of Great Britain, he said, "and this man walked in and said he'd like us to do his theater. He said he had no money, but liked our work."
The man was the director Michael Elliott, who started the Royal Exchange Theater in Manchester. "He wanted a courtyard-style theater in the round, which I hadn't done before," Mr. Pilbrow recalled. "It took some time, but we did it."
The courtyard theater, now T.P.C.'s signature style, recalls the 16th-century Italian opera houses, or the Globe Theater of Shakespeare's day. The audience on the ground floor looks up at the stage and is surrounded by several tiers of balconies stacked overhead. In the Royal Exchange Theater, none of the 700 seats is farther than 32 feet away from the stage.
"It's like acting under a magnifying glass," Mr. Pilbrow said.
Mr. Hall added that "theaters since the 1960's have all been designed like movie houses. You have these long orchestra sections and a few balconies, which are fine if you're watching a 20-foot-high 'Hamlet' on the screen. They aren't very conducive to live performance."
"The old opera houses had several balconies, which kept you close to the action. We like that."
"Another problem," Mr. Pilbrow said, "is the economy of theater. All the managers want 3,000-seat houses thinking that the more seats, the more money. The horrible truth is that anything over 2,000 seats is too big for an enjoyable experience."
The New Amsterdam, a Disney project on 42d Street, perhaps best exemplifies T.P.C.'s knack for combining the best of the new and the classic. The landmark theater, originally built by Florence Ziegfeld in 1903, had been idle since the 60's and was in painful disrepair. Mr. Taylor, the project manager, had his work cut out for him.
"The building itself has taken about four years," he said. "That's not including all the research involved."
"We found the original structure drawings at the Shubert office," Mr. Taylor said. "Without that, we couldn't be sure of copying everything in its original detail."
With drawings in hand, the architects, Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, restored every gilded detail on the 1,800-seat house.

LENGTH: 690 words

HEADLINE: Playing, Singing, Speaking and 'Doing Politics'

BYLINE: By RICHARD TRENNER 

DATELINE: FAR HILLS

 BODY:
THE inevitable epidemics of runny noses and daydreaming aside, the Far Hills Country Day School kindergarten is a happy, lively place, where children are kept busy learning to play games, sing, feel good about being away from home, and "share." In this regard, it is a typical kindergarten.
But Far Hills Country Day, a private institution on 45 acres, is situated in an area in which it is not uncommon to see advertisements for residences like Blythewood, a century-old house on Bernardsville Mountain that features "a 50-foot ballroom with gold leaf ceiling, sweeping marble staircase, and 90-foot loggia." Even in kindergarten, there are bound to be differences. 
 When a former kindergartner visits, he might be Nicholas Brady, former Senator and Secretary of the Treasury. Growing up at Hamilton Farm, his family's 5,000-acre estate encompassing parts of Hunterdon, Morris, and Somerset counties, he spent six "wonderful years" at Far Hills Country Day. Four of his children and four of his grandchildren have followed him there. When Governor Whitman graduated from the eighth grade in 1960, her mother, Eleanor Schley Todd, was chairman of the board and very active at the school.
Another difference is that kindergartners at Far Hills are taught public speaking. Microphone in hand, every child is encouraged to stand and deliver before a weekly gathering of teachers and students -- early exercises in quick thinking and confidence-building.
"Public speaking starts in kindergarten and continues through eighth grade," Jayne Geiger Wyatt, the head of school, said in a recent interview. "The idea is to help the children be confident about what they believe and also learn to articulate and defend those beliefs. In kindergarten, the atmosphere for public speaking is very supportive and informal. In the upper grades, sixth through eighth, the process becomes more formal, the topics more complex, like questions of social justice or women's roles."
As the idea of 5-year-olds addressing their peers suggests, training for leadership, whether in doing business or in "doing politics," starts early in the Somerset Hills. And, more than any other institution there, Far Hills Country Day School is the traditional first training ground.
The sense of continuity among generations and the belief in giving back through public service or philanthropy seem important aspects of the school's identity. Beside the door to each classroom a plaque bears the name of one or more donors and the school's motto: "In virtute multi ascensus" (In excellence there are many degrees). Moreover, the children participate in outreach, like working with developmentally delayed children at the Jerry Davis Early Childhood Center in Manville.
Along with the emphasis on helping others, a central part of the school's mission is to prepare children for leadership later in life. "Learning how to attain excellence early in unique, individual ways is an essential pattern for later success," Mrs. Geiger Wyatt said.
In an upper school classroom, with lovely western views of Somerset and Hunterdon counties, the walls are covered with tools for learning success. On a bulletin board, a list of assemblies tells of a coming visit from Quentin Keynes, a great-grandson of Charles Darwin, who will "talk about time he spent on remote islands in the Indian Ocean." Nearby, a posted math problem begins: "A company offers two options for sales partners . . ."
Tacked to a bulletin board at the front of the classroom, a poster presents a brief history of the New York Stock Exchange, while the headline from a newspaper clipping reads: "Dow Tumbles 6%, Erasing Gains for 1998."
In recent years, according to Judith Ann Corrente, president of the board from 1993 to 1997 and parent of three Far Hills graduates, the school has made "a strong effort to be more inclusive, both geographically and socio-economically."
"As we burnished the school's academic reputation and introduced need-based and merit-based scholarships, we were able to develop a significantly more diverse school community," Ms. Corrente said. RICHARD TRENNER

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 6; Column 4; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Long And Short of It Is Long and Short of It. Then There's the Bar.

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
Most of the visitors at this trade show arrived in limousines, as one would expect. Some then tried to sell the limousines, and some shopped for more limousines. Those not too hung over from the toga party or the beach bash reported for morning seminars on topics like chauffeur training tips.
In this city, with its already high resident-to-limousine ratio, they were not even conspicuous. They were highly concentrated, though, at the annual Limousine Digest show: 5,000 people who live limousines coursed into an arena at the Trump Taj Mahal last week to peer into cars with fiber-optic stargazer ceilings, oriental rugs, pull-down television screens and, above all, elaborate bars. 
 "I could use this in New York," Frank Ray said as he sidled up to a $130,000 white Hummer stretched to 30 feet. "It's murder in the city." The Hummer, with a fog machine and laser-show setup in the back, was one of the biggest items, literally and figuratively, in the arena. It was a powerful distraction for customers like Mr. Ray, who as owner of F & Z Transportation in Freeport, N.Y., was shopping for a limousine bus for missions like transporting groups of church ladies.
While the industry is growing even faster than the economy -- Ric Cohen, president of Limousine Digest, estimates that the number of limousine vehicles on the roads has increased from 45,000 to 60,000 in about two years -- the consensus here was that the mom-and-pop owners who have dominated the business for years are getting squeezed by big corporate owners. It was a big corporate owner, Scott A. Solombrino of Dav El Chauffeured Transportation, who gave the keynote address, telling show-goers in nylon jackets how to compete with the publicly held giants that are scooping up small operations. (Dav El is privately held.)
"It comes down to service, service and more service," Mr. Solombrino said in an interview inside his personal bus. "Everybody has a favorite restaurant and a favorite waiter. You're not going to say, 'I'm going to go to McDonald's because it's a bigger company.' You're spending day after day with the president of a company, his wife and children. They're not going to change the guy who drives the kids to school."
He added, "People with money spend it well, and God bless them."
Mr. Solombrino, who started his business as a college student and now has 11,000 limos in 400 cities, is chauffeured everywhere. His bus has a microwave and a fruit bowl on the kitchen counter, thermostat and humidity gauge on the wall, and two sleeping compartments with royal blue comforters that match the color scheme in the back bedroom.
The typical limousine -- and that would be a Lincoln Town Car, cut in half and stretched with panels four to ten feet long -- is not especially showy. As for the corporate clients who are the largest single source of revenue in the industry, "to them a car's a car," one dealer said with a wave of the hand.
"It used to be only for the rich and famous," said Carl Geiger of Atlantic Limousine in Atlantic City. When he was the teen-age heir to his family's business, Mr. Geiger said, "I used to go out in a limo with my friends, and at intersections girls would knock on the windows; now it's more, well, a vehicle for everybody."
At times, some of the operators say, this is just a little too true. Prom season wears on drivers' nerves, for example, although 18-year-olds out on the town are better than the dreaded bachelor parties.
"Bachelorette parties," said Armando Ocando, owner of All Star Limousines in Pittsburgh, emphasizing the "-ette." "The women are the worst. They're not used to drinking as much as the men are."
Don Wilson of V.I.P. Limousine Service in Macomb, Mich., said: "You don't want to know what people do back there. No, I don't want to say. Well, we've had girls standing up on the sunroofs taking their tops off."
The fellowship of limousine people let loose a little itself on this rare escape from a job that knows no weekends. The awards dinner was warm with gossip and applause. At the toga party afterward only a few ties appeared, and some partygoers showed no evidence of clothing beneath their sheets. One man danced in a black terrycloth bathrobe.
The next morning, shopping resumed. At the silent auction of used vehicles in the Taj Mahal garage, Mr. Ocando showed off his White Diamond limo, which he said "takes after the Dusenberg."
The white car, with gold eagle on the hood and trumpets arrayed between the headlights, brings $100 an hour for weddings. But Mr. Ocando said he needed to sell it to buy something else, which he hoped he could drive home, in the caravan of limousine guys from Pittsburgh, across the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Deeds Delayed, Loans Lost

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
In a room inside the Essex County Hall of Records, stacks of boxes are filled with unopened envelopes containing property deeds and checks covering recording fees that officials say easily total hundreds of thousands of dollars. For those trying to make the most of low interest rates by buying a hew home or refinancing their old one, the "unopened" part has left them furious, and maybe poorer.
The envelopes have been mailed to Carole A. Graves, the county Register of Deeds and Mortgages, by people seeking to have their deeds recorded, officially proving to banks, mortgage companies and real estate lawyers that they are the rightful owners of a particular house, candy store, vacant lot or other property. Without that proof, property owners have trouble obtaining a home equity loan or line of credit, refinancing a mortgage or selling their property. 
 But a two-month backlog in the register's office at least since the spring means many property owners have, at the least, been inconvenienced. And, county officials acknowledged, the undeposited checks for the deed search, costing $15 and up, represent money lost to the county for now. Ms. Graves noted that $7 million in checks had been received by her office through August.
Ms. Graves said the strong economy and rapidly falling interest rates generated a spurt in real estate transactions, just when illnesses and pregnancies among half a dozen workers in the register's office effectively cut the staff by about a third. She also said the office's computer system, installed in 1988, finally crashed for good in June, after periodic outages. Aside from the crash's disruption, Ms. Graves said, workers needed time for training on a temporary network.
M. Dean Haines, president of the County Officers Association of New Jersey, said there had been modest backlogs across the state as a result of record numbers of mortgage refinancings to take advantage of low interest rates. But, said Mr. Haines, who is the Ocean County clerk, the situation in Essex is worse because of its simultaneous computer and personnel problems.
One family affected by delay in Essex County is that of Michael Andriolo Jr., 79, of West Orange. He said a two-month wait caused him to cancel a home equity loan application. He had transferred ownership of his house to his three grown children, two of whom already live with him, and planned to expand it to accommodate his third, Michael 3d, who recently retired as a teacher in South Carolina. But because Mr. Andriolo Jr. only recently got his deed, construction will have to be postponed to spring, to keep winter cold away from exposed walls. Michael 3d will be spending money on renting an apartment in Verona for several months.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1363 words

HEADLINE: NOTICED;
Making Their Hair Not Curl

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
SOME call it an addiction. They must have it once, twice or three times a week.
The truly indulgent need it twice a day, before and after work. 
 Do it once, they say, before a special occasion, and you will never be able to stop.
That works out well for Robert Lyon, a hair stylist at the Peter Coppola salon on Madison Avenue, who because of his magic fingers and upper-arm strength is in constant demand. On Halloween night, Mr. Lyon, who is in his 20's and has a soothing English accent, had to get to bed early for an 8:30 house call the following morning, a Sunday, to a woman on Park Avenue.
Why?
To blow out her hair before she went to church.
For all the New York women, whether heading to the Park Avenue Methodist Church or to Moomba, who love to sport a straight, shiny, smooth-hair look, with just the right flip and swing, there is an army of people like Mr. Lyon. They will tug on their locks with big, round brushes for 20 to 40 minutes and dry them with a jet blast of hot air.
The demand for the talents of blow-dry specialists, who charge from $20 (Astor Place Hair Stylists) to $275 (John Sahag salon on Madison Avenue), seems to be at an all-time high. That is because the long curl-free look, as flaunted by women from Jennifer Aniston on "Friends" to Hillary Rodham Clinton on the cover of the coming December Vogue, bespeaks power and unassailable style at this moment, especially in New York. It has led to a virtual cult of the blowout, as the blow-dry is often called.
"Eighty-five percent of my business is from blow-drying," said Renato Vasconcellos, the owner of Color and Cut on East 43d Street, an economy-class hair salon that does a land-office business weekday evenings in the hour preceding cocktail parties and dinners.
Around 6 P.M., "the place is a nightmare," Mr. Vasconcellos said, filled with clients from midtown office buildings, their heads wrapped in towels after a quick shampoo or just a wet-down -- but generally not a hair cut -- awaiting their blowouts.
Before last week's charity reception for the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, held at the Chanel store on East 57th Street, the Frederic Fekkai salon in the same building was packed with partygoers waiting for a blowout by Ronald Braso, a stylist who is a favorite of the preppy set. "We had a cocktail party before the cocktail party," Mr. Braso said, describing how the women gossiped and sipped soda as he twirled his round, natural-bristle brushes into their hair, working the brushes like rollers.
Just as women who dyed their hair once had a secret that "only their hairdresser knew for sure," many devotees of the blowout conceal it. They want friends and colleagues to think their hair is naturally straight and full.
(Some blow-dry specialists are also secretive, because they do not fully report earnings. One such stylist, who spoke on the condition that his identity not be revealed, said, "You can't believe how much money we're making just to blow out hair." He charges $60 a house call, $100 to $150 on weekends, and admitted making more than $1,000 a week off the books.)
But other women are proud of the fact that they are getting their hair blown out regularly, since it smacks of a luxury once available only to the rich.
In the 1960's and 70's, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis had her hair blown out two or three times a week, either at home or at Kenneth, the salon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. "If she had things to do, things that mattered, she wanted to look polished and together," Kenneth Battelle, the salon's owner, said.
It was an era when the approach many women took to styling was to visit a salon once a week to have their hair set, then to petrify it with spray so they wouldn't have to touch it until the next visit.
Now, many more women avail themselves of a beauty treatment once the exclusive preserve of the super-chic. "All those girls, models, have their hair and makeup done before they go to parties, and that's why they look so good -- not because they're models," Candace Bushnell, the author of "Sex and the City," said. "Who knew? How come no one ever told us to do this before?" Now Ms. Bushnell gets her hair blown out two to three times a week. "The problem is you get addicted to blow-drying because your hair looks so much better instead of the ratty mess before," she added.
Stephanie Greenfield, 31, owner of the hip clothing store Scoop, has standing appointments two mornings a week at Color and Cut to get her long, wavy hair blown out by Bernadette Brady (although only Brian Devine at Garren New York is allowed to cut her hair). With someone holding her toy poodle, Annabelle, Ms. Greenfield does paperwork while getting her hair blow-dried.
Cheryl Kramer, 29, a beauty director at Fitness magazine, is also usually in a hurry, so she goes to the John Frieda salon, where two people, at the same time, blow out her reddish-brown hair. One person directs the air and someone else holds the brush. She calls it her "menage a trois blow-dry."
And Lizzie Grubman, 27, the owner of a public relations agency, has her hair blown out four times a week by four different stylists -- at home, in her office and in the salon. "No one has ever seen me with curly hair," she said, "and they never will."
Why all the fuss about a salon blow-dry? The home blow-dryer, after all, has been around for decades, so presumably most women would have learned to master it by now. But devotees say an expert can do a better job. When the hair is wet, a stylist with a blow-dryer pulls out sections of hair with a round bristle brush and stretches the hair until it dries straight inch by inch.
"The obsession is that since hair has gotten longer and less layered, and the finishing has gotten smooth and straight, women can't do that on their own," said Garren, owner of the Garren New York salon at Henri Bendel, where a blowout is $70 to $110. "Since the clothes have become more minimal and the hair has become simpler, there isn't a lot going on. It's smooth and simple, shiny and swings. Women love hair that swings."
Hair experts say the blow-out-only salon visit is mainly a New York phenomenon, although it is also found in Los Angeles. Elsewhere, it is almost unknown. In Washington, where Mr. Braso of Fekkai worked until recently, he said stylish women dress in evening gowns with beautiful jewelry, but leave for parties with their hair still wet from the shower. Why such a difference between the two cities? New York women, he surmised, are more image-conscious, thanks to all the photographers snapping them at parties for magazines.
Many women in a hurry press salons to speed their blowouts, and the salons in turn are using hotter dryers, which leads to hair damage, says Dr. Steven Victor, a dermatologist at Lenox Hill Hospital, who has a private practice on the Upper East Side.
"Remember, 10 years ago the blow-dryers were 500 or 700 watts," he said. "Now I think I've seen one for 2,000 watts."
"Hair is dead protein that has moisture and water," Dr. Victor added. "When it's moist, it's bendable and pliable. When you dry it out, you take out all the moisture and it's basically burning it and it breaks."
He said hair can endure regular blow-drying, but that practitioners should slow down, use less heat and apply a hair conditioner with animal protein twice a week.
At a party on Wednesday night for the shoemaker Sergio Rossi at Simply Caviar, a restaurant on Park Avenue, an informal survey revealed that 1 out of 10 women had had her hair blown out that evening.
Randy Spendlove, 33, a vice president for music and soundtracks at Miramax Films, recalled his surprise at discovering the love affair of New York women for the blowout. He had no idea so many of the women he met really had curly hair. He recalled one day coming across an acquaintance at the gym, when her hair was curled from sweat. "I had no idea who she was," he said.
The woman probably didn't want him to.
Because, like the Wicked Witch of the West, there is one thing that instantly spells the demise of blow-dried hair, no matter how expensively styled.
"Water is our enemy," Ms. Grubman said.

PUB-DATE: November 15, 1998

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2718 words

HEADLINE: Scrub-a-Dub-Dub, There's Money In That Tub

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY

 BODY:
NEW YORK, no matter what Mayor Giuliani says, is still a filthy place. But fear not. All over town, professional dirt-busters are at the ready to purge the darkest, most forbidden corners of the Naked City, like behind the toilet and under the couch.
The city's housecleaning industry is booming, people in the business say, as more New Yorkers seem willing to pay someone else to scrub the toilet, damp-mop the kitchen and dust the tchotchkes on the mantle. What was once considered a luxury for Fifth Avenue matrons and assorted parvenus has become a near necessity for many working New Yorkers, whose household calculus has changed with the upswing in the city's economy. Too busy or too tired to clean, they reckon it's better, and sometimes more cost effective, to hire someone than to spend hours hunting dust bunnies behind the davenport. 
 And while nobody ever got rich cleaning anything, plenty of New Yorkers are making money taking brush and bucket to the dirt in strangers' homes. For Lynette Bell, a former welfare recipient who trains and supervises teams from the Call-a-Maid company at grand manors like the deanery at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, cleaning puts food on the table. For Richard Sauer, a former instructor at the Rhode Island School of Design who gets clients through an agency for artist-cleaners called Manhattan Feather Dusters, cleaning up other people's messes is more than a way to supplement his income as artist. He also appreciates the flexible hours and sense of Zenlike peace he gets from unsullying someone else's house when they're not home.
And for Jim Ireland, an actor, cleaning turned out to be such a great gig he started his own company, White Glove Elite. Mr. Ireland, who dashes from auditioning to vacuuming to running an empire of 65 independent cleaners and 700 clients out of a small midtown office, said his business has tripled in the last two years.
"The demand is tremendous," he said. "Many people like myself are having their apartments cleaned. A few years ago, they definitely would have done it themselves. But many clients are waiters and bartenders. They make far more per hour than what it costs per hour to have someone clean."
"For many New Yorkers, housecleaners have become habit," he added. "It's one of the last things to go. People will give up fancy meals and nice clothes before they give up their maid."
Jerry Bohne, a 25-year veteran of the housekeeping business in New York and the owner of three domestic employment agencies on the Upper East Side, also said that business was flourishing.
"In the last few years it's increased tremendously," he said. "More people are working more, including both parents in many families. That means two incomes but much less time."
And an increasingly affluent yuppie class has fueled demand for more rent-a-Hazels. "These days there are a lot of 21- to 35-year-olds on Wall Street making big money right out of college," Mr. Bohne said. "They start at $75,000, but they work very, very hard. They have no time to clean. They do, however, have the money to clean."
Because housecleaning is an unorganized and a largely unregulated industry, nobody can say exactly how big the business is or how much cleaners typically earn a year. There's no umbrella organization or union for housecleaners, little payroll reporting and no official count of cleaning companies (though some domestic employment agencies are licensed). Many domestic workers are undocumented aliens who inhabit a tax-free world of cash-only work and quiet referrals among neighbors and friends.
Still, the Yellow Pages show a 39 percent increase in ads for companies that offer cleaning services between 1994 and 1998, to 198 companies this year from 142 in 1994, said Phil Santoro, a spokesman for Bell Atlantic Yellow Pages. "It's definitely a growth industry," he said. The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, which tracks salaried employees in private homes -- a small fraction of those who do household work -- reports that the number of such jobs in the city grew 21.6 percent between 1992 and 1997, to 15,156 from 12,466.
Housecleaners, who often work alone in an empty apartment, are afforded glimpses into intimate aspects of private lives that many people wouldn't feel comfortable sharing with friends. They see what's in the refrigerator, the garbage and the closet; they inspect underwear. And they do it with the client's permission.
"Being a cleaner is just like being a detective," said Bill Leonhart, a linguist and musician who cleans for Manhattan Feather Dusters. He said he can tell a room's recent history by its mess. Was there a party? A fight? An intimate dinner? "There are always clues," he said. "By inference, you can put together everything that went on there since the last time you cleaned. You learn the details of people's lives."
Louise Rafkin, a housecleaner and the author of "Other People's Dirt" (Algonquin, 1998), also sees cleaning as inadvertent espionage. Ms. Rafkin, who used to work in New York but now lives in California, said housecleaners gathered intelligence from phone messages, shopping lists, open mail and the medicine cabinet. "Prozac, I learned, is Manhattan popcorn," she said.
"The great thing about New York," she added, "is that there are so many people, you can dump clients and go on. And New Yorkers live less in their houses, so it's a bit easier. Most New York refrigerators contain just vitamins, drugs and those little pouches of duck sauce from the Chinese takeout."
But cleaning is not just a sightseeing tour through someone else's life. Ana K., who works for a cleaning company in Manhattan and who would not give her full name for fear of being fired, said clients sometimes treated her terribly. On one job, "at a huge but tacky mansion with gold faucets and Jacuzzis in the bedrooms," she said, "the woman followed me around, making me do everything over. In the bathroom, she screamed that I missed one hair on the floor. Instead of letting me pick it up, she made me wash and wax the floor again."
Ana, who is a legal immigrant, plans to quit the cleaning business entirely. But for undocumented workers, like Silvia Moreno, housecleaning is one of their few options. Ms. Moreno arrived last year from Peru after her sisters wrote from New York saying she could make $6.50 an hour cleaning, a princely sum by Peruvian standards.
Ms. Moreno, who entered the country on a tourist visa, found herself scouring a Fifth Avenue apartment the following day, having been recommended for the job by her cousin, who also cleans. "I'd never seen anything like it, not even in the movies," she said.
Her experience was anything but grand. "They kept yelling, ordering me around," she said. "I didn't understand a word. It was very scary." The myriad cleaning products were bewildering, especially for someone who grew up without running hot water. "I had no idea what to use on what," Ms. Moreno said. "Everything looked and smelled so strange." After cleaning the floors with Raid, she said, she was fired and went home in tears.
Recent immigrants, many of them illegal, often have a tough time, said Jerry Dominguez, a union representative for Unite, the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees, and head of the Mexican American Workers Association. "We've had many problems with agencies that charge workers a $100 fee, then fire them in two or three weeks before they even get paid," Mr. Dominguez said. "They are too afraid or too ignorant to seek help."
Mr. Dominguez said some undocumented immigrants who clean work 12-hour days, six days a week, for about $3 an hour. And some legal immigrants, he said, must fight to get paid for every hour they have worked. Some, he continued, are intimidated into not quitting. "They are told that it's illegal to work for another company," Mr. Dominguez said. "Or if they quit, they won't receive back pay."
But for others, like Lynette Bell, cleaning for a living is thoroughly enjoyable. "When people come home to a clean place, it picks them right up," she said. "It clears some space, clears their head. Dust and dirt are so depressing to come home to. It makes me feel good to deal with it for them."
A couple of weeks ago she was supervising three women as they all cleaned the four-story, 12-bedroom deanery of St. John the Divine, next to the cathedral. "I just love coming here!" she said. "The first time, I was so excited. I'd never seen a house so big. I couldn't wait to clean this thing."
Ms. Bell spent a year in the city's welfare-to-work program, training people to clean government buildings. A few months ago she joined Call-a-Maid, quickly becoming a supervisor because of her management skills and zest for all things spic-and-span.
Her enthusiasm seemed catching. "I don't mind cleaning at home, so I really don't mind doing it for pay," said Connie Melvin, a former nursing aide. She said she had recently decided that cleaning houses was "a whole lot better than cleaning and dressing old folks."
"Anyway," Ms. Bell said, "there's no room for moaners or complainers, because you won't be called back."
Getting callbacks is the key to Mr. Ireland's business, which he runs with his wife, Sarah. He began cleaning in 1993 to support his acting, earning $10 an hour through an agency. "I got more and more work," he said. "People said I was the best, which was strange since I'd never cleaned before."
Eventually, he began cleaning on his own. "I made lots of money, but I realized this wasn't why I came to the city," he said. "I tried to quit. I raised my rates hoping people would go away, but they didn't." Instead, he invited two unemployed friends to join him in the business, which he named White Glove Elite. Now Mr. Ireland spends more time doing business than cleaning. Still, he keeps two weekly clients. "But I clean while on the cordless phone, running the business the whole time," he said.
White Glove's rates are typical for a New York agency: $17 an hour with a four-hour minimum. To keep workers from taking clients for themselves, the company takes a relatively small commission of $2 to $4 per hour. "People still leave and stick us," Mr. Ireland said. "We call their clients and say, 'That person is untrustworthy.' The clients usually ask us for someone else."
Like others in the business, Mr. Ireland has met his share of characters. One old woman who lived near Columbus Circle, he said, "met us in the hall and said, 'Before you come in, it's very, very messy.' We had to squeeze through the door, there was so much trash. Like up to our waists."
The cleaners were summoned to clear paths through the garbage so that new windows could be installed. "It took three days," he said. "The trash was so old we found a Kleenex box from the 50's with a T-shirt offer for 75 cents with proof of purchase. We were going to tell the poor woman she needed help when I found a pill bottle and prescription pad. Turns out she was a psychiatrist. I think she was prescribing some rather strong stuff for herself."
Another client, a socialite, used heroin, Ms. Ireland said. "Our worker saw her doing it," Ms. Ireland said. "Then one day the woman offered her an apple turnover, only there was nothing on the plate."
Derek Cecil, who works for White Glove, said, "As an actor, you can definitely do some great character studies cleaning apartments." For example, he said, there was the couple with "serious hygiene difficulties" who expected him to do five heavy loads of laundry and clean "months of dirt and filth" in four hours. "Well, it didn't happen that way," he said. "They weren't satisfied. But then I wasn't satisfied with their expectations, either."
Mr. Cecil, 25, a graduate of the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, said he was "well aware of the irony of coming to New York to vacuum the halls." Recently, he cleaned a four-bedroom triplex for men his age. "They were sitting on the couch, skipping work, drinking beer and watching soccer," he said. "It was like some entry-level frat house. One guy was actually collecting unemployment while paying me to clean his house."
But "people are generally really cool," Mr. Cecil said. "Of course, they usually want to meet me, to establish some sort of trust that I won't walk out with half their valuables."
For Mr. Leonhart, who works for Manhattan Feather Dusters, client trust sometimes evolves into friendship. Some of his clients come to see him play guitar and mandolin at places like the Blue Note, he said.
"As a soloist, I like working alone," Mr. Leonhart said. "It's the atmosphere I'm most comfortable in. I can think about my music. And it's very physical." Though he is 60, he said, "my doctor says I have the heart of someone 29."
The owner of Manhattan Feather Dusters, Everet Goldberg, said he started the business 10 years ago using artists because they were "esthetically oriented, detail oriented and fastidious." And cleaning can be therapeutic for artists, Mr. Goldberg said. "It helps them think," he said. "And they get instant results. If you're a writer, you work a long time to see your book published. But if you clean a bathtub, you see the fruits of your labor instantly."
Though he screens each applicant, Mr. Goldberg said, he doesn't do much training. "What's important is their attitude toward work," he said. "Do they want and like to clean?"
For Mary Cavanaugh, who owns Best Home Services Ltd., an employment agency, wanting to clean is not enough. You must really, really know how. She regularly "auditions" women at her Roosevelt Island apartment, running them through good-housekeeping hints that would shame Heloise. Call it boot camp for maids. There's no sweeping under the rug here.
On a recent Friday, Ms. Cavanaugh was trying out two prospective workers. Dusting is a nightmare, she warned them. "Every picture frame, every gewgaw must be dusted. Replace each photo exactly where you found it. Some people don't want to see Great-Grandma up front. And, please, piles of papers mean something to clients. Do not just put them in one pile. At tax time, they will cry."
She doesn't pay for the five-hour training-audition. And not everyone makes the grade. Once hired, they'll be fired if caught "stealing a client, stealing from a client or not being professional," Ms. Cavanaugh said. "One woman was going through coat pockets and stealing tokens. It took people a while to get hip, but then a pattern emerged. Color her gone. Real fast."
Nancy K., a Manhattan psychotherapist who would not give her full name because some of those she employed were illegal immigrants, said she had shown the door to maybe 100 housekeepers over the last two decades. "Some lasted years, some lasted minutes," she said. "One woman did cocaine all day. My husband caught her in the act. She couldn't get the laundry done she was so high. And she had great references."
That one they got through a newspaper ad, she said. "But the next one came from a very fancy agency and with 24 years of references. She was great all day, but about 4 o'clock she'd go out and come back drunk, laid out. We fired her the third day." Then there was the woman who poured an entire soapbox in the dishwasher, filling the house with bubbles, and the masochist who got down on all fours to tie "madame's" shoelaces and refused to be paid.
But clients aren't the only ones who gripe. Mr. Bohne, the owner of the Adele Poston, Bonfield and Park Avenue domestic employment agencies, said rich people can be the toughest. "They are the most likely to argue over that extra $25 a week," he said. "The rich are extra-value conscious. They most often insist on negotiating a lower rate."
"Most complaints come from people of means who weren't born into it. And their expectations are way beyond boundaries," Mr. Bohne said. Indeed, he said, there is an unofficial blacklist of wealthy New Yorkers "who abuse or don't pay or expect the moon and the stars."
"Still, there are some wonderful nouveaux riches," he added. "They don't all treat workers like slave laborers." As for the middle class, he said: "They're regular people who respect and appreciate us and the workers. They never bargain, even if they're struggling."

Some television shows and movies set in New York have had memorable housecleaners as characters. A sampling:

FLORENCE in "THE JEFFERSONS"
Played by Marla Gibbs
When the successful dry cleaner George Jefferson, and his wife, Louise (Wheezy) moved on up to the East Side, they engaged the dubious services of Florence, one of the sassiest -- and laziest -- maids ever to hit the small screen. But she could always be counted on for caustic comebacks to George's inane insults.
CLASSIC LINE:
Whenever the doorbell rang: "Can you get that, Mr. Jefferson?"
 
MR. FRENCH in "FAMILY AFFAIR"
Played by Sebastian Cabot and, for nine episodes, John Williams
Fastidious, stuffy and terribly British, Giles French, gentleman's gentleman to Uncle Bill, unwillingly became cook, housecleaner and dispenser of wisdom to Uncle Bill's orphaned nephew and nices, Jody, Sissy and Buffy.
CLASSIC LINE:
While cleaning up yet another mess: "You know, Jody, that the punishment for breaking lamps is temporary exile to one's bedroom."

MRS. PORTER in "I LOVE LUCY"
Played by Verna Felton
In the classic episode "Lucy Hires a Maid," Lucy pesters Ricky for household help, only to get more than she bargained for in the big and bossy Mrs. Porter, who arrives with her own list of "Do's and Dont's." Lucy is too cowarldy to dismiss Mrs. Porter, so she trashes her own apartment in the hope of scaring her into quitting. The plan backfires because Ricky has already dismissed her and Lucy is stuck cleaning up the mess.
CLASSSIC LINES:
Lucy: "What's your name?"
Mrs. Porter: "Mrs. Porter."
Lucy: "Well, what should I call you?"
Mrs. Porter: "Mrs. Porter."

ALMA in "PILLOW TALK"
Played by Thelma Ritter
This salty New York maid came with a sharp wit, jaundiced outlook and Tech-nicolor drinking problem that wouldn't remotely pass for comedy today. Her boss, Doris Day, looking devilish in Dior, enabled her with morning Bloody Marys in exchange for hard-nosed counsel on dealing with her dashing scoundrel of a suitor, played by Rock Hudson. Precious little was actually cleaned, but Alma spent hours eavesdropping on her boss's party line.
CLASSIC LINE:
"You know I never get into focus until 10 o'clock." DAVID KIRBY

Chart: "TIPS: Windows Extra"
Looking for help at home? Some tips from people in the cleaning business:
 
FINDING A CLEANER
There are four options: companies that send their own employees, agencies that send self-employed cleaners, individuals who advertise and word of mouth.
 
TRUSTING A CLEANER
Always check references. And don't expect much from assurances that employees are bonded, said Jerry Bohne, who owns three domestic employment agencies. To be bonded, cleaners simply sign an affidavit saying they've never been convicted of a felony. "It's supposed to protect you from someone stealing jewelry or putting Pledge on the Renoir," Mr. Bohne said. "But to collect, you need absolute proof, like videotape."
 
WHAT TO PAY
Companies and agencies usually charge $15 to $20 per hour per cleaner. Paying by the job typically runs from about $55 for a studio to $75 for a two-bedroom apartment.
 
HEEDING THE LAW
It's illegal to employ undocumented aliens. And if you pay someone $1,000 or more a year , you are liable for their Social Security and Medicare taxes. If you pay $500 or more a quarter, you are also required to pay state unemployment insurance taxes. If you hire a cleaning company, they take care of all that.
 
GREAT EXPECTATIONS
Give detailed instructions (but not a minute-by-minute to-do list). Discuss hours, breaks, smoking and meals. Restrain pets and children. And get out of the way. (pg. 13)

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Mixing Up the Projects

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A NEW law to revive the nation's troubled public housing had a simple goal when it was first proposed several years go: Allow more working poor families into projects that had become dominated -- some would say decimated -- by very poor welfare families.
The rationale, first pushed by Republicans, was that working families would be role models for their neighbors, would help stabilize projects and, by paying higher rents, would help housing authorities financially. 
 But buried in the 300-page bill that President Clinton signed last month is a provision that local officials warn could paralyze that effort: It requires cities to mix working families with poorer families in each and every project.
Cities say this provision will be self-defeating because it will mean having to persuade working families to move into the worst projects, while trying to keep working families already living in the better projects from fleeing when the poorest of the poor move in.
Inserted during last-minute Congressional negotiations by Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, the provision has been hailed by the Clinton Administration as a tool to reach an even more important goal than income-mixing: racial desegregation. That's because, generally, the poorest tenants tend to be black and Hispanic; among the working poor, a greater proportion are white.
Mr. Cuomo says cities will have to find ways to make it work. "They will not get a penny from this department as long as they maintain segregated housing," he said in an interview, referring to race. Calling the law "a revolutionary integration plan," he said it would keep public housing from becoming even more of what it already is: separate worlds, one for working familes, another for those on welfare.
Public housing in almost every city, he said, is characterized by far too many " 'white' buildings and 'black' buildings and 'Latino' buildings and 'welfare' buildings." Ideally, he said, every building should reflect the racial makeup of each city's public housing system.
 
'Deconcentration'
Mr. Cuomo's provision calls only for economic integration. But the Clinton Administration has portrayed it as being much more about race. In September, President Clinton urged a public housing law that would "deconcentrate poverty, mix incomes and thereby mix people of all races and ethnicities."
Both sides agree that racial imbalances remain widespread in public housing and that years of official discrimination are largely to blame. Mr. Cuomo complains that local housing officials oppose his initiative because they do not want to desegregate. But the local officials insist the law won't work.
They say there's a big difference between rooting out discrimination and trying to make people live where they don't want to live in the name of racial balance. And, they warn that at its worst, the law could turn public housing into a political battleground, as mandatory busing once did for public education.
 
Sweeteners
Over the last decade, even New York City, praised as having some of the best public housing, has seen its proportion of working tenants fall from half to less than a third, in part because of Federal rules favoring the poorest applicants.
The new law allows cities to offer sweeteners to working families -- like lower rents or moving costs -- to lure them to less desirable buildings. But many city officials say that while they favor economic integration and racial integration, too, it is unrealistic to enforce the same numerical goals in every project.
"There are places that working families are just not going to want to go," said a housing official in New York City.
Donald J. Smith, executive director of the Los Angeles Housing Authority, said, "I think given the traditional image of public housing, it's going to be difficult."
The new law says that 40 percent of newly vacant apartments must go to the poorest, those making less than 30 percent of an area's median income. (In New York, this means $15,000 for a family of four. Familes making near that amount could be working minimum-wage jobs, but those making much less tend to be on welfare.) The other 60 percent of vacancies can go to those making more -- people who almost certainly have jobs. In New York, this could mean families earning up to $40,000, in South Texas up to $25,000 and in Chicago up to $45,000.
Joseph Ventrone, the staff director for the Republican-controlled House subcommittee on housing, calls Mr. Cuomo's provision "an extraordinary example of H.U.D. micromanagement which is contrary to one of the main purposes of the bill" -- to give decision-making power to cities so they can find ways to attract working families.
Even some advocates for the poorest of the poor are wary.
"It's certainly necessary for someone to say it," said David Bryce, deputy director of the National Housing Law Center, "and it would be nice if someone could do something about it, but the reality is that it's incredibly complex. You've got to factor in what people of color want for themselves. You can say segregation is bad -- and forced segregation is certainly bad -- but you can't leap from that to say that you must desegegrate all public housing projects."
But other housing advocates, including Jeff Lubell, an analyst for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a nonprofit research group, say the law must find some way -- if not Mr. Cuomo's way -- to address racial segregation or risk worsening the imbalance when cities bring in working families, more of whom will be white.
"If all you achieve through the new targeting rules," Mr. Lubell said, "is lower-income familes in some of the higher-income developments and other developments remaining largely very poor and minority, then is that really a good policy?"

CORRECTION-DATE: November 29, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 15 about mixing the poor with the very poor in public housing gave an incorrect surname for the deputy director of the National Housing Law Center, who commented on racial segregation in housing projects. He is David Bryson, not Bryce.

HEADLINE: Xcacel Journal;
Voice of the Turtles Opposes a Hotel Development

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: XCACEL, Mexico

 BODY:
This pristine Caribbean beach is one of the world's most important nesting areas for sea turtles, and Mexican environmentalists view its ivory sands and emerald waters as sacred terrain, on a smaller scale but a bit the way people in the United States see Yosemite or the Grand Canyon.
For years the environmentalists have been pleading with the authorities to protect the beach, 67 miles south of Cancun, from the bulldozers and chain saws that are devouring vast stretches of palm-covered dunes and mangrove marshes as the Government sells off the coast of the state of Quintana Roo to commercial developers. 
 But in February, after months of secret negotiations, the state government announced that Xcacel (pronounced shkah-SELL) had been sold for $2.2 million to a Spanish conglomerate that plans to build a 450-room hotel. The sale has set off one of Mexico's most bitter environmental battles.
Greenpeace, the Sierra Club and other international and Mexican conservation groups are campaigning to reverse the deal. Government officials and the developers are shrugging off the protests.
"Everywhere there are extremists who say development can't move in concert with nature, but we disagree," said Jorge Polanco Zapata, who represents Quintana Roo as a Senator from Mexico's governing party and supports the Xcacel hotel project. "We think the turtles will be a tourist attraction."
The sale has become a symbol of what ecologists describe as predatory development desecrating a wonderland of squawking parrots and pre-Columbian ruins along 80 miles of coast stretching from Cancun to the Mayan site of Tulum.
Environmentalists complain that land use plans and environmental impact statements have been ignored in the construction of a new corridor of luxury hotels and "eco-tourism" resorts.
Aracely Dominguez, the founder of the region's most important conservation group and the owner of a small Cancun hotel, said highways had been gouged through coastal rain forests, mangrove swamps paved into parking lots and delicate coastal bays dredged with hydraulic draglines.
"We can't permit them to plunder Xcacel as they have all these other beaches," she said.
Xcacel has become the focus for scientists because of research showing that thousands of Atlantic green and loggerhead turtles nest there, apparently attracted to the gentle slope of its sands, so many that those species' genetic diversity is dependent on the beach. As a result, scientists and conservationists have based turtle protection and environmental education programs for the entire Yucatan Peninsula here.
For a decade, thousands of children and their families have made pilgrimages to Xcacel each year to experience the wonder of the summer nesting season, when on any evening scores of 400-pound loggerheads glide through the surf, lumber up the sloping beach and burrow into the dune to lay eggs. Turtle rangers protect the nests from the poachers who sack beaches elsewhere in Mexico.
Xcacel was a federal reserve until 1992, when control passed to Quintana Roo. Aides to Gov. Mario Villanueva secretly negotiated the sale, and federal environmental officials have ignored entreaties to intervene.
"This sale has fed cynicism about the Government's environmental policies, because an entire generation of children has learned that Xcacel is a protected area," said Julio Zurita, a Quintana Roo biologist who helped identify its importance. "Then overnight they were told it's been sold."
The announcement of the sale in February touched off an outcry from scores of international environmental groups.
"We don't think the builder of a hotel should come in and destroy the habitat of a creature that's been around for millions of years," said Edgar Wayburn, honorary president of the Sierra Club.
Governor Villanueva reacted by declaring a swath of dune 100 yards wide the length of the beach to be a "protected natural area" and prohibiting construction there. Conservationists said the move had little practical consequence, since few hotels build on the dune anyway.
The Spanish corporation that purchased Xcacel, Sol Melia, which operates hotels in 23 countries, has said it plans to build "a 450-room Paradisus Tulum All-Inclusive Beach Resort."
Evagrio Sanchez, a senior executive of Sol Melia's real estate division, said his company was awaiting an environmental study before elaborating final designs. But the hotel will be built away from the beach, with subdued illumination that will not confuse the nesting turtles, he said.
"We want sustainable development, with scrupulous protection, not just for the turtles but for all the fauna and flora," Mr. Sanchez said.
But environmentalists were alarmed when, during a meeting in May, Sol Melia executives outlined plans for a golf course at Xcacel. A seaside hotel in Costa Rica that Sol Melia has touted as an example of its commitment to build "in concert with nature" features an 18-hole golf course and a discotheque.
Construction at Xcacel has not yet begun, but Sol Melia employees who put up a barbed-wire fence around their newly purchased property chopped down 1,200 rare palm trees, said Juan Carlos Cantu, Greenpeace's Mexico director. Mr. Sanchez denied that. "We're not going to do anything that will go against nature," he said.
If most of the debate has been about ecology, Alfredo Cesar Dachary, director of Quintana Roo's Caribbean Center for Sustainable Development, has questioned the economics of the deal. Why, he asks, did the Government sell a coastal treasure like Xcacel for a price fetched by some private homes in Cancun or the nearby island of Cozumel.
"That $2.25 million price is completely laughable," Mr. Cesar said.
The Government sold several beaches in the same area last year. Atop a mangrove marsh on the beach adjoining Xcacel, a developer is currently building tracts of concrete bungalows. Builders describe the sprawling resort as "low-density" development, but from the air it looks like Levittown.
All the construction has attracted thousands of workers to Quintana Roo, and many live in coastal slums. One squatters' settlement near Playa del Carmen, 42 miles south of Cancun, has 30,000 inhabitants. When Hurricane Mitch was threatening Quintana Roo recently, there was an incident that was emblematic of developers' attitudes.
The owners at several seacoast hotel projects summarily fired 7,000 construction workers, shorting them a week's pay, and fled. The panicked laborers, many of whom live in other states, blocked the coastal highway for hours until the authorities sent buses to take them to Cancun. After sleeping in streets there for two nights, mobs of hungry workers rioted, shattering windows and overturning vending machines.
Artemio Santos Santos, president of the Coparmex, the state's most important business group, said environmental and social disputes were beginning to disrupt Quintana Roo's coastal development because the government had failed to enforce clear environmental policies.
"There need to be clear rules for investors about respecting our fauna and flora, and that's where we've fallen short," Mr. Santos said. "And that could be what's happening with this Xcacel project. They're developing an area that should be dedicated to the turtles."
