HEADLINE: GORE, IN MALAYSIA, SAYS ITS LEADERS SUPPRESS FREEDOM

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore today rebuked the Malaysian Government for suppressing freedom and championed the growing protest movement here as tensions between the United States and Malaysia boiled over at a meeting of Pacific Rim countries.
Standing in for President Clinton at the annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, Mr. Gore praised Malaysians who have rallied against Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad as brave people. 
 "Democracies have done better in coping with economic crises than nations where freedom is suppressed," Mr. Gore said in a speech. "Democracy confers a stamp of legitimacy that reforms must have in order to be effective.
"And so, among nations suffering economic crises, we continue to hear calls for democracy and reform in many languages -- people's power, doi moi, reformasi," he said, referring to the slogans of reform movements in the Philippines, Vietnam and Malaysia. "We hear them today -- right here, right now -- among the brave people of Malaysia."
"Reformasi," or reform, is the rallying cry of protesters who are demanding the resignation of Dr. Mahathir. The Prime Minister has been under searing criticism for ousting and imprisoning his reform-minded deputy, Anwar Ibrahim, who is on trial on corruption and sex-related charges.
 The Malaysian Government reacted angrily to the remarks early Tuesday, saying they were an incitement to unrest, Agence France-Presse reported.
 "Malaysia rejects as most unwarranted the provocative remarks made by U.S. Vice President Al Gore and the White House," a statementby Foreign Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi said. "Malaysians would hold the U.S. accountable for any rupture of this harmony arising from this irresponsible incitement."
Though few people have taken to the heavily guarded streets of Kuala Lumpur this week, the Anwar case has poisoned the atmosphere at a meeting of leaders who were trying to focus on the crushing economic crisis.
Mr. Gore's broadside against his Malaysian hosts eclipsed his announcement that the United States and Japan would join in a plan to provide $10 billion in financing to help rebuild Asia's shattered banks and corporations.
The plan is the first major collaboration of the United States and Japan in confronting the Asian crisis. And it comes after the two countries sparred over lowering trade barriers.
Today, though, the rancor was entirely between the United States and Malaysia. Prime Minister Mahathir and other top Malaysian officials were in the audience during Mr. Gore's speech, and his words drew a sulfurous reaction.
"It was the most disgusting speech I've heard in my life," Trade Minister Rafidah Aziz said to a group of reporters afterward.
The ill will between the United States and Malaysia has been building since this meeting began. When Mr. Clinton, who started these gatherings six years ago, canceled his visit because of the Iraq crisis, some people here interpreted it as a convenient excuse to avoid coming to a country in disfavor.
 The speech that Mr. Gore delivered was drafted for President Clinton by the National Security Council, a senior Administration official in Washington said. But Mr. Clinton, immersed in the standoff with Iraq, did not see the speech before it was given to Mr. Gore. So it is impossible to know, the official said, whether Mr. Clinton would have delivered it as drafted -- or toned it down, something he often does in a foreign land.
 "The Vice President read it as it was written for him," another official said.
On Sunday, Ms. Rafidah clashed publicly with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who met with Mr. Anwar's wife, Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, during her 24-hour visit here.
American officials are not the only visitors who have sought to make an issue of Mr. Anwar's plight. President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines met with Mr. Anwar's wife today, and on Saturday the Canadian Foreign Minister, Lloyd Axworthy, also met with Ms. Wan Azizah.
Dr. Mahathir has bitterly criticized visitors for meddling in Malaysia's internal affairs, and people who watched him tonight during Mr. Gore's speech said he appeared deeply offended by the Vice President's remarks.
The wording particularly stung in Malaysia because Dr. Mahathir views himself as far more savvy than President Suharto, the fallen Indonesian leader, and believes that his country has been the most advanced in Southeast Asia in promoting high technology and designing an economy to attract world markets.
Although several hundred people milled outside the convention center while Mr. Gore spoke -- a typical prelude to a demonstration in this country -- the crowd did not coalesce and it eventually dispersed. Red water-cannon trucks were parked prominently around the building.
After Mr. Gore's speech American and Japanese officials struggled to switch the focus to their new financing package. Under the terms of the plan, the United States has pledged to contribute $5 billion worth of trade financing and insurance to help bolster the efforts of Governments in Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia to recapitalize their debt-stricken banks and companies.
Another $5 billion is to be provided by a separate Asian recovery fund, officials said. Japan has agreed to commit $3 billion to that fund, which is also to include money from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. Malaysia may qualify for some aid from the fund, but neither American nor Japanese officials specified it as a potential recipient.
With its emphasis on recovery rather than rescue, the proposal is in keeping with the tone of this meeting, which aside from the political pyrotechnics has been marked by subdued reflection on the costs of the Asian crisis.
President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea said his country had to bear much of the responsibility for its currency collapse in July 1997, which devastated South Korea's economy and left it within a whisker of defaulting on its loans.
"We now know why and how the crisis came," Mr. Kim said. "It was because of the collusive ties between politics and businesses, Government-controlled financing and widespread corruption."
Western business leaders exhorted Asian countries not to give up on reforming their economies. But they acknowledged that the United States and Europe bore some responsibility for the crisis.
Jon S. Corzine, the co-chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company, said developed countries must rein in the vast, unpredictable flows of capital in and out of emerging markets. Mr. Corzine even called for government regulation of hedge funds, which contribute to these sudden surges.
But after Mr. Gore's speech, it is not clear that Kuala Lumpur will be a place for earnest discussions of global finance. Asked this evening about the American commitment to provide $5 billion in financing to Asia, Ms. Rafidah said: "I don't care. To me it's not worth five cents."

HEADLINE: CRISIS WITH IRAQ: HOUR BY HOUR;
From the Brink to the Blink: Washington's Iraq Weekend

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER and PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen told the President to attack Iraq. Her aides said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who was then en route to an economic summit in Malaysia, would agree.
But it was President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, serving as the conduit between the senior officials and the President, whose view prevailed. Spurred by a vague bulletin on CNN, Mr. Berger advised Mr. Clinton on Saturday morning to hold off. 
 Only minutes before hundreds of cruise missiles were to rain down on Iraq, Mr. Clinton called off what would have been the deadliest military attack of his Presidency, according to a reconstruction of this weekend's events based on interviews with several of the participants who insisted on anonymity.
"It was very close, as close as it could possibly come," Mr. Cohen said at a news conference today.
The attack was set to begin at 9 A.M. on Saturday, Eastern time. A few minutes past 8, the phone rang in Mr. Berger's Washington home. The galvanizing news came not from the Central Intelligence Agency, but CNN, reporting from Baghdad that Iraq had blinked. The Iraqis had sent a letter to the United Nations agreeing to allow weapons inspectors to resume their work.
The President would have to decide whether to call off the attack or kill an unpredictable number of Iraqis, including civilians, even as Baghdad was appearing to capitulate. Armed only with this secondhand information, Mr. Berger raced to the White House, arriving in his office in the West Wing at about 8:15 A.M.
Nobody knew what the Iraqi letter said. And even if the Iraqis had agreed to allow the arms inspections to resume, why should the United States trust them this time?
"It was touch and go," a senior Administration official said, adding, in reference to Mr. Berger: "Sandy's saying: 'Get me the text of that letter right now! Get what you can off the wires right now! We've got 60 minutes, 45 minutes left.' And the President had to sit there and stare at the phone and make the decision."
Mr. Clinton sat by a phone in his residence on the second floor of the White House. With only minutes to go, Mr. Berger called the Pentagon, the State Department and the office of Vice President Al Gore, asking all to offer advice on whether the President should delay the attack.
Mr. Berger felt that the attack should be delayed to study the Iraqi offer. Mr. Cohen thought that it should go forward, and that the Iraqi letter was too late and too confused.
Senior aides who had spoken to Ms. Albright, who was then flying to the meeting of Pacific Rim leaders, said she would also want the attack to proceed. Gen. Henry H. Shelton, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in an interview today that "all the pros and cons were discussed" and that the military had been ready to carry out the President's orders.
Administration officials said the tone of the debate among the President's security advisers was understandably tense given the time pressure, but never angry. "This was not people at one extreme or the other," a senior official said.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said that in making his decision, he was troubled by Pentagon estimates that several thousand Iraqis, including civilians, would be killed in the air strikes, a death toll far greater than from any other American military strike since the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
"Can you order a military mission that kills thousands of people if there is the possibility that your adversary is giving in to your demands?" a White House official asked. "To my mind, he had no choice but to delay this thing."
Mr. Clinton picked up the phone, called the Pentagon and aborted the attack. By the time his order reached seven B-52 bombers nearing Iraq and 14 warships in the Persian Gulf poised to fire nearly 300 cruise missiles, it was 8:45 A.M. -- 15 minutes to go until an assault that could have killed thousands of people.
Mr. Clinton realized that he was about to make war on a nation that might have just sued for peace, his aides said. "The President decided at that point to halt -- to put a pause, actually -- in the operation to see what that response was," another senior official said.
Thus began a day and a night of nonstop talks in the White House and around the world. The argument swung back and forth. The attack was rescheduled for Sunday. But after receiving assurances from the Iraqis and Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, that the ousted weapons inspectors could return to work unhampered by President Saddam Hussein's soldiers and spies, Mr. Clinton decided that there would be no war.
His decision to call off the mission entirely came shortly after 3 A.M. Sunday.
Less than 40 hours before, Mr. Clinton had ordered the Pentagon to bombard Mr. Hussein's strongholds. "We were going to give it to him with both barrels," an official said.
Then President Hussein tossed a monkey wrench into the war machine, in the form of a four-page fax to Mr. Annan that arrived in New York at about 7:30 A.M on Saturday. A copy of the letter reached the White House at mid-morning, as the President, Mr. Gore and top national security officials convened in person and by telephone at the White House situation room. The meeting went on into late afternoon.
They studied the letter and decided that it might be another Iraqi ruse.
"The more we looked at it, the less we liked it," a senior official said. "The President said 'I'm not prepared to accept this.' "
The war plans were back on.
On Saturday afternoon, in the White House situation room, the Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, offered the C.I.A.'s opinion that if Iraq readmitted the weapons inspectors, Mr. Hussein would probably cooperate for a few days, perhaps a few weeks -- unless the inspectors found his cache of biological or chemical weapons materiel. But sooner or later, the C.I.A.'s analysts predicted, the Iraqi leader would return to his old ways of concealment and deception, blocking the inspectors' work.
On Saturday evening, two more letters arrived at the White House. They had been sent to the United Nations Security Council by the Iraqi delegate, Nizar Hamdoon. At 7:20 P.M., the Iraqis offered unconditional cooperation with the weapons inspectors. By telephone, the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, weighed in, saying Iraq should specifically renounce its Aug. 5 and Oct. 31 refusals to comply with the weapons inspectors. A second letter from the Iraqis followed at 9:06 P.M. It met Mr. Blair's demand.
At this point the United States thought that it had what it sought, an unconditional, unequivocal statement that Iraq would let the weapons inspectors do their work. But the argument continued through the night: Should the attack plans be called off? Should a lesser attack proceed? Could the Iraqis be trusted in any way, given their record of breaking agreements with the inspectors?
Mr. Clinton returned to the Oval Office shortly after 9 P.M. on Saturday. He spent most of the next five hours on the telephone with Mr. Gore, who was in Air Force Two, on his way to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; with Secretary Albright, who already had arrived there after a 20-hour trip; and with Mr. Cohen, Mr. Tenet, General Shelton, Mr. Blair and the French President, Jacques Chirac.
Ultimately, senior officials said, the consensus was that the United States could not strike Iraq if the Iraqis had essentially done what Washington had demanded.
At 3 A.M. on Sunday, Mr. Berger talked to Mr. Annan in New York, trying to make sure that they were agreed on what the Iraqis' statements meant. They agreed on the promises that Iraq had made.
A few minutes later, Mr. Berger called General Shelton at the Pentagon and transmitted an order from the President: Cancel the attack .
Now the decision had to be explained to the American people.
Senior Administration officials, including Mr. Berger, had been saying privately all week that the United Nations' weapons inspection program was essentially dead, killed by Mr. Hussein's intransigence. The weapons inspectors had not conducted a thorough search since August; 100 days had passed, allowing Mr. Hussein to hide evidence of his suspected biological and chemical weapons programs. Now the United States had to strike Iraq swiftly and severely or lose all credibility, they had argued.
Mr. Clinton evidently disagreed. On Sunday, he called the weapons inspectors' ability to return to Iraq "the best outcome" of the crisis, the saving grace of the frustrated war plans. Bombing Iraq, he argued, probably would not have achieved that result.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Tops 9,000 On Hope for a Rate Cut
Stock prices rose, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average past 9,000 for the first time since late July, on hopes the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates at today's policy-making meeting.
The Dow industrials were up 91.66 points, or 1.03 percent, at 9,011.25. Broader market indexes also advanced. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 10.16 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,135.88, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 13.69 points, or 0.74 percent, to 1,861.68. Page C13. 

G.M. expects to raise $1.5 billion from spinning off as much as 19 percent of its Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation supplier unit. C12.
 
Treasury prices fell for the first time in more than a week on uncertainty over a rate cut. The 30-year bond yield rose to 5.29 percent. C13.
 
Hewlett-Packard Exceeds Forecast
Hewlett-Packard reported a 12 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings that nevertheless exceeded analysts' estimates. C2.
 
Industrial Production Off in October
Industrial production unexpectedly fell one-tenth of a percent in October, the fourth drop in five months. C2.
 
Two Plead Guilty in Insider Case
Two former brokers pleaded guilty to taking secret stock information, another victory for New York State prosecutors in an important insider trading case. C8.
 
Amazon.com in Holiday Expansion
Amazon.com, the on-line retailer that dominates Internet book sales and, increasingly, music, is expanding into a broader array of merchandise that includes consumer electronics, games and toys. C12.
 
Profit Slide Continues at Toys 'R' Us
Toys "R" Us, the world's biggest toy retailer, reported a 57 percent slide in third-quarter operating profit. The fall was expected because of slow sales and competition from discount chains like Wal-Mart. C2.
 
Nike Shifts to Safer Solvents
Nike said it was shifting to safer glues and solvents, so that less than 1 percent of its Asian work force now came into contact with dangerous vapors from petroleum-based solvents, a three-quarters reduction from last year. C6.
 
Skepticism Greets Japanese Plan
Although the $195 billion economic stimulus plan announced by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan is the nation's largest ever, investors were not overly enthusiastic. They have been disappointed in Japan so many times that they are hard to impress. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks ended up 160.06 points, or a modest 1.12 percent, at 14,428.27. But critics called the package misguided. News Analysis. A7.
 
Moody's lowered Japan's top-rated credit rating because of its troubled economy. C2.
 
Telebras Spinoffs on Big Board
The 12 holding companies spun off from Brazil's telecommunications giant Telebras during its privatization in the summer began trading on the New York Stock Exchange, bolstered by the Government's rescue agreement with the I.M.F. Market Place. C12.
 
Corporate Germany Cutting Back
The streamlining of corporate Germany is accelerating, reflecting pressure to shed businesses that drag down overall profit. In the last two weeks three of the biggest conglomerates, Siemens, Viag and Metro, have announced plans for huge spinoffs of units that employ tens of thousands of people. C6.

HEADLINE: Moody's Decides to Downgrade Its Financial Ratings for Japan

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Japan lost its top "Aaa" credit rating from Moody's Investors Service, as the nation remains mired in its worst recession in five decades.
The rating company cut Japan's foreign currency ceilings for bonds, notes and bank deposits one notch to "Aa1," as well as its rating on securities issued or guaranteed by the Government. The move indicates that Japan may not be in as solid a position to repay debts as other top-rated countries such as the United States, Germany and Britain. 
 Moody's said that the downgrade from "Aaa," which Japan had held for 17 years, reflects "uncertainties and heightened risks over the long term arising from economic and policy weaknesses that have led to sig nificant deterioration in the government's fiscal position."
Moody's downgrade -- the first of a Group of Seven nation since Canada was cut to "Aa2" in 1995 -- comes one day after the Government announced its biggest-ever economic stimulus package, about 24 trillion yen, or $197 billion, in public works spending and tax cuts.
"It's understandable that someone needed to give a black mark to Japan" after the country announced the measures, said Tetsu Aikawa, a foreign exchange manager at Sanwa Bank. "That's because Japan's budget deficit will expand."
The dollar surged after Moody's announcement, trading for 121.90 yen, up from 120.36 yen in New York trading on Monday. The announcement was made after the Japanese stock and bond markets closed for today's midday break. In the morning session, the Nikkei 225 stock index slipped 15 points, to 14,413.25, while bonds were little changed.
Asked about the Moody's downgrade, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said Japanese Government bonds are "the most trustworthy in the world."
Moody's placed Japan on review for downgrade on July 23. The cut gives Japan the same credit rating as Belgium, Denmark and Singapore, among others.

HEADLINE: Livery Cabs Get the Blame For Increase in Accidents

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN and JOSH BARBANEL 

 BODY:
As taxi accidents have risen steadily in New York City over the past decade, the most recognizable image of the danger has been that of a yellow cab wrecked on a Manhattan sidewalk, debris strewn about, perhaps a pedestrian pinned against a light pole. But an analysis of newly released accident data shows that car services and livery cabs are actually responsible for the increase.
The New York Times analysis of more than 100,000 accidents reported to the state found that crashes involving livery vehicles -- which include call-for-pickup car services, corporate "black cars," some commuter vans and vans for the handicapped -- increased by 60 percent from 1990 to 1997. 
 The number of yellow-cab crashes in the city, the analysis found, has dropped significantly since 1994 after rising during the early 90's and is now only slightly above what it was at the start of the decade.
Serious injuries in yellow-cab accidents are down by more than 20 percent since 1990, even including the rash of disfiguring facial injuries caused by partitions affixed to the driver's seat since they became standard equipment in yellow cabs in 1994.
The number of livery cars has increased significantly over that period while the number of medallion cabs is up only slightly. On a per-cab basis, livery-car accidents were still up 25 percent while yellow-cab accidents were virtually the same in 1997 as in 1990.
The analysis sheds light on an overlooked sector of the transportation industry that does most of its business in the boroughs outside Manhattan and that regulators have only recently begun to take seriously, even though livery cars outnumber yellow cabs more than three to one.
The diverging trends had been hidden because the State Department of Motor Vehicles lumps all vehicles for hire together as "taxis" and because the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission did not track accidents at all from 1990 until it passed a broad package of new rules in May.
The state agency turned down repeated requests from The Times for data on individual accidents for eight months, saying that generating the data would require an extensive computer run that was beyond the requirements of the Freedom of Information Law. It finally released the data last week, but still has not furnished it to the taxi commission.
Earlier this year, the only data available from the state showed a 40 percent increase in accidents involving all "taxis" from 1990 to 1996. This, along with several high-profile yellow-cab crashes, prompted a spate of news articles, including several in The Times, and helped spur a crackdown by the city that included a ticket-writing blitz against yellow cabs and much steeper fines and insurance requirements for all kinds of taxis.
But the trends are sharply different in various parts of the city. In Manhattan south of 96th Street, where yellow cabs predominate, accidents involving all "taxis" have increased 17 percent since 1990, although in recent years the numbers have declined. But outside Manhattan, where yellow cabs are seldom seen except at the airports, accidents involving all cars classified as "taxis" have increased by 53 percent since 1990. "Taxi" accidents in Brooklyn have jumped even more dramatically, by 81 percent over the decade.
Experts and officials offered several possible explanations for the accident pattern. Livery cars, which are only allowed to pick up riders by prearrangement, have been far less regulated over the years than yellow cabs, which can cruise for fares, and several police and taxi commission initiatives during the 90's have applied only to yellow cabs. And Bruce Schaller, a former regulator for the taxi commission, has produced a study showing that the economic boom of the last few years may have done more to increase wages for yellow cabbies than for livery drivers, leading them, he concluded, to drive less recklessly.
Eugene Pero, the president of the Livery Owners Coalition of New York, said that much of the increase in livery accidents was due simply to the increase in livery cars -- to about 41,000 in 1997, up from about 32,000 in 1990, according to the commission. (There are 12,187 yellow cabs, up 400 since 1990.)
But the increase in accidents has outpaced the growth in the fleet, with the accident rate per livery car up by about 25 percent, the analysis showed. The accident rate per yellow cab, by contrast, was virtually the same in 1997 as in 1990.
The accident rate per car for yellow cabs is somewhat higher than that for liveries, but most yellow cabs are driven round the clock while most livery cars are driven less than 12 hours a day.
Whatever the reason, the analysis was greeted with an "I-told-you-so" by yellow-cab executives, who, along with their biggest insurer, American Transit Insurance Company, asserted for months as they fought the new rules that yellow-cab accidents were dropping.
"I think we've been unfairly blamed and targeted," said Ronald Sherman, president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents big fleet owners. "We would hope that the T.L.C. and the city adjust their enforcement accordingly."
But the chairwoman of the taxi commission, Diane McGrath-McKechnie, said the agency would not change course.
"This is not a numbers game for the T.L.C.," Ms. McGrath-McKechnie said. "This is about public safety. Whether the numbers go up a little bit or down a little bit, there are still too many accidents, and we need safe drivers for medallion cabs and for livery vehicles."
The Police Department, however, said it would consider cracking down on livery cars. This spring, when attention was focused on taxi dangers, a special police department unit that focuses on yellow cabs stepped up its enforcement sharply; tickets written by the unit rose 36 percent for the first eight months of this year over the same period in 1997.
"We have had focused enforcement on livery cabs and will continue to do so," said Lieut. Stephen Biegel, a police spokesman. "We'll also review the data and see if a formal unit would be in order."
Ms. McGrath-McKechnie said the commission's new rules, most of which apply equally to yellow and livery cabs, should bring the two industries into line with each other. And she said she planned to call for votes at the next commission meeting on Thursday on the two proposed rules that the commissioners balked at passing in May.
One rule would require all yellow-cab owners to post a $100,000 bond for accident victims to collect against. The other would lower the penalty-point threshold at which drivers lose their licenses.
The Times analysis found that yellow cab accidents reported to the state increased from about 3,850 in 1990 to a peak of about 4,850 in 1994, then decreased to about 3,950 last year. Accidents involving livery cars rose steadily from about 6,300 in 1990 to about 9,050 in 1994 and 10,150 last year. The analysis used statistical methods to estimate the distribution of accidents where data was incomplete.
Serious injuries in livery accidents, including severe cuts, broken bones, and other internal injuries also increased during the decade, to about 800 in 1997 from 675 in 1990. During the same period, serious injuries in yellow cabs dropped to about 350 in 1997 from about 450 in 1990.
The Times analysis found that in 1994, when the partitions became standard, the number of yellow-cab accidents in which the most serious injury was to the face or eye jumped drastically, to 81 from 52. But those accidents represent such a small portion of the total -- 2 or 3 percent -- that the increase was swallowed up by the overall decrease.
And by the end of 1997, yellow-cab accidents in which the most serious injury was to the face or eye had dropped below the 1990 level of 46, to 36, due at least in part to an aggressive campaign by the taxi commission to get passengers to wear their seat belts.
Fidel F. Del Valle, the chairman of the taxi commission from 1991 to 1995, said that until the new rules were passed, most of the enforcement against livery cabs consisted of making sure the cars were properly registered and were not cruising for fares. He said that holders of livery licenses often allowed friends or relatives to work their cars when they were not using them, whether or not they had hack licenses.
"Until the recent rules," he said, "there have been no real rules as to the behavior of for-hire vehicle drivers."
Yellow cabs, meanwhile, have been held to a standard that, whatever its shortcomings, has become more strict over the course of the decade. In 1990, the commission began a persistent-violator program for yellow cabs that has resulted in hundreds of suspensions. In 1995, the police took over enforcement against yellow cabs from taxi commission inspectors and began writing what many yellow-cab drivers complained was a blizzard of nuisance tickets for minor infractions.
In 1996, the commission passed a rule requiring owners to buy new cabs every four years at most. Some livery drivers, Mr. Pero said, keep their cars on the road for up to 15 years.
"I see cars on the road in the livery industry that I'd be ashamed to put in my fleet," said Mr. Pero, who runs a fleet of 42 car-service and black cars.
Mr. Pero agreed that regulation of liveries had been too lax, but like many yellow-cab owners, he said that the commission and the police had gone overboard since the new rules were passed in the spring, and he said he was worried that it could get much harder for him to make a living.
"What has happened in past administrations is that they haven't corrected the industry," he said. "The T.L.C. hasn't protected the public until now. But all of a sudden they implement this stuff on both industries and it becomes chaotic."
 
Analysis Methods
The Times analysis was based on an examination of a state database of nearly 120,000 taxi accidents involving 127,000 cabs, 133,000 other vehicles and 320,000 people, more than half of whom were injured, across New York State between 1990 and 1997.
The database, compiled from police reports, included the license plate number of each vehicle. The Times classified each New York City taxi as either a yellow cab or a livery car based on unique sequences of plate numbers assigned to each type.
In roughly 15 to 20 percent of all New York City taxi accidents, the plate number was missing from the state files, typically because the plate number reported by the police did not match state license records.
The analysis found that the pattern of missing records strongly matched the pattern of medallion taxi accidents across the city. As a result, The Times classified these accidents based on a statistical model that considered the number of medallion and livery plates in each precinct.
Over all years, 80 percent of the missing cases were allocated to yellow cabs. Experts said yellow cab license plates were complicated, often containing a small subscripted number that caused errors in state accident reports. The model assumed that there were no other factors that might explain the pattern of missing plates. But even if all the missing plates were livery cars or taxis, the pattern the analysis found -- a decline in yellow cab accidents and an increase in livery car accidents -- was still valid.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
German Central Banker Opposes Rate Cut Now

BYLINE: Bridge News 

 BODY:
A member of the Bundesbank council, Guntram Palm, said yesterday that it would not be appropriate now to reduce official German interest rates, an action that has been repeatedly called for by members of the new German Government. Mr. Palm also rejected establishing foreign-exchange target zones for the United States dollar, the euro and the Japanese yen.
In a speech prepared for delivery at a Baden-Wurttemberg state central bank function, Mr. Palm said the money supply in Germany and Europe was ample for economic growth. He would not rule out a rate move by the European Central Bank during 1999, but he stressed that rate cuts were not a cure-all for economic problems.

HEADLINE: What to Do About the Gridlock?;
Second Ave. Subway

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Nov. 12 news article on lagging subway service points out that the sharp increase in ridership has increased crowding and slowed service but produced a $240 million budget surplus so far for New York City Transit.
In order to alleviate these problems and take advantage of the growing surplus, New York City Transit should restart a project that has been in limbo for more than two decades. This would be to revive the now-forgotten Second Avenue subway line construction. 
 This would be an economic boon for the city because of the jobs it would create. Also, with the effect of the economic multiplier, several times the annual construction expenditures would flow into the city's economy.
 
E. MAGNUS OPPENHEIM
New York, Nov. 13, 1998
 
The writer is an economist and investment analyst.

HEADLINE: Confronting a $1.4 Billion Blank Page

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
DORIS DUKE, reputedly the richest woman in the United States when she died in 1993 at the age of 80, loved jazz, modern dance, gospel music and Islamic art. She cared about children, animals and the great outdoors. She worried about people with heart disease, cancer, AIDS and sickle cell anemia.
What Ms. Duke did not pay much attention to, apparently, was organization. 
 When Joan E. Spero, the president of the brand-new, $1.4 billion Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, showed up for her first day on the job in February 1997, she found a temporary office near Times Square lent by Morgan Stanley (whose president, John J. Mack, sits on the board) and a temporary secretary.
"I gave her $20 to go out and get some supplies," Ms. Spero recalled. Then she opened her briefcase, which contained a copy of Ms. Duke's will, a few notes from debriefing the estate's lawyers, their printout of key phone numbers and a virgin Filofax, and sat down to work.
But to do what? Many rich people leave detailed instructions and even established organizations to carry out their philanthropic wishes. But not Ms. Duke, who was famous for her independent spirit. Her will directed that money go toward "the improvement of humanity" and made references to entertainers, flora, fauna and a few other causes close to her heart. That was about it.
Ms. Spero, 54, had to build an organization for the 25th largest American foundation from scratch -- in time to hand out nearly $20 million last year, as required by law. With the annual sum beginning this year at around $55 million, the nonprofit world has been watching.
"There had just been cuts in government funding, so the idea of a new foundation with a substantial amount of money was a boost to all of us in the field," said Harvey Lichtenstein, the president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Now, almost two years later, suspense remains rampant -- even more so after the announcement last December that the initial grants each exceeded $1 million, a huge sum for perpetually needy organizations.
Though now ensconced in its own office on Fifth Avenue overlooking St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Duke foundation is not fully in place. "We still don't have the capacity to take grant applications," Ms. Spero said, sounding apologetic, "although we're in dialogue with some people." She promised to have some guidelines ready by January.
Serious, mild-mannered and dressed in shades of gray and powder blue, Joan Spero seems an unlikely alter ego for the flamboyant Ms. Duke, whom most people remember for the posthumous legal battles with the alcoholic, semiliterate butler she had named as executor and with the adopted daughter Ms. Duke had disinherited.
Nevertheless, as soon as Ms. Spero took the job, "I was everybody's new best friend in New York." Ms. Duke's will had been posted on the Internet, allowing everyone to read about, among other things, her "special interest in the prevention of cruelty to animals" and of the $100,000 she left in trust for the care of her dog. Thousands of music and ballet companies, environment and historic-preservation groups and others had inundated the foundation with pleas for money. "Of course we made a call," Mr. Lichtenstein said.
The foundation's trustees -- who include James F. Gill, a lawyer who acts as the chairman; Marion Charles, a Newport resident known as "Oatsie," and Harry Demopoulos, Ms. Duke's former doctor -- were counting on Ms. Spero's broad experience to help her sort everything out. Before taking the $400,000-a-year job, she was Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs. Before that, Ms. Spero held posts at American Express Company, where she rose to executive vice president, and was an assistant professor at Columbia University.
The trustees cared little that she had no experience in the nonprofit world, though that prolonged her learning curve. For months, she was the foundation's only professional employee; she said she felt she could not hire staff until she had a strategy.
She began meeting with the foundation's trustees individually to solicit their ideas. She hired a management consultant, Brian Knapp, to help her design a structure for the foundation, and she visited other foundation officials, like Susan V. Berresford, president of the Ford Foundation, and William G. Bowen, president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, to pick their brains about the business.
But Ms. Spero also needed to learn about Doris Duke. Besides reading books and newspaper clippings, reviewing decades of her charity records, poring over her personal papers and going through her possessions, Ms. Spero visited Ms. Duke's properties -- Duke Farms in Somerville, N.J.; Rough Point, a mansion in Newport, R.I., that will probably house her decorative-arts collection, and Shangri-La, a Moroccan-style mansion in Honolulu that likely will become an Islamic art center (all of which fall under Ms. Spero's bailiwick).
She interviewed dozens of people who knew Ms. Duke, like Tony Gsell, who manages the gardens at Duke Farms, which Ms. Duke helped design; "Cupie," her Indian housekeeper, and Phil Mello, the manager of Rough Point, with whom Ms. Duke restored furniture. In Hawaii, Ms. Spero even tracked down Johnny Gomez, who, she said, traveled around the world with Ms. Duke in the 30's.
Ms. Spero, not surprisingly, is protective of Ms. Duke and reluctant to say anything that might further her legend as an eccentric. She said she learned about Ms. Duke's idiosyncrasies, but also developed an appreciation for Ms. Duke's serious side.
"She was a hands-on person," Ms. Spero said. "And Oatsie Charles has said that she was a very take-charge person. When she led the restoration of Newport, she purchased the properties herself. These things were rundown, but she had a good eye and knew what had to be done to them."
The point of Ms. Spero's research was to shape Ms. Duke's patchwork of wishes into a few defined program areas. By April 1997, Ms. Spero had settled on the performing arts, the environment and medical research. Lacking experience in these fields, she hired consultants to be temporary program officers. Mary Hays, a former executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, and Susan Bloom, a former cultural-affairs officer at American Express, worked in the arts; Pat Noonan, a former president of the Nature Conservancy, assisted on the environment; Joan Leiman and Richard Sohn of Columbia University Medical School advised her on medicine.
As part of what she called her fast-track plan, Ms. Spero decided that the Duke foundation would make large grants to well-established institutions (which may, in turn, disperse the money to individuals), and that it would initiate its own grants, filling in perceived needs instead of responding to requests.
Many grants have captured Ms. Duke's offbeat nature: $4.9 million to create the Doris Duke Clinical Scientist Award Program to support medical research; $2 million to the National Dance Project of the New England Foundation for the Arts to finance new choreography; $1.5 million to the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis to pay for new dance programming and create a performing arts endowment, and $2 million for the Jazz at Lincoln Center program.
Ms. Spero said that the willingness to take risks on individual artists, as Ms. Duke did, would happen indirectly. "We didn't have the capacity to judge, so we're outsourcing," she explained.
Ms. Spero's tenure has been hailed, especially by recipients of unsolicited Duke grants. Several praised the size of the awards because, as Mr. Lichtenstein said, "that kind of money can really make a difference." At the very least, others, many of whom covet grants, gave her a "so far, so good" grade.
As the foundation doles out its money, Ms. Spero said "a byproduct of what we want to do is to tell the world that Doris Duke was more than a lady who left the money to the butler." In the beginning, $8 million to $10 million will maintain Ms. Duke's three properties and build an archive of her possessions. The other $45 million of the $55 million in annual grants will be split among the arts, environment and medicine for now. "But we're trying to stay flexible," Ms. Spero said.
"We have over $1 billion that we can put to some definition of the public good, and that is awesome," she said. "It is frightening."

HEADLINE: The $20,000 Surprise and Other Foundation Shakers

BYLINE: By ANNE ADAMS LANG; Anne Adams Lang writes about political, social and health issues.

 BODY:
"IT'S become the Wild West," said Virginia Esposito, the president of the National Center for Family Philanthropy in Washington. "The changes are seismic. It's the numbers of people involved, the diversity of interests and opportunity, with new foundations being created every day."
Parvenus, freshly minted millionaires and roll-up-your-sleeves venture capitalists are invading foundation country. The onslaught is turning the staid world of Northeastern patricians and elite professionals into an anarchic laboratory of do-gooders running their own private and family foundations. 
 The numbers are impressive. The ranks of family and private foundations swelled to 54,000 in 1997 from 22,000 in 1980, according to Internal Revenue Service figures. The Foundation Center in New York estimates that the assets of these organizations have sextupled to an astonishing $300 billion from a decade-and-a-half ago.
And they are everywhere. From Indiana, Nebraska and Ohio to Texas, California and Washington State, a new generation of philanthropists is branding the landscape with names as remote as some of the places they serve. Several, like the Packard Foundation, have endowments larger than an island nation's G.N.P. Most flex their social muscles on a great deal less.
"What you've got are large numbers of families and individuals who have never had a legacy of wealth and are just beginning in philanthropy," said Peter Karoff, the president of the Philanthropic Initiative, a Boston consulting firm that advises the wealthy on philanthropic options. "People are starting projects directly out of their life experiences. They are using a whole new language and a whole new approach to giving."
In the last few months, Mr. Karoff said, one man offered to "throw $300 million" at locating the "brilliant black and Hispanic kids who don't know that they are brilliant." Another neophyte suggested that $40 million "felt like the right number" to do "something with accountability in the public schools." Both these programs are being developed.
Mr. Karoff guided another first-timer who "hates organizations and would just as soon drive down a street in Roxbury and throw the money out the window" into creating Boston Neighborhood Fellows.
"This guy finds six unsung heroes each year, calls them up and says, 'You won $20,000,' " Mr. Karoff said. "This year, he's raising it to $25,000."
This infusion of untamed blood into a field seen as the preserve of Rockefellers, Carnegies and Fords is forcing citizens of the foundation universe to examine what they do and how they do it. Old ways are under attack as the arrivistes take a get-in-the-trenches approach.
An emerging force is Paul Brainerd, who founded Social Venture Partners in Seattle. Mr. Brainerd, the software savant behind desktop publishing, sold his company in 1994 and promptly started a family foundation devoted to local environmental issues. But in conversations with suddenly rich high-techies, Mr. Brainerd discovered a passionate desire to give back to the community and a frustrating lack of skills.
In June 1997, he joined with Scott Oki, one of the many Microscoft millionaires, to start Social Venture Partners. By the end of this year, S.V.P. will have 110 partners who have each contributed a minimum of $5,000 into an operating-investment pool that distributed $300,000 to education and child welfare projects in its first year.
"We use the venture capital model as a way to invest in the community," Mr. Brainerd explained. "People give more than money. They give time and expertise. It's more of a partnership with the nonprofits we're going to serve. Like venture capitalists, we're willing to take more risks and eventually hope to have a portfolio of community investments, both high and low risk."
REJECTING the standard practice of sifting through written proposals and responding -- in writing -- months later, Mr. Brainerd said S.V.P. talks directly with grant applicants about their projects, their leadership and their problems. "Many grantees told us this was the first time anyone has done this," he said.
The venture-capital approach focuses on measurable results. Mr. Brainerd acknowledged that in some areas, like education, that is hard to achieve. "But we're not religious about the venture-capital model," he said, adding that S.V.P. partners study where the model breaks down while seeking alternatives.
William O'Neill Jr. came to the foundation-as-investor model after setting up the William J. and Dorothy O'Neill Foundation in Cleveland primarily as an estate-planning vehicle. For the first few years, Mr. O'Neill said, the foundation was passive, limiting its work to check writing.
By 1992, Mr. O'Neill was urging his 60 clan members to select a focus and "become involved with time and whatever talents we could bring to bear." They chose family issues, he said, because "if we could restore families to what they can and should be, we might be able to get at a lot of other problems, like poverty and unwed teen-age parents."
The foundation developed a partnership with the Cleveland Center for Families and Children and created Fathers and Families Together. The program recruits fathers from the distressed Glenville neighborhood to attend classes in education, motivation, self-image and some job skills so that they can reunite with their children and families in a "caring, supporting, respecting way." Mr. O'Neill said 60 fathers graduate annually and have an alumni support group to keep them going.
Like other venture capital philanthropists, Mr. O'Neill conceded: "We're trying to measure things that are sort of intangible. But we figure if it costs $2,000 a year per graduate and even half those graduates permanently reunite with their families and become responsible fathers, the return to society has to be at least $2,000 a year."
Approaches like that of the O'Neill Foundation directly challenge the established order. During the 1960's and 70's, mainline foundations like Ford and Rockefeller operated on the principle that once a problem was identified, they could pour money into a test program and, if it worked, the Federal Government would pick up the financing. But in the 1980's Federal dollars for these initiatives began evaporating.
David Saltzman, the executive director of the Robin Hood Foundation, in New York, said: "There are now as many different operating ideologies as there are foundations. The influx of living donors is a powerful force because they want to control how their money is spent. Most want an accounting of every penny."
That degree of control can backfire, said Susan Berresford, the president of the Ford Foundation. "A venture capital investor is in a very strong position, putting certain people on the board and making decisions based on looking for a return on investment," Ms. Berresford said. "To be a foundation is to make an investment in other people. You have to stay back to a degree so that they can build independence and organizational capacity."
But the venture-capital model has underscored critiques of mainline foundations as far removed from the needs of grant recipients.
"When foundations mature and move away from the donor and the heirs to a self-selecting and self-perpetuating board," said Bruce Sievers, the executive director of the Walter and Elise Haas Fund in San Francisco, "the question is, where are they getting their inspiration and legitimacy for managing this money? They operate in their own little world without much negative feedback."
The criticisms and competition have put mainline foundations on the defensive.
Ms. Berresford countered that Ford wants to insure that "people with fresh ideas know they're welcome here." This means identifying new fields of operation and building alliances with the public and private sectors, and with other foundations and nonprofits.
A recent example: a $50 million grant to the Center for Community Self-Help in North Carolina will guarantee loans that banks make to low-income home buyers so that those loans can be sold to Fannie Mae. Over the five-year course of the grant, Ford expects 35,000 families to become home owners.
So it is that Rockefeller, working in historically high-unemployment neighborhoods in Milwaukee, Indianapolis and Seattle, is negotiating with private businesses to hire community residents. At the same time, it is prodding government agencies to maintain safety-net protections, including food stamps, subsidized housing and training programs.
"That's an unusual approach for foundations like ours," said Denise Grey-Felder, Rockefeller's director of communications. Rockefeller, she said, is even contemplating using the endowment less as a grant and more as an investment, in line with the venture-capital model.
"This is an amazing time of upheaval," said Stacy Palmer, the editor of the Chronicle of Philanthropy. "You've got a lot of people experimenting with all kinds of things. What you're seeing is that people haven't figured out what the solutions are; they don't how to cope with the fact that the ground is shifting."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Paul Brainerd organized Social Venture Partners in Seattle, Susan Berresford has sought new directions as the Ford Foundation's president and William O'Neill Jr. focused his family's Cleveland foundation on family issues. (Photos by Therese Frare for The New York Times; Barney Taxel for The New York Times; Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Giving Is Easy, but Growing Is Hard

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR 

 BODY:
THE idea was too good to pass up: turning pennies salvaged from sidewalks and purse bottoms into thousands of dollars for charities. But from the start, Theodore F. Gross was ambivalent about pursuing the idea himself. He was a playwright, not a neighborhood do-gooder.
Still, using pennies to promote community service -- an idea born after his daughter, Nora, who was 4, asked how they could help a homeless man -- struck Mr. Gross as powerful. So, in late 1989, half hiding behind his child, Mr. Gross went door-to-door asking his Manhattan neighbors for pennies. Their bounty that year: $1,879. 
 Since then, the Grosses' penny-collecting campaign has grown into a citywide civic program in which students collect pennies, then form "round tables" to decide where to donate their money. Last year, about 470 public and private schools in New York collected and gave away close to $300,000.
But as the program has matured, so have the organization and its founder, experiencing growing pains along the way.
Common Cents, the nonprofit group, has evolved in only eight years from a daughter-and-pop enterprise operated in Mr. Gross's apartment with a staff of two (Mr. Gross and Nora), a pocket-change budget and friends volunteering, into something that looks suspiciously like a traditional grant-making foundation. It has a professional staff of three plus six full-time Americorps-Vista volunteers; a proposed million-dollar budget; a $10,000 endowment; a roster of organizations courted for contributions and a board of trustees with their eye on raising money.
Like many nonprofit agencies, it has also struggled with finances. "As adolescence goes, it's been pretty smooth," said Ted Greenwood, an executive at the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and the president of the Common Cents board. "But growth is hard. We've had moments of financial crisis. It's not a good thing not to know how to meet next month's payroll."
While Common Cents has transformed itself, so has Mr. Gross -- from a creative guy with a good idea to a social entrepreneur learning to make hard decisions. His admirers are many; his critics, generally gentle in their rebukes. Both say it is an odd mix of passion and reluctance -- Mr. Gross's passion for his idea and reluctance to be its sole champion -- that has moved Common Cents from baby to teen-ager with its mission clear and virtue intact.
It hasn't been easy for him.
"Teddy is engaging, tenacious and determined, and these are good qualities," said Hildy J. Simmons, a managing director in charge of community relations and philanthropic services at J. P. Morgan. "But there is never enough money for everything, and decisions are always difficult, especially with these small organizations. It's been very hard to manage all the complicated pieces and keep the core of engagement and excitement."
Mr. Gross described his work as a "journey" and a "transformational experience." When he began to expand the organization, he looked for someone else to lead the charge. "We needed someone who understood the nuts and bolts of a nonprofit," he said. "I didn't have nearly the confidence in myself that I felt we needed."
About the same time, the Robin Hood Foundation approached him with an offer to run the program. But according to Mr. Gross, when the foundation insisted that its board members decide how the pennies were donated, he balked. David Saltzman, the executive director of Robin Hood, said that discussions with Mr. Gross about taking over the penny harvesting had ended because of "insurmountable differences in opinion about how the program should be run, where the money should go and how much the program should cost."
Mr. Gross decided that diversifying -- starting penny harvests in other communities besides New York -- would help to secure the program's future. He wrote a handbook and sent hundreds of copies nationwide to respond to queries. He even appeared on "The Oprah Winfrey Show." Still, there was not much follow-through.
Meanwhile, in New York, the program was taking off and needed Mr. Gross's full attention. He began establishing a focus -- children -- with schools as his vehicle. And on July 1, 1995, he became the full-time director of Common Cents, earning $40,000 a year. Six months later, he set up an office on West 88th Street in Manhattan.
"That was a moment of truth," Mr. Gross said, "when I decided this was going to be my occupation."
Since then, Mr. Gross has undergone a crash course in nonprofit administration. He called on the organizational skills he developed as a playwright and as a former editor of The Boston Phoenix weekly newspaper. He even dredged up lessons he learned as a boy while proofreading his father's books on management. His father, Bertram M. Gross, a public-policy specialist, author and academician, helped devise policies that were cornerstones of the New Deal.
So, despite his own iconoclastic tendencies, Mr. Gross said, he has "come to respect some traditional approaches."
Until recently, for example, securing grant money has been something of an afterthought. "We are running on fumes," Mr. Gross said. Financial statements bear that out. Between 1991 and 1997, the total amount of money supplied by support grants -- the main source of income other than penny-harvest money -- went from from $77,194 to $135,371. Thousands of dollars in equipment and services were donated, too. But during the same period, as salaries and the staff size increased, operating expenses rose almost fourfold, jumping to $186,420 from $45,450, creating a budget gap.
Mr. Gross has responded by establishing an endowment and trying to build long-standing foundation support. His trustees is also changing. "We were like his band of merry men" -- mostly old friends and devoted supporters, said Michael Miller, an editor at The Wall Street Journal and a former trustee. Now, the group includes some people with previous corporate-board experience or with ties to the city's public schools.
Perhaps the two most critical decisions in Mr. Gross's brief administrative life have involved resisting temptation: first, the allure of commercial interests willing to finance the organization's operations -- at a price; then, the enticements of power and a national stage.
Coin-sorting companies have suggested becoming Common Cents's partner by handling the coin bagging chores, which would allow them to put their sorting machines in schools. Mr. Gross refused. "They were just trying to make a buck, and we are trying to give children a way to feel that they count," he explained.
Controlling growth has been tougher and costlier. Early on, a trustee quit when Mr. Gross and his supporters decided to place penny harvesting in the hands of schoolchildren, not adults. More recently, Mr. Gross recommended that Common Cents set aside plans to go national until it stabilized the New York operation. The board agreed. "There are so many pressures on nonprofits," said Raymond D. Horton, the director of the public and nonprofit management program at Columbia University's business school. "The ability to stop and sit back and review is a big-time skill and smart management."
Mr. Gross said his learning curve is still uphill. Although he hired an executive director fairly quickly, it took him awhile to see the need for an office manager. He was also slow to grasp the importance of making his own salary -- now $80,000 -- more competitive.
"People often ask how we are doing this, and the fact of the matter is, we're still trying to figure out program designs that have wheels," he said.
 
Where Some Children Put Their Pennies
THOUGH there are general rules about who gets the money harvested by Common Cents participants (people, not animals, for one), students are urged to research and pick causes that interest them.
"Philanthropy is not what we are really teaching," said Theodore F. Gross, the director of Common Cents, which is in New York. "It's just a tool in our case, a tool for an education in democracy and moral civic skills and cooperative learning."
A few schools have dropped the program, citing scheduling problems. And others said they could have used more administrative support from Common Cents -- help finding telephone numbers for charities, for example. There is no formal method to make sure the money is being used as intended. Still, Rudy Crew, the New York City schools chancellor, describes the Common Cents programs as "a golden opportunity." New schools continue to join the program, and interviews with more than 50 students, teachers and administrators underscored participants' delight.
On a warm day last spring at Public School 98, in Douglaston, Queens, seven fourth graders gathered in the guidance counselor's office to determine who gets the grants.
Initially, the students did not understand the concept of giving money away, the counselor, Veronica Matuk, said. But after figuring out what charities were, they made suggestions, looked up telephone numbers, wrote a script for the cold calls and took to the phones. In some cases, the students said, they were dismissed by the charities as pranksters. A few respondents even hung up.
"They didn't believe we were a real organization," said Sean Ford, a fifth grader last spring.
Only three charities responded by filling out a form. The students chose, among others, a senior citizens' center nearby.
When they visited the site, the youngsters talked with the residents and created artwork together -- the sort of intergenerational activity their grant would support. "It felt great to be helping them," said Delilah Hutson-Ellenberg, one of the children.
Sheila Huggins, the school's principal, said that for students, "it's another way to relate to each other, and they've learned things they didn't even know they didn't know." MARY B. W. TABOR

HEADLINE: Growing Gap Is Found in College Affordability and Grants to Needy Students

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
As college costs have risen and Federal grants to needy students have declined over the last two decades, higher education has become significantly less affordable for students from poor families, a new national survey shows.
Some academicians who took part in the survey blamed the higher-education lobby in Washington for the predicament, maintaining that the lobbyists exercised political triage by throwing most of their weight behind winning a lower interest rate on federally backed college loans rather than more money for Federal Pell grants. Loans serve primarily the middle class, while Pell grants help low-income families. 
 In 1976 and 1977, the average Pell grant covered 19 percent of the annual price of a private four-year institution and 39 percent of a public four-year institution. But in 1996 and 1997, it covered only 9 percent of a private college and 22 percent of a public college, the survey found.
Similarly, over the same period, the maximum Pell grant declined to 13 percent of the price of a private college, from 35 percent, and to 34 percent of the price of a public institution, from 72 percent.
The last Congress raised maximum Pell grants to $3,125, from $3,000, and reduced the interest rate on college loans to 7.46 percent, from 8.25 percent.
The continuing erosion of Pell grants is partly a result of the priorities of the higher-education lobby facing the realities of Congress, said Thomas D. Parker, a senior vice president of the Educational Resources Institute. The institute, based in Boston, is a nonprofit educational research organization that cosponsored the survey, with the Institute for Higher Education Policy, whose headquarters are in Washington.
"We did get a small expansion of the Pell grants last year," Mr. Parker said, "but the higher-education lobbyists in Washington decided that it's better to accept the fact that it won't be possible to get much of an increase in Pell grants than to make a stink about it. They decided to put most of their effort behind Federal college loans, which have a much bigger constituency: the middle class. The result is that many low-income people can't even begin to think about going to a four-year college."
Terry Hartle, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, an organization based in Washington that represents 1,600 colleges and universities, called Mr. Parker "woefully misinformed" and said the Pell grant program had been "the most important Federal policy objective of colleges and universities for the past 25 years."
"Over the last two years, the value of the maximum Pell grant has increased by $425, or 14 percent," Mr. Hartle said. "Increasing the Pell grant by $100 costs $350 million, which is a lot even by Washington standards, especially when it competes directly with Head Start, biomedical research and job training."
The survey, entitled "Do Grants Matter? Student Grant Aid and College Affordability," found that in the six years that ended in the 1995-96 academic year, the average net cost of a public four-year institution rose 28 percent, to $7,829 from $6,140, for undergraduates whose annual family incomes were $20,000 to $39,999.
The researchers also found an overall disparity between the college enrollment of low-income and high-income students.
"Overall enrollments are up and Federal funding has modestly increased," said Jamie P. Merisotis, president of the Institute for Higher Education Policy, the cosponsor of the survey, "but these trends mask the fact that there is a gap of almost 30 percentage points in enrollment between low-income and high-income students."
Mr. Merisotis said colleges deserved credit for having invested heavily in financial aid based on need, but added, "The fact remains that the prices are still increasing, and the lower-income students and parents bear the brunt of that."
Asked about a possible solution, Mr. Merisotis replied, "It's not just more Federal money that's needed, but a different political attitude about how and why we should be investing in student aid."
"In addition, the schools must keep prices down by improved cost-management strategies," he said. "For example, some colleges might consider eliminating a program in electrical engineering that is high-cost and has very few graduates."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
SharesRally, Then Sputter, After the Fed Trims Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Widely anticipated cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board did not invigorate the stock market yesterday. Prices, which have rallied sharply the last six weeks, closed mixed in moderate trading.
Stocks moved lower early in the session, then jumped abruptly in midafternoon after the Fed announced its third cut in the overnight Federal funds rate and second reduction in its discount rate in the last seven weeks. But sellers emerged in the last hour of trading, particularly in big, blue-chip issues. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell as much as 82 points in the morning and was up as much as 91 after the Fed's announcement, closed down 24.97, or nearly three-tenths of 1 percent, at 8,986.28. Nearly all the average's decline resulted from a sharp slide in Hewlett-Packard, which closed at 60 1/16, down 6 1/16. Hewlett-Packard warned that first-quarter earnings might fall and that sales in its 1999 fiscal year were not likely to meet forecasts because of increased competition and weakness in Asia and Latin America.
Most broader market indexes did better than the Dow. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.45, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,139.32. And the Nasdaq composite index gained 16.84, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,878.52. But the Russell 2000 index of mostly small-capitalization stocks dipped 0.99 point, or a quarter of 1 percent, closing at 389.43.
"We have come a very long way in a very short time," said Al Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards, noting that since Oct. 8 the Dow rose 21 percent; the S.& P. 500, 24 percent, and the Nasdaq composite, 39 percent.
"The market was doing some consolidating last week and is likely to be doing some more of that," he said. "But I don't see a lot of downside risk below 8,600 on the Dow. If there had been a 1-in-3 risk of a recession next year before the Fed started to cut rates, it has been reduced to a risk of 1 in 10."
The cuts in the Federal funds rate and the discount rate pushed those two rates to their lowest levels in four years and helped lift prices of financial service and bank stocks, which have been on the rise since the Fed began to cut rates in late September.
J. P. Morgan and American Express, two Dow stocks, rose for the second consecutive day. Morgan gained 3 3/8, to 106 7/8. American Express rose 2 7/16, to 99 3/8. BankAmerica rose 1, to 60 3/4, and Chase Manhattan climbed 3 3/8, to 61 1/4.
Brokerage stocks also gained. Merrill Lynch rose 2 13/16, to 66 5/16, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter closed at 66 5/8, up 2 9/16.
But not everyone was sanguine. Richard Bernstein, chief quantitative strategist at Merrill Lynch, said Hewlett-Packard was not likely to be the last company to issue a somber message on earnings for the coming year.
"Most people think that if you get Fed easing, you will get earnings growth," he said. "But we are in a period where earnings growth is negative. That is something people have pretty much ignored over the last six to seven weeks."
With interest rates at current levels, Mr. Bernstein said stocks were between 10 and 20 percent above what he considered fair valuation.
Slumping crude oil prices, which fell to a 10-year low in London and a 4-year low in New York, pushed down oil stocks.
Chevron fell 2 1/2, to 80 3/4. Exxon dropped 7/8, to 70 9/16. And Mobil lost 11/16, to 71 15/16.
With much fanfare, DaimlerChrysler, formed by the merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler, introduced its shares on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But the stock ended lower, closing at 83 7/8, down 7/16.
The stars of Nasdaq included Amazon.com. Shares in the on-line bookseller soared 22 1/4, to 148 1/2, after it said it had opened an on-line video store to compete with Hollywood Entertainment's Reel.com Web site.
Bigger high-technology companies that trade on the Nasdaq system also moved higher. Microsoft gained 3 1/16, to 111 7/8. Cisco Systems rose 1 13/16, to 68 3/4. And Intel closed at 108 1/2, up 1 5/8.
K-Tel International was one of the session's biggest losers. The seller of music, videos and other entertainment was notified by Nasdaq that it had failed to meet the minimum tangible net asset requirement for trading, and faced delisting. The stock tumbled 5 5/8, to 12.

Treasuries Are Mixed
By Reuters
 Treasury bond prices ended mixed yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates as investors booked profits on the view the Fed would keep rates steady for the near future.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 99 10/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.30 percent, from 5.29 percent on Monday.
"It was buy the rumor, sell the fact," said Charles Parkhurst, the head bond trader at Salomon Smith Barney.
Treasuries rose early in the session and held those gains until the Fed announced late in the session that it had lowered its Federal funds rate by a quarter of a point, to 4.75 percent, and cut the discount rate also by a quarter of a point, to 4.5 percent.
The early gains were extended after the Fed's announcement, but the rally quickly faded as a wave of retail selling emerged.
"People were ready to sell when the market went up," said John Spinello, fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch.

HEADLINE: Gore Scolded In Malaysia For Defense Of Dissenters

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Declaring that it would hold the United States responsible for outbreaks of "lawlessness," Malaysia denounced Vice President Al Gore today for a speech here in which he praised simmering protests against Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.
In a statement, Malaysia's Foreign Minister said that Mr. Gore's remarks on Monday were a "gross interference in the internal affairs of the country and a brazen violation of the basic tenets of relations between sovereign states." 
 "Malaysians hold dearly the harmony and stability which they have painstakingly built up through the years," said the Foreign Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. "Malaysians would hold the United States accountable for any rupture of harmony arising from this irresponsible incitement."
In his speech at a regional summit meeting of Pacific Rim countries, Mr. Gore accused Malaysia of suppressing freedom.
As Dr. Mahathir and other Malaysian officials seethed in the audience, Mr. Gore saluted anti-Government protesters as brave people. He even invoked the rallying cry "reformasi," which was coined during Indonesia's student movement and is now chanted here to protest the jailing of Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim.
Mr. Gore's blunt words, and Malaysia's enraged reaction, have left this meeting of Pacific Rim nations in a shambles. At the gathering, called the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, discussions of how to lower trade barriers or rein in global capital flows were scarcely heard today.
Instead, there were sharp divisions over whether the Vice President had taken a principled stand in defense of human rights or hijacked a meeting intended to be devoted to the Asian financial crisis.
New Zealand's Prime Minister, Jenny Shipley, accused Mr. Gore of practicing "megaphone diplomacy," while officials from Singapore and China offered more subtle criticism of the speech -- reaffirming that they would stick to economic matters and not wade into the affairs of other countries.
However, the President of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, said in an interview, "I feel the same way as the Vice President."
"I don't interfere in Malaysia's domestic problems, but I've said human rights and due process of law transcend all boundaries," said Mr. Estrada, who earlier threatened to boycott the meeting to protest Mr. Anwar's treatment.
Early this morning, Mr. Estrada met with Mr. Anwar's wife, Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, defying a stern warning by Dr. Mahathir that visiting dignitaries should not use the summit meeting to get involved in the Anwar dispute.
"I told her that it was a great sacrifice on the part of Anwar for the future of freedom," Mr. Estrada said of the meeting.
"I really can't tell you if he will receive a fair trial. Hopefully because of the media, it will help."
If Mr. Gore's speech was meant to be a call to arms, however, it had a muffled echo on the streets of Kuala Lumpur. About 500 people gathered in a neighborhood near Mr. Gore's hotel this evening to chant and wave placards calling for Dr. Mahathir to step down. But they did not carry through on a threat to march to the luxury hotel where the Vice President was staying.
Protesters have assembled in front of a mosque here nearly every weekend since Mr. Anwar was arrested. And while this was the first rally held during the week, it lacked the size or intensity of previous protests.
People here said the demonstrators may have been discouraged by a phalanx of riot policemen who stood three deep across the road, wielding bamboo sticks and glaring from behind plastic shields.
Some political analysts who support Mr. Anwar said they were troubled by the stridency of the speech. They said Mr. Gore might have played into the hands of Dr. Mahathir.
"This speech may have given ammunition to Dr. Mahathir to discredit the reform movement, in the sense that he can now say it is sponsored by the U.S.," said Chandra Muzaffar, a professor of political science at the University of Malaya.
Advisers to Mr. Gore contended that the Vice President's speech was no different from President Clinton's performance in Beijing last July, when he pointedly challenged the Chinese Government's human rights record in a televised news conference with President Jiang Zemin.
And despite the furor over his words, Mr. Gore did not retreat today. "My point is very simple," he said. "These economies have some very difficult choices to make. Democracy and freedom are essential prerequisites for making those choices."
