HEADLINE: A Fight to Preserve Abandoned Asylums;
Sales Seen as Threat to Landmarks Of Architecture and Idealism

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

DATELINE: UTICA, N.Y.

 BODY:
More than a century ago, aproned nurses in starched white caps bustled along highly polished corridors in this city's elegant insane asylum, a limestone monument to the prevailing Victorian belief that mental illness could be improved with air, light -- and imposing architecture.
Now, after 20 years of neglect, the corridors are unheated ruins; their cornflower-blue walls are shedding saucer-sized flakes of paint. Trefoil-embossed stair treads are brushed with rust. Graffiti and smashed windows deface the summer porch, and the glass blocks imbedded in the dusty floors, once a revolutionary means of seducing light, have become a possible death trap. 
 The Empire State Development Corporation, acting on Gov. George E. Pataki's platform of privatization, is beginning to decide which developers will buy this and 11 other obsolete mental hospitals scattered throughout the state, from the South Shore of Long Island to the St. Lawrence River. In most cases, the developers do not want the antique asylums, some of which have been elevated to national landmark status. Instead, they covet the hundreds of acres surrounding them, the potentially lucrative open land fronting rivers and highways.
So preservationists, many of whom have been working to protect the buildings since some closed decades ago, fear that the asylums will be demolished or left to deteriorate further. And they worry there is little they can do to save them.
"There's not much else we can do," said William C. Bolger, who runs the National Historic Landmark program for the National Park Service in the Northeast, and who labeled New York's historic asylums among the country's most endangered landmarks in his last report. "The state owns them and they have the right to sell them."
What is at stake, though, is a big chunk of the state's architectural legacy. While there are 19th century asylums scattered throughout the country, New York State is known among preservation historians for its wealth of them. Of only 10 mental hospitals designated as national landmarks throughout the nation, four are in New York.
Of the four, three are being sold by the state: a turreted castle fit for King Arthur in Binghamton, an elaborate Venetian fantasy of bluestone, limestone and brick in Poughkeepsie, and the austere columned limestone palace here, with its eight-foot-wide, 48-foot-tall Doric columns.
In the report nominating the Utica State Hospital, now called the Mohawk Valley Psychiatric Center, state preservation historians wrote that the Main Building was "one of the most powerful architectural statements in the Greek Revival style built during America's 19th century years." Equally glowing descriptions accompany the other landmarks singled out for recognition.
Although the three asylums have been deemed National Historic Landmarks, the designation has little legal force, especially if the properties are sold to private interests. And in their pursuit to save the buildings, the preservationists have struggled to solve a thorny problem: what to do with the abandoned asylums.
Unlike other conversions, like turning a warehouse or school into loft apartments, finding new uses for a mental hospital can be sticky. Mr. Bolger admits that transforming an asylum into, say, garden condominiums might be tough. Would anybody want to live in condominiums in the brick shell of the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane?
When the imposing structures opened their grand carved doors in the mid-to-late 19th century, they stood at the forefront of psychiatric care. But as the 20th century wore on, the state started cutting their budgets, and jamming more and more patients into them.
"The Victorians started off with a wonderful reformist idea," said Dr. Roger Christenfeld, the research director at the Hudson River Psychiatric Center, the latest name for the Poughkeepsie asylum. "They were tremendously idealistic and their ideas were indeed therapeutic. But over the next decades, the funds dwindled, while there seemed to be an ever-increasing number of people in need."
In the past, preservation groups tried to recycle the buildings with new uses. In Binghamton, one group thought they had the solution in 1997: a state senator said there was money to fix up the building if tenants were found. But by the time a group of nonprofit agencies signed letters of intent, the building was on a list to be offered to developers.
There was, however, one last-minute reprieve. In Buffalo, where a brooding assemblage of stone towers by H.H. Richardson was slated for the bidding block, Mayor Anthony Masiello asked to withdraw the 1880 building from the sale. Mr. Masiello said he wanted the city to control what happens to the land and is considering a new magnet school and housing for the 87-acre site.
Peter Brink, a vice president at the private National Trust for Historic Preservation, said that within the next month -- preferably before the properties are actually transferred to developers -- he hoped to help sponsor a one-day workshop to draft reuse goals for another asylum, the one in Poughkeepsie, with conclusions that might apply to all the threatened asylums.
And Bernadette Castro, New York's Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, said she would contiue to try to secure covenants from Charles A. Gargano, Empire State's chairman, to protect the historic buildings. But she conceded, "If it's a choice of not developing the property at all, well, we know we've got to be flexible."
Altogether, there are 20 mental institutions -- a dozen in this first phase -- that will be sold off by Empire State Development. Combined, they cost the state $40 million a year in property maintenance and debt service, said Patrick Panero, the Empire State official who is running the sales. The transfers to developers will bring untold millions in sale prices and increased taxes, and generate jobs.
The developers will bid money only -- there is no place on the form to explain what they want to do with the land and buildings. Nevertheless, Mr. Panero speculated that on Long Island, where four of the properties will be sold, the buildings, less significant architecturally and historically, may be razed for offices and new housing for senior citizens.
Preservation advocates complain that in some press releases announcing the sale, Empire State does not even mention the buildings. For example, the description of the hospital in Poughkeepsie -- with its High Victorian Italianate building and wings by the noted church architect Frederick Clarke Withers, and a landscape by Frederick Law Olmsted (who was a co-designer of Central Park) -- appears this way in a news release:
"A 387-acre property east of Route 9 with a nine-hole golf course in Poughkeepsie, Dutchess County, in the desirable Hudson Valley; the site is accessible to major highways and is minutes from the Poughkeepsie train station served by Amtrak and Metro North."
Yet Mr. Panero said it was doubtful that developers would tear down all of the Poughkeepsie complex. If a developer offered to reuse a historic structure, he explained, the project might be eligible for a 20 percent tax credit. "With properties like Hudson River," he said, referring to the Poughkeepsie center, "the Federal tax credits are the thing that makes it feasible."
One developer, who is bidding on the Poughkeepsie property and who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he hoped to preserve much of the main building, although he would gut the inside to introduce modern amenities like air-conditioning.
The developer envisions a multitude of uses, including hotel rooms to serve neighboring colleges including Vassar and Marist, along with some faculty housing. In the small antique brick buildings that once housed the asylum laundry and butcher shop, he sees one or more restaurants.
A more modern concrete building on the site, the Chaney Memorial Building, still houses 270 patients who, after the sale, will move to another building higher on the hill that is not included in the offering. The 1950's building, with vaguely Art Deco touches like bow-fronted windows, has Hudson River views, and other developers have said they would immediately turn it into apartments.
In Binghamton, the psychiatric center sits vacant on a hill. The building closed its five-inch-thick mahoghany doors in 1993, after having been used as offices for administrators who supervise the patients in the much newer Garvin Center below it.
Inside, the 1858 building is in the best shape of the three structures: the heat has been kept on. There is a surprisingly intact oak-paneled room with an elaborate carved mantle, tiny brown brick-shaped tiles and a surfeit of drawers; one contains dozens of empty glass cigar tubes.
In 1993, when the roof of the turreted asylum sprang a leak, state workers decided to hack off the stone crenellations at the top of the eight turrets. It wasn't easy. It also wasn't the source of the leak.
Preservationists, who have worried about the fate of the castlelike hospital for years, use the example of the battlements to argue against demolition. "It won't be easy to knock it down," said Ruth S. Levy, past president of the Preservation Association of the Southern Tier.
And it won't be cheap. In many cases, that is what keeps the buildings standing: their old-fashioned, overbuilt construction, usually of stone or brick.
But in Travers City, Mich., the site of another behemoth landmark, the Northern Michigan Asylum, the state's economic development corporation has approved a private development plan to demolish the 1885 hospital to build housing for elderly people.
That plan has been delayed -- after preservationists protested -- pending a survey on how much it would cost to stabilize the structure.
But the preservationists know that just stabilizing the building won't save it. "Mental hospitals across the country are on such a grand scale, we know that only large multipurpose solutions will work: complexes with studio apartments and artists' studios and restaurants and museums," said Janese Horton, who is the chairwoman of a committee to save the building. The group is desperately trying to find a developer who doesn't want to tear it down.
"We just need a little more time to get it together," she said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CERIDIAN TO BUY LIFEWORKS, A RIVAL IN EMPLOYEE SERVICES

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Ceridian Corporation, a major provider of employee counseling and information services to companies in the United States, is buying Lifeworks, a Boston-based business that was a pioneer in the field. Ceridian's purchase of Lifeworks from Work/Family Directions Inc., also based in Boston, makes it the largest player in the work-family services field. The combined businesses will have $100 million in annual revenues and employ 800 people. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Shares in Ceridian, which is based in Minneapolis, rose $3.50, to $58.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Work/Family Directions, which is privately held, will shrink after the sale from employing nearly 450 to employing 90 and will narrow its focus to helping companies increase employee commitment and invest in communities.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New Jersey Shows Strong Employment

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate last month was 4.5 percent, the State Labor Department reported yesterday, falling below the national average.
The national rate for October was 4.6 percent, unchanged from September, while the state rate fell from a revised 4.7 percent rate in September. 
 The state's Labor Commissioner, Mel Gelade, said the economy was bolstered by more jobs in the service and retail sectors.
"The fact that we're in the same ball park as the national economy is an achievement," Mr. Gelade said. "We seem to be at full employment."
He said the last time New Jersey's rate was below the national average was December 1991. But both the state and the nation were in the grips of a recession then: the New Jersey rate was 7.2 percent, and the national rate was 7.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Days and Nights in Kosovo: Relief Worker's Diary

BYLINE: By Robert Turner

 BODY:
SINCE September, Robert Turner has been coordinating the International Rescue Committee's emergency program to provide assistance to some of the 200,000 to 300,000 ethnic Albanians left homeless in the fighting that has gripped the Kosovo province of Serbia. The International Rescue Committee has been operating there since February 1997 through a community building program financed by the Swiss Government and two Swiss religious donor groups. From the city of Pristina, where he is based, Mr. Turner has been meeting with representatives of the United Nations and other relief agencies, preparing grant proposals and overseeing security for the International Rescue Committee team. He has also waited -- first for grant money that would allow his planning to become reality, then for a resolution of the standoff between the international community and President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, which could have led to bombing and curtailment of relief efforts in the area.
Editors at The Times asked Mr. Turner, a 34-year-old Canadian from Salmon Arm, British Columbia, who has also worked on relief efforts in Burundi, Rwanda and Sierra Leone (and been a forest firefighter in British Columbia), to record his experiences, and feelings, in Kosovo. What follows is the diary he filed. 
 Thursday, Sept. 24, Pristina -- Dad's 57th birthday. I sent an E-mail because, given his work schedule, time zones don't work for a call to British Columbia. Financial and logistics systems here are being beefed up in preparation for the new grants, which we hope will come soon from the United States Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. We had a shelter coordination meeting today with people from Swiss Disaster Relief, International Management Group, Oxfam, World Vision and Norwegian Church Aid, and started working out a format that all agencies can use to assess damage to houses in a village. Will meet again tomorrow. Lots of military overflights today. Kosovo was the subject of "CNN Insight." There wasn't any.
Friday, Sept. 25, Pristina -- The Serb reaction to NATO's posturing? The largest offensive in months. They returned to shelled villages and torched them. The shelter meeting went well; we came up with standards and will field-test them together next week -- if we're still here. Drew Gilmour, Roy Brennen and I reviewed our security plan and I decided to raise the security level. Roy has been here for seven months working on the community building project. Drew is the other half of the emergency team. Both have a lot of experience. Our new rule is that no one is to travel outside Pristina until further notice. With no real life-saving operation in place, and no radio communication (the Government won't grant us licenses), we can't risk it.
Saturday, Sept. 26, Pristina -- Went to the market to get some things for the house and warmer clothes. I had made the assumption that 42 degrees latitude in September would be warm. It isn't. I haven't done a full winter in Canada in four years, and my blood has gotten pretty thin.
Sunday, Sept. 27, Pristina -- Had a security meeting with other NGO's nongovernmental organizations and the humanitarian liaison of the Kosovo Diplomatic Observer Mission, a group of diplomats that monitors events in Kosovo. There are reports of Albanian medical staff being targeted by police. Beautiful day, so I took a walk. Pristina is a fairly pretty city of about 300,000, the administrative center of Kosovo. It has a university and dozens of cafes catering to their own crowd -- students or workers, Albanians or Serbs. They don't mix much now. Sat in a park at the top of a hill. Very peaceful, except for shelling to the southwest.
Monday, Sept. 28, Pristina -- I'm looking for warehouse space. Would like 600 to 1,200 square feet for storage and to house our logistics operation, but we can't sign a lease until the grants are signed, and who knows when that will be? Julia Taft, from the United States Bureau for Population, Refugees and Migration, said we had a six-week window to get assistance to the displaced. That was five weeks ago. Have an idea for setting up emergency schools in areas where schools have been destroyed or where displaced populations have moved and overwhelmed local capacity. I am trying to get someone to donate tents and then will find money for stoves, school supplies, benches, etc. More reports of targeting medical staff members, torture and execution. Mark McGwire hit his 69th and 70th yesterday. Amazing. Haven't been sleeping well.
Tuesday, Sept. 29, Pristina -- Had a visit from a representative of the European Community Humanitarian Office, the main European relief donor. We have to prepare a shelter proposal for them. There was a large military convoy returning to Pristina, which made the Serb population rambunctious. A delegation of International Rescue Committee board members arrived from New York so I had to show them around.
The torture and mutilation of civilians and medical staff members have been confirmed. Numbers unknown. We (and everyone else) have been operating under the assumption that the military campaign would stop in the next few weeks, and that over the winter we would be dealing with a stable population of displaced people. That seems less certain now. More fighting will make things more difficult as the refugees continue their pattern of changing locations quickly when fighting erupts.
Wednesday, Sept. 30, Sedlare Valley -- Went to Sedlare village and the valley above Kisna Reka with the International Rescue Committee delegation. There are 2,000 to 3,000 people from Kisna Reka living under plastic sheeting stretched over tree branches. The sanitation is abysmal, with open defecation and latrines that run directly into living space and the water supply. Most children are without proper footwear. Nighttime temperatures are near freezing and snow is expected soon. These people want to return to their villages, but they keep getting shot at when they go back.
A Red Cross vehicle hit a mine; one person was killed and three injured. Some of our local staff members knew the victim, so the mood was pretty low this afternoon.
I'm amazed by the cohesion and solidarity of the Albanian population. They make a real effort to help one another. We have three proposals out for shelter, water andsanitation and for mobile medical clinics; altogether they are worth about $2.8 million. The shelter and water-sanitation proposals are to assist 10,000 displaced families, about 80,000 people. Large families are common among the rural population of Kosovo. The mobile clinics are to be operated by the Children's Advocacy International, a British NGO under our umbrella.
Roy Brennen and the other expatriate in the community building project, Carey McIntosh, saw a big convoy of police leaving Pristina. Are the Serbs really downsizing, or just rotating?
Thursday, Oct. 1, Pristina -- There was a funeral today for the Red Cross staff member who was killed. Thousands of people came. Two more NGO's showed up, looking to help provide shelter. Every emergency sees an influx of organizations. In Rwanda, there were more than 200 NGO's; Kosovo has gone from about 10 to more than 30 in the last few months.
Friday, Oct. 2, Pristina -- The United States issued a travel warning for Kosovo, which has created some panic, mostly because people have misinterpreted it as an evacuation order. Last weekend, I overreacted by giving too much credence to media reports and raising the security level. Now I'm worried about being too complacent. There has been a tremendous amount of press coverage of the discovery of a massacre of about 35 Albanians in the Drenica Valley. Not to minimize the barbarity of this act, nor the importance of drawing attention to it, but I can't help thinking that there is a lot more coverage if white people are getting killed. This would just be a normal week in Burundi or a dozen other places.
Saturday, Oct. 3, Pristina -- Checked the Web to find out what NATO and the U.N. are doing. It appears that the Russians are not going to allow any kind of U.N.-sanctioned NATO military action against Serbia, and I can't see the United States and Britain acting on their own. There is fighting, but I think the Serbs are making attempts to adhere to the Security Council resolution calling for cutbacks of police and soldiers in Kosovo.
I've been looking through resumes for staff members, just in case some money arrives. The Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance doesn't have any financing, but the Bureau for Population, Refugees and Migration does, so they are supposed to be picking up our proposals. They said they will call on Monday with good news.
Sunday, Oct. 4, Pristina -- Spoke with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees security officer today to let him know our evacuation plans. We will wait for the U.N. Secretary General's report to the Security Council and then decide if we need to leave for Skopje. I don't see what positive purpose air strikes alone will serve. The Serbs' integrated air-defense system will probably be destroyed in the first wave, after which the military and police can run amok while the bombs fly. Without an Allied ground force to insure their compliance, the Serbs will be even more recalcitrant, making access for us more difficult. And the Albanian people will be angry at us for abandoning them, which we will have to do when and if the bombing begins. Went home and packed in case we must leave quickly.
Monday, Oct. 5, Pristina -- Two NGO's left today. We will evacuate two of four expats tomorrow. Most field visits have been canceled by all organizations.
Met with all 17 local staff members again to let them know what we are doing. Most of them work on the community building project. The concern is less about air strikes, which we don't think can happen in fewer than three days, than about the deterioration of security for expats. The radical Serb media are trying to paint the humanitarian community as responsible for the current crisis. Most expats live on one hill in Pristina, and it would be very easy to target them. The military base is only about a thousand yards away, and now it's packed with armored equipment. I'm getting a cold.
Tuesday, Oct. 6, Pristina -- A mixed day. The good news was from the United States Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration -- about $2.8 million in grant money has come through. Now it should pick up: procurement, recruitment, systems, new offices and actual operations; in other words, assisting people, the reason we're here. On the bad side, Roy and Carey were evacuated today to reduce our exposure here. Have changed houses to be closer to others and will be restricting movements even within Pristina. Am very concerned about our local staff members. Given the attitude of the Serb officials toward humanitarian agencies, it is entirely possible that they will be targeted, and taking them with us is not an option if we have to leave.
Wednesday, Oct. 7, Pristina -- My cold is worse and there was shooting behind the house, so I didn't get much sleep. It appears that Milosevic has told U.S. American negotiator Richard C. Holbrooke are at odds, so we'll probably be in Skopje by the weekend. If there are air strikes, I don't expect we will return for a few weeks, if ever.
The decision has been made to leave tomorrow. Our staff members will be paid and all remaining supplies, plastic sheeting and public health kits loaded on two trucks for tomorrow's convoy. They will go to the Mother Teresa Society in Vucitrn. Better distributed than looted.
Thursday, Oct. 8, Pristina and Skopje -- We got the trucks off with the convoy. Went to the bank to pick up cash to pay our suppliers. Left at 2:15, and had no problems at checkpoints. One Serb official asked if we were leaving Pristina before it goes boom.
Saturday, Oct. 10, Skopje -- Was supposed to go to a meeting today, but couldn't find the place. Even paid a taxi to escort me, but he couldn't find it either. Got a haircut. I think the only English the barber understood was "short." If it is possible, I now look even more like a Serb policeman. Some local staff members already called me Bobovic.
Sunday, Oct. 11, Skopje and Pristina -- Went to Pristina after conferring with U.N. and other relief officials. Got waved through the checkpoint; must be the haircut. Took some of the local staff members to lunch. They were very happy for the visit, even though it was only for a couple of hours. I hope it helped them feel they haven't been completely abandoned. Our problems pale in comparison with what the locals are facing, even if they aren't displaced: increased police harassment; displaced friends and relatives living with them; constant uncertainty. This is our job, but it's their lives.
Tuesday, Oct. 13, Skopje -- Milosevic agreed to a deal! People with more experience in the region are more skeptical, but I hope it holds. People need to get out of the hills soon or they will start dying in large numbers.
Canadians must pay for visas in Macedonia, so I went to get a multiple-entry visa so I wouldn't have to pay $20 every time I cross the border. I went to three buildings to get the right department. When I got there, the officials had a discussion in Macedonian, after which I was told I must leave by tomorrow. I was confused.
Turns out I did not have my police registration card and therefore was considered illegal. Went back to the hotel, found the card and returned to the office. I was told that I could, in fact, remain in the country for the 90-day period granted by my single-entry visa, but could not have a multiple-entry because that was reserved for people doing business. I said we expected to do a lot of procurement in Macedonia and would need to cross the border frequently.
The final word was that I could not have a multiple-entry business visa because I already had one for Yugoslavia, and you cannot have one for both countries. In West Africa, we called these days WAWA's: West Africa Wins Again.
Thursday, Oct. 15, Pristina -- Opened the office and worked on a strategic plan for transportation. A problem all agencies will face this winter is access to villages that are off tarmac roads. Many of these roads will be impassable to commercial trucks. We have found a source of ex-German military four-wheel drive trucks, which we might be able to purchase and use to carry materials for different agencies. We'll see how far it gets. I am off to Sarajevo for the weekend; will visit our office there to get information on shelter programs.
Friday, Oct. 16, Pristina and Sarajevo -- Drove to Sarajevo. Almost 300 miles of very twisty roads. It was striking how portions of the route were not damaged, but at one point every structure was completely destroyed. Arrived without incident. Visited our office and then went to the Canadian Embassy to have more pages added to my passport. Wandered around the old town with some friends. A very picturesque city, except for the bits that have been blown up and the mined areas.
Saturday, Oct. 17, Sarajevo -- Ran errands and played touch football with people from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and a friend from the United Nations World Food Program. There is an incredible number of expats in Sarajevo; I have heard as many as 20,000. The economy seems very dependent on the humanitarian and military agencies. The brakes on the truck are not working very well, metal on metal. There are no garages open. Found a pub with real draft Guinness!
Sunday, Oct. 18, Sarajevo and Belgrade -- Drove to Belgrade through Tuzla to visit our shelter coordinator there, but couldn't find him. Passed through beautiful territory, nice meadows and rock bluffs. Lots of destruction and mined areas cordoned off with yellow tape. The brakes are so bad I had to drive using the gears and the hand brake. Exciting. Had no problems at the border, didn't even show a passport. Strange. Had a great dinner at a floating restaurant on the Danube. I'm sore from the football.
Monday, Oct. 19, Belgrade and Pristina -- Went into the Belgrade office and met with Allen Jelich, the International Rescue Committee country director, and Marcel Grogan, the new deputy. Dropped off the truck to have the brakes fixed. Went to the Macedonian Embassy and got a multiple-entry visa. Left the truck at the shop and borrowed a Belgrade car to return to Pristina. Not far from Belgrade, it overheated so I waited at a roadside cafe for a driver to bring another car. It has now been two weeks since we received verbal approval of our winterizing and water-sanitation proposal, but nothing signed to date. International Rescue Committee New York has advanced us $100,000 against the grant to get started. Never seen so many police in Pristina as tonight.
Tuesday, Oct. 20, Pristina -- Finally signed a lease on a warehouse. It is close to town, has offices in which we can house the logistics team, 1,200 square feet of warehouse space and a fenced compound to park vehicles. Did more interviews. It is amazing how good the candidates are. Tried to see a film called "Lulu on the Bridge," There are two screens at the theater, and both features started at 9. About 10 minutes into a film that I think was in Russian, I turned to my friend and asked her if they normally showed a short before the feature. They didn't. She assumed this was the film I had wanted to see. Perhaps another night.
Wednesday, Oct. 21, Pristina -- The transportation idea is taking off. Met with people from the Office of Food and Disaster Assistance this morning to discuss the concept, then met with representatives of several other NGO's, who are all supportive. Also found a large, unfinished workshop we could use to house a transport unit.
Thursday, Oct. 22, Pristina -- Had a look at the workshop. It will take some effort to make it operational, but it is the best facility available. Allen has finished a large $2 million medical proposal to provide assistance to urban medical facilities that have been overwhelmed by the conflict. The United States Government has promised in-kind contributions of reinforced plastic sheeting and 100 tents for emergency schools. I need to find a donor for the supplies.
Friday, Oct. 23, Pristina -- The owners of the workshop say we can use it if we finish it. I'm looking for a new apartment for myself. Found one I like, but they are asking too much. Everyone is getting panicky over residences and offices, since the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe is already here nosing around. They visited one of our apartments yesterday and told the landlord they wanted it. He said it was already rented, but they wouldn't leave him alone. Two-thousand more expats coming into Kosovo is going to completely skew the housing market and local salary structure.
Monday, Oct. 26, Sedlare Valley -- We had received a $4,000 donation from the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and staff from the International Rescue Committee in New York and Belgrade to buy long underwear for children. It doesn't sound that important, but for children living under plastic sheeting and without proper clothing, it means a great deal. Children and the elderly are always the first to suffer in an emergency. They just don't have the same strength as young adults, and in some circumstances, do not receive the food and other care they need. For that relatively small amount, we procured 1,400 pairs of tops and bottoms for children under 7. We came to the Sedlare Valley, southwest of Pristina, to distribute them.
It rained all day. We visited Kisna Reka, where the vast majority of the displaced are children, as is usually the case. We gave 500 pairs of underwear to the local representatives of the Mother Teresa Society, a local Albanian organization that has been handling most of the distributions. It has done a tremendous job, with almost entirely volunteer labor. Its people immediately began the distribution, registering the children as the underwear was given out to insure that no one was getting too much.
Tuesday, Oct. 27, Pristina -- Two of our expats received visas today. I hope this is the beginning of a softening by the Yugoslav authorities. There has been a lot of pressure on them to do this -- it is a compliance issue for the guarantee of freedom for humanitarian assistance. I got the apartment I wanted. Looked at another new house, which we will need if the medical and transportation proposals are financed.
Wednesday, Oct. 28, Pristina -- Stayed at home in the morning and finished a draft of the transportation proposal. Talked to our engineer to get better numbers on rehabilitation costs for the workshop. Heard back about the truck costs for the budget. Talked to World Food Program again about operating costs for the trucks. The total for this proposal is about $1.2 million to set up the workshop and operate it for a year with a fleet of 20 trucks for the winter months. New York will front us more money on the shelter grant so we can get started. And more good news: the Young Green Foundation, a private United States donor, has given us $65,000 to be used for children's clothing. With that, we should be able to put together a package of boots, long underwear and a raincoat for about 10,000 children.
People are beginning to return to their homes. Some of them have been forced out by host families who were afraid that they would have to house the displaced for the winter. I guess the solidarity only goes so far.
Thursday, Oct. 29, Pristina -- Met with the owners of the workshop; it looks as if we can agree on repairs and rehabilitation as in-kind rent. It is a quasi-state company that has no cash and really wants the workshop finished. Word from New York is that the United States Bureau for Population, Refugees and Migration is sending the grants tomorrow to be signed, which means we might have a grant code by Monday and can really start working. That would be nice, but I'm too tired of this to get excited. We ordered nine new four-wheel drives.
Monday, Nov. 2, Pristina -- Met with the High Commissioner for Refugees about the database project I want to carry out. We developed a shelter database and want to expand it to include data from other sectors, then link it to a geographic information system to create maps. Two expats arrived today, John Rickard to set up our logistics system, and Dr. Lynne Jones of Children's Advocacy International, to run the mobile clinics program. Still no confirmation of the grants being signed.
Tuesday, Nov. 3, Pristina -- The transportation proposal is now up to $1.6 million with a provision for 40 trucks. We have to make sure that any trucks we bring in are used only for areas that are inaccessible to commercial, two-wheel drive trucks because we don't want to take business from local truckers. Completely forgot about two interviews I was supposed to do. Damn. Roy submitted the water-sanitation proposal to the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance: $650,000 for water treatment, mostly well disinfection, and for displaced families returning to homes with damaged water systems.
Wednesday, Nov. 4, Pristina -- Got word from the European Community Humanitarian Organization that the emergency school- supplies proposal does not fall within the guidelines for microprojects. I will present it to the High Commissioner for Refugees and UNICEF. It is only about $65,000, which would outfit 100 classrooms.
Thursday, Nov. 5, Pristina -- We got grant codes! That means the contracts have reached New York, and we can make charges against accounts. I can't believe they have actually come. Allen Jelich came down from Belgrade with Buck Northrup, our regional director from New York, and we met again with the High Commissioner for Refugees to discuss the general situation and some proposal issues.
There has been a debate about the number of displaced and how many are living in the open. The range is from a Government figure of 3,000 to more than 500,000, according to the Mother Teresa Society. The truth is very likely closer to the society's number. Of that figure, there might have once been 40,000 to 50,000 living under plastic supplied by relief agencies.
In the last week, almost all the displaced who have been living in the open have returned to their compounds, though many are still under plastic because their homes are damaged or are destroyed.
Friday, Nov. 6, Pristina -- Received word that the 100 tents and 290 rolls of reinforced plastic sheeting donated by the United States Government have arrived in Belgrade. Was visiting a friend tonight and could hear an argument in the parking lot below. Someone started shooting, and one bullet hit the outside wall of the apartment just below the window. Lots of Serb civilians have been armed by the police.
Saturday, Nov. 7, Pristina -- Allen and I figure that if all our grant proposals come through, we will have a base of around $7 million and will have to expand the staff to about 30 expatriates and 120 to 150 locals. We will have 6 offices, about 10 residences, 20 passenger cars plus a truck fleet. We will need driver-translators, office people, water and sanitation specialists, public-health experts, civil engineers and medical staff.
Roy, Lynne, Buck and John went into the field. The valley above Kisna Reka is now empty; the displaced have all gone home, though for most that isn't much of an improvement in their living conditions.
Monday, Nov. 9, Pristina -- The bodies of two policemen were found today in Malisevo, 20 miles west of here. They were probably killed in retaliation for the killing of five Kosovo Liberation Army members Friday. More worrisome is the increase in reported mines and booby traps. The newspapers are reporting that six people were killed Friday in the shooting outside my friend's apartment.
Thursday, Nov. 12, Pristina -- Closing date for receipt of C.V.'s of national staff. We have a pile about two feet high. Drew is moving the shelter program into the new office today, as there won't be room in this office for everyone.
Friday, Nov. 13, Pristina -- Looks like we will get the supplies for the schools from the High Commissioner's office, which has also agreed to import the trucks for our transport unit. The new water-sanitation proposal has been approved, too. Two more expats got visas, so the team will start to come together -- though I shouldn't get too excited until I see the grant codes.
There has been an increase in fighting between the K.L.A. and the police. Dropped off two friends after dinner tonight and two of the tires on their Land Cruiser had been slashed. And so it goes.

HEADLINE: Rancorous Asia Pacific Talks End With a Pledge and a Sigh

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 18

 BODY:
With an almost palpable sigh of relief, the leaders of Malaysia and 20 other Pacific Rim countries wrapped up a contentious summit meeting here today by pledging to revive a region they said had been set back decades by the Asian economic crisis.
In a communique short on concrete proposals, the leaders agreed to pursue a "cooperative growth strategy" that would draw on billions of dollars in fresh financing from the United States, Japan, and agencies including the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. 
 But cooperation was notably absent from this year's Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, as the United States and Malaysia engaged in a war of words over a speech by Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Gore accused the host country of suppressing freedom and threw his support behind protesters who are demanding the ouster of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.
Dr. Mahathir had the last word at a news conference late today, but he steadfastly refused to criticize the Vice President.
"Whatever comments needed to be made about that speech have already been made," Dr. Mahathir said, in a subdued appearance. "I don't see any need to comment further."
On Tuesday, Malaysia's Foreign Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, condemned the United States for an "abhorrent" attempt to incite the overthrow of Malaysia's constitutionally elected Government.
Today, though, there were efforts on both sides to heal the rift. Dr. Mahathir said Mr. Gore's speech would not affect relations between Malaysia and the United States, and the White House made no further mention of Anwar Ibrahim, the former Deputy Prime Minister, whose ouster and arrest ignited the protest movement against Dr. Mahathir.
Instead, a senior Clinton Administration official said Malaysia had displayed "vision" in setting the agenda for the meeting and praised Malaysian officials for being "willing to listen to the ideas of others."
Even before Mr. Gore criticized its human-rights record, Malaysia had been a contentious site for the meeting. In September, Dr. Mahathir imposed sweeping controls on Malaysia's currency and stock markets -- effectively digging a moat around this country of 20 million people.
Malaysia did not win an endorsement of capital controls in today's communique, and other Asian leaders said they would not impose controls on their markets. But the countries called for changes in the international financial markets to avoid "destructive disruptions" in the ebb and flow of global capital.
And Dr. Mahathir did manage to insert a passage calling for a review of one of his pet peeves: agencies like Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investor Services, which rate the creditworthiness of corporate and government debt. He has criticized them for what he asserts are sloppy judgments that drive up a country's cost of borrowing.
In perhaps another victory for Dr. Mahathir, none of the demonstrations against his Government this week erupted into violence, as some political analysts here predicted. With only scattered protests that petered out quickly, Kuala Lumpur hardly seemed a city on the edge of anarchy. As he has before, Dr. Mahathir blamed the foreign news media for exaggerating the extent of civil unrest.
The Government discouraged would-be protesters by mobilizing hundreds of riot police officers and parking water-cannon trucks behind trees at the hotels where the leaders stayed. And with Mr. Gore and other leaders now gone, some people here fear that Dr. Mahathir will crack down on the dissidents.
At his news conference, though, the Prime Minister seemed almost mellow. He acknowledged, for example, that Asian countries deserved some responsibility for the crisis -- a striking departure for someone who has vilified foreign currency traders for causing the meltdown.
"Most of the Asian governments are now aware of their own weaknesses, and have undertaken to correct those weaknesses," he said. "So because of that, I think investors will feel much more confident to come into the region."
If there were any concrete steps at this summit meeting, they were in the area of reviving Asia's financially moribund corporate sector. On Monday, the United States and Japan announced that they would join in a plan to contribute $10 billion in trade financing to help countries recapitalize debt-swamped companies.
"Obviously, it's nothing concrete, but nonetheless it is important because the U.S. and Japan are the linchpins in the region," said Razak Baginda, executive director of the Malaysian Strategic Research Center, a research organization here.
The countries also committed to create stronger social safety nets. That issue seemed especially urgent this week after recent violence and looting in Indonesia set off by its economic crisis.
American officials noted that the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank would multiply their aid for social programs in the region. The total by both agencies will be $6 billion from 1997 to 1999.
Unquestionably, the big disappointment of the meeting was in trade negotiations. Japan balked at a sweeping deal to lower trade tariffs in Asia, forcing the countries to defer the package to the World Trade Organization. There is no guarantee that Japan will not resist the tariff cuts there, too.
Although officials from the United States labored to portray this compromise in a positive light, Dr. Mahathir felt no need to gild the lily.
"Being urgent is one thing, getting things done in the international community is another thing," he said in the tone of a man happy to have his week in the spotlight behind him.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC EYE;
Wheels for Sipowicz?

BYLINE: By Philip Nobel 

 BODY:
FOR all of their diversity, the streetscapes of New York City can be boiled down to a few representative elements: a yellow cab, a hot dog stand and a steaming manhole cover. Throw in a light-blue and white police car, and the location is fixed beyond all doubt. Only in New York, kids, only in New York.
Unfortunately, that last component of the city's visual signature will soon go the way of all things. One by one, the N.Y.P.D.'s familiar patrol cars, Chevrolet Caprices painted white and a custom shade that the department calls "grabber blue," are being replaced by lily-white Ford Crown Victorias. By 2000, when the transition is complete, New York will be a bit more like everywhere else. 
 The new cars fall in line with a standard used throughout the country: factory-painted white cars decorated with reflective decals, in this case two dark blue racing stripes, the department shield and a bold "N.Y.P.D." The new car is an unlikely award winner. In the 1997 Police Vehicle Design Contest, sponsored by Law and Order magazine, the N.Y.P.D. won second prize, beating a white car with blue stripes from Little Rock, Ark., but losing to a white car with blue stripes from Lynnwood, Wash.
William Flynn, executive director of support services for the Police Department, said that the new color scheme was "primarily an economic move." Each white car is about $800 cheaper to produce than the blue and white car it replaces, he says. But despite total savings in the millions of dollars -- the patrol cars' street life is only three years -- the introduction of the new design has been something of a stealth campaign. Police Commissioner Howard Safir approved the new cars in June 1996, and the first 200 or so rolled on to the streets with little fanfare in the spring of 1997.
Half of the city's 1,700 patrol cars have now been replaced, but the new cars are still well below the radar of most New Yorkers. Allen Adamson, the managing director of the New York office of Landor Associates, a large graphic design firm responsible for the corporate identities of Federal Express, Xerox and Delta Air Lines, suggested that New Yorkers have been slow to notice the change because the cars were sending the wrong message.
"From a branding point of view, I think they made a mistake," he said. "You want an image of toughness, but the new image is more suburban, more Mayberry. When I call the police in New York, I want Detective Sipowicz, not Andy Griffith."
Curiously, the fearsome blue cars were originally part of a program to make the police more user-friendly. Benjamin Ward, Police Commissioner from 1984 to 1989, was serving as Deputy Commissioner for Human Relations when the color was adopted in 1973. "Probably because the department had been Irish for so long, we all thought that green would be everybody's favorite color," he said. "But research showed that baby blue was the most popular color in America."
No formal studies were conducted to test public reaction to the all-white cars, but Hank Seiden, founder of the Seiden Group, a Manhattan-based marketing and advertising firm, worked with the department to develop the new look. Mr. Seiden also oversaw a more modest redesign of the patrol car graphics in the early 1990's, when the police introduced the bubble-headed Caprice but retained the distinctive grabber blue.
Now, he is sorry to see them go. "I designed those cars and I loved them," he said. "The white car starts to look like thousands of other police forces. But I'm happy with the way they came out. It's a friendly car. It's like a guy on a white horse with a white hat."
But the new cars may be too friendly, and too indistinct. Mark Lerner, the president of Epic Security, one of the city's largest private guard services, is concerned that people will mistake his white, blue-striped fleet for the new white, blue-striped police cars.
"I hope it's not going to be an issue of contention," he said. "I've had this look for 20 years and I like it."
Speaking in his academic capacity -- Mr. Lerner has a Ph.D. in criminology and has taught at John Jay College in Manhattan -- he said that the new cars would probably not make a difference in the way the police were perceived. But he worried that the department's distinctive edge had been lost. "I think the old black, white and green cars from the 1960's had the most effective look. New York City should look different than other places."

HEADLINE: Younger Workers in Russia Found More Likely to Be Poor

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Russians younger than 64 are more likely to be poor than older Russians, the United States Census Bureau reported today.
An analysis of data collected by a Russian statistical agency and analyzed here also found that poverty is more likely to affect women and those who failed to finish high school. 
 A major factor in Russian poverty is the availability of income supplements like disability allowances, pensions, private gifts and other allowances, the Census Bureau said.
Pensions, disability benefits and other such stipends are generally not available to younger workers, resulting in greater poverty among the young than among older people. In fact, 60 percent of poor households with members between the ages of 18 and 54 had no such supplemental income.
Unemployment benefits are often "quite meager," the report said.
Education also played a significant role, with people who had the equivalent of a high school education or less found twice as likely to be poor as someone with more education. And poverty was higher for women than men.
The analysis was based on data collected by the Russian State Statistical Bureau, Goskomstat. That survey was done with financing from the United States Agency for International Development, the National Institutes of Health, National Science Foundation and the University of North Carolina.
In its own report, released last month, Goskomstat said that living standards in Russia were falling even more rapidly than previously believed, with almost one in three people now living in poverty.
More than 44 million of Russia's 148 million people live below the poverty level, defined as less than $32 a month, and 8.4 million are without jobs, the agency said.

2 Million Orphans
 MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (Agence France-Presse) -- Two million Russian children lack families, and almost two-thirds of those live in the street, a press report said here today.
A study by the Association of Child Psychologists and Psychiatrists, a nongovernmental organization, said the number surpasses the period following World War II, the weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta reported.
Only about 650,000 of these children without families live in orphanages. The rest survive in cellars, attics, abandoned houses, and in larger cities by seeking shelter from cold in sewer systems.
After leaving orphanages, one in three become alcoholic and one in 10 commit suicide after a year on their own, the Labor ministry said. The suicide rate among children has doubled in 10 years, said the ministry.
It said about 10 million Russian school-age children never attend school.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Demand Is Heavy for Offering by Argentina

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Argentina raised $1 billion in seven-year debt yesterday, extending a bond-sale binge as interest rates fall and concerns ease over a financial calamity in neighboring Brazil.
The Government increased the offer to $1.3 billion from $750 million on strong demand. The bonds were priced to yield 11 percent, or 622 basis points more than the yield on comparable United States Treasuries. 
 J. P. Morgan & Company, which managed the sale with Deutsche Bank A.G., said it was the biggest Latin bond sale since last May.
"This is a huge deal," said Carlos Gadala, who manages $1 billion of emerging-market debt for Americas Trust Bank in Miami, which bought some of the bonds. "It shows there's still emerging-market money out there and borrowers won't have to pay exorbitant sums to get it."
Argentina has proved it can still tap international markets just three months after Russia's debt default caused emerging markets around the world to crash. In the last month, the country has sold $1.9 billion in five separate sales, underlining investor confidence in its finances.
In the United States, bonds rallied, outpacing shorter-term Treasuries, on expectations that inflation will remain subdued and that the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cut on Tuesday will be the last this year.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 18/32 , to 9928/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.26 percent, from 5.30 percent on Tuesday. Yields on two-year notes, among the most actively traded Treasuries, rose 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percent, to 4.61 percent.
An absence of inflation, and little concern that it will reappear, makes bond yields of 5.26 percent attractive on an inflation-adjusted basis, traders said. Inflation eats away at the value of bonds' fixed payments.
Real yields, or yields minus inflation, show how much of a premium investors demand to guard against rising inflation. They are calculated by subtracting the inflation rate, now 1.5 percent annually, from a bond's yield.
The last time inflation was at 2 percent or lower for any extended length of time -- from 1951 to 1966 -- real yields on a basket of Treasuries due in more than one year averaged 3.32 percent, according to data from Ryan Labs Inc. in New York. That is about 31 basis points lower than where they are now.

HEADLINE: Hitachi Data to Cut Staff

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Hitachi Data Systems, owned by the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and Hitachi Ltd. of Japan, said today that it planned to cut its work force by 400 employees. Hitachi Data said the cuts were likely to affect all areas of the company. It attributed the reductions to changes in business conditions and global markets. Hitachi Data, based here, sells high-performance enterprise servers, storage systems and professional services. It employs about 2,750 workers worldwide.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Big shareholders sold off Coca-Cola Enterprises stock, just as the company was buying it.

BYLINE: By Constance L. Hays 

 BODY:
WHILE much of America spent its summer vacation lying on the beach or relaxing on a mountaintop, some key shareholders of Coca-Cola Enterprises spent theirs in a flurry of trading on the stock exchange.
Early filings for the third quarter show that at least one big mutual fund company, a money manager and a trust company with significant positions in Coca-Cola Enterprises sold nearly all their shares during that period. Another mutual fund is said to have sold 10 million shares, possibly in a private deal. And the buyer of at least 14 million of the shares on the block was the company itself. 
 Two factors helped prompt the selling. In late July, Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is the Coca-Cola Company's main bottler in the United States and parts of Europe, announced a $5 billion capital spending plan that alarmed some investors, particularly when the company said it would not start showing increased positive cash flow until next year.
"A lot of investors just didn't want to wait," said Jennifer Solomon, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney.
Then the stock market, rattled by global economic crises in Russia and other regions, fell into an August swoon that carried the stock price of Coca-Cola Enterprises south along with those of many other companies.
The biggest sellers included Prudential Mutual Fund Investment Management, which sold slightly more than 6.2 million shares, worth $158.9 million, at the end of August. The company had held those shares since June, said Tim Biggs, a spokesman for Prudential, but declined to say why Prudential had decided to sell. Prudential still has about 242,000 Coca-Cola Enterprises shares in its portfolio.
Another big seller was the Bessemer Trust Company, which sold 2.9 million shares, worth $73.3 million, according to its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, which has been a long-term shareholder, still has about 46,000 shares.
And the word on Wall Street is that Putnam Investment Management, the second-biggest shareholder in Coca-Cola Enterprises, quietly sold about 10 million of its 15.8 million shares during the third quarter as well, possibly in a private deal. A spokesman for Putnam, part of Marsh & McLennan, refused to comment. Meanwhile, filings show that Warburg Pincus Asset Management sold 901,167 shares during the quarter for $22.7 million; the firm kept 9,600 shares.
Where did all those shares go? As it turns out, 14 million were bought by the company itself, for $404 million -- issuing more debt to pay for them at a time when it is already heavy with debt from acquisitions of smaller bottlers. The company frequently uses its own stock in acquisitions, which can mean tax-free deals for the owners of companies it takes over.
Interestingly, Coca-Cola Enterprises went on its shopping spree without fanfare, though companies often publicize buybacks, since the purchases can give the stock a lift. The first mention came in late October, at the end of its third-quarter earnings release.
The company's most recent buyback plan, aimed at reclaiming 30 million shares altogether, was authorized in April 1996, a company spokeswoman said. But until Jan. 1 of this year, no shares had been repurchased, because the company was reluctant to take on more debt.
While one million shares were bought in the first quarter -- and preceded by a detailed news release -- that move was dwarfed by the activity in the third quarter.
"To me, that's not the way to use shareholder capital," said Albert L. Meyer, an accountant and consultant in Indianapolis who has previously criticized the company. "And it's capital they don't have, because they had to borrow to do it."
Like merger activity, corporate share repurchases are at an all-time high. Last year, companies spent $182 billion buying back their own stock, said Laurie Hodrick, a professor of economics and finance at the Columbia University business school. They did so to invest in the stock when it appears to be undervalued, or for tax advantages, or as a deterrent to possible takeovers, she added.
"If you're repurchasing to communicate confidence, you'd want to announce it," she said. "But if the purchasing is done on the open market, firms need not disclose it and whether they do so or not depends on the purpose of the activity."
Margaret Carton, vice president for investor relations and planning at Coca-Cola Enterprises, says that share repurchases have long been part of the company's strategy, and the third quarter was merely an example of that strategy in action.
"We took advantage of the soft share price and bought a lot of shares," she said, adding that the purchases took place in August and September, at prices "from the mid-30's to low 30's all the way down to the mid-20's." Some shares purchased were part of a 17.7 million block that had been issued in the spring as a means of financing the company's takeover of a large Texan bottler, Coke Southwest.
Some purchases were made on the open market, and others were "privately negotiated transactions that we're not able to disclose," she said, adding that "short-term paper" was used to finance the deals.
"If somebody calls us and says we'd like to do this privately, we're interested," she said, calling a private sale "a more direct transaction" that permits the company to negotiate the price.
The company's decision to take on more debt to do that, though, may not sit well with every investor. "If interest rates were to spike, I think C.C.E. would be in serious trouble, just to make their interest payments," Mr. Meyer said.
In addition, at least one analyst is worried that price-cutting in the next few months may further erode earnings. "I didn't sense that this significantly improving pricing environment is around the corner," said Caroline Levy, an analyst with Schroder & Company, who removed the stock from her recommended list yesterday.
Still, Coca-Cola Enterprises' share price has bounced back. Working in the company's favor was its inclusion in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index on Oct. 7. That alone pushed up the stock somewhat, since index funds had to add its shares to their holdings. And, as the market in general has returned to early-summer levels, the company's share price has risen as well. Coca-Cola Enterprises stock closed at $38.0625 a share yesterday, off 93.75 cents.
Finally, even during the third quarter, there was at least one new big buyer: Merrill Lynch Asset Management, which bought 2.9 million shares for $73.5 million. Morgan Stanley Asset Management added 2.8 million shares to its holdings during the quarter as well.
The quarter's single heaviest session of trading came July 22, the day Coca-Cola Enterprises released its second-quarter earnings and described the details of the capital-spending plan. Trading volume, typically less than one million shares daily, soared to 7,996,100 shares; the price dropped from $38.4375 to $35.3125.
"Many people who invested in the company have become concerned about the divergence between E.B.I.T.D.A. and earnings," said Marc Cohen, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs, referring to earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. "While E.B.I.T.D.A. is growing, the big financial commitments they are making to expand the business are causing real earnings measures, and most importantly, free cash flow, to weaken."
Some think that as time goes on the stock repurchasing may prove a wise move. "It's a fabulous use of funds as long as there's money to borrow," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst for Merrill Lynch.

HEADLINE: Armstrong World Set to Lay Off 750

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 18

 BODY:
The floor covering giant Armstrong World Industries said today that it was laying off 7 percent of its 10,400 workers and taking a $78 million charge in the fourth quarter of 1998.
The layoffs, representing about 750 salaried and hourly workers, are expected to occur within the next 12 months, the company said. 
 About $29 million will be allotted for severance payments, the company said. The remainder of the charge reflects $40 million for enhanced retirement benefits and $9 million of expected losses for the disposal of certain machinery and equipment.
The company said the changes were the result of several initiatives taken to improve the company's costs in major product lines, lower overall break-even operating levels and better ways of developing and quickly marketing new products.
The news of the layoffs was released after the close of the market today in which shares of Armstrong were down 37.5 cents, to $65.125.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
There are wise and less wise ways to control cheap imports.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
ASIAN, Latin American and Russian imports are pouring into the United States, trapping the Administration in an embarrassing trade hypocrisy.
Last week, President Clinton promised to stop the "flooding of our markets" with low-priced steel and other imports that he said threatened American workers. This week, he sent Vice President Al Gore to Malaysia to preach open borders to a gathering of Asian-Pacific countries, many of which are clawing their way out of recession. 
 Apparently it is acceptable for Russia and other countries to export their way to recovery as long as those exports do not land here. Mr. Clinton is right to seek protection from a deluge of temporarily cheap steel imports. But there are good and bad ways to go about this task. So far the Administration has not chosen the best course of action..
American steel manufacturers have accused Japan, Russia and Brazil of "dumping" steel in the United States, or selling it for less than it costs them to make it at home. But anti-dumping rules too often amount to protectionism, shutting out legitimate exports and provoking trading partners to retaliate. The better course would be for the Administration to exploit a different provision of international trade rules, known as the safeguard clause, which permits countries to impose quotas or tariffs in order to block a sudden rush of cheap imports. That would give the United States a principled and constructive way to insulate workers from the temporary ravages of trade.
The steel industry's complaints center on imports of hot-rolled steel, which account for more than half of all steel products. These imports are soaring in part because Japanese and Brazilian mills are selling steel to the United States because buyers are evaporating in neighboring countries mired in recession. Russian steel is flooding America in part because the ruble has collapsed, cutting the dollar price of Russian goods. The price of steel in the United States has fallen by up to a third, and imports have risen about 80 percent since last year. Layoffs have already started.
The steel industry's answer is to accuse Japan, Russia and Brazil, which account for all of the explosive rise this year, of dumping. The one-third price drop "is out of bounds," said Keith Busse, president of of Steel Dynamics Inc. of Indiana, one of the 12 companies that brought the dumping charges. "Right is right and wrong is wrong," he said, and "import prices are crazy and will take out not just inefficient producers."
But to many economists, invoking international anti-dumping rules lies somewhere between a joke and protectionist fraud. The Commerce Department, which determines whether dumping has occurred, not only gets to decide what another country's costs are but also gets to tack on a nifty profit. In the case of Russia, the Commerce Department can determine that its markets are too primitive to yield reliable cost estimates and substitute figures based on higher production costs in, say, Turkey. The process is designed to help the domestic industry win.
An independent agency then decides whether the dumped imports have caused the aggrieved industry "material harm," a low threshold. If the steel industry gets its way, the United States will then impose prohibitive tariffs.
Americans' overuse of dumping charges is now taking a large toll. The rest of the world is catching on to the charade. The dumper now often claims to be the dumpee -- last year the United States was a defendant in about as many cases as it was the plaintiff.
Start from first principles. Low-cost imports are a gift to American consumers if they can be expected to last. If foreigners want to give us $2 worth of steel for $1 year in and year out, the country would be foolish to turn down the largess. But if the something-for-nothing is only temporary -- as is almost certain in the current case -- then the gift can turn sour. The temporary influx would trifle with the livelihoods of ordinary steelworkers, throwing them out of work one year only to lure them back in another.
That is why international trade rules include a safeguard clause. It allows nations to impose quotas or tariffs in an effort to hold off a sudden rush of cheap imports. But the safeguard clause is better tailored than anti-dumping rules to prevent abuse. The safeguard clause can only be invoked temporarily and must be phased out. An independent agency must determine that imports impose "serious harm" to the domestic industry rather than merely "material harm" under the anti-dumping rules. And if countermeasures are left in place for an extended period, then the United States, in the steel case, would be required to compensate Russia, Japan and Brazil.
That is the right principle. Americans protect their steelworkers from needless ravage but do so in a way that minimizes harm to suffering workers in Russia and Brazil.
The Administration is right to pursue relief for the domestic steel industry. But how it pursues that relief also matters. If the domestic industry successfully exploits anti-dumping rules in this case, the semiconductor, apparel and scores of other industries will follow suit. Then watch retaliatory measures take hold by America's trading partners around the globe.
The steel mills that brought dumping charges cannot be blamed for resorting to a legal device stacked in their favor. But Congress and the President are obligated to take a wider view. Under the law, each can initiate use of the safeguard clause on behalf of steelmakers. There is, despite the continuing dumping case, still time.

HEADLINE: Tiffany Names President to Succeed Chief

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Tiffany & Company, the second-largest United States jewelry retailer, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Michael Kowalski, would succeed William Chaney as chief executive on Jan. 31.
Mr. Chaney, 66, will continue as chairman. He was chief executive for 15 years. Mr. Kowalski, 46, will retain the title of president. He has worked at the New York-based Tiffany for more than 20 years in finance, merchandising, marketing, operations and sales. 
 On Monday, Tiffany said its third-quarter earnings rose 5.7 percent even though a falling stock market and concerns about the economy led to a 7 percent decline in sales at its New York flagship store. United States sales picked up in October and November, the company said.
Tiffany operates 130 stores worldwide, including 34 in the United States It is the No. 2 United States jewelry retailer based on revenue, behind the Zale Corporation.

HEADLINE: Delta Sets 2% Raise For Workers in U.S.

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines Inc., the No. 3 carrier in the United States, said today that it would give its 50,000 American employees a 2 percent raise, part of an effort to appease pilots who made pay concessions in a 1994 cost-cutting plan.
The 2 percent raise comes as Delta also shifts money out of a profit-sharing plan and adds it to employees' base salaries. The two actions mean paychecks will rise by an average of 8 percent effective Jan. 1, said Katie Moussouri, a Delta spokeswoman. 
 The airline's 9,000 pilots must approve the pay increase because they are covered by a labor contract. The pilots agreed to a 2 percent pay cut during a 1994 cost-cutting campaign and were scheduled to receive it back in May 2000. Pilots are to vote on the plan on Dec. 9.
"I would assume they'd approve it," said Karen McGuffey, a union spokeswoman. "They were due to get it back anyway."
The pilots have been clamoring for Delta, based in Atlanta, to increase their pay as the company's profit increases. The company has also spurned their efforts to win a voting seat on its board.
Delta's net income for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30 rose 29 percent, to $327 million, or $4.16 a diluted share, from $254 million, or $3.26 a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: World Briefs

BYLINE: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: WARNING ON DEBT PAYMENTS -- With a mission of the International Monetary Fund in Moscow for talks on loans, Deputy Prime Minister Yuri D. Maslyukov warned that inflation would soar out of control unless the Government reached agreements with its creditors to reschedule some of the $17 billion in foreign debt payments due next year. The chairman of the Finance Committee in Parliament, Aleksandr Zhukov, said that Russia could not meet the repayments. (AP, Agence France-Presse) 

RUSSIA: SHAM MISSILES ON PARADE -- Many of the huge missiles displayed in Red Square parades in the Soviet era were only dummies, but they scared the West into an expensive response, a weekly reported. One such fake, shown a May 9, 1965, parade prompted the United States to build an anti-missile defense system worth billions of dollars, said the magazine, Vlast. (AP)
 
RUSSIA: TO SEARCH FOR U.S. P.O.W.'S -- Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov has promised to help find evidence of whether Soviet spies plotted to seize American prisoners from the Vietnam War, a United States official said. Vice President Al Gore asked Mr. Primakov for help at a meeting in Malaysia. A bilateral looked into similar suspicions that the Soviets had detained American servicemen from the Korean War but said last year that it could not confirm that. (AP)
 
FRANCE: BRITISH AGENT FREED -- An appeals court rejected a British extradition request for a former British secret agent and ordered him freed. The agent, David Shayler, was arrested on Aug. 1 in Paris as he reportedly considered releasing information on a British plot to kill Muammar el-Qaddafi. (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: QUEEN GOES TO MARKET -- Queen Elizabeth II, left, took a turn around the City of London financial district for what aides called her first all-day visit to London's equivalent of Wall Street. Asked whether the Queen had been was fazed by the markets, Naomi Hill, a trader at Merrill Lynch, said after having chatted with Elizabeth, "She was totally knowledgeable." Alan Cowell (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: PINOCHET RULING DUE WEDNESDAY -- Gen. Augusto Pinochet will learn on Wednesday whether he is free to return to Chile or face extradition proceedings brought by Spain, which wants to try him for genocide. England's highest court is to rule on an appeal of a decision on Oct. 28 that found General Pinochet immune from arrest as a former head of state. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
PORTUGAL: MEAT EXPORTS BANNED -- The European Commission banned the export of beef and cattle from Portugal after a sharp rise in mad cow disease this year. Sixty-seven cases have been reported. (NYT)
 
FRANCE: STRIKE GROUNDS AIR FRANCE -- Air France flight attendants grounded more than half of the state-owned airline's flights on Tuesday and Wednesday in a strike for higher wages and longer rest periods between flights. Air France said it expected traffic to return to normal today. Craig R. Whitney (NYT)
 
AZERBAIJAN: EDITORS START HUNGER STRIKE -- Editors from 19 newspapers started a hunger strike to protest what they say is a campaign of repression against them by the Government of President Haydar Aliyev. The editors say criminal cases opened into the reported defamation of Mr. Aliyev in the press, as well as recent calls for tighter media controls by Parliament, are attempts at harassment and censorship. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
NORTH KOREA: 62% OF CHILDREN FOUND STUNTED -- An extensive survey of children found that 62 percent had been stunted by a lack of good food and that 16 percent were acutely malnourished, according to the United Nations World Food Program and other agencies. The survey suggested that North Korea ranked among the 10 countries in the world with the highest malnutrition rates. Nicholas D. Kristof (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: PALESTINIANS TO SEIZE ARMS -- The Palestinian police said they would start confiscating illegal weapons next week in compliance with the peace accord with Israel. The action, required under the land-for-security accord, will be among the issues that the Israeli Cabinet will examine when it decides on carrying out a first withdrawal of troops from part of the West Bank. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
DJIBOUTI: REACTION TO ERITREANS -- Djibouti has closed its embassy in Asmara and broken off diplomatic relations to protest an allegation by neighboring Eritrea that it sided with a third neighbor, Ethiopia, in a six-month border conflict. Eritrea fought a 30-year war against Ethiopia, gaining independence in 1993. But the border between the two has not officially been declared. (NYT)
 
ZIMBABWE: STRIKE OVER FARM SEIZURES -- Cities and farms were affected by discontent with President Robert Mugabe as a national strike paralyzed industry and white farmers faced new threats to their land. As factories fell silent and armed mobs besieged farms, 841 white farmers reportedly began receiving notices that the Government was planning to take their land. (Agence France-Presse)
