HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Deficit Ebbs, but Asia Toll Is Evident

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
As President Clinton left for Japan today declaring that "our workers and our farmers pay the price" for declining American exports to Asia, the Commerce Department reported trade figures suggesting that the price was not rising so quickly as many feared.
Shipments abroad of Boeing Company aircraft nearly doubled, narrowing the September trade deficit to $14 billion, down nearly $2 billion from a record monthly deficit in August. But the plane sales appeared to be a one-time statistical oddity, and the overall figures showed that the huge falloff in exports to the Pacific Rim -- combined with growing imports of steel, toys and electronics -- was beginning to take a larger toll on jobs and profits. 
 The figures underscored the political imperatives behind the dual messages that Mr. Clinton is expected to deliver in Japan and South Korea: that the United States wants to help the Asian economies, but not at the cost of absorbing more and more of their products.
Despite the slight improvement in the recent month's figures, for the first nine months of 1998 the United States trade deficit has been running about 50 percent higher than it was a year ago, when the Asian crisis was in its early months. That widening deficit poses what Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley recently called "a political problem of enormous magnitude."
This morning, Mr. Clinton said: "Nothing is more important to restoring stability and growth in Asia than efforts to restore Japan's economy. But it has been stalled for five years."
And for the first time he cited South Korea's giant conglomerates, the chaebol, saying that their resistance to economic liberalization had to end.
In both Tokyo and Seoul, Mr. Clinton's aides say, he will raise the subject of soaring shipments of foreign steel to the American market, an issue that has mobilized unions and steelmakers alike. The companies point to a first wave of layoffs in the steel industry as an indicator of what will happen to other American industries as the full effects of the Asian crisis begin to be felt broadly in American manufacturing.
"The fact is that the import explosion here has yet to really occur," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist of Primark Decision Economics in Boston. "The aircraft-export days are numbered for us. And when the Asian economies begin to do better with their production, the flood of cheaper imports will be noticeable, even on lean-and-mean American companies."
To be sure, those cheaper imports also offer advantages for American consumers and companies. They lower the cost of production for many concerns, particularly auto makers and construction companies that can buy parts or steel more cheaply. Many are now searching the world for such deals, gradually relying on more foreign suppliers. That often contributes to restraints in prices, allowing the kind of interest-rate cuts that the Federal Reserve announced on Tuesday.
The figures released today show how much of the current trade problem is rooted in Asia. The deficit with China for September, $5.9 billion, is larger than that with Japan for the month, $5.1 billion. Together, the two countries have surpluses in the trade of goods with the United States amounting to nearly $89 billion since the beginning of the year.
American car exports to Japan -- the subject of the Clinton Administration's big confrontation with Tokyo three years ago -- amounted to $79 million in September, and $709 million since the beginning of the year -- figures so paltry that they provide vivid evidence of how the economic downturn has wiped out any advantages from the 1995 agreement with the Japanese.
After Asian nations, the biggest trade deficits were with Canada and Mexico, the two other members of the North American Free Trade Agreement, totaling a little over $6 billion for September, and $24.4 billion since the beginning of the year. The United States continues to run a small surplus with Brazil, which received a $41.5 billion I.M.F. bailout last week. Trade with Brazil, however, is expected to turn into deficit as the Brazilians slip deeper into recession.
The Commerce Department said that exports in September increased to $77.1 billion, from $75.4 billion in August, but the entire difference was attributed to the aircraft sales.
Imports edged down to $91.2 billion from $91.3 billion in August.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Late Surges Bring Wide Gains as Dow Climbs by 54.83

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Late-session surges drove stocks to broad gains yesterday as investors more thoroughly digested the Federal Reserve's decision the day before to cut interest rates for a third time in seven weeks.
"There's a heightened degree of confidence that the Fed is doing the right thing," said Frederick Taylor, chief investment officer at the United States Trust Company, predicting that the economy would "barely" grow next year while profits modestly fall. 
 The Dow Jones industrials finished with a gain of 54.83 points, to 9,041.11, a level just 3.2 percent below its mid-July record. The blue-chip gauge was down 19.3 percent from that record at the end of August.
Even better was yesterday's performance of the Nasdaq market, which climbed 18.92 points, just more than 1 percent, as various Internet and other technology raced ahead.
Netscape jumped 10, to 39 1/4, and America Online jumped 8 3/8, to 83 3/4, on talk of an alliance between the two companies. Ebay soared 18 7/8, to 147 1/2; Amazon.com 15 1/2, to 164, and Yahoo 13 3/8, to 190 1/8.
Earnings of these current darlings may be skimpy or nonexistent but according to one school of thought, their corporate fortunes would probably suffer far less than other businesses from recession or deflation.
Bank stocks, by contrast, were mostly lower yesterday. Cutting the prime rate in respose to the Fed rate reduction may have been a factor, but a bigger reason seemed to be disclosure of steeper costs associated with the Year 2000 computer problem.
J. P. Morgan eased 1, to 105 7/8; Bankers Trust 1 1/8, to 67 7/16. American Express, on the other hand, jumped 2 3/4, to 102 1/8, to account for about one-fifth of the Dow's rise.
The bond market was mixed, with short-term rates edging higher and longer-term rates a bit lower as traders and investors continued to bet on another round of interest-rate reductions at the next meeting of the Fed's policy-making committee on Dec. 22.
"Right now, I expect the Fed to ease again," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers. The central bank might hold off then if stocks are at or near new highs, especially if holiday shopping is strong, he added, but "more easing is needed to prevent a liquidity squeeze from grabbing capital markets."
Mr. Stovall also cited the Wall Street maxim, supported by history, that any time the Fed cuts rates two or more times in sequence, both the stock and bond markets will advance over the following 12 months.
Another optimist yesterday was Clare W. Zempel, chief investment strategist at Robert W. Baird in Milwaukee, who said, "The broad stock market has considerable room to rise."
He pointed to the relationship of yields on three-month Treasury bills to the earnings yield -- the inverse of the more common price-earnings calculation -- for the Standard & Poor's 500, a ratio now at its lowest level since early 1996.
"The risk-reward relationship is decisively on the side of reward," Mr. Zempel said.
Other Dow stocks with sizable gains yesterday were 3M, 2 7/16, to 82 1/16; Merck, 2 1/4, to 149 5/8; General Electric 1 3/4, to 91 3/4, and Wal-Mart, 1 3/4, to 73 3/8.
Because of the uncertainty of the general earnings outlook, "people are looking for the steady growers," said John E. Silvia, economist at Scudder Kemper Investments.
Campbell Soup, which reported higher earnings, climbed 15/16, to 56 7/16. DaimlerChrysler, in its second day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, rose 1 1/8, to 85.
The strength in drug stocks went well beyond Merck. Warner-Lambert rose 3 1/4, to 77 15/16, while gains for Bristol-Myers, Lilly and Schering-Plough reached 2 points or more.
Sun Microsystems closed down 1/16, to 66 5/8, after trading as high as 69 13/16. The stock had added 3 7/8 Tuesday as it won a licensing suit against Microsoft.
On the New York Stock Exchange, 51 issues hit new yearly highs and 32 sank to new lows, but declining issues slightly outnumbered advancing ones, 1,545 to 1,514. Volume was a moderate 652.5 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500 added 5.16 points, or 45-hundredths of 1 percent, while the small-cap Russell 2000 gained 69-hundredths of 1 percent.
Overseas, two of the most closely watched markets these days posted gains. Brazil's main index climbed 2.60 percent while Japan's Nikkei 225 gained 1.29 percent.
Stocks rose 2.30 percent in Mexico, 64-hundredths of 1 percent in Hong Kong and 30-hundredths of 1 percent in France but fell 52-hundredths of 1 percent in Britain and 37-hundredths of 1 percent in Germany.

HEADLINE: As New Mexico Courts Spain, Both Sides Are Hoping to Profit

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADRID, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Four hundred years after Spain conquered New Mexico, the state this week sent its first trade mission here, along with American Indian religious dancers, to show there are no hard feelings.
In fact, ties between New Mexico and Spain have been on the mend since last April, when a Spanish official visited the state and met with American Indians whose ancestors suffered during the conquest by 500 Spaniards in 1598. 
 Both sides sensed opportunity in the 400th anniversary, deciding it was time to set a new course between Spain and New Mexico, which belonged to the Spanish Crown until 1821 and gained statehood in 1912.
The 140-member trade and cultural delegation, among the largest ever sent by any American state to Spain, comes just months after the arrival of the new American Ambassador, Edward L. Romero, a Democrat and a New Mexico businessman who traces his lineage back four centuries to a village near Madrid.
"If we're not able to make inroads into Spain with him being Ambassador, I don't know how we ever will," said New Mexico's Governor, Gary Johnson, a Republican.
Spain has rolled out the red carpet for the New Mexico delegation, part of its plan to build ties with all of its former territories, whether in Latin America, which has long received Madrid's attention, or in certain parts of the United States, where Spain is taking a closer look at the Hispanic traditions.
"Spain, at the end of the 20th century, with a bigger presence in the world, and more economic capacity and enthusiasm, wants to recuperate contact with those areas," said Jose Luis Solano, a Foreign Ministry spokesman.
Spain has worked hard since last spring to gain the confidence of New Mexico's Indians. Projects under discussion include assisting in the restoration of Pueblo Indian villages or exchanging teachers. The effort seems to be paying off.
"We cannot teach our children to hate. We have to establish a positive relationship for the next 400 years," said Earl Salazar, Governor of the San Juan Pueblo, whose dancers will perform at a ceremony this week in Madrid and in the village of Ambassador Romero's ancestors to bless the new relationship with Spain.
Madrid officials would like to be involved in New Mexico's $45 million Hispanic Cultural Center, which is scheduled to open in Albuquerque in December 1999. It will showcase Hispanic fine arts, literature and even cuisine.
"We couldn't stay out of an international Hispanic Cultural Center, could we?" said Maria Bassols, a Spanish diplomat. But she added, "We don't want big cooperation projects that will fall to nothing. We want little things that will grow."
Mr. Romero said Spain appeared to have a two-track approach with New Mexico, wooing the Indians and also the Hispanic residents in the state -- like him and his wife -- who have long been proud of their direct Spanish roots.
"I think they're playing up to both cultures," Mr. Romero said. "But it's hard to separate Spanish history in New Mexico from Native American history. A lot of Spaniards married Native Americans."
The state's population of 1.75 million is 40 percent Hispanic and 10 percent American Indian, and many of the latter have Spanish surnames.
During the visit, New Mexico's Indians, including 19 Pueblo tribes, hope to sell to Spain's largest department store chain, El Corte Ingles, at least $600,000 of their hand-made jewelry, while also courting other retailers.

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICAN TRANSITION: MAN IN THE NEWS -- Richard Keith Armey;
Ideologue With Swagger

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The House majority leader, Richard K. Armey, a man from North Dakota with Texas in his swagger, cannot help indulging in a hokey fishing tale or two when he is in a cheery mood. But seldom do they blossom into allegory.
"Think about the poor bass," Mr. Armey told reporters way back in September. "Put yourself in his place. You go into Denny's and you sit down and somebody puts your hamburger in front of you and you pick it up and take a bite. All of a sudden somebody grabs you by the mouth, drags you around the store, drags you outside, pulls the hook out of your mouth and throws you back into Denny's. That is what the poor fish goes through." 
 For Mr. Armey, the past three weeks have been no different. Many of his Republican colleagues aligned against him, eager to yank him out of the leadership position he has held since 1995. But, today, after weeks of intense lobbying for a second chance at the post of majority leader, Mr. Armey was re-elected.
It was far from a runaway victory; members voted three times in today's in-House election before the ballots finally sifted out the three other challengers and fell conclusively in Mr. Armey's favor.
"Each of us provided for the other a merry chase," said Mr. Armey, who represents suburban Dallas, after the secret votes were counted. Summing up the rigors of the challenge he faced, he added, "I have an even more keenly honed opportunity to live and learn."
On Nov. 4, the day after the election, it looked as if Mr. Armey, 58, would not survive the wrath of his Republican colleagues, who blamed their House leaders for ending up with a net loss of five seats. Few of them could forget the sight of the majority leader, on national television, sweeping aside dire predictions of Republican losses with braggadocio just hours before the polls close.
Speaker Newt Gingrich quickly resigned, and two other leaders were ousted today.
But Mr. Armey rallied, spending days on the phone and calling into action allies to help sway disillusioned members his way. The power of incumbency and his years of experience helped bolster his chances.
Born on July 7, 1940, in Cando, N.D., Richard Keith Armey worked as a grain elevator operator and a telephone lineman before he traded in blue-collar work for a degree from Jamestown College and a Ph.D. in economics from the University of Oklahoma. He and his wife, Susan, have five children from previous marriages.
Mr. Armey is an ideologue who dislikes the current tax rate and the International Monetary Fund as much as he does the Washington cocktail circuit. (He reluctantly bought a tuxedo this year, which he pairs with armadillo-skin cowboy boots.) An architect of the Contract With America, he has fought against abortion and gun control, and championed school vouchers, which permit tax dollars to travel to private schools.
When asked amid the Lewinsky scandal what would happen if he ever found himself in President Clinton's position, Mr. Armey thought of his wife and replied, "I would be looking up from a pool of blood and hearing, 'How do I reload this thing?' "
Although he emerged victorious today, it has been a rocky year and a half for Mr. Armey. In July 1997, Mr. Armey attended a meeting of Republican rebels who sought to oust Mr. Gingrich. He told Mr. Gingrich about the plot, then disavowed any role in it. That left members distrustful.
Then, early in the year, he faced a brief challenge to his position from Representative Bill Paxon of upstate New York. In the end, it was Mr. Paxon who backed down and later retired.
But today, his allies reminded colleagues that Mr. Armey had campaigned hard for them, and is capable of learning from his mistakes. Although the vote was close, 127 to 95 in the third ballot, the argument worked.
Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin of Louisiana, who supported Mr. Armey, said Mr. Armey needs to bid farewell to the new style of firebrand Republican governance and develop a less abrasive leadership style.
"He's got to receive it as a stern message that members want him to work with Livingston," Mr. Tauzin added, referring to the new Speaker of the House, Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana. "This took a lot of assurances that Armey would be very much a team player."

HEADLINE: Even U.S. Sees Iraq Opposition As Faint Hope

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN and BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, committed to renewed support for Iraqi dissidents, finds the opposition groups so weak and divided and penetrated by Iraqi agents that it is uncertain how to form a united front capable of toppling Saddam Hussein.
President Clinton caught the dissident groups and even some American officials off guard last weekend when he said the best way to avoid another crisis with Iraq was a change in Baghdad's Government. After aborting a planned air strike, he said the Administration would do more to support "forces of change in Iraq." 
 Mr. Clinton also embraced a new law that many in the Pentagon and his Administration had criticized as a waste of money. It calls for Washington to provide $97 million worth of military equipment and other resources to the dissidents.
Administration officials acknowledged that the President's address suddenly revived a policy that many critics believe had been on the back burner. Indeed, the President's announcement came weeks after the top United States commander in the gulf, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, dismissed the new law, saying "I don't think these things have been thought out." Now, the White House and State Department are moving quickly to try to fill in the blanks.
And some of the Iraqi groups themselves have misgivings about new American backing. Leaders of some of the smaller groups say the United States may do little but revive discredited projects that lack popular support inside Iraq.
Soon after the President's address, Martin Indyk, an Assistant Secretary of State, met with Ahmed Chalabi, the leader of the Iraqi National Congress, which has been out of favor with the Administration since its operations in northern Iraq were decimated by the Iraqi Army two years ago. Mr. Chalabi lobbied Congress to pass the $97 million funding plan, and now hopes to push the Administration to designate his group as a prime beneficiary.
The Administration's support "represents a policy reversal," Mr. Chalabi said. "They have opened their arms."
The Administration also is accelerating efforts to help unite feuding Kurdish and other groups into a cohesive opposition. These include an influential Iranian-backed Islamic Shiite group. That group, the Supreme Assembly of the Islamic Revolution of Iraq, met privately with Clinton Administration officials in Washington three months ago, according to other dissident leaders. It is the largest among Iraqi Shiites in southern Iraq and may now be willing to take part in a United States-sponsored military action against Mr. Hussein, if Teheran approves.
Meanwhile, more than a dozen opposition groups in London were asked to meet with a British Government official the day after Prime Minister Tony Blair said Britain supported the efforts to undermine Saddam Hussein's regime.
But altogether, the number of dissident groups and their competing interests have hampered Washington and London in their search for a way to topple Mr. Hussein.
Clinton Administration officials acknowledged today that they are not yet ready to decide which groups would receive American support, and whether any would receive arms. Under the terms of law, called the Iraq Liberation Act, the President has until the end of January to announce which groups will receive American support.
"We are intensifying our engagement with the opposition groups by strengthening our economic and political support for them," said the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin. "With respect to arming them, we haven't ruled that out, but we think it is premature to do that."
Another senior State Department official was equally cautious. "We have to be realistic about how we go forward," he said. "Working with the opposition to help them unify to create an alternative is a critical first step."
Republicans in Congress say they are not convinced that the White House is serious. "They have taken a step towards support for the Iraq Liberation Act, but I don't see that they have really made a commitment to overthrow Saddam," said a senior Republican Senate aide. "And that's the purpose of the act."
Some Iraqi dissident groups, which divide across ethnic and sectarian lines, worry about American and British intentions, saying that any plan that provides support for the Iraqi National Congress will have little support inside the country.
"From the beginning, I realized that this is not for changing the regime in Iraq," said Sami Faraq, who writes a weekly column for a London-based weekly newspaper, Free Iraq. "This just to give cover to other activities, like influencing the situation in the north of Iraq, to make the Kurdish movement look like part of the opposition to Saddam Hussein, when in reality they are completely independent."
Saad Jabr, the publisher of Free Iraq and the son of a former Prime Minister of Iraq when it had a British-installed monarchy, recommended an indictment of Mr. Hussein for crimes against humanity and total diplomatic isolation for his regime, among other measures.
He also recommended spending "big money" on an effective satellite system for broadcasting to Iraq. A number of exiles mentioned that the Radio Free Iraq broadcasts that the United States has now begun are too little, too late.
"We don't think America is serious, unfortunately, about removing Saddam Hussein," Mr. Jabr said in an interview. And if the Clinton Administration wants to count on any serious support within the country, the Iraqi middle class living mostly in Baghdad or other towns in the country's Arabic, Sunni Muslim heartland, needed a psychological boost.
In Minnesota, Abbas Mehdi, a university professor who is chairman of the Union of Independent Iraqis, a group linking about 30 small groups, said the United States has embraced sanctions that cut into the living standards of the Iraqi middle class whose support it would need if Washington were to open up Iraqi politics.
"Sanctions are destroying the people and the country," he said. "They have weakened the people who now have to depend on Saddam Hussein more than ever. It pains me to see how people talk about the U.S. in the Middle East, not only in Iraq. People are angry."
Despite the new American interest, many American officials have grown wary of investing too much time or resources into groups that often seem more intent on fighting each other than toppling Mr. Hussein. Since the end of the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Hussein has exploited their differences and managed to subvert them, rather than the other way around.
American options have been so limited that the Central Intelligence Agency has been secretly funding one group that agency officials know has been betrayed by Iraqi agents, U.S. officials said.
The Iraqi National Accord, a group made up of former military officers and other defectors from the Baghdad regime, is still receiving C.I.A. backing more than two years after Iraq revealed that it knew all about the I.N.A.'s covert efforts to subvert Mr. Hussein's rule. In June 1996, Iraq rounded up and executed about 100 army officers and others suspected of involvement with the group, making it clear that he had agents inside the group.
Today, United States officials say they strongly suspect that the I.N.A., with offices in Amman, Jordan and London, is still riddled with double agents.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with Joyce Wadler and Monique P. Yazigi 

 BODY:

Tripp Is Shopping For an Agent
LINDA R. TRIPP, who surreptitiously punched the record button when MONICA S. LEWINSKY poured out her heart on the phone, is looking for an agent. No, not LUCIANNE S. GOLDBERG.
A person close to Ms. Tripp who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that she and Ms. Goldberg never had a formal arrangement for Ms. Goldberg, a Manhattan literary agent, to represent her. This person said that Ms. Tripp and Ms. Goldberg remained friends but had "agreed" that Ms. Goldberg's appearance before a grand jury in Maryland last week made it impossible for them to have a "formal relationship." 
 The grand jury is considering whether Ms. Tripp, who lives in Howard County, Md., broke the Maryland wiretapping law by taping about 22 hours of conversations without Ms. Lewinsky's knowledge. Ms. Goldberg said after she testified last week that she was wrong when she told Ms. Tripp it would be legal to make the tapes.
The person close to Ms. Tripp said that Ms. Tripp had been dining with media types in Washington, including LARRY KING, the CNN talk-show host. "She certainly would be well within her rights to write a book," the person said. The Pentagon's refusal to let Ms. Tripp return to her job there and the possibility that she might be dismissed "makes it particularly important for her now to explore her economic options," the person said.
As for Ms. Goldberg, she, too, said that she had never represented Ms. Tripp. "I don't know why," she said yesterday, "but it's taken me a year to get people to realize I'm not Linda Tripp's agent and I never was."
 
A Bit Too Jumbo
The United Nations Sculpture Garden now has a full-size bronze elephant, a gift from Kenya, Namibia and Nepal. And it caused a stir even before its unveiling yesterday at a ceremony attended by SECRETARY GENERAL KOFI ANNAN.
It was too well-endowed for some.
"On Sunday, I received a call from the Ambassador from Nepal, who said: 'The penis is enormous. We brought in an expert to look. There has to be a surgical operation,' " said HANS JANITSCHEK, the chairman of a nonprofit group that had raised money for the project. "Where this expert came from I do not know."
NARENDRA BIKRAM SHAH, the permanent representative from Nepal, said yesterday that he had no problem with the sculpture. But such was the concern at the United Nations that a meeting was held in the office of UNDERSECRETARY GENERAL ALVARO DESOTO. The solution? To plant some bushes that block the view.
 
Runway Irregulars
So they were not really supermodels. But on Tuesday evening, half a dozen women looked like runway regulars in the Fifth Avenue showroom of Asprey & Garrard, jewelers for the English royals.
The models, women in their 30's who belong to the director's council of the Museum of the City of New York or the store's "tastemaking" advisory board, included WHITNEY FAIRCHILD, TARA ROCKEFELLER, RACHEL HOVNANIAN, ALEXIA PICKETT and OLEXA FARRELL. They got to dress up in beaded evening wear by TOMASZ STARZEWSKI. They had hair and makeup done by JOHN BARRETT at Bergdorf Goodman. And they got to wear baubles from Asprey & Garrard -- several million dollars' worth of diamonds, emeralds and gold.
They had to give back the dresses and the jewelry. But that was after they had paraded in front of 350 guests, who had packed the store and spilled out onto the sidewalk on 56th Street at Fifth Avenue.
"It was like a fantasy," said Ms. Hovnanian, who was perhaps a little too attached to the $57,000 diamond pave dropped earrings she had been wearing.
"They look great on you," a woman at the party said to her, and then suggested that maybe Ms. Hovnanian's husband, ARA, a New Jersey real-estate executive, might buy them for her.
He shrugged. The earrings went back to the vault. JAMES BARRON with Joyce Wadler and Monique P. Yazigi

HEADLINE: Brazil Preoccupied With Mystery Tapes

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Washington and Wall Street may be breathing a sigh of relief now that a rescue package for the Brazilian economy has been stitched together. But the political leaders who will have to hold up Brazil's end of the bargain have suddenly become preoccupied with another troublesome question: Who fabricated the mysterious tapes and documents that implicate Brazil's President in potentially impeachable offenses?
Shortly before the re-election of Fernando Henrique Cardoso last month, potentially compromising recordings of intercepted telephone calls between senior Government officials, including Mr. Cardoso, were left under a highway underpass here. About the same time, an anonymous person sent a series of faxes highly unfavorable to the image of the President to a Government Minister, who made them available to the press in recent days. 
 The faxes purport to show that since 1994, Mr. Cardoso and three allies have maintained a secret offshore bank account and slush fund in the Cayman Islands with a balance of $368 million. In coded language, the faxed correspondence describes deposits and transfers made by a company in the Bahamas, CH, J & T Inc., whose initials correspond to those of its supposed owners.
The audiotapes, on the other hand, raise questions about the propriety of the Government's handling of the $19 billion privatization of the telephone company. Edited transcripts published this week indicate that those who were tapped talked with embarrassing and even vulgar frankness about friends and enemies: the Minister of Communications, for instance, has acknowledged that he referred to a senior aide to the Treasury Minister as "a blockhead," though, he asserted, only "in an affectionate manner."
The matter has quickly become a distraction for the Congress at the precise moment that Mr. Cardoso had been hoping to focus the attention of legislators on the $41.5 billion loan and credit package agreement reached with the International Monetary Fund last week. The accord is contingent on the Government adopting a series of budget cuts and administrative reforms, most of which would need to be approved by both houses of the Congress.
"Suddenly the President is confronting something no one expected, something that can consume the energy of his Government," said Alexandre Barros, a political analyst and commentator in Brasilia. "Clearly someone is trying to pull the rug from under his feet, and whether the charges are true or false, there is an element of wear and tear in this."
Mr. Cardoso's spokesman, Sergio Amaral, has dismissed the entire dossier as a crude forgery. "Of course he does not own any companies abroad," Mr. Amaral said at a news conference in Brasilia last week, adding that the only assets the President has overseas are two bank accounts in New York City with a total of about $23,000.
Indeed, nearly everything about the documents seems to indicate they are fraudulent. Though officials in the Bahamas have confirmed the existence of the company named in the correspondence, questions have arisen about the authenticity of signatures, and the letters contain misspellings and very awkward syntax, as if written by someone whose native language is not English.
For that reason, press accounts here have been openly skeptical about the effort to make Mr. Cardoso, who has a reputation for personal rectitude, look like the Brazilian equivalent of Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico. Nevertheless, the incidents have provoked several rounds of finger-pointing and speculation as to who is attempting to do in the President, who is scheduled to be inaugurated for his second four-year term in January.
Last week, a Senator said that former President Fernando Collor de Melo offered to send him a copy of the dossier and suggested to him that he make the information public. Mr. Collor, who resigned in 1992 just as the Congress was about to vote to impeach him on corruption charges, has denied making any such proposal. On Friday, Mr. Cardoso angrily attacked those behind the intrigue, calling them "farceurs and forgers" and indirectly pointing a finger at Mr. Collor. "It is necessary to express to the nation the indignation I feel at seeing people with no credibility whatsoever returning again to the public scene with insinuations," he said.
More enigmatic is the role played by Paulo Maluf, a former Mayor and Governor of Sao Paulo, the country's largest city and state. Mr. Maluf is nominally an ally of the President, but has long harbored presidential ambitions of his own, and admitted that his daughters also had a copy of the dossier and offered it to leaders of the main opposition party, who rejected the overture.
Mr. Maluf asserted that the women "acted on their own account" and without his knowledge. But he has also lashed out at members of Mr. Cardoso's Cabinet, saying their aim was to discredit his party.
The President's supporters have had to mute their criticisms of Mr. Maluf's conduct, though. The reason: If the financial rescue package crafted by the Cardoso Government and the I.M.F. during two months of difficult negotiations is to pass in the Congress, the support of legislators loyal to Mr. Maluf is essential.
Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, the Senate majority leader and one of Mr. Cardoso's closest political associates, last week appeared to rebuke Mr. Maluf, saying that the plot against Mr. Cardoso was "reprehensible" and that if Mr. Maluf was involved in any way "obviously it is an attitude that is disconcerting and does not dignify him." But, he continued, "I am not going to break with Maluf."
Sensing a political opportunity, opposition parties are now demanding a full-scale parliamentary investigation, which could drag on for months. Mr. Cardoso's supporters have resisted that effort, but then the head of the federal police announced the start of an official investigation and said he would call on all those whose names are mentioned in the affair, including Mr. Cardoso, to testify.
Mr. Amaral, the presidential spokesman, said that Mr. Cardoso was willing to cooperate "because it is necessary to bring an end to this infamy based on rumors."

HEADLINE: Beijing to Expel Foreign Reporter, 2d in a Month

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 18

 BODY:
China today expelled a reporter for the German news magazine Der Spiegel, one day after eight officials burst into his office and accused him of possessing secret documents. The reporter, Jurgen Kremb, said he was told he must leave China within 48 hours and could not return for five years.
Last month another foreign reporter, from the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun, was also charged with possessing state secrets and was deported. 
 Both reporters denied the charges.
In China almost any political or economic information that has not been published in the state media or announced by a senior official can be defined as a state secret, giving the authorities a ready tool for attacking people seen as opponents.
Both recent cases involved reporters who have angered security agencies with their reporting on human rights issues.
Mr. Kremb, 41, has reported from China for eight years. He is the author of a recent biography of Wei Jingsheng, the prominent democracy advocate who was sent from prison into exile in the United States last fall.
In 1997 Mr. Kremb was detained for two days when he visited Mr. Wei's family in Anhui Province. In a spottily enforced rule, journalists are supposed to obtain the permission of provincial authorities before conducting interviews anywhere in China.
Last summer Mr. Kremb began working in Singapore, but he was in Beijing this week in the latest of several reporting trips before his official accreditation and visa to work here as a journalist expire at the end of the year.
Mr. Kremb said the agents who raided his office pushed him roughly against a wall and read loudly from a document accusing him of violating the law. They searched the office for three hours, then confronted him with what they said were secret papers he held, and demanded that he sign a confession.
Mr. Kremb said he had refused to sign, and suggested that the officers might have planted evidence. "I was shown documents but refused to touch or even read them," he told the Reuters news agency. "I haven't been in my office for a long time and I don't even know if they were mine."
In a statement today, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said, "Mr. Kremb illegally possessed secret Chinese documents in violation of the law." The security agents lawfully searched Mr. Kremb's office, the statement said, "found a large amount of evidence and ordered him to leave China."
The German Foreign Ministry said it had complained about the treatment of Mr. Kremb to the Chinese Ambassador in Bonn.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Microsoft Accuses I.B.M. Of Attempted Collusion
In a series of attacks in Federal court, Microsoft accused I.B.M. of engaging in many of the same practices that led the Government and 20 states to file antitrust charges against Microsoft.
A Microsoft lawyer produced an E-mail message in which John M. Thompson, I.B.M.'s software chief, last year proposed to the leaders of Sun Microsystems and Netscape Communications a strategy for a joint campaign against Microsoft. Page C4. 

The staunchest supporters of William H. Gates can be found in the Microsoft Partner's Pavilion at the heart of the Comdex computer trade show in Las Vegas, Nev. C4.
 
Brazil Economy Contracts by 1.5%
Fanning widespread fears that Brazil is plunging into a full-fledged recession, the Government announced that the economy contracted by 1.5 percent in the third quarter. C6.
 
Stocks Post Broad Gains Late
Late-session surges drove stocks to broad gains as investors more thoroughly digested the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to cut interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 54.83 points, to 9,041.11. The Nasdaq did even better, climbing 18.92 points, or just more than 1 percent, to 1,897.44. The S.& P. 500 rose 5.16 points, to 1,144.48. C8.
 
Argentina raised $1 billion in seven-year debt, extending a bond-sale binge and proving it can still tap international markets. C8.
 
Tighter Rules Seen for Hedge Funds
As United States regulators tighten their scrutiny of hedge funds, officials say that they will likely require the often secretive funds to reveal more about how much debt they use and the risks they take with their money. C2.
 
Clinton's Stance on Cheap Imports
In the view of the Clinton Administration, it is acceptable for Russia and other countries to export their way to recovery as long as those exports do not land here. Mr. Clinton is right to seek protection from a deluge of temporarily cheap steel imports, but there are good and bad ways to do that. So far the Administration has not chosen the best course of action. Michael M. Weinstein: Economic Scene. C2.
 
Sales Fall 4% for Glaxo Wellcome
Glaxo Wellcome, the world's second-largest drug maker, said that its 1998 sales through Oct. 31 fell 4 percent, within market forecasts, as increased sales of asthma drugs failed to offset slowing growth for other drugs. C6.
 
Profit Up 4.8% for Campbell Soup
Campbell Soup, which makes about 75 percent of the soup sold in the United States, said that first-quarter profit rose 4.8 percent because of cost cuts and higher-than-expected sales. Net income rose to $264 million, or 58 cents a diluted share, matching analysts' estimates. Campbell reduced spending, expanded overseas and shed some businesses. C5.
 
Surgery Set for Chief Executive
Waste Management said that its chief executive, John Drury, was scheduled to have a mass removed from his brain. But the company said that the operation was not life threatening and that Mr. Drury was expected back at work within a week to 10 days. C5.
 
Allied Signal Case in Lower Court
In an advance for Allied Signal, the company said that a Federal appeals court had given jurisdiction over the company's attempt to expand the board of AMP with its own directors back to a district court judge, who is likely to lift a preliminary injunction he imposed last month barring the board election. C5.

HEADLINE: Clinton Says He'll Press Japan to Take Strong Action

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Leaving Washington for an abbreviated five-day trip to Asia, President Clinton vowed today to press Japan to take "decisive steps" to open its markets and revive its economy in hopes of easing the global financial crisis.
In a sign of the cool if not downright suspicious reception that the Clinton Administration has given to the $195 billion package of tax cuts and spending announced here on Monday, the President did not even mention the package. Instead he emphasized the need for follow-through on longstanding commitments to such policies. 
 "Nothing is more important to restoring stability and growth in Asia than efforts to restart Japan's economy," Mr. Clinton said before boarding a helicopter on the South Lawn of the White House.
Declaring that the economy here has been "stalled for five years," he said he looked forward to "discussing how Japan can promptly and effectively implement its commitment" to reforming its banking system, opening protected industries to foreign competitors and priming consumer demand.
Mr. Clinton canceled the first part of the trip, to the annual summit meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation organization, held this year in Malaysia, as he planned and then aborted a military assault on Iraq. He sent Vice President Al Gore instead and then left to complete the other legs of the trip, to Japan, South Korea and Guam.
The decision to make the rest of the stops had the incidental benefit of placing Mr. Clinton out of the country as Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater special prosecutor, testifies before the House Judiciary Committee, which is weighing possible impeachment.
Administration officials hope that the trip will display Mr. Clinton as pointedly removed from Washington wrangling, conducting high-minded business -- confronting economic and security worries -- as Mr. Starr squares off with friendly Republicans and hostile Democrats. But the trip was long planned, and White House aides dismissed as preposterous any suggestion that Mr. Clinton was fleeing at Mr. Starr's approach.
"The international financial issues have been at the top of the President's agenda, and this trip offers him the chance to go and make the case for the new global financial architecture that he's been talking about, directly to the people of Japan and Korea," said the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart.
Mr. Clinton will probably not avoid unpleasant matters at home altogether. He plans to answer reporters' questions on Saturday, in a joint appearance with President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea. White House aides said Mr. Clinton was highly unlikely to take more than two questions, however, insisting that the Koreans had set the ground rules.
As always Mr. Clinton tried today to emphasize the stakes for Americans in his financial negotiating abroad. "If people overseas lose their jobs," he said, "they can't afford American products, and our workers and farmers pay the price."
That thought seemed also to reflect the Administration's increasing worry about the possibility of rising protectionist sentiment. The American trade deficit with Japan totaled $5.1 billion in September, a great part of the nation's overall $14 billion deficit, Washington announced today. In particular, the Administration has come under great pressure from the American steel industry and steel workers to address a surge in steel imports from Japan.
"There's no question that there has been a surge and that that is certainly causing pain, real pain, in some steel communities in this country," said Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's national economics adviser.
Mr. Clinton plans to take his economic message directly to the Japanese people on Thursday. He is to hold a televised town-hall meeting with what the White House is billing as a cross-section of young Japanese, from 20 to 40.
In South Korea, where the Administration is pleased with economic steps that the Government has taken, Mr. Clinton is planning to deliver a gentler message of encouragement. But he said today that he would also press Mr. Kim to reform South Korea's banks and the huge conglomerates, whose debt is dragging down the economy.
On Sunday, Mr. Clinton plans to visit at least two American military bases in South Korea, in a reminder of the American security commitment there. But Joel Witt, a senior associate at the Henry L. Stimson Center, a military research organization in Washington, said that Japan and South Korea also wanted "to hear from the President that he's committed to seeking peaceful resolution of our differences with the North."
After leaving South Korea on Monday morning, Mr. Clinton is to give two speeches to residents of Guam before returning to the White House on Monday night.

HEADLINE: Stepping Back From the Brink With Iraq

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Kuwaitis Are Puzzled by Lack of U.S. Action" (news article, Nov. 18): How quickly we forget what happened the last time there was sustained military activity in the Persian Gulf: oil prices skyrocketed before a shot was fired. With the winter coming and the economy in a fragile state, is it possible that the Clinton Administration was considering the economic costs of another war in the Persian Gulf? 
 What we have seen appears to be a consistent example of Clintonian strategic policy. "It's the economy, stupid" may not sound very Presidential, but it works well for the American electorate and for our allies.
 
STEPHEN BELLINGER
San Francisco, Nov. 18, 1998

HEADLINE: On Its Own Turf, It's Microsoft, Right or Wrong

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Just as President Nixon found support among construction workers during the Vietnam War, it is here in the PC-filled aisles of the Microsoft Partner's Pavilion at the heart of the sprawling Comdex computer trade show that the Microsoft Corporation's besieged chairman, William H. Gates, finds his staunchest supporters.
Like Nixon's defenders, whose rallying cry was "My country, right or wrong," many of these digital hard hats today say that Mr. Gates is the victim of a conspiracy. His enemies, they say, competitors who have lost in the marketplace, turned to the Government to save them when their products failed. 
 On Tuesday, in Federal court in San Jose, Calif., Mr. Gates's Internet strategy of "embrace and extend" -- in other words, to add Microsoft-specific features to industry-standard software -- suffered a stinging defeat.
Federal District Judge Ronald H. Whyte issued a temporary restraining order that gave Microsoft 90 days to make its Java software compatible with the version created by its archrival, Sun Microsystems, which owns the programming language, or remove it from its Windows software.
Moreover, that ruling followed weeks of damaging testimony in the trial of the Government's antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft, which has seen a parade of Government witnesses accuse the software giant of systematically using its control of the Windows operating system to defeat its competition.
To be sure, in other parts of the nation's largest computer trade show there were people who cheered the decision today and shared dark whispers accusing Microsoft of using strong-arm business tactics.
Yet here in the Microsoft Pavillion, one of the most crowded sections of the trade show, under banners trumpeting new advances in ease-of-use and productivity, neither court case dimmed the support of hundreds of Gates loyalists.
In row after row of personal computers featuring Windows software products of every description, from industrial automation to architectural support, 252 companies see themselves as living proof that the Windows business model is making money for more than just Microsoft.
These are companies that have started small, just as Mr. Gates did more than two decades ago, and have prospered writing programs that run on his Windows operating systems.
There is little love here for the idea of Government regulation or intervention. There is a pervasive hope that with perhaps just a bit of luck and a strong dose of entrepreneurial sweat and labor, it is still possible to match the success of Mr. Gates, the nation's wealthiest person.
"This is just Big Brother trying to beat this guy up," said Jack Ross, president of Cedar Systems, a five-person start-up in Bellevue, Wash.
Mr. Ross views Mr. Gates as a consistent innovator who has suffered some bad public relations defeats in recent weeks at the hands of the Justice Department.
"I don't see how the Government can come in and help settle the score after these guys have lost in the marketplace," he said, referring to Silicon Valley companies like Sun, the Netscape Communications Corporation and the Oracle Corporation, which are Microsoft's most bitter enemies.
That view is apparently shared by a majority of Americans. A CNN-USA Today poll by the Gallup organization that was reported on Tuesday found that 56 percent of 1,039 adults interviewed last weekend had a favorable opinion of Mr. Gates, compared with 55 percent in March before the antitrust trial began.
Of those polled, 44 percent said they sided with Microsoft in the trial, while only 28 percent backed the Justice Department.
Some at Comdex portray Mr. Gates's problem as simple politics. Microsoft, they say, has failed to educate the Government on how the software industry differs from other, more traditional American businesses.
"Microsoft is an extremely competitive company, like many others," said Paula Gil, an alliance manager at Best Software, a company in Reston, Va., that develops business software. Since going public last year, Best has seen the value of its stock almost double.
Ms. Gil, who expresses great admiration for Mr. Gates, recalled that when she heard him speak years ago, an audience member asked whom he feared most as a competitor. Without hesitation, she said, Mr. Gates answered that it was somebody working in a garage on a new idea that he had never heard about.
"I see guys walking up and down these aisles who look like they are barely 15 years old, and they are presidents of their own companies," Ms. Gil said. "That's the spirit of competition that characterizes this industry, and that's the perspective the Government is missing."
It was not just the cottage programmers here who believed that what is good for Microsoft is good for the country. Among the software industry's most successful figures, there are some who argue that while Microsoft's tactics have occasionally crossed the line, it is still important to defend the powerful company.
"Microsoft has done some bad things," said Gordon Eubanks, chairman of the Symantec Corporation, a Cupertino, Calif., developer of utility software.
But at the same time, Mr. Eubanks said, Mr. Gates is the victim of a broader trend in American culture: attacking and tearing down those who are too successful.
That view of Mr. Gates and Microsoft, as examplars of success that are being tampered with, is echoed repeatedly among those who believe that the operating-systems marketing wars of the 1980's are over and that resurrecting them will hurt business and slow progress.
"It's a privilege to work with Microsoft," said Ed Murray, a senior consultant at Wind 2 Software Inc. He values the broad computer industry compatibility that Microsoft's Windows operating systems has created. 'They're an innovator, and they're leading technology forward, and it will hurt the economy and hurt our business" if the Justice Department wins.
Microsoft loyalists share the view that the system is not broken, so the Government should not try to fix it.
"For us, Microsoft's size is a big advantage," said Robert W. Mosolgo, president of Owensville Systems, a six-person start-up in Charlottesville, Va., which makes network monitoring software. "They're a good supporter, and it would be impossible for us to even consider partnering against them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: What's good for Microsoft is good for the country -- that was the battle cry at the Microsoft Partners Pavilion at the Comdex show in Las Vegas, Nev., where support for the software giant was understandably high. (Mark J. Terrill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Microsoft Says I.B.M. Tried To Enlist Rivals in Collusion

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
In a series of attacks in Federal court today, the Microsoft Corporation accused I.B.M. of engaging in many of the same practices that led the Federal Government and 20 states to file antitrust charges against Microsoft.
While cross-examining John Soyring, director of network computing software for the International Business Machines Corporation, a Microsoft lawyer produced an E-mail message in which John M. Thompson, I.B.M.'s software chief, last year proposed to the leaders of Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Netscape Communications Corporation a strategy for a joint campaign against Microsoft. 
 Mr. Thompson urged the others to help him enlist Oracle and Novell in the effort "to put Microsoft on the defensive." The E-mail was written in response to a plan by Microsoft to establish its own version of the Java programming language.
On Tuesday, a Federal judge in California gave Microsoft 90 days to make its version of Java compatible with the standards set by Sun, which invented and licenses the language.
But in court today, Microsoft's lawyer, Steven Holley, used Mr. Thompson's memo to contend that I.B.M. had been attempting collusion with several other companies to disadvantage Microsoft.
"We must clearly explain to our customers that Internet Explorer is Microsoft's primary weapon to kill 100 percent pure Java," Mr. Thompson wrote. Internet Explorer is Microsoft's World Wide Web browser, and it uses Microsoft's version of Java -- not the "100 percent pure" version authorized by Sun.
Mr. Holley asked Mr. Soyring, "Do you think it is appropriate for five of the leading computer companies in the world to meet and collude" against Microsoft?
Mr. Soyring said he had not been involved in the discussions and knew nothing about them. But the disclosure was potentially useful to Microsoft because the Government, in its antitrust suit, accuses Microsoft of illegally colluding with several other companies, including America Online and Apple Computer, to the disadvantage of Netscape, Microsoft's chief competitor in the market for Internet software.
The Government made public today the written testimony of Frederick R. Warren-Boulton, who will take the stand on Thursday. Mr. Warren-Boulton, an economist and former Justice Department official, makes a long and detailed academic and political argument that Microsoft is a monopolist, as antitrust law defines the term, and is therefore engaging in several activities that appear to violate antitrust laws.
"The price to consumers from Microsoft's maintenance of its PC operating system monopoly and its creation of a new monopoly in Internet browsers through its exclusionary practices is substantial," he wrote. "The price paid for personal-computer systems likely will be higher than it otherwise would have been," and "Microsoft's conduct will slow or halt the natural tendency of the marketplace to provide alternative technologies." As a result, "Microsoft's operating system monopoly would be further entrenched."
Mr. Warren-Boulton has held a number of prominent academic and political positions. But perhaps most interesting for someone arguing for antitrust enforcement against Microsoft is that he was chief economist for the antitrust division of the Justice Department during the Reagan Administration, which chose to pursue few antitrust cases.
In a statement today, Microsoft contended that "Mr. Warren-Boulton's testimony is clearly that of an ivory tower consultant with little or no direct experience in the day-to-day business and competitiveness of the U.S. software industry."
Several times during the trial, Microsoft has used the tactic of accusing its accusers of similar practices. The company argues that the computer industry plays by different rules than the rest of corporate America and that Federal prosecutors do not understand those rules.
But Justice Department lawyers say the argument means nothing; if other companies are violating the law, they should be prosecuted, too.
Today, Mr. Holley tried to make the case that I.B.M. was "integrating" the company's own browser, Web Explorer, with I.B.M.'s personal-computer operating system, O/S2 Warp. A key charge in the suit is that Microsoft illegally integrated Internet Explorer in the Windows operating system in an attempt to disadvantage Netscape. As part of his argument against I.B.M., Mr. Holley introduced into evidence the packaging for commerical copies of OS/2. Advertising copy on the box states, "IBM's WebExplorer is built in," and "Internet access has been integrated into OS/2 Warp."
"Why does it say that?" Mr. Holley asked.
Mr. Soyring replied that the phrases were marketing language, not an accurate technological description. Unlike Internet Explorer, he added, Web Explorer can be loaded into an OS/2 computer, and taken out again, without impairing the functioning of the operating system.
Still, Mr. Holley's questions, and similar questions he asked an Apple Computer executive early this month, may prove useful in showing that many other companies believe that including a Web browser along with an operating system is a useful and even essential marketing step.

HEADLINE: Guggenheim Plans a Branch At the Hudson

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL and CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is quietly developing plans for a large new branch to be designed by the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry and built at the Hudson River on Pier 40 off Houston Street, said people who were consulted on the project.
The proposed museum, part of a growing empire of Guggenheim outposts, including those in Spain and Germany, would be built on state land in the middle of a new shorefront state park, a short walk to Chelsea or SoHo, Manhattan's two major art centers. It would be the first major museum building to rise in the city since the Whitney in 1966 and perhaps the biggest change in the West Side skyline since the $500 million glass-sheathed New York Convention Center opened in 1986. 
 Like all projects affecting the ecology of the Hudson River, the museum would face extensive Federal, state and local review. Approval from the Army Corps of Engineers would be required if the building were to extend beyond the pier and into the river.
Mr. Gehry also designed the striking and highly acclaimed $100 million museum that the Guggenheim opened a year ago in Bilbao, Spain. The museum, with its rakish silhouette, sweeping curves and titanium skin, attracts more than 1.4 million visitors and millions of dollars in the last year to the old Basque riverfront city.
The proposed new museum in Manhattan could cost four times as much, with some prospective donors already offering support, people at the museum said. It would allow the Guggenheim to exhibit more of its permanent holdings of modern art as well as new collections and to greatly expand its programming, beefing up areas like photography, architecture and video.
Mr. Gehry and Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director, declined to discuss the project yesterday. Other officials at the museum said it was simply an idea in the early stages of development. Mr. Gehry, however, has already produced architectural drawings for the building.
The museum has also assembled figures on the project's economic benefits, claiming that in the first two years of operation, the new museum would generate $1 billion in tax revenues, extra tourism and employment for the city and state.
City and state officials said they had not yet been consulted, although Mr. Krens was said to have held a preliminary discussion about it with Gov. George E. Pataki in EastHampton last summer. Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for the Governor, did not respond to calls about the matter.
Pier 40 is, at nearly 15 acres, the largest pier jutting into the Hudson on Manhattan's West Side, sitting amid the new five-mile Hudson River Park established by the State Legislature and signed into law by Governor Pataki on Sept. 8. Work on the 500-acre park, which runs from Battery Park City to 59th Street, has just begun and is scheduled to last until 2003 at a cost of up to $390 million. Pier 40, on state-owned land, is now occupied by a three-story 2,200-car garage, in the shape of an oblong donut, which also has soccer fields on the roof and some areas for community use inside.
It is not yet clear how the museum would fit into the lengthy sliver park and the anticipated commercial development projects planned for as many as 19 renovated piers within the park area. Community leaders questioned about the museum's plan said it was the first they had heard of it and that they would not want the museum to supplant or dominate an important segment of the park.
The park, now controlled by a 13-member state-city trust, grew out of the long-disputed highway plan Westway, the multibillion-dollar sunken roadway that was to have run along the Hudson, but which was defeated in a concerted campaign by local opponents who cited environmental concerns.
People who have spoken with Mr. Krens said that the project has already been promised substantial private support from at least one trustee of the Guggenheim, Peter B. Lewis. Mr. Lewis, the new chairman of the Guggenheim Foundation and chairman and chief executive of the Progressive Corporation, a Cleveland-based insurance company, made an unrelated cash pledge of $50 million to the Guggenheim in April. Reached by phone, Mr. Lewis said he would not discuss the new project.
Mr. Lewis has long been close to Mr. Gehry, who worked for more than five years with Mr. Lewis on a $30 million house in Cleveland before the project was shelved several years ago. It was Mr. Gehry who introduced Mr. Krens to Mr. Lewis, who became a trustee of the Guggenheim in 1993.
If the new museum is built, people at the museum said, the Guggenheim would probably close its six-year-old branch on the corner of Broadway and Prince Street in SoHo. The outpost in SoHo has been a financial drain on the institution, reportedly incurring losses close to $40 million up to now.
Under Mr. Krens, who has led the museum for 11 years, the Guggenheim has embarked on a series of bold expansions.
Besides Bilbao, which has been hailed by critics as one of the most important works of architecture in the 20th-century and has already generated $219 million of revenue as well as $35 million in new tax revenue for the long-neglected industrial city on the Nervion River, it also opened a 7,000-square-foot exhibition space in Berlin on the ground floor of the newly renovated Deutsche Bank on the Unter den Linden, near the Brandenburg Gate.
Besides these completed projects, Mr. Krens has had ambitions for a Guggenheim presence in cities like Paris and Salzburg. But neither of the sites he had in mind for these cities has worked out.
Three years ago Mr. Krens announced that the Guggenheim was planning to open three new museum sites in Venice. (The museum already operates the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in the Palazzo Venier dei Leoni on Venice's Grand Canal.) But progress on these projects is moving slowly, Guggenheim officials said.
Floating an unusual $54 million bond issue, Mr. Krens also directed a sweeping $58 million renovation and expansion of the museum's landmark Frank Lloyd Wright structure on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street. And he opened the Guggenheim branch in SoHo in 1992.
Plans for the new branch in Manhattan have been so closely held that they did not come up on Monday night at a small private dinner of Guggenheim trustees and patrons to mark the election of Mr. Lewis as foundation chairman, one participant said.
Mr. Krens was said to have broached the plan last summer with Governor Pataki at the East Hampton home of Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of Revlon and the former president of the Guggenheim. Mr. Perelman would not discuss it, said a spokesman, Jim Conroy.
The state's economic development arm, the Empire State Development Corporation, has not been advised of any plans, said a spokesman for its chairman, Charles A. Gargano.
Asked whether he had been advised of the plan, Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, referred the question to City Hall. A spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Jennifer Chait, said the administration had not been contacted, but "we're always willing to listen to ideas."
Alan Jay Gerson, chairman of Community Board 2, covering SoHo and Greenwich Village, said no word of the project had circulated in the community. Mr. Gerson, who is also chairman of the waterways committee of the advisory panel to the Hudson River Park Conservancy, which planned the new park, said that a design competition had recently produced many proposals for the pier, but that the Guggenheim's was not among them.
The results will be discussed at a forum in January, he said. "I hope if the Guggenheim is serious, it will participate in this forum," he said.
"No one is against a wonderful art museum," Mr. Gerson said.
But he said the community would not want to sacrifice its park space. At any rate, he said, there might be any number of other sites to consider.

HEADLINE: Paying for Mideast Plan, U.S. Walks Tightrope

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton is promising Israel and the Palestinian Authority to pick up much of the bill for their new land-for-security plan. But buying peace will not be cheap, or easy.
The House Republican leadership change means that Congressional scrutiny could be more acute than originally anticipated. Israel's new aid request raises potential diplomatic problems, as the United States runs the risk of subsidizing roads to Jewish West Bank settlements. And greatly increasing aid to the Palestinians poses financial and political difficulties, American officials say. 
As the Clinton Administration weighs the Israeli and Palestinian requests, it is striving to insure that the entire aid package strengthens rather than further complicates its role as a mediator.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to seek up to $1 billion for pulling Israeli forces out of the West Bank, over and above the $2.9 billion in military and economic aid already earmarked for Israel this fiscal year. The new request comes just as Congress has reduced assistance to Israel for the first time in decades, cutting its yearly economic support check to $1.08 billion, from $1.2 billion, the beginning of what was announced as a 10-year phase-out of nonmilitary aid.
And Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, says he believes he has a green light to solicit as much as $300 million in new American assistance -- a big jump in American aid to Palestinian-controlled Gaza and the West Bank, which has been kept at $75 million annually for the last five years.
Until recently, Congressional approval did not seem much at issue. The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, and the minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, had signaled readiness to provide substantial new assistance. But as the Appropriations Committee chairman, Representative Robert Livingston, now assured of becoming Mr. Gingrich's successor, was one of the few Congressional leaders who has publicly questioned economic aid to Israel. Congressional critics of Mr. Arafat, meanwhile, are likely to try to continue to block direct bilateral-style aid.
The Clinton Administration has not yet disclosed the full scope of its new appropriation request, which represents the fulfillment of a pledge by the President to help underwrite the costs of the interim peace accord negotiated last month in Wye, Md.
"The Administration is considering the details of a package which will address Israeli security requirements relating to Wye and Palestinian economic needs," Jim Foley, a State Department spokesman, said last Friday. "We are planning to consult with the Hill on this package."
Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and the Palestinian negotiator Mahmoud Abbas met at Israel's Foreign Ministry in Jerusalem today to discuss an agenda for full-scale talks on a final peace treaty. The talks are expected to begin by the end of the month.
While the expected American aid package will spotlight the large and widening gap between aid to Israel and aid to the Palestinians, irking some of Mr. Arafat's supporters, Palestinian economic officials hope that it will institutionalize American economic support of the kind Egypt has enjoyed since its 1979 peace treaty with Israel.
After the Oslo self-rule agreement in 1993, the United States announced a five-year, $500 million economic aid package for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip: $375 million in grants from the Agency for International Development and $125 million in loan guarantees for new local American business ventures from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.
The promised AID money was mostly spent -- the bulk of it on wells, sewage systems and other water installations -- but OPIC has provided just $6 million in the last five years. "We cannot undertake any assistance without a willing private investor," said Lawrence Spinelli, a spokesman for the investment corporation.
From all international sources, the Palestinian Authority was promised $4.2 billion in foreign assistance in the five years following Oslo, but received just $2.5 billion, most of it from Western Europe.
Over the same five-year period, Israel collected $15.3 billion in military and economic support from the United States, Palestinians note.
The Clinton Administration will gather international donors in Washington later this month to present a new aid pledge for Palestinian-controlled areas. The Palestinians hope that the meeting will nearly double international aid outlays, to $800 million or $900 million yearly, said Anis al-Qaq, who supervises Palestinian aid receipts as Deputy Minister of Planning and International Cooperation.
Israel gets economic aid in a yearly lump sum. "We basically just send a check," an American diplomat said. By contrast, all grants in areas governed by the Palestinian Authority go to specific projects supervised by a 60-member Agency for International Development office in Tel Aviv -- strictures imposed in part to avoid any inference that Washington is treating Mr. Arafat's administration as a sovereign entity.
"We are hoping for more symmetry between the aid we receive and what Israel receives," Mr. Qaq said. "We should be treated equally as to procedures and amounts for comparable projects."
Support for the Palestinians comes in the form of development assistance aimed at an impoverished population widely lacking jobs and basic public services.
The Israeli request is expected to be presented as a military-aid package, though some funds would be slotted for roads and other projects not exclusively linked to security. The biggest item will be the relocation of West Bank military installations -- some quite extensive.
Most Israeli analysts consider those expenses essential. The Israeli military is preparing estimates for "the costs of transferring Israeli Defense Force bases, of bypass roads, and of community security systems," said Dan Weinreich, chief spokesman for the Defense Ministry.
The most contentious financing issue is the widening network of bypass roads, circuitously linking isolated Jewish settlements in Palestinian-governed territory and Israeli-controlled fragments of the West Bank with each other and with Israel proper.
After the vote to approve the Wye withdrawal pact, the Israeli Cabinet gave the go-ahead for 12 new bypass routes serving settlements that will now be left as enclaves within autonomous Palestinian territory. The proposed 1999 budget, now being debated in the Israeli Parliament, had already called for a tripling of annual spending on bypass roads, to $28 million.
Avoiding the hearts and often even the periphery of local towns and villages, this emerging parallel road system enables Israeli motorists to traverse the West Bank with little or no contact with Palestinian residents. The roads also speed access to and from Israeli military bases.
Critics contend the bypass roads are leaching money away from public works within Israel's borders and entrenching settlements they oppose. A recent opinion poll commissioned by Washington showed most Israelis opposing further spending to support Jewish settlements deep inside the West Bank.
The road-building program is even more politically fraught for the Palestinian Authority. The bypasses almost invariably involve expropriations of Palestinian property, followed quickly by home demolitions, the forcible expulsion of local residents and angry street protests led by Mr. Arafat's Palestinian opponents.
Israeli military officers persuaded the Netanyahu Government last week to hold off on one planned route through a Palestinian refugee camp, warning that land seizures there could provoke violence and disrupt the Wye-mandated troop redeployments.
Still, Mr. Netanyahu has said that it is "as clear as daylight" that putting into effect the new peace accords would accelerate land seizures for new bypass projects.

HEADLINE: A Village With Music In the Family, And in Class

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
While many public schools, struggling under budget constraints and competing academic interests, are marginalizing arts programs, if not eliminating them altogether, the opposite is happening in the small village of Greenport at the tip of the North Fork on Long Island.
Early next year, under the leadership of David E. Kapell, the Mayor of Greenport since 1994, a new program will bring classical music to the 600 students in the town's single public school. Mr. Kapell's support for classical music comes not just from his belief in the value of the arts but also from his personal history. He is the son of the pianist William Kapell, who died in a plane crash in 1953 when he was just 31 and at the peak of acclaim. At the time, David Kapell was 4. 
 Mr. Kapell's mission has been aided by another Greenport resident, John Serkin, also the son of a famous pianist. Mr. Serkin, the third of Rudolf Serkin's six children and a onetime French horn player, is now a piano technician and tuner and serves on the village's Arts and Culture Committee. He was instrumental in working out the details of the new arts program, which will bring students from the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia to classrooms in Greenport, where they will discuss and perform music. Rudolf Serkin, who died in 1991, was a longtime director of the Curtis Institute.
To raise money for the program, Mr. Serkin has solicited the help of his younger brother, the pianist Peter Serkin, who is to play a benefit recital on Sunday at 2 P.M. in the Greenport School Auditorium. Mr. Serkin will perform on a grand piano provided by Steinway & Sons in Manhattan. With this gesture, the company is both supporting the educational initiative and honoring the memory of two major pianists who were exclusive Steinway artists.
The piano, valued at $50,000, is essentially being lent to the school, though the term the company prefers to describe the arrangement is "long-term placement." It will be moved to the auditorium for Mr. Serkin's recital but will be kept permanently in a new wing of the village's Floyd Memorial Library, where the Curtis students will present concerts in conjunction with their work in the classrooms.
"We couldn't be more grateful," Mr. Kapell said recently, speaking of the Steinway company's and Peter Serkin's contributions. "The arts program in Greenport has been minimal, if anything. Our kids were missing cultural expansion, which is a shame."
The program has two goals: nurturing aspiring musicians and developing appreciation and audiences for the arts. The response, Mr. Kapell said, is "really surprising" and "very encouraging." The hall, which seats more than 700, is sold out for Sunday's concert, and the waiting list for tickets is approaching 100.
"It's overwhelmingly local people who are coming, people who live within 10 miles of the village," Mr. Kapell said.
And, thanks to benefactors who contributed $500 each, at least 150 seats will be occupied free by students from nearby school districts.
The Mayor described Greenport as a "true blue-collar town, fundamentally," though this "belies the broader demographics" of the area and its small, stable and diverse economy. Local industries include fishing, wineries, retail and tourism. While the population of the incorporated village is 2,100, the school serves a district of 5,000 residents.
John Serkin has been tuning the piano and voicing it (adjusting the density of the felt hammerheads for sound quality) in preparation for his brother's recital.
"David Kapell and I had the good fortune to have four pianos in the Steinway showroom to choose from," Mr. Serkin said. "Three were brand new, but we picked the one that was three years old, and it's fantastic, one of the nicest model B's I've ever worked on."
He added that his brother's benefit recital should generate enough money to support the music program for a full three years.
In choosing the works he will play, Peter Serkin has devised a substantive and varied program, including shorter pieces by Chopin, Debussy and Messiaen; recent works by Gyorgy Kurtag and George Benjamin; Schoenberg's Piano Suite, Op. 25 (a challenging 12-tone work that Mr. Serkin plays vibrantly), and, in the second half, Mozart's Sonata K. 332 and Beethoven's "Les Adieu" Sonata.
"We can't wait," the Mayor said. "The students are excited. You never know where the next great musician is going to come from. It could be Greenport."

GRAPHIC: Photo: They know a fine way: Mayor David E. Kapell of Greenport, N.Y., left, and John Serkin admire the village's new Steinway grand piano. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)
