HEADLINE: Handshake on Deal to Move Patriots to Hartford

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 19

 BODY:
A team owner spurned at home and an eager Governor next door shook hands today, promising the New England Patriots a new home in downtown Hartford and infusing Connecticut's blighted capital with big-league cachet. Gov. John G. Rowland agreed to build a $350 million football stadium for the Patriots' owner, Robert K. Kraft, who said he felt the Massachusetts Legislature had been too stingy with him.
The deal has been under way behind the scenes for months but arrived with almost no public prelude, adding to the sense of unreality among Hartford officials, who have sought and lost so many smaller projects. About 200 of Hartford's business and government leaders packed into the stained-glass splendor of a ceremonial hall at the Connecticut Capitol, applauding with a sustained rhythm that sounded like rowdy fans when their team is first-and-goal. 
 "I can't tell you what it means to me to get that kind of warm reception from a community," Mr. Kraft said, in a pointed reference to political battles in Boston as he tried and failed to win a huge state subsidy for a new stadium near the Patriots' current home in Foxboro, Mass. That stadium, built 27 years ago, is considered to be inaccessible and unattractive and lacks many of the amenities of a modern park.
Today, Mr. Kraft joked that he had driven from Boston to Hartford in the same time it took him to get out of the parking lot at Foxboro Stadium. And later, he apologized for choking up as the crowd erupted in yet another wave of cheers. "You really overwhelmed me," he said.
The deal -- which would be financed by bonds and paid off through stadium revenues -- must be approved by the Connecticut Legislature. But leaders of both houses took the podium today to promise quick passage. As part of the 18-page agreement, Mr. Kraft said he would not negotiate with any other state between now and Dec. 31. Mr. Kraft was required to deposit $2 million in escrow, which he would forfeit if he began negotiations with another state.
If the state fails to pass the stadium proposal by Dec. 31, the $2 million, plus interest, is to be returned to Mr. Kraft.
Mr. Rowland, who has failed to close several other major deals he has championed publicly, said he insisted on the escrow payment and exclusive negotiating window in an effort to avoid being used as leverage in Mr. Kraft's negotiations with Massachusetts lawmakers.
Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci of Massachusetts said he spoke with Mr. Kraft late Wednesday night, and said he did not see any way to prevent the move. "I believe the Patriots belong in Massachusetts," Mr. Cellucci said in an interview in New Orleans, where he is attending the Republican Governors Association meeting. "However, there was a difference of opinion in the Legislature on this point, and it appears that that difference is insurmountable."
The 68,000-seat stadium would be part of a $1 billion development on the Connecticut River that is to include a convention center, a hotel and sports stores. The site is now home to parking lots, blocky buildings and a steam plant.
The team, which has played in the Boston area since 1960, is scheduled to move to Hartford in the fall of 2001, and Mr. Kraft has committed to staying for 30 years. Twenty-four of the National Football League's 31 teams would have to approve any move by the Patriots.
The stadium is to include 125 to 150 luxury boxes and 6,000 club seats, and is envisioned as the centerpiece of Adriaen's Landing, a redevelopment project that was already planned near the intersection of Interstates 84 and 91.
The complex was to include a 35,000-seat stadium for the University of Connecticut. Under the deal announced today, UConn will play in the proposed stadium.
Mr. Rowland billed Mr. Kraft as "a partner" in Hartford's renewal. Under the agreement, the Patriots are to invest $75 million in downtown, including $50 million for a hotel for the convention center, $20 million for a retail and entertainment pavilion and $5 million for a fitness center. The team will move its headquarters to Hartford and, within one year of the stadium's opening, will move its practice field to Connecticut.
Mayor Michael P. Peters of Hartford hailed the team's plans, but said some people still had reservations about whether the city was being used to force the hand of Massachusetts lawmakers. "Two million dollars is nothing -- it doesn't lock anybody in," he said. "But I think Mr. Kraft is very sincere about coming here."
Despite the euphoria that greeted the news here, some experts were skeptical about the wisdom of abandoning Boston for the nation's 27th largest television market, 28th largest state and 37th largest metropolitan area.
Mark S. Rosentraub, a professor of public affairs at Indiana University who specializes in sports economics, said the plan posed "a grave risk" for Connecticut. He said many Connecticut residents were fans of the New York Giants, and he questioned how many current Patriots fans would drive from the Boston area year after year -- especially if some are bitter about the team's departure, or if the team or the economy slump. "Connecticut is too small, and already has split loyalties," he said. "It all rests on the Boston market accepting the move."
Several Democratic legislators also raised questions about the administration's projections for attendance and revenue. The revenue projections were based on the assumption that home games would be consistent sellouts. The Senate majority leader, George C. Jepsen, acknowledged that some members think "the numbers may not quite be there," but said the expected impact on the region would lead most members to support the proposal.
"An N.F.L. team is one of the very things that, overnight, will turn around the image of Hartford as a city in decline," he said.
The state would finance the stadium by selling bonds, which would be paid back through a 10 percent tax on tickets, snacks and parking revenue from the stadium. Although officials emphasized that taxes would not rise to finance the stadium, taxpayers could ultimately be liable if revenue fell short.
As the two men sat side by side behind a long table as if contemplating a peace treaty, Mr. Rowland signed first and then glanced back at the document after Mr. Kraft took his turn. "Just double-checking," Mr. Rowland said with a chuckle. Mr. Kraft handed him a football, autographed by the team.
Standing beside a color drawing of the proposed stadium, Mr. Rowland said that with today's announcement, the state would stop talking about redeveloping the worn core of Hartford and start doing it. "A state is defined by its capital city, and today we have a chance to define ourselves," Mr. Rowland said. "Twenty-four million people per year drive by and drive through Hartford. The idea here is to get some of them to stop. We want to be more than a mile marker between Boston and New York."
Mr. Kraft said he turned to Connecticut in frustration after years of unsuccessful effort to win the subsidies he wanted from the Massachusetts Legislature for a new stadium. He reached an agreement with the State Senate that would have required him to spend $200 million, with the state contributing $72 million. But House leaders would approve only $57 million, which Mr. Kraft said killed the deal.
"Massachusetts has had over 35 years to try to solve this problem and has been unable to do it," he said.
"Some of you might be uncomfortable with this move," he said. "We had no opportunity to solve our problem in the near term. If the city of Hartford and the people of this state had not gotten together and come up with this, our family would have to put this team up for sale."
He said that for viewers and fans, "nothing changes: the New England Patriots will be able to stay in this region -- please, God -- for the next 30 years, and we're going to bring a championship home."
He later said he was confident that he would retain many of his current fans, in part because 40 percent of the Patriots' season ticket holders live outside Massachusetts -- most of them in Rhode Island, Connecticut and the Albany area.
Boston television reporters trailed Mr. Kraft through the Capitol, asking him repeatedly if there were any way the team would remain in Boston. "We're not considering other options now," he said flatly. He noted that Connecticut had until the end of the year to begin implementing its part of the agreement. "If they do it," he said, "we're coming here."

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: While Boston Points Fingers, Hartford Claps Hands in Glee;
Failure of Political Leadership Is Seen

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:

In Boston, the saying goes, there are only three things that count: sports, politics and revenge. And the announcement today that the New England Patriots will leave suburban Boston to play in Hartford combines all three, revealing that underneath the sheen of its economic boom, Boston is often still a city of tribal neighborhoods and vendettas without strong leadership.
"Today is not our finest hour," said Chad Gifford, the chairman and chief executive of BankBoston, who is also the head of Boston's Chamber of Commerce and a close friend of the Patriots' owner, Robert K. Kraft. 
 "Boston is a great city, from our history to our cultural institutions to our geography by the water," Mr. Gifford said. "But there was a good opportunity here for the city, and sometimes we are so proud, it verges on arrogance."
The loss of the Patriots to Hartford, 38 years after they played the first game in the old American Football League here against the Denver Broncos, is being blamed largely on one man, Thomas M. Finneran, the Speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives. Mr. Finneran seemed to make it a personal crusade to stop Mr. Kraft, whom he at one point referred to as a "whiny billionaire," from getting state financing to help build a new stadium in Foxboro, where the team now plays, even though Mr. Kraft had proposed putting up $200 million of his own money to pay the bulk of the cost.
Today, on WEEI-AM, a sports talk radio station, Mr. Finneran said he would not mind if his role in driving the Patriots out of Massachusetts was "chiseled on my gravestone." One caller to the radio station said Mr. Finneran's actions were "immoral."
But in the view of many sports fans, real estate developers and other politicians, there was enough blame to go around.
Former Gov. William F. Weld and the newly elected governor, Paul Cellucci, had both promised to help Mr. Kraft get the government financing to keep the team in Massachusetts. They failed. So, too, did Mayor Thomas M. Menino, who last year blocked a plan by Mr. Kraft to build a privately financed stadium in South Boston after opposition from neighborhood groups.
Mayor Menino said he was disappointed the Patriots were moving to Hartford, but he did not sound deeply troubled. "If it was the Red Sox, I'd be concerned," he said.
The Patriots have not played in Boston itself in years, Mr. Menino said, whereas the Red Sox play 81 games a year at Fenway Park and have a big impact on the city's restaurants and hotels.
The Red Sox are also trying to build a new ball park to replace Fenway, the smallest and next-to-oldest baseball stadium in the nation, but they too have so far been unable to come up with a plan that will satisfy neighborhood groups. Although Fenway Park remains one of the best places to watch a baseball game, it is simply too small and outdated to generate the revenues needed to compete with teams like the Yankees.
Football fans were despondent and rejected Mr. Kraft's contention that he was keeping the Patriots in New England, close enough for them to still go to games. "If it was going to be the Providence Patriots, I would view it differently," said Steve Doran, a marketing consultant in Hingham and a former season ticket holder. "But I think of Hartford as being a bedroom community for New York, Giants country. I don't even think of Connecticut as being part of New England."
Mr. Finneran did not return phone calls to his office today. But on WEEI radio he blamed Mr. Kraft's greed for the move. "Why are the owners of pro sports teams entitled to hundreds of millions of dollars?" he asked. "Entertainment is not a public responsibility."
But the State Senate President, Thomas F. Birmingham, like Mr. Finneran a Democrat, said he was "befuddled" by Mr. Finneran's position. Under Mr. Birmingham, the Senate last spring approved a bill, by a 36-to-1 vote, to provide $70 million in state money to improve roads and highway ramps as part of Mr. Kraft's plan to build a new stadium in Foxboro.
Mr. Finneran rejected that as too generous, and the bill failed in the House, even though Mr. Birmingham said the proposal was the "stingiest" government support in the nation for the construction of a new professional sports stadium.
The bottom line, Mr. Birmingham said, is that the Patriots contribute $10 million a year in payroll taxes to Massachusetts, and his bill would have involved an expenditure of $2.3 million a year in government money. Now the state will lose $7.7 million a year. "How can this be justified in the name of fiscal responsibility?" he asked.

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Ability to Sell Luxury Seats Is Called Key To Success

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The New England Patriots' proposed move from the Boston area to the much smaller Hartford market could make the team much richer, but only if the team can sell out the luxury seating planned for a 68,000-seat stadium, stadium experts say.
The proposed $350 million stadium would have 125 to 150 luxury suites, and 6,000 club seats, which typically feature comfortable chairs and waiter service. Luxury suites typically cost $50,000 to $100,000 for a home season of eight league games and two exhibition games. Club seats can range from $1,000 to several thousand dollars a season. 
 But the Hartford market, which saw the Whalers hockey team leave last year for North Carolina, is the 27th largest in the country, with 915,770 households, according to Nielsen Media Research. The Boston market has nearly 2.2 million households. "That's an immense amount of luxury seating for that market to absorb," said Mark S. Rosentraub, director of the Center for Urban Policy and the Environment at Indiana University. "The real downside is if they can't sell it all and need an extra state subsidy."
A move to Hartford would add another National Football League team to the ranks of those that have moved to smaller markets in the 1990's, drawn by the lure of stadium leases that confer almost all the revenue upon the team. The Rams and Raiders left the Los Angeles area, the second largest market, for St. Louis, the No. 21 market, and Oakland, which is part of the No. 5 market, respectively. The Oilers were lured to Tennessee from Houston, the 11th largest market, and will start the 1999 season in a new stadium in Nashville, the No. 33 market.
And the Cleveland Browns' owner took the team from the 13th largest market to Baltimore, the 23d largest. The newly named Ravens play in a stadium paid for largely through state lottery proceeds.
The Raiders' return to Oakland has been fraught with difficulties in selling luxury seating and season tickets. But the other moves have been largely successful because they tapped into a fan base hungry for a first crack at pro football, like Nashville, or eager to get a team back, like Baltimore, whose Colts bolted for Indianapolis in 1984.
"Going to Hartford is really trading down," said Mr. Rosentraub, who added that a concern for the Patriots should be whether it can continue to tap into the corporate wealth of the Boston market for luxury seating while playing 85 miles away in Hartford.
Robert Kraft, the team's owner, said renters of the 35 luxury suites in the Patriots' stadium, in Foxboro, Mass., are scattered across the region. But the Hartford suites would be more plentiful and more expensive, requiring the team to draw a broader, wealthier clientele.
"The 25-mile radius around Hartford isn't that strong, but when you expand it to 75 miles it's better," said Marc Ganis, the president of SportsCorp Ltd., a Chicago-based consulting firm. "If they can tap into Fairfield County, with its Fortune 100 headquarters, to sell luxury suites and club seats, that would be a big plus. But it's a big challenge."
Mr. Kraft, who bought the Patriots nearly five years ago, declined to say whether he had received any guarantees to lease the luxury suites. But he said: "We think we'll be able to sell the luxury suites out before the stadium is finished. We've done the studies. We feel the location can support the stadium."
Dean Bonham, head of the Bonham Group, based in Denver, said: "You can have a $350 million stadium, 150 luxury boxes and a sweet lease, but if not enough people show up, you have a problem. I hope they're doing good market research on the fan base."
The proposed Patriots-Hartford deal is a wrinkle in the game of threats and cajolery that team owners play, pitting city against city for the best stadium deal. Mr. Kraft wanted to stay in his region -- he even wanted to use his own money to build a stadium in South Boston, which is rare among owners -- but got caught in the politicking in the Massachusetts Legislature and found a nicer reception in Connecticut. "If we couldn't solve this problem for New England, I'd have to put the team up for sale, which I didn't want to do," he said.
By being lured to Hartford with a plan that requires him to pay only 10 percent of gross revenues, Mr. Kraft could reap a windfall like those being received by teams in new stadiums, raising his stadium income to between $20 million and $30 million.
Mr. Bonham said that the Connecticut agreement could be the leverage Mr. Kraft needs to stay in Massachusetts. If Mr. Kraft tried to move elsewhere between now and Dec. 31, he would forfeit $2 million now in escrow. "The $2 million would be an inexpensive price for a deal in Massachusetts," Mr. Bonham said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 32; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Revving Up Japan

 BODY:
Of all the economic events of the 1990's, the decline of Japan's financial colossus was perhaps the least expected. A decade ago the Japanese appeared to be in command of the most successful economy in the world. Now, as President Clinton concludes his Tokyo visit, it is hard to be optimistic about the financial condition and future of the world's second-largest economy. 
 Japan has recently done much better at announcing economic repair plans than putting them into effect. The Government's $195 billion economic stimulus package -- including money that is to be given to people on condition that it be spent, not saved -- got a tepid reception in part because of doubts about details and whether the Government will follow through on its promises. Even if it does, more is likely to be needed. Structural reforms must be made to promote competition, and Japan's banking mess must be dealt with.
Japan continues to run big trade surpluses, and is a very rich economy. But wealth has not kept it out of a severe recession. Savings are high and consumer spending is low. Many of the problems stem from the bubble economy of the late 1980's, when stock and real estate prices soared beyond all reason. The collapse left Japanese financial institutions mired in bad debts that were long ignored.
Although the Government has set aside money for bank bailouts -- and two major banks yesterday said they would need more than $7 billion -- little has so far been accomplished. Japanese banks are reluctant to lend money except to the safest borrowers, producing a lethal combination of credit crunch and recession.
To be fair, Japan faces a difficult task in dealing with its banking system. The problem was caused by banks that lent too willingly. But the country's economic problems now are being exacerbated by the opposite problem as banks refuse to lend. Japan must close banks that are insolvent while providing additional capital to other banks to enable them to lend money to creditworthy companies. Unfortunately, the Japanese Government has yet to show it can accomplish that delicate balancing act.
Some economists argue that Japan is now in a liquidity trap, in which worried consumers hoard rather than spend any increase in the money supply. They say Japan must adopt a policy of promoting inflation so that consumers spend for fear that the yen they save will be worth less next year.
Such dire forecasts may be right, but it is also possible that bold action would make a difference. It is encouraging that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, as part of a deal to bring an opposition party into his Government, agreed to consider tax cuts. It would also be wise for Japan to reduce its resistance to imports. An Asia-Pacific trade liberalization plan was scuttled by Japan's refusal to lower tariffs on fish and forest products. Such protection is one of the factors depressing domestic demand and slowing Japan's economy. As President Clinton said, "Nothing is more important to restore growth in Asia than efforts to restart Japan's economy."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns Japan to Keep Its Markets Open to U.S. Goods

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 20

 BODY:
President Clinton warned Japan today that the United States might feel pressure to restrict some markets if the American trade deficit keeps rising and Japan continues to limit American imports.
He also suggested that a $195 billion package of tax cuts and new spending announced by the Government here on Monday might not be enough to revive Japan's economy. "The people here may conclude that even more must be done to jolt the economy back into growth," he said in a speech to the American Chamber of Commerce here. 
 Mr. Clinton said that as the Asian financial crisis spread he decided to do "everything we could to leave America's markets as open as possible," although he knew that lower-priced goods from Asia would cause the American trade deficit to grow.
But, he warned, "if there is a perception of unfair trade," public support in the United States for open markets could disappear. He cited as an example the surge this year in imports of Japanese steel, which has dismayed the American steel industry and unions.
"And if you put that against an inability to open more markets," he said, it will "create in our country the potential for a retrenchment here in a way that will not be good for Asia or Japan, or for the United States over the long run."
At the annual Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, held last weekend in Malaysia, efforts to proceed with economic liberalization in nine sectors collapsed in the face of Japan's refusal to open its timber and fishing markets out of deference to its powerful rural political constituencies. "We wish that they had been more forthcoming on all nine areas," Mr. Clinton said during his speech, his first direct reference to the dispute.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said he planned to deliver a similar message, if a softer one, in meetings later today with Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi.
As Mr. Clinton presses Japan to revive the economy, he is notably short of either carrots or sticks. He took a new tack today in suggesting that the American free-trade policy was in effect an act of generosity toward ailing Asian economies -- and could be reversed.
The President tried to present himself as reluctantly compelled to inform Japan of the risk of a change in American political sentiment, saying "I want this mostly to be a good-news speech."
And he said he understood that in every society there are certain industries that are "especially sensitive to trade-opening initiatives."
He said even wealthy societies "face a constant conflict between the desire to get the aggregate benefit of an open economy and the gnawing fear that it will not be possible to maintain the social contract in the face of global economics."
The Administration has so far reacted coolly to the Japanese Government's stimulus package. Suggesting a certain skepticism, the President said the speed with which it is carried out will determine whether it was successful. Citing the American experience with the collapse of its savings and loans, he said, "Delay in a crisis like this only makes matters worse."
He also called for vigorous enactment of Mr. Obuchi's plan for reforming Japan's banking system, which has suffered from an inbred network of weak loans that were often made for political and personal reasons, rather than for economic ones.

HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley Will Build Glass Tower Near Times Sq.

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company signed a deal yesterday to build a million-square-foot office tower on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, creating a pinstriped corporate campus in what was once the unlikeliest of locations: the Times Square area.
The planned 33-story glass skyscraper, tentatively named Morgan Stanley Dean Witter Plaza, would be the giant financial service company's third building at the northern end of the Times Square area, where peep shows and T-shirt shops have given way to new theaters, restaurants, hotels and MTV. The tower would rise on what is now a parking lot. 
 Morgan Stanley signed an agreement yesterday afternoon with the current landowner, the Rockefeller Group, after 11 months of on-again, off-again negotiations. Under the terms of the deal, the tower would be developed as a joint venture of Morgan Stanley and the Rockefeller Group, a subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Estate Company.
Designed by Kohn Pederson Fox, the new tower would be the latest element of a building boom that has swept through Times Square. The Planet Hollywood Hotel is under construction at the southwest corner of Broadway and 48th Street, along with movie theaters, theme restaurants and a Madame Tussaud's museum on 42d Street. Douglas Durst, the developer, is completing the first new office tower in Manhattan since 1992, on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets.
Two other towers may soon loom over Times Square as well. Bertelsmann A.G. is inching closer to a deal to build a new home for Random House at Broadway and 45th Street and the newly combined Nasdaq and American Stock Exchange may build a headquarters and trading floor at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas.
"Times Square has become a center for financial, legal and entertainment companies," said Peter Riguardi, executive vice president of Colliers ABR, a real estate broker that represented Morgan Stanley.
The new Morgan Stanley tower will sit across the street from the investment bank's building at 750 Seventh Avenue and only a block north of the company's 43-story headquarters at 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets.
The design for the building is nearing the end of the city's land use review process, although Morgan Stanley may revise the plans and begin the process again. The tower would include retail stores at the base, an entrance to the subway, a plaza with a large reflecting pool and the kind of large neon signs required in the Times Square district. Morgan Stanley's headquarters is festooned with a three-line stock ticker.
Like many financial institutions, Morgan Stanley moved to midtown in the 1970's from lower Manhattan. In 1995, the company moved to two empty skyscrapers in Times Square with almost 6,000 employees. An additional 1,500 workers will move to the new tower when Morgan Stanley's lease at the McGraw-Hill Building at 1221 Avenue of the Americas expires in 2002.
"This project will insure that our firm continues to provide an unparalleled level of service to our clients," John J. Mack, president of Morgan Stanley, said in a statement last night.
In the last two years, Morgan Stanley has been joined by Disney and Viacom, as well as the Proskauer Rose law firm. Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and Conde Nast Publications are moving in next year.
The new Morgan Stanley tower, however, has been a long time in coming for the Rockefeller Group and Mitsubishi Estate, which lost a billion-dollar investment in the historic Rockefeller Center complex during the recession. The development company began buying the land for the project in the 1970's and gained approval for a skyscraper in 1990. But the real estate market soon plunged into a recession and in 1994 the site was turned into a parking lot.
The developer negotiated unsuccessfully with Bear, Stearns & Company and Guardian Life Insurance before opening talks in January with Morgan Stanley. The tower was originally envisioned as a sedate bookend to the Rockefeller Center complex. But the revised tower took its inspiration from the new vitality of the Times Square district to the south.
After negotiations between the two sides almost broke down in October, the Rockefeller Group opened talks with PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm that has been looking for a new home. But Morgan Stanley and the Rockefeller Group managed to put the deal back together and signed an agreement yesterday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CUTTING 1,040 JOBS AT 3 OFFICES

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation is cutting 1,040 jobs, or 25 percent of the staff at its various headquarters, as part of a plan to reduce costs by $200 million by 2000. The cuts will affect the corporate headquarters in Los Angeles; oil and gas offices in Bakersfield, Calif., and its chemicals-business headquarters in Dallas. The company said yesterday that it had already cut 540 of the positions. Like other oil companies, Occidental has felt the pressure of depressed oil prices, which are down at least 25 percent from levels a year ago, and of a decline in the petrochemicals business.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
WITH DEMAND FOR TRACTORS DOWN, DEERE PLANS LAYOFFS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Deere & Company, the world's largest farm-equipment maker, said yesterday that it would lay off about 2,400 workers for several weeks because of weakening demand in North America. Most employees at the company's Waterloo Works tractor plant in Waterloo, Iowa, will be laid off for two to three weeks in December. The plant will also extend its traditional weeklong holiday shutdown for an extra two weeks, through Jan. 19. Deere, based in Moline, Ill., and its competitors are scaling back production as crop prices slump. Deere's shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $39.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Minutes Show Concern Over Perception of Cuts
The Federal Reserve decided to limit its rate cut on Sept. 29 to a quarter of a percentage point because it was worried that a bigger reduction might exaggerate its concerns about the risks of an economic slowdown, according to minutes of the deliberations. 
 But just more than two weeks later, the central bank cut interest rates again by another quarter of a point between meetings despite continued concern among some members of the committee that the move would be interpreted as a signal that the central bank saw bad news on the horizon. C5.
 
Microsoft Accused of Lifting Prices
Microsoft has kept the price of personal computer software significantly higher than would be expected if the company faced real competition, an economic consultant testified at the software giant's antitrust trial. C2.
 
Livent Gets $5 Million in Loans
Some of Livent's wealthy board members came to the Broadway theater company's rescue, lending it $5 million, enough to keep the curtain up for 10 days. Meanwhile, the company's two founders, Garth H. Drabinsky, left, and Myron I. Gottlieb angrily disputed allegations made by Livent's new managers that the two men had engaged in a widespread corporate fraud. C6.
 
Asset-Management Unit Sold
Senior managers of Robertson Stephens Investment Management, the asset-management arm of the old Robertson, Stephens & Company, teamed up to buy the company from BankAmerica for an undisclosed price. C4.
 
Intel Demand Lifts Stock Market
Stocks rose, led by demand for Intel and MCI Worldcom. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.94 points, to 9,056.05. The S.& P. 500 rose 8.13 points, to 1,152.61, and the Nasdaq rose 22.24 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,919.68. In the bond market, prices rose as the yield on the 30-year Treasury fell to 5.23 percent. C8.
 
French authorities said the Paris stock exchange would join an alliance between London and Frankfurt that is seen as the precursor of a pan-European market. C6.
 
Entergy to Buy Nuclear Reactor
Entergy, a major utility company in the South, emerged as the winning buyer in the first multiple-bid auction for an American nuclear power plant, a 26-year-old reactor in Massachusetts that sold for $80 million in cash. C2.
 
American Airlines to Buy Reno Air
American Airlines agreed to acquire Reno Air for $124 million. The purchase, which would help bolster American's presence in the West, could be completed early next year. C2.
 
Starts of Housing Increase 7.3%
Housing starts recorded their largest increase in 13 months during October, and building permits rose to their highest level in almost nine years, bolstered by low mortgage rates. The Commerce Department said that housing starts rose 7.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.695 million units. C5.
 
Analysts Wary of Finance Vacancies
A company that goes for some time without a chief financial officer may be raising a red flag for investors. That is why some analysts have been looking warily at Electronic Data Systems and Nike. Market Place. C6.
 
Middle East Trade Discussions
Israel's chilly trade relationship with Jordan and the Palestinian Authority warmed slightly this week as the three held their first face-to-face discussions. C4.
 
China Thwarts Tobacco Companies
As cigarette sales threaten to decline precipitously in the United States, American tobacco companies are counting on China as a land of growth. But their plans are being thwarted by China's Government monopoly. A16.
 
China has begun efforts to comply with the coming American ban on imports containing untreated wood-packing material, a United States agricultural official said. C4.

HEADLINE: Clinton Ends Japan Trip With No Sign of Economic Progress

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan ended two days of talk and ceremony here tonight with an affirmation of their national partnership but no evidence of progress on trade and other economic disputes that are festering between their countries.
While he appealed to the Japanese to have patience with Mr. Obuchi's plan to revive the economy, Mr. Clinton gave little sign of such patience himself or of optimism that the plan would be enough. 
 "Sometimes when you have to turn a country around it takes more than you think in the beginning," Mr. Clinton said, standing beside Mr. Obuchi to address reporters this evening. "I don't know."
Under pressure from the United States, Mr. Obuchi announced on Monday a $195 billion package of spending and tax cuts to increase investment and consumer demand. The markets shrugged, and in a meeting today with private economists here the most optimistic forecast for the Japanese economy heard by Clinton advisers was that it would shrink by only 1 percent next year.
Standing with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Obuchi predicted "positive growth" next year.
But Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers offered a dimmer view at a subsequent briefing. "The recognition that there is a risk of slow or negative growth is why there's a view that it may be necessary over time to do more," Mr. Summers said.
In the morning Mr. Clinton suggested that a surge in exports to the United States of certain types of Japanese steel might stem from illegal trade practices. He raised the issue in the afternoon in meetings with Mr. Obuchi but received no specific assurances from Mr. Obuchi that he would address the problem, Mr. Summers said.
Mr. Summers said that Mr. Clinton's concerns over steel "were very clearly heard" and that the Japanese showed an "awareness here of the importance of making sure that trade is by the rules in steel and other sectors."
In his unusually blunt speech, to the American Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Clinton warned of the possibility of "retaliatory protectionism," saying that protectionist sentiment could rise in the United States if its trade deficit continued to grow while Japan resisted opening its markets.
Japan has frustrated the Clinton Administration's hopes to liberalize trade this year in nine specific economic sectors, including timber and fishing. The President said today that he now hoped to achieve that goal next year.
The leaders also devoted 45 minutes to security, including what Mr. Clinton in his public remarks called "disturbing signs" in North Korea. The Administration, which has been criticized in the region as letting its policy on North Korea drift, is worried that North Korea may be preparing to build a plant for nuclear weapons at a vast new underground site, in violation of a 1994 agreement. The United States wants to inspect the site, but the North Koreans informed an American representative this week that they would grant such an inspection only in exchange for hundreds of millions of dollars.
Mr. Clinton said such conditions were "completely unacceptable." He said that North Korea's intentions remained mysterious and that it was unclear whether "they're attempting to get more money out of various countries for doing what they ought to be doing anyway or whether they really are moving toward a more hostile posture."
Mr. Clinton flew tonight to South Korea.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Opening Door Policy;
Latin America Leads Way in Emerging Markets' Revival

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The door to the global bond market has opened a crack, and Argentina and some Latin American companies are starting to slip through. Their success in borrowing money in the last few weeks is a sign that the financial crisis that seemed so severe in emerging markets and elsewhere just two months ago is easing.
This reservoir of needed cash had been all but closed to borrowers from emerging markets ever since Russia effectively defaulted on its debt in mid-August. With the heat of the world financial crisis turned up to white hot, investors were suddenly demanding a crippling 20 percent return for lending in these economically troubled nations. 
 Now the picture is changing. The Federal Reserve began to cut interest rates, and the International Monetary Fund revamped its rescue strategy, allowing the fund to offer assistance to a country before its economy plunged into deep trouble. And last week, the I.M.F., the United States and other countries agreed on a $42 billion plan to stabilize the Brazilian economy. If Brazil's economy collapsed, many economists have said, that would be sure to set off a far more serious worldwide economic crisis.
But investors, although willing to dip a toe in emerging markets once more, are still cautious about plunging back in, reflecting the sentiment the Federal Reserve expressed when it cut its interest rate target this week for the third time in less than two months. "Although conditions in the financial markets have settled down materially since mid-October, unusual strains remain," the Fed statement said. So investors are snapping up only those issues with special extras that make the risk more palatable.
"Investors have money to put to work in this market, but they still need bells and whistles to attract them," said Rachel Hines, managing director for Latin American capital markets at J. P. Morgan & Company, a lead manager on a $1 billion Argentine issue on Wednesday, which really pushed the door ajar.
Analysts are expressing the same caution about the stock markets in Latin America, Asia and elsewhere, which have done quite well lately. The Morgan Stanley Capital International overall index of emerging markets is up 28 percent since Sept. 10 in dollar terms. The Mexican market has bounced back 40 percent, Argentina 66 percent, and Hong Kong 54 percent. In Thailand, where the emerging markets collapse began in July 1997, the stock market is up 79 percent.
Those rallies have meant profits for those who went in near the bottom but only cut the huge losses for investors who did not get out in time. The Morgan Stanley index had dropped 59 percent from its high before the crisis began.
Gary Kleiman, the head of Kleiman International Consultants in Washington, said he thinks these are just traders' rallies and do not represent the return of money that will stay for the long haul. He is telling his clients to go in "only very selectively and only if they are prepared to go in and get out."
Robert J. Pelosky Jr., the global emerging markets strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, is also cautious, but in the "glass is half full" vein. "A two-week trip through Korea, Thailand, India and Hong Kong," he wrote in a recent report, "left me feeling that the big question is no longer survival, but how long before economies bottom. As such, it's time to gradually begin looking back at the region for opportunities."
The modest reopening of the bond market is probably even more important to the health of Latin American and Asian markets than the bounce of the stock markets. Countries and companies all across the globe are starved for capital. And if they do not get it, then a recoverywill be all that much more difficult. It was this fear of a shut-off of lending of all sorts -- and the potential economic collapse that would follow -- that prompted the Federal Reserve to begin cutting interest rates in September.
Although the recent surge in bond issues from new emerging markets is mostly from Argentina, the success of the issues holds broader significance, said Desmond Lachman, head of emerging markets economic research at the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup. "This does pave the way for more countries to come back into the market in the months ahead," he said.
The enhancements that have made these issues popular include guarantees of principal and interest payments, opportunities for the buyers to sell the bonds back to the issuer if prices fall and warrants that give the buyer the right to buy another bond in the future at a possibly advantageous price.
In addition, some corporate issuers are considering making their bonds attractive by tying the payment of principal and interest to future revenue. Some countries are also reopening bond issues, a move that investors like because, by increasing the pool, it makes it easier to trade those bonds.
The biggest new issue to date came on Wednesday, the day after the Fed cut rates in the United States. Argentina sold $1 billion of seven-year notes in a deal led by J. P. Morgan and Deutsche Bank. The bonus for investors was a warrant that gives them the opportunity to buy an existing 30-year Argentine bond at a price of $93.30 for each $100 on Dec. 4, 1999. The 30-year bond was priced at $85.50 on Wednesday but will rally if the global financial crisis abates further. By yesterday, the price had already jumped to more than $88.
According to Ms. Hines of J. P. Morgan, the issue was oversubscribed, with orders nearing $1.5 billion. The yield on the bond was 11 percent, 626 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- over the comparable seven-year United States Treasury note.
Among the other deals that have been done recently are a $200 million seven-year note by Banco Santander Chile that was insured by MBIA-Ambac International, a joint venture of two firms that have traditionally guaranteed municipal bond issues. The insurance gave the note a triple-A credit rating. Its yield was 6.585 percent, 210 basis points over comparable Treasuries.
YPF S.A., the Argentine oil company, sold $100 million in 30-year bonds on Nov. 4. The added attraction is that investors can sell the bond back to YPF after three years at face value.
On Thursday, Petroleos Mexicanos, the oil company also known as Pemex, was the first Mexican company to come back to the market since the Russian crisis. It sold $600 million of 10-year notes that can also be returned to the company after three years for their face value. And Pemex is considering a bond offer in which it will pledge its future oil revenues to pay off the principal and interest.
In late October and in November, the Argentine Government reopened two existing bond issues to raise $250 million and $300 million.
Joyce Chang, manager of emerging markets research at Merrill Lynch & Company, said there had also been some new issues in German marks. These were aimed at small groups of investors and could be handled at a slightly lower cost.
Before this spurt, the market was dead. According to Merrill Lynch, only $125 million of new Latin American debt was sold in September and just $250 million in October. Now, in November, new issues already total more than $1.4 billion. With the deals already in the pipeline, Ms. Chang is forecasting $3 billion for the month.
Outside Latin America, Ms. Chang said there was no new activity -- yet. But she said Asian borrowers could come back into this market if they chose to.
The revival in emerging markets has come hand in hand with an even bigger comeback in the markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and high-yield junk bonds. Both have seen a flurry of activity the last several weeks. "It is as if we woke up last week and nobody remembered what happened in September," said Tracy T. Eccles, a bond portfolio manager at Himco in Hartford. But she added, "If you are a portfolio manager and you don't buy now, you won't get that price appreciation."
Investors are tiptoeing back into emerging markets now that the huge premium that issuers had to pay at the height of the financial crisis has begun to shrink. In September, this premium, or spread, spiked as high as 17 percentage points over comparable United States Treasury securities, making the long-term interest rate on sovereign debt 22 percent.
That spread is down to around 10 points, but remains well above the 4.5 points it was from February into May and further above the 3.3-point low it hit just before the Asian crisis really began to hit the West in October 1997. Ms. Chang of Merrill Lynch said that Argentina, even with the enhancement it included in its newest issue, was paying about two percentage points more in interest than it was before.
The success of these issues, however, does not mean the door will stay open or is open for everyone. "Corporations, that is where the questions will be," Ms. Chang said. It is not clear yet how high a price they will have to pay to borrow.
Mr. Lachman of Salomon Smith Barney is worried about Russia, where he says the "outlook isn't very good" and new debt payments are coming due. And he is concerned that Brazil, whose economy is already slowing sharply, faces a "steep recession" next year. A recession would challenge the country's reform program, worry foreign investors and might "derail" the recent improvement in emerging markets. "So it is not a time to go big into emerging markets," he said.

Banks Tighten Credit
 
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Worry about the economy in the last three months caused a bigger proportion of banks to toughen their lending terms to businesses than at any time since 1990, the Federal Reserve said today.
"The survey results suggest a broad tightening of business lending practices," the periodic Fed survey of senior loan officers at 55 United States and foreign banks said.
The Fed has cited concern about credit availability in its decisions to lower interest rates three times in the last two months. It said more than a third of the American banks surveyed had reported tightening their standards for commercial and industrial loans to big companies.

LENGTH: 325 words

HEADLINE: Dangerous Delays in Indonesia

 BODY:
After 32 years of dictatorship under President Suharto, Indonesians are understandably eager for free elections. President B. J. Habibie must move faster in providing them, and avoid the Suharto-style repression he has flirted with in recent weeks.
Mr. Habibie, who was Mr. Suharto's protege, took over when his mentor was forced from power last May. He has made some limited steps toward democracy. But instead of seeking legitimacy through early elections, Mr. Habibie has stretched out what should have been a brief transition.
This month, students returned to the streets of Jakarta for the largest demonstrations since the fall of Mr. Suharto. They were protesting the slow pace of Mr. Habibie's transition timetable, his anemic efforts to recover money stolen by the Suharto family and the military's continued role in government. Unlike last May, the protests were not joined by the middle class. But they did draw support from the far more numerous, and desperate, urban poor. 
 Security forces overreacted, killing several students. Mr. Habibie seized on the violent crackdown as a pretext for interrogating several opposition political figures.
Mr. Habibie is pushing ahead with plans that would defer selection of the next president until the end of 1999. Even then, the choice would not be made by Indonesia's voters but by a partially elected assembly likely to include large numbers of military officers and government appointees. It will lack the legitimacy to carry out painful economic reforms or cope with popular protests.
Next week, Indonesia's Parliament will consider the army's future role in politics. Mr. Habibie and his political allies want the army to retain its hand in selecting presidents for 5 to 10 more years. That kind of military influence has no place in a democratic Indonesia. A quicker, cleaner transition to full civilian democracy is needed, and Washington should not be shy about saying so.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Literary Sherman in Pastels, Tom Wolfe Takes Atlanta

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 20

 BODY:
You might have the grandest house in all of Buckhead and the summer place on Sea Island and the biggest private jet and the ranch or two in Wyoming, every toy a man could possibly long for -- and yet your failure to make the roster of the Piedmont Driving Club would always be hanging over you, like a reproach.
 -- Tom Wolfe, in "A Man in Full."
 As if stepping into his own novel, there was Tom Wolfe on Thursday dining on herb-crusted salmon and baby carrots in the perfectly proportioned ballroom of Atlanta's Piedmont Driving Club, the magnolia blossom tint of the walls a perfect match for his creamy three-piece suit. 
 The club, which was founded 111 years ago so that Atlanta's aristocrats could show off their horse-drawn carriages, had invited the celebrated writer to lunch with its members, and 470 were now seated beneath two grand chandeliers.
They came despite their understanding that Mr. Wolfe's new novel, "A Man in Full" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), had pretty well skewered their club by using it as a metaphor for the social separation of the races in the capital of the New South. The home to countless debutante balls and Junior League follies, the Driving Club remains a place, both in fact and in Mr. Wolfe's fiction, where the only blacks in view usually are wearing waiters' uniforms.
Mr. Wolfe regaled the crowd with stories about how intrigued he had become with the club's history and architecture. And he recounted the night, which he molded into one of the book's most vivid scenes, when formally attired white partygoers stood on a terrace at the club and watched powerlessly as raucous black college students attending the Freaknik spring break weekend paralyzed traffic on Piedmont Road.
"I knew I had to make some literary capital out of this," Mr. Wolfe explained impishly, as the society matrons and managing partners who had been capitalized upon laughed approvingly.
And so it was all across Atlanta this week, as Mr. Wolfe made a three-day publicity tour of the city that serves as the primary setting for his novel about the feeble condition of American morality at the turn of the millennium. Despite the reviews characterizing Mr. Wolfe as a modern-day Sherman, Atlantans turned his visit into a citywide sensation that the amused author likened to the Beatles' first trip to America.
The 742-page book, which will make its debut atop The New York Times best-seller list on Sunday, has received such broad attention here that even those who have not cracked its binding offer ready critiques. Predictably, Mr. Wolfe's trip has also prompted one of the periodic bouts of introspection that afflict this famously image-obsessed city.
With his depictions of crass white developers and opportunistic black politicians, Mr. Wolfe lampoons both the casing and the core of a city that he likens to a baseball: a suburban shell of white economic might surrounding an inner-city nucleus of black political power.
In the course of explaining "the Atlanta way," the path of mutual benefit negotiated between black politics and white commerce, Mr. Wolfe also illuminates some dark corners of civic life. In his Atlanta, white corporate titans measure their worth in status and possessions, while black political success is determined by skin tone and walking-around money.
While many Atlanta readers have found Mr. Wolfe's descriptions and characters eerily recognizable, some fault him for simplifying the city's racial dynamic. Because Mr. Wolfe takes such pride in the journalistic foundations of his fiction, and because his details are so precise, many have had trouble remembering that the book is a novel. As a result, some feathers have been ruffled.
Several corporate sponsors and a number of guests backed out of a benefit on Wednesday night honoring Mr. Wolfe after reading the early publicity on the book.
"The sponsors backed out because they were afraid of being involved in anything that could be racially controversial," said Mary Rose Taylor, a longtime friend of Mr. Wolfe who organized the dinner. "And some guests felt if they attended the dinner they would appear to be endorsing the book, and they did not want to appear to be doing that."
Although he has not read the book, former Mayor Sam Massell, who heads a business group called the Buckhead Coalition, was so offended by what he had heard that he made a public show of rescinding a luncheon invitation from the group before Mr. Wolfe had even received it. Mr. Massell said he was put off by a passage describing how Charlie Croker, the book's developer protagonist, had manufactured a Ku Klux Klan rally to deflate the price of property he wanted to buy.
"I understand this is fiction and he has the right to do what he wants," said Mr. Massell, who was Mayor from 1970 to 1974. "But that doesn't mean I have to have lunch with him."
Asked whether he plans to read the book, Mr. Massell paused. "When I cool down," he said.
A number of prominent Atlantans said they were more offended by Mr. Massell's sense of public relations than by Mr. Wolfe's book. Sam A. Williams, the president of the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, called Mr. Massell's disinvitation "a little crass." Rick Beard, the director of the Atlanta History Center, said he kept hoping for a city "that has a little bit more self-confidence and cares a little bit less about what other people think of us."
Atlanta's Mayor, Bill Campbell, anticipated Mr. Wolfe's arrival on Wednesday by issuing a statement that pleaded for calm: "Given our achievements and history of racial harmony, there is no reason to overreact to a novel that explores several important issues, but like all literature, from the vantage point of the author."
Mr. Campbell, the city's third black Mayor, said in an interview that he was particularly pleased that the novel explored race relations, a topic that he said demanded more discussion. But when Mr. Campbell, who has yet to read the book, was told that a major theme involved the political tensions between light-skinned and dark-skinned blacks, the Mayor virtually denied that such an undercurrent even existed.
"As a reality, it's not an issue at all," he said, although it was a widely, if quietly, discussed subtext of Mr. Campbell's re-election in 1997. "Like the ebola plague, it's very deadly when it does rear its head, but it's very rare."
Despite mixed feelings about the book, much of Atlanta has been flattered by Mr. Wolfe's attention, and views the book's publication as an opportunity to demonstrate that the city has developed a thicker skin since it was host to the 1996 Summer Olympic Games. After all, did not Mr. Wolfe use his first novel, "The Bonfire of the Vanities," to send up New York City, the commercial and cultural capital of the world?
"We Atlantans are supposed to be sitting here in mortal terror that our pretensions are going to be held up to ridicule, when the truth is, everyone I know is tickled pink about this," said Frederick Allen, a local author and city historian. "To have someone of Tom Wolfe's stature hold you up to scorn is really the Good Housekeeping seal of approval. He wouldn't do this to Birmingham or Orlando."
Mr. Wolfe was welcomed at the airport on Wednesday with camera flashes, and a press contingent has trailed him this week like a Presidential candidate in the snows of New Hampshire. The Atlanta Journal-Constitution instituted a daily Wolfe Watch column, and dutifully reported what Mr. Wolfe ate and what his wife wore.
The crowd attending Mr. Wolfe's speech and reading at the Atlanta History Center on Wednesday night spilled out of the 400-seat auditorium and into a room where his address was shown on closed-circuit television. Later, some 150 Atlantans paid $600 apiece to attend the black-tie benefit honoring Mr. Wolfe who, alone among the guests, did not adhere to the dress code.
On Thursday, 200 people joined Mr. Wolfe at a breakfast sponsored by the Atlanta Convention and Visitors Bureau, which hopes that his book will do for Atlanta tourism what John Berendt's "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil" (Random House, 1994) did for Savannah.
On Thursday night, an estimated 1,100 fans jammed Borders Books and Music in trendy Buckhead for a reading and signing, some waiting up to nine hours for Mr. Wolfe's arrival. Like eager children queued up to see a shopping-mall Santa, they snaked in lines throughout the expansive store as Mr. Wolfe scribbled his autograph from a thronelike stage. By the time he finished at 11:45 P.M., more than two hours later than scheduled, the 68-year-old Mr. Wolfe had signed about 2,000 books.
Mr. Wolfe, a Virginia native who lives in New York, takes note in "A Man in Full" of Atlanta's sensitivity to image, with one character saying Atlantans cannot stand "the idea that somebody in New York might be calling them Southern hicks." While here this week, he seemed eager to make amends for any slight, praising the city's ambition and optimism and telling his audiences that Atlanta just might become the next great international city. He also praised the city's manners and unfailing generosity, saying he was treated graciously in the dozen trips he made here to research the book.
"I've always loved courtesy in the South, even when it takes the form of hypocrisy," he told the crowd at breakfast on Thursday. "I can stand insults, so long as they're couched in courteous terms."
Perhaps after Mr. Wolfe's visit, Atlanta may discover that it feels the same way about him.

HEADLINE: U.S. Questions The Placement Of City Pupils

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
The Federal Education Department's Office of Civil Rights has challenged Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to show evidence that thousands of black and Hispanic students are being properly placed in special education programs, saying that a Federal analysis shows evidence of discrimination that Dr. Crew has failed to report or investigate.
The department's order comes 18 months after Dr. Crew agreed to Federal monitoring of his efforts to reduce the number of children consigned to special education classes in New York City public schools. Federal officials had raised questions about disproportionate referrals of black and Hispanic students into the classes, which are supposed to accommodate children with learning or behavioral problems, but usually end up as pathways to academic failure. Once placed in special education classes, children seldom return to regular classes or receive a diploma, even though the vast majority have only minor impairments, not severe handicaps. 
 In a letter sent to the Chancellor this month, Steven Pereira, chief attorney for the New York Office for Civil Rights, said that Federal analysts had found "anomalies and omissions" in data on special education placements submitted by Dr. Crew to the Federal Government.
For example, the analysis found that a third of the city's school districts sent unusually high numbers of children who spoke limited English into special education. In 11 of the 32 districts, more than 20 percent of the students whose native language is not English were in special education classes in the 1996-97 school year. Citywide, the study said, the rate was 8.2 percent of students with limited English and 4 percent for native English speakers.
The study did not do much analysis beyond the raw numbers to assess factors like learning ability or the economic status of families, which might contribute to a greater need for special education.
In nine districts, the study found that black students were more than twice as likely as white students to be referred to special education. What is more, black students were three times as likely as white students to be recommended for the most restrictive special education classes, from which they were least likely to be transferred back to the mainstream. Federal officials said that even among districts with the same rates of poverty, there were wide discrepancies in special education placements that appeared to be based on race or ethnicity.
In the letter to the Chancellor, Mr. Pereira said the data indicated that Dr. Crew and the Board of Education had not been aggressive enough in tracking how individual schools and school districts place children in special education. "None of these statistical anomalies were identified by the board as problematic, triggering further inquiry," the letter said. The Office of Civil Rights "is very concerned that the board is too narrowly defining what it considers to be inappropriately high rates of referral or restrictive special education placement, thereby limiting the necessity to intervene with schools or districts."
J. D. LaRock, a spokesman for the Chancellor, said that the Federal data were not up to date and that Dr. Crew was sending more recent data to the Office of Civil Rights that would show more progress in reducing special education placements.
"That problem doesn't get fixed overnight," Mr. LaRock said. "It should be pointed out that this does not reflect the latest data regarding referrals to special education."
Phil Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, which has been tracking special education for years, said that children from impoverished families often did need extra support, and that these children tended to be black and Hispanic. The problem, he said, was that they were not necessarily getting it in special education.
Mr. Coltoff said that Dr. Crew had begun to put supports in some schools, including an extended school day and school year. "If these schools had more extensive mental health staff, guidance staff and clinics," Mr. Coltoff said, "a lot of those students would not have to go to special education."
Under the agreement with the Federal Government, the Board of Education must reduce the numbers of black and Hispanic students in special education or lose Federal aid -- about 10 percent of its $8 billion budget. The so-called memorandum of agreement, signed in May 1997, came after a two-year investigation of special education placements in New York City found that such programs had become warehouses for minority children.
The agreement was not based on any specific complaint from an advocacy group or from students or their parents. Rather, it was what Mr. Pereira called "a proactive effort" by the Office of Civil Rights to prevent racial and ethnic discrimination in special education programs.
Mr. LaRock pointed out that the Office of Civil Rights had not found New York City to be in violation of the agreement, and he characterized Mr. Pereira's letter as "routine correspondence" in a cooperative relationship. Mr. Pereira, in an interview, agreed that Dr. Crew had been cooperating with Federal officials.
In his letter, Mr. Pereira complained that Dr. Crew had provided little evidence that he had carried out plans to improve training for teachers, who often initiate placements for special education, and to inform parents of alternatives to special education. Although the board submitted a description of training sessions to the Office of Civil Rights in May, "many of the topics of the training seem extraneous to the goals" of the Federal agreement.
For instance, his letter said, the Board had reported that all 32 school districts had been given training in the prevention of teen-age suicide. But only one district was given training in putting special education students in regular classrooms, but giving them extra help.
The Federal report found that eight schools with extremely low reading and math scores had transferred large numbers of students into special education in 1996-97. The percentage of students moved ranged from 29 percent at Hostos Academy in East Harlem to a low of 13 percent at Public School 111 in Brooklyn. Five of the eight schools were on a state list of "schools under registration review," which are threatened with closing if they do not improve. The scores of special education students on standardized tests are not used to determine school rankings. So moving children into special education could sharply raise the overall scores of those schools.
Lucila Rodriguez, the director of Hostos Academy, where 21 percent of students were reading at grade level in 1996, declined comment yesterday on the Federal report.
The proportion of black students moved to special education in 1996-97 ranged from 2 percent in District 5, which is in Harlem, to 10 percent in District 21, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. Citywide, 3.8 percent of white students and 5 percent of black students were moved to special education that year.
The share of students with limited English who were placed in special education in 1996-97 ranged from a low of 2.6 percent in Harlem to 22 percent in District 31, which comprises Staten Island.
Using statistics from 1995-96, which Federal officials said were the latest available to them, the Office of Civil Rights found 11 districts in which more than 15 percent of black students were in special education. In two of those districts, District 1 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, and District 21, in Brooklyn, more than 20 percent of black students were in special education.

HEADLINE: The High Price of Happiness

 BODY:
When Gov. John Rowland ran for re-election, he promised to make the rejuvenation of Connecticut's cities a top priority for his second administration. Now the state has learned that Mr. Rowland was secretly negotiating to bring the New England Patriots to Hartford as the centerpiece of his urban development. This week the Governor and the Patriots' owner, Robert Kraft, stunned both Massachusetts and Connecticut by announcing a deal to move the football team into a new $350 million, publicly financed stadium. This is a story in which almost every position deserves to be regarded with both sympathy and a degree of skepticism.
Mr. Kraft agreed to move his team to Hartford after long and drawn-out negotiations to keep the Patriots in the Boston area fell through. It is impossible to feel much concern for Mr. Kraft, who was prospering in Massachusetts. But as team owners go, he did not seem to have been asking for very much to keep the team in its present location in Foxboro. The Massachusetts House Speaker, Thomas Finneran, who calls Mr. Kraft a "whiney millionaire," vetoed a deal that would have required the state to make about $70 million in infrastructure improvements in order to keep a team that generates $10 million a year in tax revenue. 
 The Boston area, which is booming, and which has three other sports teams closer to residents' hearts, does not really need the Patriots as a symbol of local solidarity and prestige. But Hartford has been mired in severe problems for years, including a disastrous school system, a half-deserted downtown and an image as a dangerous place that suburban residents prefer to shun.
It is hard to accept the idea that a football team ought to be a top priority for a city with so many needs. But the psychological jolt of grabbing big-league status might help to ignite a rebirth of the commercial district. The big question is whether Mr. Rowland is right in believing that a football team that plays only 10 regular and preseason games a year at home could be the catalyst that turns Hartford's fortunes around.
The stadium is supposed to be the center of a larger urban development project along the Connecticut River, and Mr. Kraft has agreed to build a hotel there, as well as make other gestures toward encouraging downtown development. But in return, the state is going to be responsible for the debt payment on $350 million in bonds. Mr. Rowland says the money will come from a tax on stadium revenues, but the estimate of how much money that tax will bring in seems optimistic.
The Connecticut State Legislature must meet before the end of the year to approve the deal. Right now, most lawmakers seem caught up in the euphoria of the moment. But that should not keep them from making hard-headed decisions about whether a state that already has a very high debt burden should be taking on this additional responsibility. It was good to see Hartford's politicians and business leaders looking optimistic for a change this week. But a $350 million investment has to buy something more than good feeling.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Pilgrims' Progress to Eager Connecticut Stirs Rancor in Bay State

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
New England is generally viewed as a bastion of civility, a place where Frostian musings about good fences making good neighbors do not immediately elicit cries to shut up. But in recent days, trash talking has replaced poetry recitals in the meadows and mill towns to the east.
Boston is calling Hartford, the proud Connecticut city built on insurance policies against bathtub falls and death, a ghost town for yahoos. Hartford counters by dismissing Boston, the noble Massachusetts metropolis that sees tragedy of Greek proportion in every Red Sox defeat, as a grimy, creaking haven for sore losers. Only Providence, the Rhode Island home to liberty and la Cosa Nostra, demonstrates having learned a lesson from the American Revolution. It democratically thumbs its nose at everyone. 
 At the root of all the discontent, waged in newspaper columns and on radio airwaves, is this week's announcement by Robert K. Kraft that he will move his National Football League team, the New England Patriots, from Foxboro, Mass., to Hartford in time for the 2001 season.
On one level, the issue merely reflects a series of business decisions: Massachusetts refused to placate the wealthy owner of a sports franchise with the subsidies that he sought, and so he went to a place where he felt more wanted, to a city looking to jump-start its revitalization. On another level, it speaks to the pull of regional identity, love for one's sports idols and contempt for one's neighbors.
Dan Shaughnessy, a sportswriter for The Boston Globe, greeted the prospect of losing the Patriots with a front-page polemic on Thursday against Mr. Kraft's choice of Hartford, whose charms apparently are lost on him. He called the city a "yahoo sports town" and "America's file cabinet," a place where "poor souls" wander "dead streets."
Vincent A. (Buddy) Cianci Jr., the Mayor of Providence, whose city also wooed the Patriots, asked: "Have the rules changed? Has Hartford become the celebrated city of the Northeast?"
"You can marry an ugly woman for enough money, I guess."
Yesterday, Jim Shea of The Hartford Courant raised his own pen in defense of his city, smearing Boston with his ink. "The best thing about Boston is Cape Cod," he said. "Boston has the charm of a storm sewer."
As for the common Boston lament that its residents would rather watch the ice sport of curling than travel to Hartford for a Patriots game, Mr. Shea wondered if it weren't for Boston fans, who would urinate in the streets, pick fights and "wander around stinking drunk?"
The exchanges have been nasty enough to make Boston's residents forget how to spell "Yastrzemski," and to make Hartford's denizens forget that the big G. Fox department store on Main Street is still vacant.
In the end, though, the dispute seems driven more by the busywork of sportswriters and commentators than by deep-seated resentment among different New England communities. First of all, the spokeswomen for the respective Mayor's offices of Boston and Hartford said they were rarely asked about rivalry between the two cities. More often, they say, their public squabbles are with Providence and its irrepressible Mayor, Mr. Cianci.
Second, the Patriots play in Foxboro, which is 30 miles from Boston, a city the team abandoned with such ill feeling years earlier that it changed its name from the Boston Patriots to the New England Patriots. Among certain Yankees, once a Benedict Arnold, always a Benedict Arnold.
Jacque Goddard, the spokeswoman for Boston's Mayor, Thomas M. Menino, said, "Many people in the city of Boston feel that the team has not had loyalty to the city, that it has purposely tried to shed its Boston image by moving elsewhere in Massachusetts and changing the name of the team."
Lastly, everyone agrees that Hartford could use a pat on its hunched back. Boston has the Red Sox and the Bruins. In addition to struggling economically, Hartford recently saw its only professional sports franchise, the Whalers hockey team, flee to North Carolina.
"It would be nice if people would see what we're all about before calling us yahoos," said Nilda Torres, the executive assistant to Hartford's Mayor, Michael Peters. "All we keep hearing is, 'Did you hear that Boston's radio stations are taking more swipes at us?' I mean, it's not our fault."
But Thomas D. Ritter, the Speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives, was more magnanimous about the disrespect that his hometown has received of late. People need to get things off their chests, he said. But it will end soon.
Mr. Ritter acknowledged that he spoke more from experience than from love for his fellow New Englanders: "When the Whalers left, I said some bad things about North Carolina."

HEADLINE: Yefim Geller, Grandmaster Of Daring Attacks, Dies at 73

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Yefim Geller, a Ukrainian-born grandmaster whose penetrating technical analysis, inspired innovations and brilliant play helped the former Soviet Union almost totally dominate international chess for decades, died on Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Moscow. He was 73.
The cause was complications of a long series of illnesses that included prostate cancer and heart disease, his family said. 
 For those with only a cursory knowledge of the ancient game of chess, it may seem surprising that a man who never won a world championship and whose most memorable public role was serving as Boris Spassky's beleaguered second in his 1972 world championship loss to Bobby Fischer, should be such a revered figure in chess circles.
That is at least partly because to its true believers chess is more than a sport -- both an art and a science, if not an actual religion -- and if Mr. Geller failed to achieve ultimate headline success, he was a feared attacker and discovered many innovations in venerable openings. His book, "The Application of Chess Theory," was reissued in paperback by Scribner's in 1995.
During a career in which he won the Soviet championship twice (1955 and 1979) and was a candidate to challenge the world champion six times, Mr. Geller also established an enviable personal record: a lifetime tournament edge over four world champions, Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian and Vasily Smyslov.
And in a satisfying personal triumph, Mr. Geller also has a winning edge (five victories, three losses, two draws) over Bobby Fischer himself.
A native of Odessa who served in the army in World War II and obtained a degree in economics from the University of Odessa, Mr. Geller was a late bloomer as a chess player. Like many in a country where chess is as popular as, say, basketball is in the United States, he learned chess as a child but did not take it seriously until college.
His other passion was basketball; though he was a short, stocky fellow built more along the lines of a wrestler he was a sure-handed star on a powerful Odessa team. Nevertheless, in a reflection of the Soviet Union's reverence for chess, his basketball coach, a chess enthusiast, urged him to concentrate on chess.
The results of his new single-minded pursuit were immediate. Making his major tournament debut in the 1949 Soviet championships while still a candidate master, he led until a final round loss dropped him to a tie for third, but his showing catapulted him into the pampered top rank of Soviet players.
Within a few years Mr. Geller, who became an international grandmaster in 1952, had a spacious house outside Moscow in Peredelkino, the artists' and writers' colony, and was a familiar figure at the elegant Central Chess Club in Moscow.
From the beginning, Mr. Geller was known for his often brilliant, sometimes reckless combinations and all-or-nothing slashing attacks, a style that sometimes cost him victories in games that came down to plodding positional battles that tried his patience. In time Mr. Geller learned to moderate his fervor for attack and obtain more consistent results, but it is a continuing tribute to his youthful daring that in winning his first Soviet championship in 1955 he became the only Soviet champion who has ever won the title while losing five games.
In one of the more bizarre episodes of his career, during the 1972 world championship in Iceland, it fell to Mr. Geller to issue a statement suggesting that Mr. Fischer's supporters might be using "electronic devices and a chemical substance" to weaken Mr. Spassky's playing ability. It is assumed that the statement was dictated by the Moscow authorities to prepare the Soviet people for Mr. Spassky's eventual loss.
In a crucial game Mr. Spassky, playing a familiar Queen's Gambit defense, failed to make an innovative move Mr. Geller had discovered.
Mr. Spassky lost the game, but a year later, playing the same line (against a weaker player, of course), Mr. Geller finally got a chance to make the new move and won the game decisively. The innovation was later hailed as one of the year's most brilliant.
He is survived by his wife, Oxana, and a son, Alexander.
