PUB-DATE: November 22, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 44; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 7042 words

HEADLINE: The Fresh Prince

BYLINE: By Warren Hoge; Warren Hoge, editor of The New York Times Magazine from 1991 to 1993, is chief of The Times's London bureau.

 BODY:
The royal train, sleek and black with pencil-thin red trimming, is hurtling toward Newcastle, and inside one of the armored middle cars, Charles, the Prince of Wales, is taking his breakfast. He's dressed down in an open-collar white-and-burgundy striped shirt, blue cardigan and khaki trousers, and as I enter the cabin, his look of welcome is mixed with one of concern. "I do hope you managed to get some sleep," he says, motioning me to sit across from him. Gales and lashing rain had rolled in from the North Sea as we made our midnight departure from Perth, and the heir to the throne seems to be apologizing for turbulence in the realm. "Ghastly night," he says.
Freshly done up in blond wood with little ornamentation, the coach reflects a new reduced configuration aimed at cutting the train's operating cost. Part of royal downsizing? I ask. "Yes," he nods. "What you see is the anorexic British monarchy." 
 In a corner bookcase, there is a small vase of flowers and a picture of the Queen Mother, said to be Prince Charles's favorite member of the family. Earlier her two corgis, Dash and Rash, had taken their morning stroll through the carpeted corridors, friskily tugging at the leash held by her footman, Leslie Campbell.
The Prince's face is ruddy from a blustery weekend at his home on the Balmoral estate in Scotland, and gray is making a debonair debut in his thinning hair. His ears are large, as advertised, but they ride closer to his head and in happier proportion to it than cartoonists' pens would have you believe. He speaks so softly that I have to strain to hear him even in the stillness of the cabin, with its thick, bulletproof windows keeping out the clatter of our passage along England's northeastern coast. If voices came in colors, his would be the burnished amber of one of his favored Highland single malts.
Smartly turned out crewmen in navy blazers, charcoal gray trousers and black shoes shined to a military gloss place before the Prince a silver tray with small jars of preserves and honeys and a bowl of wheat germ and cereal grains, all of which meet his high threshold for unadulterated, healthful food. He reaches for a container of honey, opens it and spoons the golden spread directly into his mouth. I think I am observing royal prerogative.
"I actually don't eat very much at all," he says, confirming the warnings I had received minutes earlier from the butlers and security men in the mess car as they tucked into their heaping platefuls of eggs, tomatoes, mushrooms, sausage, bacon and toast. In the kind of jocular banter you'd expect from swabbies talking about a captain known to carry on in the wheelhouse, the men around the Prince made light fun of their boss, aping his plummy vowels, arched-brow hauteur and aristocratic mutter. Lee Dobson, the Prince's valet, entertained the crowd with stories of spending the entire weekend at an incline as he followed the Princely party on its shootings and hikes up and down the Scottish hills.
When he saw me summoned to join Charles in his private dining car, he elbowed his neighbors. "Hope you enjoy your fig," he said.
There is no mistaking the fact that the atmosphere around the Prince and his once-embattled retinue is assured and upbeat these days. Not long ago the most reviled member of the British royal family, Charles was able on his 50th birthday earlier this month to look back on a year in which he was liberated from the competition with Diana, the Princess of Wales, for attention and approval; was given credit previously denied him for being a sensitive parent to his two sons; was celebrated by the new Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair for the pioneering social work his Prince's Trust has done; and was encouraged by significantly growing public endorsement of him as the next sovereign and of his mistress, Camilla Parker Bowles, as his private life companion and possible wife.
He has turned the most convulsive moment in his life -- the death in August 1997 of his former wife, Diana -- into an opportunity for staging his own revival and for staking a strong claim on the role of guiding the monarchy into the 21st century. His progress from royal problem child to royal eminence has freshened the image of the monarchy itself, casting upon its smudged face the bright reflection of his notion that the institution has a responsibility to consider the well-being of its poorest and most neglected subjects. Mutinous feelings in Britain toward the royals have subsided, and the major player in disarming the public has surprisingly been Prince Charles.
For a long time the percussive, single-syllable words like "twit," "wimp" and "prat" that Britons use to dress down their well-born often accompanied mention of his name. The product of an undemonstrative mother, a chastising father and the decidedly uncozy Windsor household, Charles suffered from self-doubt and appeared hesitant and distracted in the face of the burdensome demands of his awesome inheritance. The question he most commonly puts to people he encounters now on his official rounds -- "What do you do?" -- is one he might have best avoided years ago for fear someone might ask him back.
When he got around to doing something, he only made matters worse, uttering ill-thought-out and crudely stated condemnations of modern architecture, medicine and education. By the time Diana began attracting favorable attention for her visits to AIDS wards and refugee camps, Charles had marked himself as something of a young fogy, dismissing new approaches to old problems as "fashionable." Meanwhile he was conducting a personal life that became an ongoing tabloid saga complete with confessional television interviews and smutty tape recordings of stunningly graceless sexual small talk.
In the past month, however, newspaper and magazine articles and new books assessing him in connection with his birthday have portrayed a new-look prince and declared him an underacknowledged overachiever whose good works went unnoticed in the press onslaught on his shortcomings. Even critics have begun to turn the Prince into a character of almost heroic proportions.
Anthony Holden, a royal biographer considered hostile by the Prince's supporters and denied all cooperation for his new book, "Charles at Fifty," concluded that "the human qualities well known to his inner circle, for all the battering they took during the Diana years, have come back to the fore. If not entirely at peace with himself, he is more so with the world around him. Throw in the shrewdest advisers he has had since his youth, extending beyond his own office to the inner councils of Government, and you have a public figure suddenly and unexpectedly at the peak of his powers, bloodied but unbowed by his past, with cause for unwonted optimism about his future."
It has been a startling turnaround, one that Robert M. Worcester, the head of MORI, says is unprecedented in his career as Britain's leading pollster. "I have never measured a sharper drop in public opinion than the 82 percent to 41 percent fall from 1991 to 1996 in the number of people who believed he would do a good job as King," he said. "Change upward tends to be glacial while images fall like a stone, but his recovery has been even faster than his fall." Today, 63 percent of Britons think Charles would be a good king.
No wonder the Prince is radiating contentment this morning. "You know this train is very useful to me," he says. "I can get on board the night before, do some reading, get some sleep, and it's the only way I can get to so many places in a day."
The only way? I ask. What about a helicopter? The blue-eyed gaze that comes back invites me to cease being a bore and join in the sybaritic conspiracy.
I had been reminded several times of the privilege of riding the royal train. Aides to the Prince had told me that I was only the second reporter allowed aboard since its creation for the Queen's Silver Jubilee in 1977. They said it was such a break with protocol that they expected a hard time from the Queen when she found out. It was not the last time this day that I heard the Monarch referred to as a nuisance.
As the cranes of Newcastle's waterfront come up in the distance, the Prince rises. It's time for him to retreat to his bedroom to put on one of his razor-creased fitted double-breasted suits for the long day ahead of royal ribbon cuttings. The schedule calls for the Prince of Wales to spend the next seven hours opening a home for the aged, a glass museum, a job-training center and, most improbably, an oil rig. He inquires if I really mean to follow him around to every event. The hangdog look of sympathy seems to say, Why would anyone ever want to do it if he didn't have to?
There's nothing new about the Prince of Wales going off to lay cornerstones and plant trees. In 1997, he had 513 engagements like this. What is new is that he is no longer alone with his ceremonial shovel. People are paying attention, and they are doing so because the ideas of a man long associated with the country's past now seem very much a part of its future. Back in the staff mess car, one of Charles's aides confided that he believed the most significant factor in the changing fortunes of the Prince was the election in May 1997 of Tony Blair and the Labor Party: "Suddenly his views became part of the political language of this country."
It is a breathtaking fact that many of the reforms the Labor Government is pursuing -- getting private enterprise engaged in public service and opening up opportunities for young people, minorities and the unemployed -- are ones that have been undertaken for years by a member of the famously out-of-touch British monarchy. On issues like the environment, genetically modified food and organic farming, the Prince has even bolder prescriptions than the Government.
Where the Queen just this year rode in her first public taxi, walked into her first McDonald's and visited her first pub, Prince Charles has been tramping through housing projects for two decades. In 1976, he began a program that made loans available to young people whom banks wouldn't go near, and the idea is credited with having helped more than 40,000 people to start new businesses. (One of them is Jake Chessum, the photographer for this article, who told the Prince on meeting him in Newcastle that he had bought his first cameras with a $6,500 loan from the Prince's Youth Business Trust in 1990.)
Several people who run sections of the Prince's Trust said they know Charles was motivated to act in the 1980's by evidence that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic revolution was leaving Britain's poor unprotected and marginalized. "It wasn't that he used her name," said one executive close to the Prince. "He spoke out when it was very unfashionable to have these concerns, and he was the one who persuaded business it had to enter areas that the Government was abandoning."
Tom Shebbeare, the head of the Prince's Trust, said of Blair's policies, "A lot of what the Government's doing, to our delight, they really filched from us." Financed by the consolidation of three royal trusts and by contributions from corporations and individuals, the trust today manages an endowment of $125 million.
"He has been in more rough housing estates than most politicians I know," said Sir Peter Davis, group chief executive of Prudential Corporation PLC and chairman of the Prince's Business in the Community -- an organization designed to spark private-sector involvement in disadvantaged communities. "He demonstrated that he was ahead of his time in raising these issues."
Sir Peter is the embodiment of just how philosophically allied the Prince's charities and the Blairites are. Not only does he run one of the Prince's organizations, he also heads the Government's New Deal program. Designed to create jobs for 250,000 young unemployed people, the initiative is a key component of Blair's welfare-to-work strategy.
Blair's people have praised the Prince for his foresightedness, and the Prince has expressed his pleasure that Labor has found inspiration in his good works. One gleeful Labor official said, "He was a Blairite before Blair."
These chummy exchanges of mutual admiration have led Conservative politicians to complain that Charles is in danger of crossing constitutional boundaries barring political activity by royals. The Queen is not known to have any political viewpoints, and in her long years on the throne she has never been caught out expressing one. She and Prince Philip are reported by biographers to be put off by their eldest son's social activism in general and the perception that he could be playing favorites in Britain's public life.
The Prince has not responded to the grumbling in the House of Commons about his role, but he has long said the monarchy of the future should be "a contributing monarchy." In a letter to Shebbeare, the head of the trust, five years ago, he addressed the question, saying, "I have no 'political' agenda -- only a desire to see people achieve their potential." He reasoned that his ability to get attention made him "a catalyst to help produce a better and more balanced response to various problems."
The Prince has known the Prime Minister since 1990, when Blair was Labor's shadow employment secretary and took an interest in the work the Prince's Trust was doing in the area of youth employment. Their relationship was to deepen in the immediate aftermath of the death of Diana, as the royal family found itself tone-deaf to the sorrow and anger of the nation and looked to the newly triumphant Labor Government for help tuning in. Blair and the Prince spoke by phone during the flight Charles made to Paris to bring Diana's body back to Britain, and associates of the Prime Minister played a prominent role in planning the funeral and in encouraging the royal family to respond to the outpouring of grief. The Prince is the member of the family credited with convincing the palace that it was too remote, and much of his counsel came from Blair officials.
It is clear that while Blair has seized on some of the Prince's approaches to social problems, the Prince has learned to appreciate Blair's brand of political stagecraft. On the Prince's staff are none of the advisers who counseled him to confess his adultery in a 1994 television interview, a strategic decision he now regrets. While the Queen has kept her private secretaries for decades at a time, Charles has had six since 1985, a measure of his temperamental leadership. He has now settled down and reached out to the worlds of politics and entertainment for help. By design, his staff is no longer all male, all white, all Oxford- and Cambridge-educated. Often at odds with their more tradition-bound counterparts in Buckingham Palace, the Prince's people are busy putting forth their man as the voice of the monarchy's future, even going so far as to set up his own Web site -- www.princeofwales.gov.uk.
In the ongoing competition with Buckingham Palace, the Prince's staff is impatient with the creaking pace of change at royal headquarters. They dismiss the role of the Way Ahead group, the committee created to chart the royal family's path after the "annus horribilis" in 1992 -- a year dominated by a devastating fire at Windsor Castle and the collapse of three royal marriages. Made up of the Queen, Prince Philip, Princess Anne and the Princes Charles, Andrew and Edward, the group has been notable mostly for its lack of action. "It was very overblown in the early days," an aide to the Prince said. "He's the heir, and he's not really interested in what his sister and brothers think about it."
The person that friends and associates give the most credit to for the Prince's rapid rebound is his deputy private secretary in charge of communications, Mark Bolland, a 32-year-old Canadian-born Briton with degrees from York University and the University of Toronto. At 6 foot 4, the former marketing man quite literally looms over the Prince, who is barely 5 foot 10. Bolland has described his mission as convincing Britons that the heir to the throne is "a good bloke."
Bolland served for four years as director of the Press Complaints Commission, an independent organization that oversees the news media. During that time, he saw a lot of "brutally harsh" coverage of the Prince. "I think he was maligned and treated unfairly, and I hope in this job I can help him understand the modern media," Bolland says. "I believe in the institution, and he's going to be it. He's only going to survive if he can take the proper path from all the interference of recent years."
In a notable piece of modern-day networking, the Prince has hired the hot London public relations firm of Brown Lloyd James, whose partners come from backgrounds the monarchy has long held at a distance. A naturalized American from Liverpool, Peter Brown was one of the original managers of the Beatles and has used his New York base to represent the BBC, Christies, Andrew Lloyd Webber and other prominent people in British culture. Howell James was in charge of the political office at 10 Downing Street under Prime Minister John Major, and Sir Nicholas Lloyd was the editor of The Daily Express.
Perhaps most important, Bolland, the three partners and Tom Shebbeare, the chief executive of the trust, are all friends of Peter Mandelson, the Minister for Trade and Industry in Blair's Government and the chief architect, strategist and enforcer of the acutely image-conscious New Labor party.
The Prince's current honeymoon with the British press began after a simple act of reconciliation suggested by his new aides. For 10 years, he had not directed a personal word at any of the reporters covering him. Then, on a trip between South Africa and Swaziland last year, a shirt-sleeved Prince walked back to the economy section of the plane where the press was riding and struck up conversations. He captivated the surprised reporters with a few jokes on himself, and by the same afternoon The Evening Standard was on the streets of London with a front page saying, "Chattering Charles Plays Royal Tour Joker."
The charm offensive was on. Public appearances increased and Charles began to be seen at West End first nights, film openings, Spice Girl concerts -- in short, the circles where Diana once reigned. The usual titled guests at dinners at St. James's Palace and at Highgrove found themselves seated next to Charles's new friends, like Emma Thompson and Rowan Atkinson, whose comic creation Mr. Bean has come, like the Prince, to represent the lovable side of English awkwardness. The Sun, Britain's largest-selling tabloid and long a Charles tormentor, became the recipient of leaks from the Prince's office and made a rapid conversion to the rehabilitation cause. The Prince and his organic garden at Highgrove were lovingly chronicled in celebrity magazines like Hello! Charles took his sons to Vancouver, where they publicly frolicked in the caps of the Canadian Winter Olympics team. And, in a gesture interpreted as a truce, the Prince agreed to serve as patron for a new press ball.
At a birthday gala televised last weekend, the Prince himself became the star of the show, appearing in a skit with the actors Stephen Fry and Roger Moore. The scene was a restaurant, and look-alikes of Michael Jackson, Tina Turner, Madonna and Humphrey Bogart appeared on stage as Fry and Moore, the diners, tried unsuccessfully to guess who they were. Charles, an accomplished college actor at Cambridge, then walked on, playing a waiter with a cloth napkin slung over his forearm and a pen and pad at the ready. When the cheers died down, he recommended the organic vegetables and cookies made from the Highgrove granary. "They're damn good," he said. Moore pondered the Prince's performance. "I know who you're supposed to be, but you are going to have work on your voice a bit," he said to the laughing crowd.
The aides who have helped engineer the turnabout in public opinion are encouraged about the future. "We find doors flying open everywhere now where we had to really struggle before," one said. Gone are moments like the time in June 1997 when Tom Shebbeare called a press conference to announce an initiative for disadvantaged youth -- and no one came. It was the same day that Camilla Parker Bowles had a minor collision driving from her house in Wiltshire to his house at Highgrove, and the royal rat pack had gone there. How much have things changed? When the royal train pulled into Newcastle at 9:45 A.M., reporters from every major British newspaper were waiting on the platform.
Though the recognition of the Prince's pioneering accomplishments and the public sympathy for him as a single parent have given him new balance, Charles can still stumble over his bulky collection of resentments.
There is, first and foremost, the somewhat icy, always complicated relationship with his parents. On the train, our conversation at one point turned to Poundbury, the Prince's planned town of rusticated stonework homes, meandering lanes and market squares outside Dorchester in southwestern England that now has 142 houses up and occupied. While an institute and a magazine aimed at furthering his notion that modern architecture owes a debt to the past have foundered, Poundbury has overcome the ridicule that greeted it at its inception 10 years ago and obtained grudging approval from onetime critics.
The Prince expressed his bewilderment over the harsh reception it first got from the design establishment. "Amazing how I was rubbished for it, isn't it?" he said. He then betrayed a keener disappointment -- the lack of enthusiasm for it shown by the two people whose approval he has spent his life craving. The Queen and Prince Philip had recently paid a 20-minute visit to the site, he said. The narrative glance at the clock was not as gratuitous as it sounds. I had been told days earlier that he had erupted when he heard about the brevity of the tour, saying, "The project of my lifetime, and my parents give it 20 minutes of their time."
It is clear, too, that the Prince has not fully freed himself from the sense of anger he felt a year ago at being cast as a villain who betrayed a saint, a careless adulterer who married a virgin for dynastic reasons and then destroyed her emotionally. "You know the Prince thought that Diana was on a mission to destroy him," one courtier explained. He recalled a night in which Charles could talk of nothing else until the aide, a relative newcomer to the staff, said: "You can't keep going on like this. You must get on with your future." The Prince agreed that he was being "obsessive" but insisted on talking on. "Unless you hear what went on in the past," he said, "you won't understand how I am today."
How he is today, friends say, is a lot more pleasant than he used to be, and the behavior figures prominently in his rehabilitation. "He's actually doing the same things he did before," said a Prince's Trust executive, "but he is much more relaxed and confident that he can do things on his own. It helps not having someone out there saying, 'I can do that better than you can.' "
Of course, he is still far from taming his notorious moodiness or mastering his tantrums, but the best antidote to them, Camilla Parker Bowles, is more frequently at hand.
"He is a world-class, wall-to-wall whinger," one of his closest aides said, invoking the English word for whining that makes self-pity sound even more insufferable. A woman who heads up one of his charities looked aghast at the recollection of a moment when she lost patience with the Prince and apparently lost track of whom she was speaking to. "He does moan about so," she said. "One day I just said to him: 'Stop complaining. We all have problem parents.' "
At a dinner at his Highgrove estate in Gloucestershire one recent night, the Prince asked one of his guests, Trade Minister Mandelson, how his fellow cabinet members regarded him. Mandelson, who can be blunt, said that they all thought he was very hard-working and possessed a deep social conscience but that they all also agreed he felt too sorry for himself.
Shortly afterward, the Prince retreated to the front hall and sat uneasily in a chair, shuffling his feet about and looking wounded. He asked people around him if Mandelson was right. Camilla was dispatched to exercise the dust-yourself-off treatment that she is apparently often called upon to administer. "I don't think any of us can cope with you asking that question over and over again for the next month," she said. He looked up sheepishly. "Well then, how about for just the next 20 minutes?" he said.
This episode was related as an example of his self-deprecating humor, a potentially winning quality in someone who was raised on such privilege and at such a remove from normal life. As the whinging has declined, his friends say, his ability to make sport over his position and background have grown.
In the Swiss ski resort of Klosters last winter, he was walking one evening to the next-door chalet of his best friends Patti and Charles Palmer-Tomkinson, and the icy pavement was proving dangerously slippery. After several near spills, Charles grasped the arm of an aide. Wouldn't it have been more sensible for the Prince to have worn boots? the aide asked gingerly. Charles shot him an arch look. "In my family," he responded, "I was brought up to wear shoes in the ev 'ening."
On a weekend this fall, the telephone rang in Bolland's London apartment. The playful voice at the other end belonged to Charles, indulging the forbidden pleasure of picking up a phone while no one from the royal household was paying attention and placing a call himself. The Prince said he was sorry for bothering his aide at home. Then he asked eagerly if he was interrupting anything exciting. "Actually, I was emptying the dishwasher," Bolland replied. "Oh, yes," said the Prince. "And now I am supposed to say, 'What's that?' "
Associates of his say that life with Camilla -- referred to as "Mrs. P.B." in the Prince's office -- has reached the comfort level of a longtime stable marriage. She is essential to him and to his recovery, they all say in one way or another. Cmdr. Richard Aylard, his former private secretary, first coined the phrase "a nonnegotiable part of his private life" to describe her importance, and it is now a mantra among the Prince's aides and friends. One
person who's often with them said their association was "telepathic," with her sensing his moods and their consequences before Charles himself did.
The Queen has never dropped the objections to Camilla that she first had in the early 1970's, when she learned that her son was sleeping with the wife of Andrew Parker Bowles, then the commander of the Household Cavalry and holder of the royal title of Silver Stick in Waiting. She does not attend functions Camilla might be at. The Queen's private secretary, Sir Robert Fellowes, the husband of Diana's sister Jane and a starchy traditionalist, blames Camilla for wrecking the marriage and shaming the House of Windsor, and he has encouraged the Queen to persist in her snub.
Prince Charles's handlers loathe Sir Robert, who is retiring in February. And hopes for a suddenly better relationship with his successor, Sir Robin Janvrin, were dashed by an incident this summer. On a day when Prince William and Camilla were to have tea together in the Prince's living quarters in St. James's Palace, Sir Robin refused the Prince's invitation to be introduced to her, pleading the absence of any authorization by the Queen. Charles later asked friends how Sir Robin could have been so rude to him in his own house.
The Prince's managers are widely suspected of dribbling out the Prince's relationship with Camilla in order to gain public acceptance of it. "I promise you there is no intention, no plan, no plot, no conspiracy," said one of them, but the spigot, now that it is open, continues to water people's curiosity drop by timely drop.
In the run-up to his birthday, the Prince's image-shapers got overconfident and committed a tactical blunder by going so far as to deconstruct the myth of Diana. It was a miscalculation that ended up producing an impression that spin doctors in the Prince's office were spiraling out of control.
What led to the stir were reports arguing that Diana, far from being the victim of a feckless and unfeeling husband and his possessive mistress, was in fact the first to commit adultery and put the royal marriage at risk and that she later telephoned death threats to Camilla. These reports, based on information supplied by people around the Prince, also contended that the two young Princes had tired of the glamorous life that Diana introduced them to and preferred the warmth of the Windsor hearth. The Prince had to put out a statement, the first ever representing both him and Camilla, saying that they had provided no assistance to Penny Junor, the author of "Charles: Victim or Villain?" the biography that contained the most explicit charges.
In their more furtive days, Charles and Camilla would meet in a Welsh farmhouse owned by a former brother-in-law of Camilla's. But nowadays they spend nights together at his Highgrove estate and at York House, the self-contained five-bedroom section of St. James's Palace that he occupies. In September, they went on a weeklong Aegean cruise with four friends in a borrowed yacht and, though they succeeded in eluding photographers the whole time, the Prince's office freely confirmed the facts of the journey once word got out on their return.
"They are really able to be together for the first time, and they are still getting used to it," a person who sees them frequently said. "This week he'll be in London for three days, and she'll be in London for three days. That's a new thing for them."
Camilla is emphatic in saying she wants no part of Charles's life of public duty and has no desire to be Queen. She even revels in her status of royal mistress. In one of her earliest meetings with the Prince more than 25 years ago, she pointed out to him that her great-grandmother Alice Keppel and his great-great-grandfather Edward VII had been lovers. Today she often wears Keppel's dress jewelry and has a portrait of her ancestor in a prominent spot on the wall of her home in Wiltshire. According to guests at a dinner in St. James's Palace in October, Camilla was fascinated to meet Brooke Astor because as a child the New York philanthropist had met Keppel.
Camilla's home, a former mill house in Chippenham, 17 miles from Highgrove, is described as studiously untidy, with muddy Wellingtons in the foyer, brimming ashtrays on fine furniture pieces and untended tears in the carpet. Friends say it perfectly reflects her lack of self-consciousness. Britain's tabloids have been less kind to her inattention to appearances. They have savaged her as slovenly and witchlike, and one recently pictured her alongside a horse and asked readers to choose which one they would rather go to bed with. She has remained resolutely silent.
She has less interest than the Prince in books and classical music, but they share a love of riding, hunting, gardening and painting watercolors, and they break each other up with bathroom humor, something that always seems to be good for a laugh among the finished products of British upper-class schools. Both also like to drive at faith-inspiring speeds around the hedgerowed back lanes of Wiltshire and Gloucestershire.
The subject of marriage remains unresolved and has been put off for the moment. "They actually talk about it less now than they did two years ago," an aide to the Prince said. Their greatest dread, he admitted, is that it will become a matter for tabloid speculation. "They are horrified at the prospect of headlines like, 'Show Her You Love Her, Charlie.' " Asked if they were simply playing for time while public accommodation with their partnership grew, the aide reasoned, "We know that a Prince of Wales with a girlfriend is fine, but a King with a girlfriend is tricky."
If they ever did decide to marry, they would have to contend with the Church of England, which has frowned on the prospects of the heir to the throne marrying a divorced woman. There are signs, though, that the relationship may be gaining acceptance in the higher ranks. The Right Rev. Richard Harries, the Bishop of Oxford and the head of the church's Board of Social Responsibility, told the BBC this month that "the fact that they can get some support and mutual encouragement from one another and clearly have a very deep relationship, I think, deserves understanding and compassion." The Bishop of Durham, the Right Rev. Michael Turnbull, went a step further, saying it would be "more desirable morally" for the couple to marry than to stay in their present state.
Charles, who is a regular churchgoer and prays daily, has often spoken of his interest in Islam and other Eastern religions and of his contempt for the latent anti-Catholicism in the original establishment of the Church of England. He has suggested he might want to change the oath to make the King not the defender of the faith but simply the defender of faith, thereby disestablishing the Church of England. Though the opportunity to marry Camilla free of religious disapproval would not be the motivation for such a move, it would be a result of it.
With his mother, 72, in excellent health and her mother going strong at 98, there is cause to wonder if Charles will ever become King and what he can do in the present post as his tenure stretches to a fourth decade. He became the Prince of Wales in 1969. He has never lost interest in becoming King, despite reports to the contrary, but he did realize a year ago that the public had little interest in his becoming King. Hence the decision to mount a campaign to regain their trust.
His aides refer to his becoming King as "moving up to No. 1"; Charles himself will allude to it by saying, "When I will be doing my mother's job." The Queen increasingly lets him represent the monarchy out of England as he did in Hong Kong in June 1997 for the turnover of the colony to China and in Omagh in August after a bomb devastated the center of that Northern Ireland town.
"The Queen quite likes being Queen, and she doesn't give up much," said one of the Prince's men, a little testily. As the Prince has set out to define himself as someone not hostage to encrusted tradition, tensions between the staffs at Buckingham and St. James's Palace are on the rise, with the Prince's people favoring more manipulation of information to benefit their royal client and an aggressive, open and direct communication with the public. "We believe the Prince is the voice of what the monarchy is going to be in the 21st century," one aide said firmly.
Is it possible to imagine what King Charles III would be like? "When he moves up to No. 1," an aide answered, "he obviously takes on responsibilities and sheds others. As King he can't run around and lecture everybody. But then, knowing him, he probably will."
Charles already has some housekeeping changes in mind. He would not live in Buckingham Palace, turning it instead into the monarchy's London office while making Windsor Castle in suburban Berkshire his residence in the capital. And he would try to readjust the financing of the monarchy to reduce the drain on the taxpayer and increase his own financial independence. Highgrove, St. James's Palace and the Duchy of Lancaster lands would go to his son William when he becomes the next Prince of Wales.
Mention the top job, and the Prince's staff talk in the future, not the conditional tense, about when, not if. They are confident to the point of arrogance that their once-belittled man can bring stature to the post. "It will be nice to have a King who's thoughtful," one said. "We haven't had one for a while."
Just a year ago, pollsters found many Britons who thought Charles should plan on stepping aside and letting William succeed his grandmother Elizabeth to the throne. All such talk has ended now, with William left free to have as normal an adolescence as an heir apparent dressed in a morning coat and striped trousers at Eton can have.
He will assume no royal duties until at least six years from now, when he graduates from university. It is not known whether Charles discusses that future with his son, but it is evident that Charles's chief concern is that his son not be subjected to the ascetic rigors of his own childhood. At the same age, Charles was sent for toughening up to the all-boys Gordonstoun school in Scotland, with its regimen of bullying, cold showers and barechested morning runs. He hated it and begged his parents to let him come home. Years later, he got verbal revenge, recalling Gordonstoun as "Colditz in kilts."
William, by contrast, is said to like school. In a series of written answers to questions on his 16th birthday last June from the Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, William emerged as a youth mature beyond his age but with the normal teen-age enthusiasms for pop music and fast food intact after a tumultuous year that forced him into a public role long before anyone intended.
As a new century approaches, England is stepping out smartly, its quickened pace symbolized more by digital pulses, darting cursors and techno-music than by the stately swagger of the British Monarchy. Yet there is hardly anyone in this toe-tapping population who wants to throw the royals out of the advancing columns.
Britons can satirize the Windsors, vilify them, make them live in smaller houses, force them to pay taxes -- whatever; the fact is, they want to keep them. That's what 73 percent of the population said in the most recent poll on the subject, and the number is on the rise with the nudge the new-and-improved Prince is applying.
Recent years have shown that no matter how badly the family behaves, in Britain no republican movement arises to turn the royals out. Mention the downsized monarchies in Scandinavia and the Netherlands, and people here talk sneeringly of "kings on bicycles."
Most members of Tony Blair's self-described "radical" government are not ashamed to call themselves monarchists. The same sentiments greeted the Prince everywhere he went on the day I followed him -- from the faces of children waving their Union Jacks on the Newcastle docks to the eager handshakes of nervous students at a job-training center to the preening of local officials, done up in sashes and gold chains of office, at a new museum in Sunderland.
The popularity of the monarchy itself in Britain has recuperated scarcely a year after it was discredited for its crabbed response to the death of Diana and during a year in which the country was being transformed by a new administration with a mission to "rebrand" Britain and discard outdated symbols of its imperial past.
How can a government bent on "modernizing" Britain -- the word appears more than any other in the voluminous literature put out by the Blair Government -- justify its enthusiasm for something as antique as the British monarchy? Mandelson, the Blair cabinet member who is on the closest terms with the Prince, said there was no contradiction. "I think you can both modernize an institution and respect its traditions," he said. "You can modernize whilst preserving if you question some of the more archaic practices and if you encourage the royal family who are the tenants of this institution to be outward looking and up with the times without losing their dignity."
On his day visiting the Northeast, Charles ended up leaving a trail of shiny new plaques behind him in the cities of Newcastle and Sunderland. He is informal and chatty in his public appearances, accomplished at small talk and surprisingly tactile for a man with a reputation for being chilly and distant.
People are courteous and decorous but not deferential. They tend to stick a "sir" into their comments to him, though there is no established requirement to do so. Speakers presenting him will always refer to him as "Your Royal Highness." In the long day of official visits in which he greeted hundreds of people, only one woman bowed at his approach, and he used a handshake to hoist her quickly back into upright position.
A daily exerciser, he's physically fit and agile as he moves through the crowded spaces of his public life. His tailoring is a lot bolder than he is, giving him a British bounder jauntiness that disguises his shyness and isolation. As the afternoon wore on in Sunderland, the Prince began to sag, his left leg bent outward and his right hand shoved into his side jacket pocket. It was a stance that recalled the days when he was mocked for being innocent, weak and indecisive, the boy who on bellying up to a pub bar for the first time famously ordered a cherry brandy. In his new made-over state, however, the posture appears more as a mark of winsome vulnerability.
Where royals once aimed at intimidating their subjects, he devotes himself to being ingratiating to them. He often undercuts a statement that might sound too regal and commanding with a phrase like, "whatever that means" or "if I may say so." He appears to invite people to share in the preposterousness of much of the ceremony he is obliged to conduct. "Now you may not think it takes great skill to do this," he told a group of trainees in Newcastle as he eyed yet another velvet curtain covering yet another plaque, "but it takes a lot of training. I've served a long apprenticeship, and I think I've seen this type before."
He told them of a large drapery in Cairo that wouldn't budge even with two people adding their muscle to his. All part of the daily challenges lurking in the small print of a modern Prince's job description, he seemed to be saying. Then he stepped up to the task at hand and announced with brio, "I will now perform this with immense skill though I have no idea where it will end up."

HEADLINE: FILM;
Grim, Shocking, Didactic, a New New Wave Rolls In

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LOPATE; Phillip Lopate's collection of film criticism, "Totally, Tenderly, Tragically," has just been published by Anchor Books.

 BODY:
THESE days a mood of optimism and brash confidence has once again taken hold of French filmmaking. A new generation of films -- "My Sex Life," "Irma Vep," "The Dreamlife of Angels" and "I Stand Alone" -- is causing an international stir with its uninhibited depictions of contemporary society, and taking festival prizes and even finding American distribution. Some are calling it the new New Wave, the Next Wave or the Re-New Wave; others, more skeptically, a hype-created ripple.
The original Nouvelle Vague, or New Wave, of the 1960's looks, in retrospect, like a miracle, with Jean-Luc Godard, Francois Truffaut, Eric Rohmer, Claude Chabrol, Alain Resnais, Louis Malle, Jacques Rivette, Agnes Varda and Jacques Demy all re-inventing cinema as free expression. Even if such a national renaissance cannot expect to be repeated in a half-century, there is no question that French filmmaking is undergoing a resurgence. 
 The old New Wave was a band of brothers: Parisian film-critics-turned-directors who started out as friends and collaborators (whatever fallings-out later occurred). But the current crop of auteurs tends to be more fragmented and tribal. To oversimplify: one tribe (Arnaud Desplechin, Olivier Assayas, Mathieu Amaric) consists of Parisian, largely Jewish, intellectuals making realistic, urbane, analytical films about the lives of graduate students, wannabe writers and professionals. Another tribe (Erick Zonca, Gaspar Noe, Mathieu Kassovitz, Bruno Dumont) focuses more somberly and often angrily on the working class -- dropout youths from the provinces or the housing project neighborhoods or suburbs, who either get into trouble or get trapped on the assembly line.
Perhaps the most gifted of the lot is Arnaud Desplechin. His first feature, "La Sentinelle" (released here last month), was a fascinatingly layered drama about a medical student finding a severed head; his attempt at identifying it leads to a hornet's nest of issues about loyalty and politics at the end of the cold war. Besides writing extraordinarily eloquent dialogues, Mr. Deplechin is a stickler for physical gestures and will film multiple takes until he gets exactly the right shrug or cigarette angle he is looking for. His second feature -- and so far the masterpiece of the new New Wave -- is "My Sex Life (or How I Got Into an Argument)," a three-hour, richly novelistic comedy about several brainy, competitive, neurotic philosophers. The charmingly hangdog Mathieu Amalric plays Paul, a perpetual student who can't seem to finish his doctorate and keeps vacillating among three women. Mr. Amalric, whom the New York Times film critic Janet Maslin described as "his generation's Jean-Pierre Leaud," projects a shy, likable warmth, self-deprecating intelligence and decency even when he is playing lecherous Peter Pan characters who resist growing up. (Mr. Amalric's own feature, "Eat Your Soup," was praised by Godard as the best film he'd seen in years.)
Fellow filmmakers were drawn to him. "I think it's because I wasn't an actor at the start that I got used so much; I know I have very little range," Mr. Amalric said in New York recently, with a puckish smile. "I mostly work for filmmakers who speak in the first person, and who can imagine me as their alter ego."
Where did this "first person" style come from? One of the less desirable effects of the original New Wave's aura was its tendency to eclipse the very talented generation of filmmakers that immediately followed. Maurice Pialat, Andre Techine, Chantal Akerman, Bertrand Tavernier, Jean Eustache, Philippe Garrel, Benoit Jacquot and Jacques Doillon, all labored in the shadow of the New Wave's glamour, creating a daring, often brilliant body of work without ever achieving name art-house status. But the personal, intransigently marginal filmmaking of (especially) Mr. Eustache, Mr. Garrel, Ms. Akerman and Mr. Doillon had a greater influence on the younger filmmakers than did their New Wave elders.
For instance, Mr. Eustache's "Mother and the Whore" (1973), a three-hour film about an overeducated, underachieving guy torn between two women, has haunted much of the French cinema that followed, setting a reproachful standard for honesty and intensity. Its archetypal French film plot, of extracting oneself from an old love and immersing oneself in a new, had an obvious influence on Mr. Deplechin's "My Sex Life" and Mr. Garrel's "Birth of Love." Speaking from the other camp, Gaspar Noe has said: "I love Eustache. He came from the lower class, and he had some anger, something existentialist, almost Dostoyevskian, that is totally missing in the other French directors."
The New Wave opened the door to a fresher, more casual filmmaking approach: real locations, improvisations, jump-cuts, hand-held camera, self-reflexive distancing jokes. Today's younger filmmakers take this vocabulary as a matter of course; their shocks come from elsewhere.
Gaspar Noe's "I Stand Alone" is an act of aggression against audiences: its protagonist, an unemployed butcher, kicks his pregnant wife in the stomach and either slits his daughter's throat (or fantasizes doing so) while spewing racist, homophobic, incestuous thoughts on the soundtrack. All in the service of what the filmmaker calls "a cinema of catharsis." Yet this brutality is undercut by jarring sound effects, supergraphic titles and a sly, over-rhetorical expressionism. Mr. Noe says that the deadpan comedy in Leonard Kastle's 1970 cult classic, "The Honeymoon Killers," served as his model. A slight, polite, head-shaven young man, Mr. Noe was delighted that a man fainted at this year's Toronto Film Festival screening, and chagrined that the New York Film Festival audience seemed to take his shock treatment in stride. Callowly provocative as his worldview sometimes seems, he has a filmmaker's instinctive touch: a genius for arresting compositions and poetically grim locations.
Mr. Noe professes little use for the films of his contemporaries Mr. Assayas and Mr. Desplechin, much less Mr. Rohmer, with their (to his mind) privileged, boringly bourgeois characters. He much prefers the stark, harsh portrait of a racist delinquent in Bruno Dumont's "Life of Jesus," which won le Prix Jean Vigo for best first feature in 1997, or Mathieu Kassovitz's lacerating if sophomoric "Hate," about disaffected multicultural youth, or this year's surprise debut hit Erick Zonca's "Dreamlife of Angels," which follows the dead-end lives of two young working-class women. "Lumpen types are more naked, you can see their scars more easily. I don't think I could ever shoot a movie about high society," says Mr. Noe.
Oliver Assayas, at 43 the veteran of the Parisian group, rolls his eyes at Noe's comments; he's heard it all before. "I respect his and his friends' filmmaking, but what I don't like is their saying that the reality they're depicting is the only reality. I don't like the sanctimonious aspect of their discourse. To my mind, modern alienation, the pain of everyday life, the lack of meaning, is as strong and disturbing for the petit bourgeoisie as for the working class."
Mr. Assayas has evoked that pain most powerfully in his 1994 film "Cold Water," about middle-class youth in the 70's who lash out at inner emptiness with drugs, stealing and self-destructive behavior. The remarkable 20-minute party scene in which they trash a suburban home is one of the apotheoses of recent French cinema, and a triumph of Mr. Assayas's patient, observantly mobile camera. He followed it up with the comic, wildly satiric "Irma Vep" (1996), starring the Hong Kong actress Maggie Cheung, about a film production that also gravitates toward chaos.
But in his most recent film, the soon-to-be-released "Late August, Early September," Mr. Assayas opts for a more thoughtful, mature focus, as he charts a circle of friends turning 40 and facing career disappointments, aging and death. There is nothing "privileged" or "safe" about the raw feelings and economic struggles of this group on the precipitous verge of middle age, still trying to construct authentic selves.
An important filmmaker who bridges the Parisian and the proletarian group is Claire Denis. She is a good friend of Mr. Assayas, and her movies (like "No Fear, No Die" and "I Can't Sleep") treat the problems of African guest-workers or Algerian immigrants. In these subtle, empathetic films, Ms. Denis uncovers the growing pains of a new, multicultural French society, without the blunt didacticism of other, politically progressive filmmakers who are trying to speak out against the National Front's brand of racism.
Issues of class, cinematic style and genre can't help intersecting. The bruised, proletariat characters in last year's "Life of Jesus" -- as inarticulate as cows in the field -- are served well by a bleakly minimalist Bressonian style. Paradoxically the audience for such movies is almost entirely the educated middle class. On the other hand, the film theorist Stanley Cavell once observed that one of the reasons the characters in witty talking comedies were nearly all middle-class was that the middle class had the leisure to converse. Another key dividing line in French cinema today is the degree to which the pervasiveness of American filmmaking is resisted or embraced. A few years back, even as the French film industry began to speak out against the market domination of Hollywood, many French film school graduates became enamored of the jazzy rhythms and darkly smirking attitudes of Quentin Tarrantino, David Lynch and other American independent filmmakers. As one of these graduates, Gaspar Noe, said, "I feel more in common with Todd Haynes's 'Velvet Goldmine' or Todd Solondz's 'Happiness' than I do with most French filmmakers." His new motion picture, "Enter the Void," will be shot in English.
His friend Mathieu Kassovitz has also moved, temporarily, to Hollywood and is trying to mount an English-language production. The Parisian tribe of Mr. Deplechin and Mr. Assayas would seem to be clinging to a more self-consciously French style, with their slower, talkier, more character-driven and nuanced chamber dramas.
The tension between the two esthetics is hilariously sent up in Mr. Assayas's "Irma Vep," when a young French journalist interviews Maggie, the beautiful Hong Kong actress who is about to star in an art-film remake of the 1915-16 classic "Les Vampires." The journalist says he can't stand these precious French art films; the only motion pictures that are truly alive are the Hong Kong and Hollywood action flicks. His harangue is actually a paraphrase of opinions expressed by Mathieu Kassovitz in an interview.
But when I asked Mr. Assayas whom he was satirizing he said: "Myself! He's like a monstrous version of myself as a young man. I began in film criticism, I wrote the issue on Hong Kong movies for Cahiers du Cinema and then I found, to my horror, that people were using Hong Kong action films to trash the values of the other moviemakers whom I loved -- like Bergman and Rohmer."
MEANWHILE, most of the original New Wave directors are still alive and working, though their avuncular expressions no longer shake the world as they did when they were Young Turks. Mr. Rohmer's most recent, "Tale of Autumn," is the wise, delicately witty work of a septuagenarian; Mr. Resnais's latest, "Same Old Song," is sublimely mellow, melancholy, lyrical; Mr. Godard continues to stretch the boundaries between fiction and essay-film with his video series, "Histoire(s) du Cinema." The patriarchs are busy commenting, kibitzing, appreciating (and sometimes, no doubt, wishing ill to) the younger filmmakers who have inherited their mantle, and who basically ignore them.
Both the new Parisian and the provincial-working-class camps have surprisingly much in common: a sexual frankness; an emotional grittiness; an openness to Cassavetes-inspired, informal camera work, a resistance to the frothy lure of "Gallic charm," which many Americans still expect from French movies. France has continuously been one of the great national cinemas -- which means that at no time in the last hundred years have impressive movies not been made there. But American audiences don't always get the chance to see French quality films because of the vagaries of distribution.
During the 80's, there was a near-blackout; now, thanks partly to the promotional hype surrounding this new New Wave, that situation may be rectified. If so, it is hype in a worthy cause.

LENGTH: 1557 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Searching Journey Into the Heart of Brazil

BYLINE: By LAURA WINTERS; Laura Winters writes about arts and entertainment here and abroad.

 BODY:
ONE morning in late 1996, the Brazilian director Walter Salles was waiting for a flight in Rio de Janeiro when he was approached by a 9-year-old shoeshine boy. At the time, Mr. Salles was preparing to shoot his third feature film, "Central Station," the tale of an older woman and a boy who meet at Rio's train station and then strike out on a journey into the hinterlands to find the boy's father.
Fernanda Montenegro, Brazil's doyenne of stage and film, had agreed to play the woman, Dora, but Mr. Salles had still not found anyone to play Josue, the child. "In one full year we had tested 1,500 boys," he said. "I was getting desperate." 
 The shoeshine boy, Vinicius de Oliveira, had other concerns, however. "It was raining that day, and I wasn't making any money," he recalled, speaking through an interpreter at the Toronto Film Festival. "I couldn't shine Walter's shoes because he was wearing sneakers, but I asked if he could lend me some money so I could eat and I would pay him back. He told me, 'I'll give you the money to buy a sandwich, but you also have to do a screen test for me.' "
When Vinicius finally showed up for the test, he brought his friends with him, "the entire fraternity of shoeshine boys from the airport," Mr. Salles said, laughing. He chose Vinicius for the role because, he said, "I was looking for a boy who knew what the battle for survival was, but who had not lost his innocence in doing so.
"I cannot even say that I found Vinicius. It's more honest to say that he found me."
The story of how "Central Station" was made, over a vast territory, with a small budget and crew and many novice collaborators, embodies the theme of the film itself: the triumph of steadfastness over adversity. Both a portrait of present day Brazil and a two-person drama, "Central Station," which opened on Friday, manages to be intimate and epic, local and universal.
"One day I woke up with this idea of a film about a quest," said Mr. Salles, 42. "It was the search for a father that a kid had never met, the search of an old woman for the feelings that she had lost and the search somehow for a certain country that was not the country I was living in anymore."
Mr. Salles's work is informed by the search for identity, both on a personal and national level, a concern stemming largely from his own background. Born in Brazil to a banking family, he spent part of his childhood in France and the United States where his father was a diplomat. When he returned to Brazil, he eventually decided to become a documentary filmmaker.
This combination of an outsider's perspective and an insider's understanding has shaped Mr. Salles's work. "I think the fact that I have been raised in several different countries has given me both a sense of continuous exile and a desire to understand my own culture," he said recently in New York, speaking in fluent English.
The dark-haired Mr. Salles, who has kind eyes and a ready laugh, is both warm and disarmingly modest. "When you come from a privileged part of Brazilian society, as I do, you have to opt either to be part of that culture of indifference or to understand what the country really is," he said.
His movie comes at a time when Brazilian cinema is once again flourishing. After a period of forced inactivity in the early 1990's, when the Government of President Fernando Collor de Mello froze individual bank accounts and shut down the state film agency, film production has risen to approximately 40 films a year.
But the reality of everyday life that "Central Station" depicts is harsh. In the film, Dora is a bitter woman who makes her living in Rio's Central Station, writing letters for illiterate people. She takes their money but discards the letters. One day she writes a letter for a mother and her little boy (Vinicius de Oliveira). When the mother is killed in an accident outside the station, Dora tries to sell the boy for adoption. Realizing that she has instead sold him to a sinister organization in which he may come to harm, she rescues the boy and the two set out on a bus trip to find his father.
For Mr. Salles, Dora is the epitome of modern Brazil, with its "culture of cynicism." But as Dora grudgingly develops a bond with the boy "she begins to understand that the boy's route and the boy's ordeal are comparable to her own," he said.
The growing friendship between these two -- more comradely than mother-son -- is, for Mr. Salles, a symbol of a Brazil where solidarity and compassion may be buried but are still present. His film is not utopian, but it celebrates the diversity both of the land and of what Mr. Salles calls the "human geography" that Dora and Josue encounter on their journey.
When the screenplay of "Central Station," based on an idea of Mr. Salles's and written by Joao Emanuel Carneiro and Marcos Bernstein, won a prize sponsored by the Sundance Institute and the Japan Broadcasting Corporation in early 1996, it attracted the attention of Arthur Cohn, the Swiss independent producer who has won five Academy Awards (one for Vittorio De Sica's "Garden of the Finzi-Continis").
LIKE De Sica, Walter's approach is humanistic," said Mr. Cohn. "De Sica taught me that there were four main points to making significant films. One was to cast actors who are right for the part, not just those with big names. Two was to shoot the film on authentic locations. Three was that sex, violence or special effects are not necessary unless they're intrinsic to the story." He smiled. "Four was not to listen to everybody's advice, but to follow your intuition."
With Mr. Cohn as producer, and with his principal cast finally in place Mr. Salles started the collaborative rehearsal process he had favored with his second film, "Foreign Land" (1995). "It's a work almost like that of theater," said Ms. Montenegro, 69, in New York. "For two months we sat around a table, reading and discussing the script."
The long preparation allowed Mr. Salles to move quickly and to improvise once filming began in November 1996. During the filming of Ms. Montenegro's scenes in the railroad station, several passersby took her to be an actual letter-writer and asked her to write letters for them, scenes that made it into the movie. In following the journey of Dora and Josue, Mr. Salles had to move his team from Rio to remote regions of northeast Brazil, to the states of Bahia and Pernambuco. "The transport from one place to another sometimes took three days on dirt roads," said Mr. Salles. "It was like being in a circus for several weeks."
Nor were conditions easy, due to the extreme heat and the poverty of the villages where Mr. Salles was filming. Yet the welcome that his crew received allowed the unforeseen to occur, as in a scene where Dora and Josue come upon a religious pilgrimage in full swing. Mr. Salles had the actual pilgrims recreate this candlelight vigil.
Mr. Salles is a largely self-taught filmmaker. After studying history and economics in college in Brazil, he attended only one year of film school, at the University of Southern California, before returning to Rio in 1981 to make documentaries.
His move toward feature films was gradual. In 1989, he directed "Exposure," starring Peter Coyote and based on the Brazilian writer Rubem Fonseca's novel "High Art." "Foreign Land," about two young Brazilians bereft in Lisbon, delved into the themes of physical and spiritual voyage and of loss. "Sometimes I am asked why I was so pessimistic in 'Foreign Land' and why I open the possibility of optimism with 'Central Station,' " Mr. Salles said. "But the films portray different moments of Brazilian reality."
He paused. "When you see films today, it seems that most of the characters endure a situation they cannot control," he said. "Here I wanted to show that tough as life may be, it can be possible to transcend this initial adversity."
That hopeful message may explain the widespread appeal of "Central Station." The film has been a big success in Brazil, where it has been seen by more than a million viewers, but it also had positive audience response at the Sundance, Toronto and Berlin film festivals. "During the screenings we held in Toronto, I saw tears rolling down people's faces," said Ramiro Puerta, the programmer for Latin American and Spanish films in Toronto.
As the film opens around the world, Mr. Salles's own life these days resembles a road movie. But even in the wake of "Central Station's" success, he has no plans to relocate from Rio -- where he lives in a forested area outside the city with his six large dogs -- or to change his thematic pursuits.
With Daniela Thomas, a co-director of "Foreign Land," Mr. Salles has written and directed a short feature called "Midnight," and he will work again with Arthur Cohn on two films still being written.
Embarking on these projects, Mr. Salles seems to want to explore further the need for connection -- whether between individuals or between peoples -- that "Central Station" embraces. " 'Central Station' is much more about brotherhood than it is about a specific country," he said. "Even as an artist, you need to know that what you do is part of a larger whole. You need to be part of a dialogue." He smiled. "In Brazil, we have this expression: 'One bird alone does not announce the spring.' "
