HEADLINE: Growing Pains;
The Midtown Direct Line, a Victim of Its Own Success, Leaves Riders Grumbling About the Rush-Hour Madness

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
ON Monday mornings, when the 8:09 Midtown Direct rolls out of the neat brick station in the upscale suburb of Summit, there are still a few open seats. Three stops and 11 minutes later, when the train, New Jersey Transit No. 6620, leaves Maplewood, suited bodies cover every bit of brown vinyl upholstery, filling even the least desired seats in the middle of the bench. Passengers try to read their papers standing; some overflow into the vestibules, those forbidden areas between the cars. Even the conductors, who greet people with compelling geniality, as if desperate to maintain morale, sometimes just give up.
"I can't tell you how many times this happens," said Susan Taylor, the owner of an advertising agency, waving her ticket in vain at the conductor's retreating back. 
 Forget the standstills at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, the blockages on the George Washington Bridge that make the New Jersey commute into Manhattan notorious. Mass transit, once heralded as the solution to the rush-hour nightmare, now offers its own brand of misery.
From the tedium of finding a parking space at the station, to trains so crowded that passengers cannot even get on board, to domino-effect delays, to the dangerous jams at Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station when a trainload of rush-hour commuters glacially makes its way along the crowded platform to a few narrow stairways or idled escalators, this is the new model of the commute. Its greenest performers, the 6,000 morning rush-hour riders on the Midtown Direct -- in operation since July 1996 -- are already labeling it the "Sardine Scene" and the "Cattle Call." Seasoned veterans, the 9,900 on the North Jersey Coast line and the 21,000 on the Northeast Corridor line, long ago became inured.
Over the last 32 years, the state has pulled together a confusing jumble of bankrupt train lines into a statewide commuter rail network that collects more than 52 million fares a year, a system that is lauded as a national model of mass transit.
Indeed, N.J. Transit has been boasting in recent weeks that for the third time in five years, it was cited by the American Public Transit Association for outstanding achievement. Yet in mass transportation's equivalent of the adage that no good deed goes unpunished, the rail system is choking on its rush-hour passengers.
"Passengers want to know, when am I going to get a seat, and why are there these delays?" said a conductor, who, like many N.J. Transit employees interviewed for this article, insisted on anonymity. "But you think it's bad now? Just wait."
The Midtown Direct crush was made possible by the $69 million Kearny connection, which allowed Morris and Essex trains to head directly into Manhattan instead of leaving riders at the PATH connection in Hoboken.
Major improvements underway for decades will go into effect over the next few years, increasing by thousands the numbers of riders. Simple population growth will add even more. But the rail tunnel under the Hudson River built early in the century -- one tunnel with two tracks -- can handle only about 20 trains an hour, and Pennsylvania Station is already near capacity at more than 800 trains a day. The station suffers vicious cycles of delays that start with a minor switching problem or a train running slightly behind schedule.
And that is not all. It was the decline of freight rail in the face of the mighty truck that cleared the state's tracks for commuter traffic in the first place. Now that commuter service is blossoming, a long-expected renaissance of rail freight is about to arrive with the takeover of Conrail by CSX and Norfolk Southern.
ALAN PISARSKI, a transit researcher, said that New Jersey Transit's problems had no parallel. New York City's mass transit has also seen demand rise, largely because of the success of the discounts possible with the MetroCard. But that, he pointed out, is in an enormous city. "On suburban lines," he said, "it's really extraordinary."
Transportation systems have had different definitions of success over the last 30 years, Mr. Pisarski said. "For airlines, it has been growing fast enough to keep pace with demand," he said. "But in rail, it was cutting supply down to match demand." So N.J. Transit's boom "is not unusual," he added, "it's unheard of."
The railroad now carries about 94,000 roundtrip passengers a day, about 65,000 of them during the peak travel hours. Only a few of the trains that operate at peak periods suffer terrible crowding, and the transit system hopes that people will spread themselves out more evenly. For instance, on the Midtown Direct, there are 7,000 seats available in the morning rush, and 6,000 riders. But the empty seats are clustered in the early and late runs. The most packed Midtown Direct train, which departs Dover at 7 A.M. and is supposed to arrive at Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station at 8:19 A.M., has an average of 1,250 riders but only 1,145 seats, according to N.J. Transit.
About 160 riders stand on the 5:38 out of Long Branch, which arrives at Pennsylvania Station at 7:14 A.M., with 834 riders and 673 seats. Far more riders are stuck standing on the Northeast Corridor. The train that leaves New Brunswick at 7:45 A.M. and arrives in Manhattan at 8:40 carries 1,400 riders but has only 1,155 seats.
"That's the price of success," said Shirley A. DeLibero, executive director of N.J. Transit for the last eight years, a period of vast change. "The better the service is, the more on-time it is, the more quality service it is, people take it once and they like it."
Complicating N.J. Transit's growing pains is the imminent departure of Ms. DeLibero, who is about to leave for Houston, where she hopes to build a rail system to supplement its bus lines.
Most rail experts agree N.J. Transit is trying. Cars have been added to some trains -- the usual complement is eight -- but the railroad tries not to have them exceed the length of the station platform.
Double-decker cars are under consideration, but most designs on the market would not fit through the lone Hudson River tunnel, with its two tracks, one eastbound and one westbound. That tunnel is nearly at capacity, according to a joint planning team called Access to the Region's Core, created in 1994 by N.J. Transit, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
In a draft report to those agencies in July, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, the team called for consideration of a second Hudson tunnel with two more tracks and a connection between Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal. The project would cost about $5 billion, and take at least a decade to complete, assuming that New York, New Jersey and their various agencies could agree on a design and a way to pay for it.
Representative Bob Franks, a Republican from the 7th Congressional District encompassing parts of Essex, Middlesex, Somerset and Union counties, said in a recent interview that design money for a new tunnel had been authorized and that in January he intended to fight for the next step, appropriation of the funds.
Lacking a new tunnel, the outlook is grim. New equipment will eventually allow a few more trains an hour through the tunnel into Manhattan, but Pennsylvania Station has only 21 tracks that are shared by the Long Island Rail Road, Amtrak and N.J. Transit. And the sharing is strained, according to some accounts, partly because the train dispatchers -- the equivalent of an airport's controllers -- are employees of Amtrak and the Long Island Rail Road.
"It's a constant flow, and when the rush hour occurs, it's crazy," said a rail manager for one of the region's commuter lines, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. He said he had seen dispatchers bicker and delay one another's trains. "Penn Station cannot handle any more trains."
But Walter Zullig, the special counsel to Metro North, who is chairman of a committee on commuter rail for a national research organization, said the rivalries were more historical than current or personal.
"Railroad people always get very nervous when some other company controls the rails they're on," Mr. Zullig said. "But we are all so interdependent now, any railroad that would start playing games like that would pay for it."
Still, new drains on the capacity of Pennsylvania Station are bearing down: Amtrak is to begin high-speed service between Boston and Washington late next year, which will bring more trains into Manhattan. And longstanding plans are on schedule to start bringing Metro North trains into Penn Station in the next decade while moving Long Island Rail Road operations to Grand Central.
Not all of the state's widening pool of commuters are bound for Manhattan. With a growing corporate presence in suburban centers like Morristown and along the Northeast Corridor, at least 10,100 commuters a day are heading somewhere in New Jersey; 41,700 are going to New York City.
Many more may be connecting to PATH service from Newark, where N.J. Transit trains deliver 20,300 people, or from Hoboken, where it carries 21,850 people. The result: the PATH train is also packed. Rich Davala, an insurance executive from Wayne, takes N.J. Transit to Hoboken and then heads to the PATH and on to the World Trade Center. On a recent day, he waited through several trains until he could board one that wasn't crammed, something Mr. Davala, who has been commuting for six years, said he had gotten used to.
Mike DePallo, the director and general manager of the PATH train, said that in 1996, the PATH collected 60,650,000 fares as against 62,200,000 in 1997. He said that this year, the line anticipates taking in 64,700,000 fares. A little more than three-fifths are from riders in the peak periods, 7 A.M. to 10 A.M. and 4 P.M. to 7 P.M. He added that by the end of the year, N.J. Transit and PATH hope to unveil a combined ticket that may also increase ridership.
The first threads of today's booming rail system were laid in the early 1800's for local access to New York City and Philadelphia. In quick bursts, rail companies laid their competing lines, prompting the creation of some of the first suburban communities like Plainfield and Somerville along the old Central Railroad of New Jersey, and, along the Morris and Essex lines, hamlets in Essex, Morris and Somerset counties.
But by the end of the century, through mergers and acquisitions, only a handful of rail companies reigned: the Pennsylvania, Erie, Jersey Central and Lackawanna, each had its own territories and terminals in Newark, Hoboken and Jersey City. Newark's Broad Street Station and its own Pennsylvania Station are not linked to this day because they were created for competing lines, just as Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal were. "We're in the process now of trying to connect all this," Ms. DeLibero said.
During the Depression, this hodgepodge of rail lines began to falter. Then came the post-World War II explosion of the automobile and the interstate highway system. Railroads began collapsing and Federal subsidies kicked in, a last-gasp effort to keep commuter lines alive. Erie and Lackawanna merged in 1960. When Penn Central -- the union of Pennsylvania and New York Central -- failed, the Federal Government stepped in and created Conrail in 1976 to run both freight and passenger trains. But the passenger lines continued to bleed money.
In 1981, Congress allowed Conrail to hand off its commuter line. In New Jersey, the recipient was the newly created N.J. Transit. In its early years, the system concentrated on replacing its aging rolling stock, much of which dated to the 1930's.
That focus had painful and unforeseen consequences. With no money left to maintain station parking lots, N.J. Transit gave them to municipalities. Today, those towns often hoard what is usually an inadequate supply of parking spaces for their residents. And building garages is controversial in the small towns along the train route because using Federal dollars means that the facilities must be open to nonresidents.
To be sure, a few stations have bucked the trend. Metropark, the Iselin station on the Northeast Corridor, built a huge garage with Federal money. In contrast, Summit, on the Midtown line, has declined government money for its garage. "They just don't want the traffic," said Ms. DeLibero.
Some municipalities are embracing jitneys instead of increasing the number of parking spaces. The first, which started last year in Maplewood, was a success, with a van circulating in parts of town at no charge. This year, N.J. Transit made grants of $10,000 apiece to encourage other municipalities along the Midtown Direct line to do the same, including West Orange, Chatham, Springfield and Berkeley Heights. The grant will also help Maplewood start a second jitney. Even so, rumors persist that the state will use its right of eminent domain to reclaim parking lots in towns where nonresidents' cars are not accommodated.
John J. Haley Jr., the state's transportation commissioner, agreed that eminent domain was indeed an option. "We have always taken the good neighbor approach," he said, "but we are not satisfied that the parking program is growing fast enough."
Rail use rose and fell with the boom and bust of the 1980's, but now the region's robust economy and development in the suburbs and beyond are fueling ridership.
The next few years are packed with anticipated improvements. A $30 million electrical substation in Queens is nearing completion, the cornerstone of a rebuilt signaling system that will increase the number of trains that can enter Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station from the west to about 25 an hour from the current 20, according to Rick Richmond, N.J. Transit's assistant executive director for engineering, development and construction.
And early in the year 2000, a light rail system will begin bringing riders from Bayonne to Hoboken, offering a connection both to N.J. Transit trains and the PATH. Next comes the rehabilitated concourse at Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station in mid 2001 -- with construction costs alone pegged at $67 million -- that should ease the boarding and exiting of passengers at the cramped terminal.
Months later, in late 2001 or early 2002, the $48 million Montclair connection, which will afford a straight shot into Manhattan from stations along the Boonton line, is expected to go into operation and increase rush-hour ridership by 1,300 passengers by 2010. Around the same time, the Port Authority expects the completion of its $415 million Newark International Airport link, which will connect N.J. Transit to the airport monorail.
But those new elements are warmups to the biggest event: the Secaucus transfer, a $448 million project already under way along two miles of the most heavily traveled commuter rail line in the nation. Plans call for completion by mid-June 2002, which will coincide with the completion of a new signal system throughout the rail network. That, N.J. Transit believes, will increase rush-hour ridership on several lines -- Pascack Valley, Main and Bergen -- to about 20,000 by 2010 from the current 12,100.
For many rail advocates, crowding is the most delightful issue they can imagine. "We had 50 years of nothing but drop-offs and consolidation and automotive mania," said Douglas Bowen, president of the New Jersey Association of Railroad Passengers, a private group. "These are the problems we like, the problems of success."

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
Another Step in Downtown New Brunswick Revival

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
LAST Monday ground was broken for the latest addition to New Brunswick's reviving downtown -- a $25-million government and academic building that will rise over the next year and provide another anchor for the southern end of downtown.
The project, Civic Square III, will comprise a four-story, 95,000-square-foot structure at the corner of Joyce Kilmer Avenue and New Street that will become the Middlesex County Family Courthouse. There will also be an adjacent five-level, 430-car parking garage over 1,000 square feet of ground-floor stores and a 13,000-square-foot urban campus for Middlesex County College. 
 The combined project, which replaces a municipal parking lot, is part of an ongoing effort by the city to transform a three-block area from George and Kirkpatrick Streets to Paterson and New Streets into a bustling government district. The area is home to the city's municipal complex and the county courthouse.
The new complex will join Civic Square II, a $49-million, two-building complex taking shape a block to the north. One structure with 115,000 square feet along Bayard and Kirkpatrick Streets will house administrative offices for Middlesex County. The second structure, a 118,000-square-foot building rising across the street, will contain the retail operations of the United States Postal Service, the planning and inspection divisions of the city's Buildings Department as well as two muncipal courts and county and local law enforcement offices, including the New Brunswick Police Department. There will also be a 200-car garage.
Both projects, in an unusual financing twist, are being built with private funds. They are to be completed by next fall and winter. The developer is a partnership of the Keating Development Corporation of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., and the nonprofit New Brunswick Development Corporation.
"There was a need from public institutions for more space that we wanted to fill," said Christopher J. Paladino, president of the nonprofit corporation. "More importantly these projects will establish a government district that bridges together the city's nearby cultural, academic, health care and business sectors."
He said they would also serve "as a jumping-off point" to push the downtown revitalization in a southeasterly direction along George Street to a five-block stretch extending from New Street to Commercial Avenue. The area is now is dominated by the city's public housing complex and scattered abandoned stores and houses.
The first link to the city's varied sectors was a 160,000-square-foot office and academic building for Rutgers University, which was built in 1994 at the corner of Livingston and New Streets. Called Civic Square, the five-story building completed the blockfront along Livingston Avenue, which had three existing theaters, and has since become the city's cultural hub,
One block north of the Civic Square developments the nonprofit development corporation, with R. Berman Development of Trenton, completed Liberty Plaza this summer. The 135,000-square-foot, $23-million office and retail building and an existing 500-car garage that connects it to the cultural district occupies an entire city block, bounded by Liberty, George and Paterson Streets. The block was formerly occupied by a cluster of small, timeworn stores.
The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey occupies the upper three floors of the four-story building for its administrative offices, which were consolidated from scattered locations in Newark, Piscataway and elsewhere in New Brunswick. The 20,000 square feet of street-level stores are mostly leased, some of them to national retailers, the first such leasing for the city.
Clearing an entire block had its share of challenges. Key among them was the developers' negotiating with nine separate property owners and 18 different retailers.
"Before we started purchasing the property we had the lease from the University of Medicine and Dentistry, which was contingent on completing the project by this August," said Ronald Berman, chairman of R. Berman Development. "So the risk was in our ability to get tenants out, which while there were some hairy moments, was ultimately resolved." Mr. Berman said the cost of acquiring the properties and relocating the tenants came to $4.8 million, up from the $3 million originally anticipated.
MOST of the retailers who were displaced by Liberty Plaza, though initially angered by the project, have since been relocated to other shops along George Street, the downtown's main retail street. One is John Blauvelt, who now operates his Jersey Subs deli in a storefront he renovated on George Street, three blocks from his old location at the corner of George and Liberty Streets.
"My old property was nicer, bigger and in a better location," said Mr. Blauvelt, who set up his business there five and a half years ago when he purchased the two-story building. "I wish I still had my corner location, but the new project is clearly an improvement for the street and the city."
The lease to the university allowed the developers to secure financing from the public capital market at a tax-exempt interest rate, lowering the cost of the development and, in turn, rents, Mr. Paladino said. Ownership of the building reverts to the university at the end of its 28-year lease. He said that the same tax-exempt financing was used in the development of Civic Square II and III.
The new County Administration Building at the Civic Square II project is rising on a vacant lot the county sold to the developers. The county will relocate its offices from a 1957 building a block away that the city's development corporation eventually will raze to make way for future development.
The second structure is taking shape on land owned by the Postal Service, where it operated a distribution center. Only the historic facade of the old post office building remains and has been incorporated into the new building. The move by the city's Police Department to the building from its current site along the Raritan River will free 18 prime riverfront acres to development, said Glenn S. Patterson, director of New Brunswick's Department of Policy, Planning and Economic Development.
"It is like a giant chess game, resulting in the creation of new opportunities elsewhere in the city," Mr. Patterson said of all the moving around caused by the Liberty Plaza and Civic Square projects. They also build on the city's existing strengths, he said, and at the same time "will fill in the middle section of and bring more people and activity to the downtown."
The city's role as the Middlesex County seat, along with the presence of Rutgers University, Johnson & Johnson, St. Peter's Medical Center and the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, have been major forces in its renewal efforts. Those efforts began nearly two decades ago at the northern end of the downtown where Johnson & Johnson's headquarters now stand along with several modern office buildings, a hotel and a spate of restaurants and shops. At the same time, hundreds of housing units have risen throughout the city.
Mr. Patterson said that while the Liberty Plaza project would increase the amount of property taxes generated on the site to $300,000 a year from $80,000, the two Civic Square projects will not generate tax ratables. Still, he added, that they, like other public projects, would set the tone for additional economic growth, including corporate office development, "which is the next thing we want to see."
Meanwhile, plans are advancing for Civic Square IV, a 300,000-square-foot mixed-use complex that will combine conference, hotel and retail space with market-rate housing and will further solidify the southern end of the downtown, Mr. Paladino said. In turn, he added, that "will help force development into the Commercial Avenue area.
The key to that area's turnaround is the city's plans to raze the four-building, 246-unit Memorial Homes public housing complex, just off Route 18.
Mr. Patterson said the housing complex would be replaced by 198 town-house rental and for-sale residences, 70 of which will rise on the old Memorial Homes site. The rest will take shape within a five-block radius and some 146 residents will be given Section 8 rent vouchers to move to apartments in locations of their choice. Construction is to start on the new housing next summer and be completed by the year 2002, he said.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 19; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 958 words

HEADLINE: A New Food and Wine Coalition Promotes Hudson Valley Visits

BYLINE: By FAY ELLIS 

 BODY:
PUFF pastry shells filled with veal and mushrooms, accompanied by vintage Zinfandel wine and finished off with fondant au chocolat for dessert. This may not sound like anyone's idea of a diet meal, but calorie counters seemed to be in short supply among the 300 guests who crammed the Putnam Country Club in Mahopac earlier this month for a food and wine tasting event that featured offerings from 21 restaurants, 10 wineries and 7 food producers from the Hudson Valley.
The event -- a fund-raiser for the Putnam-Northern Westchester Women's Resource Center, which helps victims of domestic violence -- marked the start of the Hudson Valley Food and Wine Experience, a coalition of the restaurateurs, food producers and wine makers who offered their wares at the country club. 
 The group's goal is to make Westchester and other counties in the Hudson Valley more of a destination for visitors and bring in more tourist dollars.
"There is arguably no more beautiful area than the Hudson Valley," said Peter Xaviar Kelly, the chef and owner of Xaviar's in Garrison, who helped organize the Hudson Valley Food and Wine Experience. "But notwithstanding the region's beauty and unique history, its world-class restaurants and wineries are the best-kept secret on the East Coast. We'd like to convince tourists to rent a car or take a train ride out to experience the history, beauty and cuisine of our region."
Mr. Kelly, who also owns Xaviar's at Piermont and Freelance Cafe and Winebar in Piermont, said that promoting the Hudson Valley poses an unusual challenge. Unlike the Napa Valley in northern California, which has restaurants and wineries clustered along one area of a highway, the Hudson Valley encompasses a large geographical expanse.
That is why a coalition like the Food and Wine Experience is needed, said Bill Primavera, who heads a Yorktown Heights public relations and marketing firm that has many clients in the food and wine industry. Tourist bureaus in each county promote tourism locally, he said, but little has been done before now to promote the region as a whole. The Hudson Valley group wants to work with existing tourist agencies.
Mr. Primavera said he had envisioned a food and wine coalition 25 years ago when he was public relations director of the Culinary Institute of America in New Hyde Park. But he felt the idea was premature then because there were not enough restaurants.
The association emerged out of an exchange of good will. Mr. Primavera asked Mr. Kelly to bring together restaurants and wineries for a food and wine event for the Putnam-Northern Westchester Women's Resource Center, one of his pet causes. In return, Mr. Primavera pledged to promote the group as a food and wine trade association.
"The consensus among the group is that everyone will benefit by working together to promote the Hudson Valley region," Mr. Primavera said.
The Westchester contingent includes, among others, George Seitz, a master chef and owner of the Arch in Brewster; Jonathan White of the Egg Farm Dairy in Peekskill and George Naumburg of the North Salem Vineyard, a retired psychiatrist.
Members of the association are seeking to promote the economic health of the Hudson Valley by taking their products and services to New York City consumers, supporting agriculture regionwide and organizing events to draw visitors to the Hudson Valley.
Elizabeth Ryan, who runs the Breezy Hill Orchard and Cider Mill in Clinton Corners in Dutchess County, sells her cider at a local farmer's market and at Union Square in Manhattan. The Rivendell Winery and Vineyard in New Paltz is negotiating for a retail outlet to sell its wine in New York City. Janet Crawshaw and Jerry Novesky, a husband-and-wife team from Middletown, recently produced the second edition of their glossy quarterly magazine, The Valley Table, which focuses farms, food and cuisine in the Hudson Valley.
The tomatoes and peppers used in the salsa products of My Brother Bobby's Salsa, a Poughkeepsie-based company, are primarily grown on farms in New Paltz and Kingston.
John M. Novi, proprietor of the Depuy Canal House, uses produce from farms in High Falls, Ulster County, near his restaurant. "Using seasonal herbs and vegetables forces me to be even more creative in planning and adapting our menus throughout the year," he said.
Mr. Naumburg said that despite the fact that the Hudson Valley is the oldest commercial winegrowing region in the United States, its winemakers have not been able to compete successfully against California, France or even the Finger Lakes. "When I was asked to join this new group, I realized it could be a chance for that to change," Mr. Naumburg said. "The food and wine tasting event is a milestone on that path."
The new group, sponsored by Mastercard, wants to work with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to offer package tours to the Hudson Valley. One such package might include a train ride to Brewster for dinner at the Arch and a tasting at the North Salem Vineyard.
Georgia Kalayjian-Murphy, president of the Westchester Convention and Tourist Bureau in White Plains, said she was enthusiastic about the new association. Last year, she said. tourists spent $187 million in food establishments in Westchester, and she said there are many more tourist dollars available. "When we go to tourism trade shows in Europe, people say they want to offer more than what is available in Manhattan," Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy said. "We feel we can draw international visitors to our area because we have more to offer here as a driving destination."
Ms. Kalayjian-Murphy added: "You can have the best restaurants in the world, but if people don't believe in the destination, they won't come."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In / College Point, Queens;
Small Enclave Feels Pressures of the City

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THERE is always a jetliner somewhere on the horizon of College Point, a low-rise, blue-collar Queens outpost on Flushing Bay where maintaining small-town virtues rooted in the 19th century is a struggle.
Sometimes jetliners landing or taking off across the bay at La Guardia Airport fly too close, and even under normal conditions their keening engines are a distant audio backdrop along College Point Boulevard, the main commercial thoroughfare. 
 Volume is pumped up in areas nearest the airport, whose main runways route air traffic around but not directly over College Point.
"You have to keep constant vigilance on them," said Rocco Cardali, a director of the 160-member College Point Civic and Taxpayers Association, which tries to keep the jets at bay.
When ever-larger trucks serving the College Point Industrial Park and other industrial enclaves mount curbs and sidewalks to make tight turns on narrow streets, people have been known to go to their owners, equipped, if necessary, with videotapes showing the offense.
At least one company started using smaller trucks, but the battle goes on in this community where roadwork on 14th Avenue, a major thoroughfare, is currently adding to traffic problems. "We keep getting pushed and pushed," said Joan Vogt, a former association president.
When the frequently flooded, 70-acre Flushing Airport, closed by the city in 1984 and now reverting to marshland, was proposed for a heliport there was an uproar in surrounding areas, including College Point. The city's Economic Development Corporation later dropped the plan.
Now some in College Point favor rebuilding and partial rerouting a ghostly stretch of Linden Boulevard, which had been abandoned within the airport fence, to relieve the expected crush of traffic to and from a new shopping center on 20th Avenue near the Whitestone Expressway.
The just-opening shopping center, with tenants including Target, BJ's Wholesale Club, Staples, Waldbaum's and T.J. Maxx, has also been a source of controversy and divided opinion.
Bill Rose, a broker and owner of Century 21 Weber and Rose Realty on College Point Boulevard, who concedes nothing to jet noise and likens his hometown to a "quiet, New England type of town," said the new stores were a long-overdue improvement. "It brings us into the 20th century," he said. "We don't have to go out to Nassau County anymore."
But Fred Mazzarello, founder and president of the College Point Board of Trade, said the stores would bring nightmare traffic, replace sustaining full-time jobs with low-wage, part-time ones, and sound the death knell for the traditional shopping area along College Point Boulevard.
"Most of the merchants look at it as a threat to their survival," Mr. Mazzarello said. "Our last women's dress shop just closed. We don't have enough quality stores left in town."
FOR newcomers -- and there has been a turnover here as Hispanics and Asians add new ethnicity to a place long inhabited by residents of German, Irish and Italian ancestry -- one attraction is lower prices than in Whitestone and much lower prices than in upscale Malba, both adjoining areas.
Real estate brokers said the market was strong, with house prices rising and sales brisk. "As fast as we list them, if they are in good condition they sell," said Ellene Wundrok, a sales agent at the Suydam Agency.
The housing stock includes one- and two-family, wood-frame homes built in the 20's and 30's, bungalows sometimes built far earlier and newer expanses of single and attached brick one- and two-family houses built in the 50's and 60's. Mr. Rose said buildings were generally 22 feet wide and 45 feet deep with rear yards that may be 40 feet by 25 feet.
Four condominium complexes -- Skyline Terrace, Bay Park Estates, Riverview and Silverpointe -- with a total of about 450 units were built in the 80's. At Silverpointe, a three-bedroom, two-bath unit with monthly charges of $235 was on the market earlier this month for $215,000. At Riverview, a one-bedroom unit with monthly charges of $140 was for sale for $107,000.
There are few apartment buildings, but many two-family houses include rentals. A two-bedroom apartment in a two-family house rents for about $850.
Neighborhoods north of 14th Avenue, where Cape Cods, ranches and bungalows predominate, are distinctly suburban. Industrial areas are mostly south of 14th.
There is a certain smallness here. Conrad Poppenhusen Park, named for the German immigrant who brought his hard-rubber industry here from the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn in 1854 with his mostly German workers in tow, is hardly large enough to contain its Poppenhusen bust.
On College Point Boulevard, St. Paul's Episcopal Church seems just a few shades larger than a large private dwelling. Across the street, in the one-room Queens public library branch named after Poppenhusen, a cough is heard in every corner.
But this compactness is counterbalanced by vistas of the distant Manhattan skyline, as seen beyond Rikers Island and Astoria from the shoreline promenade at Herman A. MacNeil Park, a rolling expanse of lawns, playing fields and towering trees with a playground that includes a boccie court.
The 29-acre park, at the tip of the College Point peninsula, was once the site of St. Paul's College, an Episcopal seminary that gave the community its name. Built in 1837, it was torn down at the turn of the century.
And if, as local historian Robert C. Friedrich laments, many of the fine details of surviving, older wood-frame homes disappeared beneath vinyl siding during the energy-conscious 1970s, there is still the imposing Poppenhusen Institute, a New York City historical landmark that combines Italianate and French Second Empire elements.
There are two public elementary schools, three religious grade schools and one girls' Roman Catholic high school in College Point. Students go to neighboring Flushing and Whitestone for upper grades in public schools.
At the 650-pupil P.S. 29, covering kindergarten through grade 6, Principal Peggy Miller said scores on standardized math and reading tests were above city and state averages. The school has a new computer lab with 32 computers. A new, 32-computer lab is also in operation at the k-6, 715-pupil P.S. 129. Students also score above state and city averages in standardized tests said the principal, Lita Adair. Both schools emphasize arts and music.
J.H.S. 185 in Flushing, with 830 students in grades 7 through 9, is one of the few in the city offering advanced math courses to selected students in the seventh grade, said Barbara Rubin, the acting principal. Test scores regularly place the school in the top 50 for intermediate and junior high schools, said Ms. Rubin.
At J.H.S. 194, covering grades 7 through 9, Anita Sobel, the principal, said about half of the 960 students were in accelerated courses and took Regents exams in the eighth and ninth grades. The school has its own Web page and is being upgraded for expanded computer programs.
A number of the 2,100 students at Flushing High School are from College Point. In 1997, 81 percent of its 181 graduates went on to higher education, according to a school spokeswoman. S.A.T. scores last school year averaged 404 in verbal and 454 in math, compared with 495 and 503, respectively, in New York State. The school has a a special program in law and criminal justice and instruction in automobile repair.
AMONG the private schools in College Point is St. Agnes Academic School, with 450 girls in grades 9 through 12. About 95 percent go on to higher education said the principal, Sister Marguerite Warren. The 90-year-old school offers advanced placement courses and emphasizes community service. Tuition is $4,680.
About 100 children attend kindergarten through grade 8 at St. John's Lutheran School, where small class size gives students extra attention. The fees are $285 monthly for nursery and kindergarten and $265 monthly for grades 1 through 8.
At the 110-pupil, nursery to grade 8 St. Paul's, an Episcopal school also in College Point, Headmaster Robert Montheard said "a values-based curriculum in a small, family-sized environment" was offered. Tuition is $2,600.
The 500-pupil, k-8 Roman Catholic St. Fidelis School emphasizes programs in music, computers and science. There is also an after-school program and the annual $2,000 tuition is reduced by half for a second child.
Youth sports programs, a staple in College Point, hit a rough spot when the city padlocked fences around fields leased to the College Point Athletic Association. The city acted after rubble of questionable origin was dumped as fill to raise the level of the flood-prone football field.
For all that embroils them, many people add to any recitation of local problems a common footnote. "I can never see myself leaving College Point," said Ms. Vogt, the former civic association president.

 SAVING POPPENHUSEN: The beer gardens, picnic groves, fine beaches and resort hotels that enlivened College Point from the mid-19th century to Prohibition are recalled in an exhibit of photographs and artifacts at Poppenhusen Institute at 114-04 14th Road. Earlier this month a sold-out 130th anniversary dance was held in the institute's ornate Victorian ballroom. That the institute, whose cornerstone was laid in 1868, exists today is a testament to its executive director, Susan K. Brustmann, and her friend, Ellen A. Stevenson, who began a grass-roots campaign to save the landmark building from being razed in the 1980's. "It wasn't hard to get support from the community and historic societies," Ms. Brustmann recalled. "Energy came from many sources." The institute, founded by Conrad Poppenhusen, housed the first free kindergarten in the country, to the benefit of employees of Poppenhusen's hard-rubber plant and other College Point industries. Today, free classes include karate for children and acting for teen-agers. Group piano lessons for children at a nominal fee are also offered, and there are theater workshops, a resident theater company and free lectures, Ms. Brustmann said. The institute is open Monday through Wednesday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Monday night from 6 to 9, Friday from 3 to 8 P.M. and on weekends by appointment. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: Will Indian Wealth Benefit Norwich?

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
IN 1994, when the Mashantucket Pequots announced plans to put $18 million into downtown Norwich, it seemed the dawn of a new age for the longtime down-on-its-luck river community. But recent tribal announcements have raised questions about whether the city will ever actually see much benefit from the Pequot wealth.
The tribe, which runs the hugely successful Foxwoods Resort Casino near Norwich, first announced in 1994 that it would build an upscale apartment building that would incorporate the city's ornate architecture and would harken to the city's golden age at the turn of the last century when wealthy whaling ship captains lived there. The tribe changed its plans in 1996 and proposed building an upscale hotel in cooperation with a major international hotel chain. 
 On Tuesday the tribe revealed plans for a more modest, unadorned hotel building that some residents said resembled a dormitory or a nursing home.
Tuesday's announcement was the latest of a series of disappointments for Norwich residents. In October, the tribe had announced that construction of the downtown hotel would not start until a new study was made of the changing market for hotel rooms in southeastern Connecticut. At that time, an official of the tribal council complained that the state and the city were not doing their part financially to support the hotel project while putting substantial amounts of money into commercial projects nearby.
Kenneth Reels, who was recently elected chairman of the tribal council, said the hotel project was not getting its fair share of state grants and needed more such support. As part of a state effort to spur development in urban areas, the state has put up $500,000 of grant money for Norwich, and that is for construction of a parking garage.
In contrast, Mr. Reels said, millions of state dollars have gone to encourage development at Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical giant that operates a large research center in the nearby city of Groton, and the state put $3.65 million into the construction of a parking garage for the Konover Hotel Group's planned $10 million restoration of the Wauregan Hotel, near the site of the tribe's planned hotel in Norwich.
The Norwich City Manager, William G. Tallman, disputed Mr. Reels' figures. The tribe's proposed project has received more than $2.4 million in state and city support, he says. Mr. Tallman said in a letter to Mr. Reels that the tribe was getting more state grant money than the Konover Hotel Group would get for the Wauregan project. The $3.65 million is for a parking garage that will provide 150 parking spaces specifically for the Wauregan Hotel, and about 200 other spaces to relieve downtown parking pressure. A centerpiece for the downtown development project, called the Mercantile Exchange Block, was bought by for $750,000 by the city, which spent an additional $70,000 in an eminent domain settlement for a property that is also being used for the tribe's hotel project.
"The city extended themselves in good faith," said Bill Stanley, a former State Senator and local newspaper columnist. "The Mashantucket Pequot have not yet reciprocated." The tribe's hotel project site is 8 miles from the tribe's Foxwoods casino and just 3 miles from the Mohegan Sun Casino, said Mr. Stanley. He said it seemed as if the Mashantucket Pequot may not want to build a hotel that would probably benefit the Mohegan Sun Casino far more than Foxwoods.
The Mashantucket Pequot are committed to assisting in Norwich's redevelopment efforts, says Susan Viafora, a tribal spokeswoman. She said the tribe has spent millions of dollars for demolition and an archeological survey. But she added that given how dramatically market conditions for hotel rooms are changing it was still reasonable to study the hotel market before beginning construction. "The tribe wants to do what is best for the city of Norwich and the tribal constituency," Ms. Viafora said .
The more modest hotel plan announced last week was a result of the study, which showed that Norwich could not support a luxury four-star hotel with rooms going for about $180 a night, said Robert Birmingham, the tribal planner.
Despite the disappointment expressed by some city residents the hotel was approved by the city's planning commission and construction is scheduled to begin on July 1.
But there were continuing doubts by some Norwich residents. Dale Plummer, the Norwich City Historian, called the latest hotel plan "an insult to the city." Arthur Lathrop, president of the Norwich Heritage Trust, said the "boxlike" structure was not appropriate for downtown.
Another resident, Thomas Bjorg questioned whether the tribe was ever serious about aiding the city's downtown redevelopment. "A question people should be asking," he said, "is why would the Mashantucket Pequot want to do anything that would take people away from the slot machines and bring them to Norwich?' "
Ron D. Aliano, a local businessman who is involved in another project with the Pequots, offered this reply to the doubters: "If you look at Las Vegas you can see the new thinking in the casino industry is that there must be other things beside gambling to attract the most people. Museums, historic districts, a wide range of available activities and entertainment doesn't compete with, but complements casinos."
Mr. Aliano is the owner of the American Wharf development on the city's waterfront, where the tribe planned to base its high-speed passenger boat, the Sassacus. To accommodate the Sassacus, which had been built by the tribal-owned Pequot River Shipworks in Norwich, the city put up about $280,000 and Mr.Aliano spent another $170,000 to build a 186-foot-long floating concrete pier. But the Sassacus has never used the pier to bring passengers to Norwich from New York City and other locations. During a test run on the Thames River, bystanders observed that at normal operating speed the Sassacus raised a potentially destructive wake.
The main problem the Sassacus has, says Mr. Aliano, is that it burns 800 gallons of fuel an hour. The extra hour of operation needed to get to and from Norwich is just not practical, he said. The tribe is considering the construction of boats with a different kind of engine that would make runs to Norwich more feasible, he said.
"It doesn't matter if the Sassacus uses the dock or doesn't use the dock," Mr. Aliano said. "It will be used." A 70-foot yacht built in 1929 is using the new pier, and Mr. Aliano and Mr. Tallman say cruise lines have expressed interest.
City officials and residents say they're much more hopeful about the completion of a development project involving the Mohegans. In 1995 the city was given a $250,000 state grant to start the development of a communication and technology instruction center in the Masonic Temple. But during a 1997 archeological survey, remnants of Mohegan burials were found.
According to municipal histories, the Masonic Temple and its grounds are on an ancient burial site, where the tribe's leaders, including the Great Sachem Uncas were buried. The cemetery, the Royal Mohegan Burial Ground, covered 26 acres between the falls of the Yantic River and Chelsea Parade.
The area is now a thickly populated residential neighborhood. The city had an understanding with the Mohegans that the burial ground was to remain consecrated ground. But in 1842, with the complicity of the tribe's state-appointed overseer, the agreement was violated and the land was used for agriculture and residential development.
When the remains were found last year, the Mohegans asked that allexcavation plans be halted. But in February the city, the Mohegans and the state came to an agreement on proceeding with the project.
It was agreed no further excavations would be made. In addition to a technology and communication education center -- which would offer instruction in state of the art television, computer and communication technology -- the theater in the building would be renovated and expanded into a performing arts center. A museum/memorial was to be established for Uncas, and for the other tribal leaders and ancestors buried in the Royal Mohegan Burial Ground. The city agreed to donate the Masonic Temple building, and the state agreed to contribute $5 million if a study concluded it was a feasible development project and the tribe would contribute another $5 million. In addition, the tribe is searching for an alternate meeting place for the Masonic Lodge.
The state has completed the feasibility study on the costs and uses of the project and submitted it to Peter Ellef, Gov. John G. Rowland's chief of staff. A final decision regarding the study has not yet been made, said Nuala Ford, a spokeswoman for Governor Rowland.
The Mohegan Tribe's leaders say the wealth generated by the Mohegan Sun Casino will not be hoarded,but used to benefit the community at large, said Mr. Stanley, the newspaper columnist, and there was no reason not to believe them at this point.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1442 words

HEADLINE: Budget Cuts Draw First Protests

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER residents had their first chance Wednesday night to have their say on the proposed $1.13 billion county budget, and they came out strongly, grumbling about proposed cuts to the county's four neighborhood health centers, applauding increased aid for day-care programs and saying the county could do still more for children and women.
The hearing at the Holmes Elementary School in Mount Vernon drew more than 100 people, including 45 speakers, and lasted about 2 hours. Among the speakers were a few, like Kelly Jones, president of the Taxpayers Alliance of New York, who called for tax cuts beyond those proposed earlier in the week by County Executive Andrew J. Spano. 
 But most of those speaking at the hearing asked for more financing for certain programs. Among them were speakers for the health centers in Mount Vernon, Ossining, Peekskill and Greenburgh, which collectively stand to lose up to $300,000. Mr. Spano said earlier that he had based his suggestion for the reduction on recommendations by county auditors about how much the per-patient costs at the centers should be.
But those cuts would cause a disaster, speakers told the Board of Legislators' Committee on Budget and Appropriations, echoing comments made earlier by Carole Morris, chief executive officer of the Mount Vernon Neighborhood Health Center, who said, "If the cuts are not restored we'll have a serious problem with serving families that are not insured."
Amy Paulin of the Westchester Women's Agenda led a contingent of speakers who discussed services for women. "Overall, we have achieved so much in the last four years that by maintaining those items we are still doing O.K.," she said before her public remarks. "But we had hoped that we would continue to see improvement for women and kids' initiatives. There is still so much that needs to be done."
After the hearing, Richard G. Wishnie, a Democratic Legislator from Briarcliff and chairman of the Budget Committee, said: "Definitely, there is a super majority of the Legislators who support restoring the health centers. I don't have much doubt that the money will be restored." But he added that the Board would seek to offset this or any other additions with cuts elsewhere to Mr. Spano's budget. "It is our goal not only to maintain the tax levy decrease but to cut it further."
How much taxes actually decrease in Mr. Spano's budget depends on how the cut is defined.
Traditionally, officials present a new budget in its best light when it comes to taxes. But the County Executive did not do that when he recently introduced a 1999 operating budget of $1.13 billion.
Under his budget, $364.5 million would be collected in property taxes, a decrease of a little more than $1 million from this year.
That is a proposed 0.29 percent reduction in the county tax levy -- the amount of money actually collected from property taxes.
Only casually in the course of his budget briefing did Mr. Spano mention that there would be a drop of more than 7 percent in the tax rate -- the calculation of the amount that a property owner would pay per $1,000 of assessed value of the property. It was later disclosed that the actual amount is 7.3 percent.
No matter which calculation is used, the effect on property owners remains unclear, since the amount varies from community to community and cannot be determined until the middle of next month. It is also probable that some of that tax decrease will be offset by higher garbage and sewer district taxes, which Mr. Spano, a Democrat, also announced.
The County Executive said of his first budget since taking office in January: "I made a pledge to Westchester residents that I would reduce the cost of government to our taxpayers, without reducing services. I have kept that pledge, although it hasn't been easy."
The budget also calls for a 10-cent increase in bus fares accompanied by the elimination of transfer fees between buses, the elimination of 127 vacant county positions, the elimination of funds for the Women's Justice Center (because Mr. Spano wants to reassess ways to provide its services) and some reorganization of the county government. Mr. Spano said the budget maintains or increases spending levels for various cultural groups and social organizations.
The proposed budget is available on the Internet at www.co.westchester.ny.us/operatingbdgt.
The Board of Legislators has until Dec. 7 to make any additions and until Dec. 27 to adopt a final spending plan. The Board's remaining public hearings on the budget will be held tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the Chappaqua Public Library, 195 South Greeley Avenue in Chappaqua, and on Dec. 7 at 7 P.M. in the Board of Legislators Chambers, on the eighth floor of the County Office Building, at 148 Martine Avenue in White Plains.
County property taxes account for about 20 percent of a property owner's tax bill, with the rest imposed by school districts, local governments and special taxing districts like those for sewers and garbage.
During his 1997 election campaign, Mr. Spano promised to cut the county property tax levy by 15 percent during his four-year term. "We are optimistic about reaching that 15 percent after four years," Mr. Spano said. Then observing how much greater is the tax rate reduction than the tax levy reduction, he quipped, "I wish I had said 'rate,' not 'levy,' " when making that promise.
But the number is of questionable usefulness except as a trend, said Kathleen M. Tooher, the county's Budget Director. This is because property values increase or decrease by different amounts from community to community, and the formula to equalize the differences is not adopted until mid-December. And when the economy is good -- as it is now -- the county's total assessment rolls grow, meaning there are more taxpayers to share the tax burden so a tax rate can go down.
"There is no average home we can use, no average community," Ms. Tooher said when asked to state the impact of Mr. Spano's budget on individual residents. "I would say that some people might find their taxes up. But for the majority, their county taxes will go down."
How much of this would be offset by increases in special district taxes, like sewer and garbage, could not be determined. Westchester has 13 sewer districts; in budgets proposed for them, the tax levy change ranged from a reduction of 3.71 percent in the Hutchinson Valley Sewer District to an increase of 4.81 percent in the New Rochelle Sewer District. A tax increase of 4 percent is proposed for the Westchester Refuse Disposal District, which includes most of the county. Taxes in the county's four water districts would either go down or stay the same, depending on the district.
In preparing his budget and trying to fulfill his pledge to cut taxes, Mr. Spano had two major hurdles to overcome, both of which he said were beyond his control: he had to finance retroactive and 1999 raises for most of the county's work force, and he had to finance $68 million in costs of a Federal- and state-mandated program to provide education and transportation services to disabled children younger than 5, an increase of $6 million over what is expected to be spent this year. (About 59 percent of those costs are reimbursed by the state, but this, Mr. Spano stressed, is less than the 75 percent reimbursement rate the state had promised.)
On the positive side, Mr. Spano said that the county's subsidy to the Westchester Health Care Corporation, which runs the Westchester Medical Center, would drop $4.6 million to $26 million and be phased out entirely over the next eight years. Also, because of a good economy and welfare reform, Mr. Spano is budgeting a decrease of $8.4 million in welfare costs.
There was generally positive reaction from County Legislators to Mr. Spano's budget, although Democrats and Republicans alike emphasized that they had not yet had a chance to study the proposal closely and that there were items that might have to be modified. Andrea Stewart-Cousins, Democrat of Yonkers, was one of several Legislators who said she was concerned about the proposed cuts to the neighborhood health centers and proposed increase in bus fares.
Kelly Jones of Greenburgh, president of the Taxpayers Alliance of New York, said his group, which has about 350 families as members, would mobilize to push for a larger tax reduction. "The county executive ran on a platform to reduce taxes 15 percent over four years. We now have about 14.75 percent to go after the first year." He questioned whether the county had a "strategic plan in place" to accomplish Mr. Spano's goal.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Born of Illness, a Grand Metamorphosis

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

DATELINE: SOUTH ORANGE

 BODY:
THE exhibition of paintings and works on paper by Kendall Shaw at the Gallery of South Orange affords a palpable sensation of a triumphant fresh start. Of course, it's not necessary to know elements of Mr. Shaw's life story to appreciate his work, but they help explain why it acquired extra verve and dimension in recent years. In the late 1980's and the early 90's Mr. Shaw battled a rare form of hepatitis that threatened his life. Because he was forced to find treatment on his own, said Judy Wukitsch, the gallery's assistant director, his painting career was halted in those years.
That he is now completely well is reflected in the vibrantly colored, highly animated work Mr. Shaw has made since 1992. The paintings are dominated by linear rhythms that are a little bit Matisse and a little bit Keith Haring. Other art-historical traditions leave their mark: many compositions seem modeled on medieval altarpieces, with side panels flanking a central one and smaller panels below. Some of the lines turn into strong suggestions of intertwined bodies, a motif central to Mr. Shaw's intentions. The exhibition is titled "Eros, Rhythm, Melody," and he is rediscovering eros, with the other two elements serving to stoke it. 
 Some recent paintings bear titles that transport Mr. Shaw, and some viewers, back a few decades. "Behind the Trellis," "The Naked Lunch" and "Back Seat at the Drive-In" give viewers license to read lusty goings-on in the paintings, but the paintings are also erotic in an overarching sense: Mr. Shaw is evidently having a romance with the act of painting itself.
He approaches it in a variety of ways. He builds discreet relief into the paintings by drawing many of his forms with thin tape. Conversely, in other areas he stains pigment into the canvas. One of his favorite recurring motifs is an area spotted with marks where bits of tape have been pulled off after paint was applied to the whole area. Color is thoroughly explored: some works have a certain dignity through the dominance of blacks and browns; elsewhere, his palette is distinguished by retina-popping brightness. A couple of paintings from 1992 contain small patches of blood, a strong symbol of Mr. Shaw's illness and recovery.
All the paintings were completed in the 90's, most in the last year, and several were begun 10 years ago, before his illness, and were considered finished then. It doesn't take an archeologist to discover which elements in these decade-spanning works are the originals and which are recent additions. In the 1980's, Mr. Shaw was allied with the movement known as Pattern and Decoration. When it began in the late 1970's, it was a reaction to the sobriety and the dominant intellectual sway of Minimal art. As in Minimalism, there is regularity and predictability in Pattern painting, but because it coincided with the rise of the feminist movement and attracted many female artists, the paintings could be colorful and, as the name implies, unabashedly decorative, qualities often thought of as feminine.
Mr. Shaw's patterns were mostly diagonal weaves of lines in somber colors that betray a humorless rigor. The strong discipline may stem from the fact that he was trained as a scientist; his biography reveals that in 1950 he studied painting and chemistry at the same time. These paintings that try to make a unity of his art before and after the disruption are awkward, for the most part; the clean-slate character of works begun after his recovery succeed because they brim with confidence.
One of these more loosely patterned works, at first glance a seeming anomaly, is "Another Target." It is also more than the lively abstract painting it at first seems to be. A closer look reveals the main motif to be a target of bombs or missiles, seen from the air through a navigational instrument. The small panels at the bottom also contain aerial targets and lumps of thick paint, which are the unloosed weapons.
Large paintings on canvas can't help dominating an exhibition, especially when the gallery is decorated neutrally and the paintings burst with color. But an artist's core convictions are often expressed in smaller, seemingly more offhand pieces. A series of works on paper, begun in 1979 and finished this year, strengthen the feeling that Mr. Shaw is at heart a political artist. In an essay in the brochure accompanying the show, Carl Hazelwood refers the strong influence on Mr. Shaw of his grandmother Emma Lottie, who was a suffragist in Louisiana, the artist's home state. Her memory is at the center of a grid of collage prints.
The other squares of this grid are dedicated to Medgar Evers and civil rights workers who were killed in the early 1960's on voter registration drives in the South. In his grandmother's square, Mr. Shaw has arranged an orderly display of collage elements with patriotic references including bits of red, white and blue paper, gummed stars and small gold buttons. But because the others had experiences with suffrage that ended in violence, the colored paper, buttons and stars fly across the paper as if a gunshot had scattered them.
The exhibition provides a complete panorama through an economy of means. Not only is Mr. Shaw unabashed about reviving "Happy Days"-like memories of furtive sexual encounters, but he also realizes that the other side of the era he is celebrating -- the often violent social struggles -- was an unremitting backdrop for sweeter emotions.
 
EROS, RHYTHM, MELODY
Gallery of South Orange, Baird Center, 5 Mead Street, South Orange
Paintings by Kendall Shaw. Through Dec. 25. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and 4 to 6 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
State's Unemployment Rate Drops Below the National Level

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate was 4.5 percent in October, the first time in nearly seven years the state's rate was lower than the national one, the state Labor Department reported last week. The national rate for October was 4.6 percent, unchanged from September. The October number for New Jersey is down from 4.7 percent in September.
The 4.5 percent rate was the lowest for New Jersey since March 1990. 
 The state's Labor Commissioner, Mel Gelade, said the economy was bolstered by more jobs in the service and retail sectors, though manufacturing employment was down.
The last time New Jersey's rate was below the national average was December 1991. But the nation was in recession then. The New Jersey rate was 7.2 percent, and the national rate was 7.3 percent.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Newark Looks at Site For Sports Complex

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
The Newark City Council voted last week to look into building an arena for the New Jersey Nets and a soccer stadium for the Metrostars on part of a 118-acre site near the Ironbound section. Monday's 8-0 vote directs the Central Planning Board to determine whether the area is in need of redevelopment, the first step in eventually clearing the area, said Frank Bell, chief analyst for the City Clerk's office.
The city would acquire about 30 percent of the area for the arena and stadium, said Al Failla, the city's Director of Economic Development, and the rest would be used for redevelopment projects. 
 The Nets now play at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford. Amid speculation that the team would move to Newark, the team's new owners last month extended their lease with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, the arena's owner, through 2007. However, under the contract, the team can leave the Meadowlands (though not the state) at any time without financial penalty. The Metrostars, who play at Giants Stadium, have a lease with the sports authority through 1999. STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Before the Renovation, Consider the Returns

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years will appear the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT seems that every house in my neighborhood is being renovated. All summer, Dumpsters occupied one driveway after another, and an angry hive of power saws started buzzing every morning, though politely waiting until 8.
This gave my wife a case of Dumpster envy. As a result, we have redone our master bath, so that the door no longer bangs against the toilet. And now, she has her sights on the cluttered family room. 
 Boomers are nesting, striving to create the perfect space in which to raise their children. Kitchens are expanding, rooms are being added, bathrooms are going upscale. Americans spent an estimated $119 billion on home improvements last year, according to the Census Bureau, up from $46 billion in 1980, and contractors say the pace has picked up this year.
Not all renovations make financial sense, however. While fixing the bathroom was a no-brainer, my wife wants to add more toy storage in the family room, somehow forgetting the inclination of our children to ignore the latest in shelves for the convenience of the floor.
The decision to renovate is often an emotional one, and my wife has a lot of company in wanting to make our home more inviting. But from an economic standpoint, that can be dangerous.
"The motivation of Americans to improve their homes is so strong that they may make choices that are not good investments," said Paul Deffenbaugh, editor in chief of Remodeling magazine. "Depending on circumstances, remodeling is usually not as good as a 401(k)."
That may sound coldblooded, but the truth is, we should treat our houses as investments as well as homes if we want to afford those condos in Florida when we retire. And contractors say more people are realizing that.
In the 80's, homeowners were throwing money at remodeling projects with little concern for future value, said Joseph Matta of Masterwork Kitchens in Goshen, N.Y. "It was a frenzy," he said. "Now, boomers have bought more BMW's, kitchens, baths and second homes than in the history of mankind. They are experienced buyers. They want to see the return of their investment."
EVEN so, many of us have only the vaguest idea of what the financial returns might be on all the hammering and sawing. Sure, we have heard that improvements to bathrooms and kitchens, compared with other parts of the house, can add the most value, but we have no clue how much. And what about the other rooms? Imagine pouring money into stocks or mutual funds on such sketchy information.
Every year, Remodeling magazine studies the payoffs of various renovation projects. The 1998 results, which have just been published, can be a useful guide to where to put your money if you want to maximize your home's value.
For example, a new kitchen, on average, increases a home's resale value a year later by 87 percent of the construction cost. A minor kitchen renovation may be smarter, at 94 percent. The lowest figure is for a home office, at 64 percent.
Keep in mind that these numbers can change, so the return on anything you do today may vary by the time you are ready to sell. If the trend of working from home continues, for example, the figure for home offices may climb.
Brent and Terri Stuart of Goshen just finished a renovation that included a new kitchen and full bath. They spent about $60,000 on the two rooms -- $50,000 on the kitchen, $10,000 on the bathroom. By the magazine's count, they can expect to recoup $52,400 of their investment -- $43,500 from the kitchen and, at 89 percent, $8,900 from the bathroom.
Anne and James Moss of Warwick, N.Y., just finished renovating their house, a job that included spending about $50,000 on a kitchen, family room, full bath and a deck.
The return on the project was very important to the couple. They consulted with experts on what work would increase the value of their home the most. They learned, for example, that people in their area were increasingly looking for a unified family room and kitchen. While just remodeling the kitchen would have cost about $28,000, for an extra $16,000 they were able to expand the family room and then combine the two.
"The cost to redo the kitchen was still going to leave the house in a form that would not necessarily increase its marketability by much," Ms. Moss said. "But to do the total renovation was in fact going to increase the value of the house significantly."
Using the magazine's numbers, the Mosses should get back about $42,400 from their four main projects.
Here are the returns from other types of projects, as calculated from the magazine's survey: a two-story addition, 84 percent; an attic bedroom, 83 percent; renovation of a master suite, 82 percent; siding replacement, 71 percent; a new deck, 70 percent, and window replacement, 68 percent.
There is no getting away from how we feel about our homes and how they reflect who we are. But there is also no getting away from how important they are to our financial well-being. A bad housing decision can do a lot of damage. That's why the return on any renovation needs to be considered before the first nail goes in.
Then you can go wild on the family room with your eyes wide open.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Comeback Time For Latin America?

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
BATTERED by the panic that swept emerging markets in the wake of Asia's financial crisis and Russia's default, Latin America is a region that seems more sinned against than sinning.
But whatever the cause, the damage there has been real. For months, stock prices spiraled lower. And the sharp rise in interest rates on emerging-markets debt has closed the capital markets to even creditworthy Latin American companies and countries. 
 Now there are signs of life. Earlier this month, Brazil, the hardest hit, signed off on a $41.5 billion rescue package led by the International Monetary Fund. Last week Argentina became the first Latin American borrower since May to tap financial markets, when it sold $1 billion worth of bonds. Stock markets have rallied accordingly.
Jose M. Barrionuevo, director of global sovereign markets strategy at Lehman Brothers, took some time last week to talk about the region's prospects.
 
Q. Latin America spent the 1980's dealing with a foreign bank debt crisis. In the process, many countries made structural changes -- of a kind that countries in Asia are only now contemplating. So why has the region been hit so hard by this crisis?
 
A. Latin America was brought into the crisis because every time we have seen a real or potential slowdown in the United States, the region gets affected. The experience is that it doesn't matter where Latin America stands at a particular point in time. If the United States slows down, that has an impact.
 
Q. The steep rise in interest rates for emerging-markets borrowers has hurt. Are credit conditions improving for potential Latin borrowers?
 
A. We have seen a significant compression of interest-rate spreads over the last month, reflecting significant improvement in global credit conditions. That is almost entirely due to a very pre-emptive and forceful Federal Reserve, which understands better than anyone what is happening to global credit conditions.
You can't really claim that the crunch or credit squeeze is over, but there is a clear sense of improvement.
 
Q. Will the Fed's actions be enough to stave off a recession here and in Latin America?
 
A. We don't see a recession, but if you see a slowdown it will be more pronounced in Latin America. Clearly, Brazil will be depressed next year, with its economy contracting about 1 or 2 percent. But we don't see recessions in either Mexico or Argentina. Growth in those countries will be enough to keep the region from going into recession, assuming the U.S. economy keeps growing.
 
Q. You just came back from Brazil. Will this package cure the country's problems?
 
A. The package is good. The key issue is how quickly President Cardoso implements it.
A critical factor is the budget. If it is approved by the end of December you will have seen the Government's sense of urgency to deal with Brazil's problems that investors have been looking for for a long time. But even if that happens, Brazil is still looking at a recession. The key test for the program's strategy will be sometime in the first quarter, when political pressure to ease the economic pain will increase.
 
Q. So far this year, mutual funds that invest in Latin American stocks have fared worse than emerging-markets funds over all. If the region is starting to come back, is it time to consider Latin stocks?
 
A. From a fundamental perspective, people will invest in Latin America because the growth prospects there are high.
Nonetheless, we still have to look at these markets on a daily basis. And I don't think people should start looking to Latin equity markets until we get a clear sense of the direction in U.S. equities. Timing is a key.
 
Q. Which industries are likely to return to health the fastest?
 
A. Typically, you see utilities doing better in the early phases of recovery, then telecommunications and then manufacturing.
 
Q. Does that mean you like a company like Telebras of Brazil?
 
A. Telebras is a company we like, but it is too early to get in, because Brazil is going into a recession. If the rescue package is implemented correctly, the recession could bottom in the second quarter. At that point it might be worth taking a look.
 
Q. Are you concerned that the experience of the last couple of years has had an adverse effect on long-term demand for Latin American securities?
 
A. You could argue there has been some structural damage in that hedge funds have been hurt, that pension funds and mutual funds will not be back because they feel they may not be getting a return comparable to the risk they are taking. But one of the reasons people are still focused on these areas is that they are worried they will not be there when things turn around.
